DOC.HEAD: Bradley Trounces Primary Opponent, Looks to General Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with 65 percent of vote in Senate race, Zimmer and Chandler winning House races; pick up at dash
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley breezed to victory Tuesday in a barely contested Democratic primary and will face Republican Christine Todd Whitman in the November general election. With 65 percent of the precincts reporting, Bradley had 114,942 votes, or 94 percent, to 7,354 votes, or 6 percent, for Daniel Seyler, a political unknown. Mrs. Whitman, former president of the state Board of Public Utilities and a former Somerset County official, had no primary opposition. At an appropriately low-key victory reception in Woodbridge, Bradley said, ``I'm very pleased to again be the standard-bearer for the Democratic Party in the Senate election.'' Seyler, 35, of Phillipsburg, spent about $1,300 of his own money and raised $83.57 from contributors in a campaign whose major issue was limiting federal officeholders to 12 years in office. Democratic Gov. Jim Florio's gubernatorial opponent, Rep. James Courter, who lost in a landslide, didn't seek re-election to his 12th District seat. State Sen. Richard A. Zimmer won the Republican primary for Courter's seat, defeating former New York Giants receiver Phil McConkey and two other candidates. With 67 percent of the precincts reporting, Zimmer had 40 percent of the vote to 30 percent for McConkey and 28 percent for Assemblyman Rodney Frelinghuysen, who had been considered the favorite to win the nomination. Businesswoman and philanthropist Marguerite Chandler defeated little known James J. Cleary in the Democratic primary for the seat.

Bradley, 46, of Denville, has a bankroll of $10 million-plus. His focus in the Senate has included foreign debt and Soviet affairs. He sidesteps talk that he may seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 1992, saying he plans to serve out his six-year Senate term if he wins re-election. Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, has said that Mrs. Whitman, 43, of Far Hills, offers GOP voters a choice for voters. But even Kean has called Bradley unbeatable.

DOC.HEAD: Memory of Gorbachev Visit Lives On As Farmer Tosses Eagle to Freedom
DOC.TEXT: A farmer returned a bald eagle to the wild Tuesday, two days after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew off without stopping by as planned to do the honors as a symbol of superpower friendship. Richard Brand's farm was scratched from Gorbachev's whirlwind tour at the last minute. But television cameras, a small crowd and Gov. Rudy Perpich looked on and applauded Tuesday as the bird flapped eastward from the farm about 20 miles south of Minneapolis. ``I'm more comfortable with cows,'' quipped Brand, a dairy farmer, just before the U.S. symbol was set in his arms and released. Brand emphasized he was not bitter about not playing host to Gorbachev. ``At least I got some work done,'' he said, referring to the help he got from the summit advance team in sprucing up the farm. In an earlier interview, he said the visit only sped up planned improvements. The eagle, named ``Spirit Lake'' after the site in Iowa where she was found, had been recovering at the University of Minnesota Raptor Center from insecticide poisoning.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Charge Enrile With Rebellion
DOC.TEXT: The government will file new charges accusing Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile of participating in December's failed coup, an official said Wednesday. The move comes a day after the Supreme Court rejected a previous indictment against Enrile and 22 others, saying the charges were legally invalid. Enrile and the others were charged with rebellion combined with murder in connection with the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt that left 113 people dead and more than 600 wounded. On Tuesday, Chief Justice Marcelo Fernan said the Supreme Court voted 11-2 against reviewing a 1956 court decision, thereby overturning the combined charges. Two justices were absent or abstained, Fernan said. Presidential Press Secretary Tomas Gomez said the government had enough evidence to charge Enrile with the lesser charge of rebellion. Murder is punishable by life imprisonment, but rebellion carries a prison sentence of six to 12 years. ``The quality of the evidence has not been diminished whatsoever,'' Gomez said in a radio interview Wednesday. ``The government will now file a case based on rebellion.'' In 1956, the court ruled that killings occurring during an armed uprising should be treated differently than crimes with common motives. The court said defendants should be charged with rebellion and not murder. Defendants in rebellion cases are allowed bail. Bail is generally denied in murder cases. Mrs. Aquino's legal adviser, Adolfo Azcuna, said the government may seek reconsideration. In the Philippines, Supreme Court rulings become final after 10 days, during which parties to the case can ask for reconsideration. In editorials Wednesday, several newspapers accused Mrs. Aquino of poor judgment in charging Enrile with the combined offense. The Daily Globe, published by Mrs. Aquino's former speechwriter Teodoro Locsin, said the government ``had lost and lost miserably.'' Sen. John Osmena said the ruling meant the government's ``attempt to bend the law to intimidate those who do not agree with the administration has been foiled.'' After the vote, Enrile said: ``I think the Supreme Court, although the members are all appointees of President Aquino, remains faithful to their role as guardians of liberty. I am happy for the country.'' Enrile, a former defense minister, was arrested in February. The Supreme Court released him on bail two weeks later pending a decision on the validity of the charge. Enrile has denied any role in the uprising. Enrile played a key role in the 1986 military mutiny that triggered the ``people power'' revolution that propelled Mrs. Aquino to power. Enrile was fired in November 1986 after a failed coup by his followers.

DOC.HEAD: Ricky Van Shelton Takes Entertainer of the Year Honors
DOC.TEXT: Ricky Van Shelton was chosen entertainer of the Year and top male vocalist Monday night at the 24th annual fan-voted TNN-Music City News Country Awards Show. Randy Travis, who was top entertainer the previous two years, won nothing despite being a finalist in five categories. ``I'm shocked, really shocked,'' Shelton said after the ceremony. ``I'm really, totally in awe. Patty Loveless was named female vocalist of the year, supplanting Reba McEntire, who had won the award five straight years. ``This tells me the people believe in the music I'm doing,'' Loveless said. The Statler Brothers were double winners, winning the vocal group award for the seventh straight time and copping single honors for ``More Than a Name on the Wall.'' Hank Williams Jr. and his late father also were double winners, for video and vocal collaboration for ``There's a Tear in My Beer.'' The video combines film of the father with shots of the son. Rising star Clint Black was honored twice, as star of tomorrow honor and for top album, ``Killin' Time.'' ``I hate to mention that word `star,' but if you force it on me, I'll take it,'' Black said. Tennessee Ernie Ford was presented with the Minnie Pearl award for dedication to the music business and humanitarian efforts during a career that has spanned 50 years. ``If I ever felt like a milk bucket under a bull, it's right now,'' the joyous Ford said in accepting the honor. Veteran Merle Haggard, best known for ``Okie From Muskogee,'' received the living legend award. Other winners included: The Judds for vocal duo; Ray Stevens for comedian; Ricky Skaggs for instrumentalist and The Chuck Wagon Gang for gospel group. The winners were chosen by subscribers to the Music City News, a monthly country music publication, and viewers of The Nashville Network, a cable station that televised the two-hour ceremony live.

DOC.HEAD: Race for Governor, Gas Tax Top California Ballot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with early returns; pick up 6th graf, `Two other ...
DOC.TEXT: Former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein took an early lead over Attorney General John Van de Kamp on Tuesday in a hotly contested race for the Democratic nomination for governor. Voters also considered a proposal to double state gasoline taxes. With 1 percent of the precincts reporting, Feinstein had 49,557 votes, or 52 percent, to Van de Kamp's 40,271 votes, or 42 percent. The Feinstein-Van de Kamp race headlined a lengthy state ballot, with U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson facing only token opposition for the GOP nomination for governor. One ballot measure called for raising the gas tax from 9 to 18 cents per gallon to renew a financially starved highway building program. It was ahead in the early returns, with 100,425 yes votes, or 53 percent, to 88,327 no votes, or 47 percent. Other state races featured new political faces with familiar family names. In the Republican race for state treasurer, incumbent Tom Hayes led Angela ``Bay'' Buchanan, former U.S. treasurer and sister of conservative commentator Pat Buchanan, by a 65-to-35 percent margin. Kathleen Brown, daughter of former Gov. Pat Brown and sister of former Gov. Jerry Brown, was leading the Democratic treasurer's race against Wesley Sanders Jr. by 59 percent to 41 percent. Two other statewide races had a unique family tie. Democratic Secretary of State March Fong Eu was seeking a fifth term as the state's chief election officer and highest ranking Chinese-American official, while her son, Matt Fong, was unopposed for the Republican nomination for state controller. California's 45 congressional races included several interesting contests: _Democratic incumbent Jim Bates faced a strong challenge in a San Diego primary because of his formal rebuke by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harassment of women employees; _Actor Ralph Waite, ``Papa Walton'' of the television series, was seeking the Democratic nomination for a seat now held by Republican Al McCandless in the Palm Springs area; _Tim Stoen, former attorney for People's Temple before the cult's mass suicide with 912 deaths over a decade ago, was seeking the Republican nomination to oppose Democratic incumbent Doug Bosco in California's north coast redwood country. In other local races, attorney William Graysen, who represented actress Zsa Zsa Gabor in her cop-slapping trial, was running for a state Senate seat from Beverly Hills, and Oakland Mayor Lionel Wilson was the underdog in his re-election bid because of the controversy over his part in Oakland's failed bid to bring the Los Angeles Raiders back to Oakland. The proposed gas tax hike, which would mark a symbolic end to the tax revolt that began with passage of Proposition 13 in 1978, was among several measures on the statewide ballot. Companion bond measures would start a multibillion-dollar program of new commuter train service. Another ballot proposition would take control of reapportionment of congressional and legislative districts out the hands of the Democratic leadership of the Legislature.

Feinstein's bid for the Democratic nomination for governor marked the first serious attempt by a woman to win California's chief job, a fact that overshadowed most other issues in her race against Van de Kamp, a less telegenic but politically well-connected prosecutor. Abortion was a major issue for all of the major candidates to succeed retiring Republican George Deukmejian as governor, even though all three were pro-choice. Feinstein and Van de Kamp competed over who was the most effective champion of a woman's right to choose. The limited opposition raised in the GOP primary against Wilson, a moderate Republican who never touted his pro-choice stand, came from anti-abortion activists. Norma McCorvey, the ``Jane Roe'' in Roe vs. Wade, the U.S. Supreme Court case that established a woman's right to an abortion, made a last-minute campaign appearance for Van de Kamp. Feinstein campaigned as tough on crime, trying to seize an issue that seemed more likely to belong to her opponent. She ran a late-campaign TV ad criticizing Van de Kamp for declining to prosecute a suspect in the Hillside Strangler case in which 10 people were killed. Van de Kamp was the Los Angeles district attorney at the time, and the suspect, Angelo Buono, was later convicted of murder after the state attorney general stepped into the case. Van de Kamp called the criticism ``baloney.'' The gasoline tax measure, Proposition 111, marked a political turning point for the state. Opponents noted that the measure, which would raise $15.5 billion over the next decade, would be the largest tax hike in the state's history. Supporters warned that defeat of the proposal would bring California's highway construction program to a halt during an era of the fastest population growth in decades.

DOC.HEAD: Dalai Lama Finds It Difficult to Retire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tibetan Troubles
DOC.TEXT: While other world leaders fight to stay in power, and some try to fend off reform, the head of the world's 6 million Tibetans has the opposite problem. The Dalai Lama's people are uncomfortable with democracy and do not want him to retire as their political leader. But then, most other political figures aren't considered living gods. ``I am insisting on stepping down,'' the Dalai Lama said in an interview. ``It is of greatest urgency that democracy comes to us. It is the most creative way for the human spirit.'' In his ornate parlor overlooking the snow-capped Himalayas, the Dalai Lama predicted communism soon would fall in China and his followers would return to their homeland within 10 years. Tibetans believe their mountainous region, with its unique culture, should be an independent nation. China claims Tibet has been part of its territory since the 13th century. To prepare for their return, the Dalai Lama said, Tibetans must embrace democracy and shed the idea that he is a god. It is proving difficult. There is strong conservative opposition to the Dalai Lama's plans to democratize his government-in-exile and few, if any, Tibetans seem willing to abandon the belief that ``His Holiness'' is divine. That belief has made Tibetans ``lazy,'' said the 54-year-old Buddhist leader, who won the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize. ``They think I will do everything for them.'' Tibetans circle his residence, pausing to clasp their hands in prayer. Elderly women, limping with age, climb steep grades to gaze at his compound, whispering ``10,000 years to His Holiness.'' Tibetan Buddhist tradition holds that the first Dalai Lama, born in 1391, was a reincarnation of Chenresi, the Buddhist god of mercy. Subsequent Dalai Lamas are revered as reincarnations of their predecessors. The current Dalai Lama, the 14th, was chosen in 1936 after a series of visions indicated the leader would be found in a house with turquoise tiles in eastern Tibet. When he first told Tibetans of his wish to give up his political position, the Dalai Lama said, ``many people were shocked and they told me I should not say this kind of thing. ``But I continuously spoke out,'' he said, with a playful grin. He remains a reluctant politician, a man of the spirit, not of law or intrigue. Clothed in maroon and saffron robes and wearing his ever-present tinted glasses, the Dalai Lama chuckled, cracked jokes and reached out to squeeze the hand of a reporter as he made a point. ``I am just a Tibetan monk,'' he said, running his fingers over wooden prayer beads. ``I would rather go to an isolated monastery and pray. Now I have no time for prayer. I am always busy, busy with the affairs of this world.''

DOC.HEAD: Power Struggle, Taiwanese Money Split Tibetan Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A scandal involving money and secrets from Taiwan has started a fight in the Tibetan independemce movement that threatens gains made since the Dalai Lama, its leader, won the Nobel Peace Prize last year. The scandal has alienated many Tibetan refugees, causing what one young Tibetan called ``a big gap between us and our leaders.'' On one side are liberals who favor talks with China and making the Tibetan movement more democratic. The Dalai Lama, spiritual and temporal leader of the world's 6 million Tibetans, leads this group. On the other are conservatives who oppose contacts with the Chinese and attempts to reform the government-in-exile. Conservative Buddhist monks and older Tibetan officials lead them. ``It's a little Iran-Contra scandal,'' said Tendzin Choegyal, the Dalai Lama's youngest brother. ``To the average Tibetan, this is a very confusing and troubling time.'' Tattered wall posters along the road to this retreat in the Himalayan foothills attest to the problem. ``Traitors, you have sold out Tibet,'' they read. ``China lovers, we will never forget your deeds.'' ``Both Chinas must be laughing their heads off,'' said an editorial in the Tibetan Review, the movement's official publication. The scandal emerged last year when Tibetan officials began accusing each other of being on Taiwan's payroll. It revolves around the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, a Taiwanese government agency. Like its communist enemy in Beijing, the government of Taiwan claims Tibet is part of China and rejects Tibetan independence. Since 1959, when the Dalai Lama fled China after an abortive uprising and set up headquarters in Dharmsala, Taiwan has donated ``hundreds of millions'' of dollars to Tibetan groups, according to Sonam Tobgyal, spokesman for the exile government. He said the Taiwanese agency aims to convince Tibetans to break with the government-in-exile, which Taiwan denies. Gene J.Y. Chang, head of the agency, said it had given much less to the Tibetans _ an average of $300,000 a year. In an interview in Taipei, Chang acknowledged some Tibetan refugees were anti-Chinese, not merely anti-communist, but said the commission would like to improve its relations with Dharmsala. Tobgyal said the commission had become increasingly active in recent years, financing a Tibetan-language newspaper in Calcutta, building monasteries in Nepal and granting scholarships to Tibetan students. ``The main aim of the money has been to create disharmony among Tibetans,'' Tobgyal said. He claimed Taiwan paid independence activists to return to Tibet and ``stir up trouble,'' thus violating the Dalai Lama's policy of non-violence. Taiwan denies the charge. The reasons for Taiwan's alleged meddling are not clear. It could seek to foment further political turmoil on the Chinese mainland by encouraging protests in Tibet, but also might be currying favor with Beijing by trying to weaken the Tibetan movement. Taiwan recently abandoned its ``no contact'' policy toward the mainland. A further complication is the relationship between the security agencies of Taiwan and the Tibetan exile government. Since 1986, Dharmsala has provided Taiwan with details about Tibet in exchange for Taiwanese intelligence about political changes in China, Tobgyal said. He defended the exchange, but granted that it raised eyebrows among Tibetans. In a speech to his Cabinet in January, the Dalai Lama said the scandal had caused ``a loss of faith in the Tibetan administration.'' He forbade unofficial contacts with Taiwan and established a committee to investigate previous dealings. ``We are wasting the best opportunity we ever had within these 30 years on minor issues,'' he said. At risk are gains made since the awarding of the prize focused attention on Tibet, where Chinese troops have killed scores of pro-independence activists in the past two years. Lhasa, Tibet's capital, had been under martial law for 13 months when it was lifted May 1. There also is concern that the conservative faction might try to take advantage of the disunity and get the Dalai Lama's concessions to China retracted, which would scuttle dreams of an early return to Tibet. In a 1988 speech, the Dalai Lama said he was willing to give China control over Tibet's foreign affairs and defense in exchange for autonomy in internal matters. The Dalai Lama recently fired several top officials, including his representative in Tokyo, in an attempt to end the crisis. He dissolved the Cabinet and instituted reforms designed to open the exile government to public scrutiny. Voting by 368 Tibetan representatives from around the world May 14 in Dharmsala filled only three of the seven Cabinet seats. At least nine candidates dropped out and some representatives handed in empty ballots to express opposition to the reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Work at American Pastime as Gorbachev Tours American Heartland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It's raz, dva, tri strikes, ``You're out!'' at Moscow State University, where Soviets were learning the American national pastime while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toured the American heartland. The Soviets started playing baseball four years ago, hoping to field a team at the Summer Games in 1992 when it will be a medal sport for the first time. But hopes are not high on the astroturf at a 1,000-seat baseball stadium built on the university grounds last September. ``I don't think a Soviet team will make it to the Olympics this time around,'' said Alexander E. Semyonov. ``The American, Cuban and Nicaraguan teams are much stronger,'' said Semyonov, who calls himself ``the only Soviet baseball writer.'' His articles appear in the monthly ``Sport'' magazine. ``The big problem is that we don't have many fans,'' Semyonov said in an interview Monday. ``They don't really understand the rules. For example, they don't know what a ball is. Or a strike.'' In a game Sunday, about half the seats were empty, including those directly behind home plate. They are considered choice spots in U.S. ballparks but shunned by Soviets because of the protective wire screen. Fans seem to prefer taking their chances with fly balls along the foul line. Otherwise, the scene was much the same as at a high school or small college ballpark in the United States. Fans wore the caps of their favorite teams. The men went shirtless and the women wore halter tops and basked in the early summer sun. It is strictly bring-your-own hot dog at Moscow stadium, which has no concessions. Cheers and jeers in Russian, English and Spanish rose from the stands as the Red Devils of the Moscow Chemical-Technical Institute ran up a 10-2 score against last year's national champions, the Army Sports Club of Balashikhov, known by its Russian acronym SKA. ``They tried what is called a double play,'' intoned the Soviet announcer, as the SKA second baseman handled a toss from the shortstop, turned the force at the bag, then buried his throw to first base in the dirt. The announcer, sprawled in the stands, wore shorts and a blue cap. He mixed his commentary with warnings about pop foul balls that sailed over a low screen and bounced among cars parked next to the stands. The stadium itself is vulnerable to the pop foul: glass skylights on either side of home plate sport neat round holes, a danger apparently not foreseen by contractors. The ballplayers themselves occupy the semi-professional gray area typical of Soviet sports. ``They are amateurs, and have other jobs. But it's hard to say how hard they work,'' said Semyonov. On the field, play alternates between poor fundamentals and prowess. A Red Devil baserunner on first broke for second and slid just as the catcher's throw reached the bag. But the SKA player bobbled the ball, and it skipped deep into center field, allowing the runner to take third base. The next pitch was wild, and the runner scored. A half inning later, SKA tried the same play. The batter missed the bunt, and the catcher pegged the ball hard to second. Again, the throw was too hot and low for the fielder, but this time the second baseman was backing up, and the runner was stranded on second after the next out. So far, there are no stars among the 14 teams in Soviet baseball. ``We don't write about individual players, because the level of play isn't really high enough yet,'' said Semyonov. The season started early this year _ in March _ with the championship slated for late June to give the national team time to prepare for European competition in Italy in August. The team will consist largely of players from SKA and the Red Devils, said Semyonov, and ``specialists say that if the Soviet team wins, we could advance'' from Group B to Group A among the European teams.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, Wu'er Kaixi Haunted by Tiananmen
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Wu'er Kaixi is haunted by thoughts that he may have enticed people to their deaths in central Beijing a year ago. On the evening of June 3, 1989, as Chinese troops prepared their bloody assault to clear Tiananmen Square of the pro-democracy protesters who had occupied it for three weeks, Wu'er appealed to the people of Beijing for help. ``As night fell I thought there weren't enough people on the square, that it was becoming more and more dangerous,'' he recalled in an interview exactly one year later. Thinking that numbers would protect the students, he rushed about the capital for more than four hours that night, holding rallies and urging people to flock to Tiananmen, China's symbolic political center. ``Many people went,'' he said. ``Looking back I feel very _ it's so difficult to say _ but I believe many people heard me speak, went to Tiananmen Square and were killed.'' Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed when soldiers rammed their way through Beijing's streets with tanks to recapture Tiananmen. Wu'er, who collapsed from exhaustion and left the square in an ambulance shortly before the soldiers arrived, says at least 3,000 died. Wu'er was born in Beijing and lived there for 16 years before attending high school in Xinjiang, the region in China's far west largely populated by Wu'er's fellow ethnic Uygurs. His proper name is Uerkesh Daolet _ Wu'er Kaixi is the Chinese transliteration of his first name. It was during his first year back in Beijing, in a pre-freshman preparatory course at Beijing Normal University in 1988, that Wu'er made a name for himself as a cocky but articulate thinker who was quick to question authority. He became head of a Confucian study group that started out as a forum to discuss his major, education, but quickly developed into an arena for political debate. ``I was outspoken. I was a headache for the administration, a troublemaker,'' he says. He was a troublemaker even to his friends who were trying to slip him out of the country after June 4. ``I didn't want to leave. Friends spent a lot of time not so much helping me leave China, but convincing me to go,'' he recalls. ``So many times I said `So what, if I get caught I get caught.' Now, however, I understand them,'' said Wu'er, now 22. He left China at the end of June, by means he declined to describe in detail. His name was No. 1 on the government's wanted list, which ensured media attention overseas, and within a few weeks he was made vice chairman of the fledgling Federation for a Democratic China, headquartered in Paris. He scoffs at reports that he embezzled money or is a womanizer. ``What bothers me is when the (Communist Party's) People's Daily says I'm disliked,'' he says. ``I have lots of friends.'' He travels widely, and has been invited by the Sakharov Committee in the Soviet Union to attend a human rights seminar in Moscow this weekend. But his top priority remains political reform from within the Chinese system. ``We have some branch organizations inside China, even in the army, and the most important thing for us is to send information to China. Just hold on and wait for an opportunity. That opportunity will probably be the death of the old man (senior leader Deng Xiaoping).'' Wu'er says the death of Deng, 85, could trigger new demonstrations, but he said change will be slow. ``Fifty or 100 years later, then probably China will become a democratic China.'' On Monday, the first anniversary of the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, Wu'er stood with a group of Chinese dissidents across from the Chinese Embassy in Paris, chastising embassy officials for refusing to see them. ``All we wanted to do was deliver a letter seeking a dialogue. We just tried to tell them we still want to go back to China, and that we're not criminals,'' he said. ``But they are afraid of us. They are afraid of popular people's power. That's the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: Avianca Survivor Indicted On Drug Possession
DOC.TEXT: A survivor of the Avianca airline crash was sentenced to six years to life in prison for having 29 rubber packets of cocaine in his digestive system, it was announced Monday. While hospitalized at the Nassau County Medical Center after the January crash, defendant Antonio Zuluaga passed the packets, which tests revealed to containe about 7{ ounces of cocaine. Zuluaga suffered a fractured spine, broken ribs and dislocated hip as a result of the crash. After serving his sentence, Antonio Zuluaga, 46, will be deported to his native Colombia, said Marie Santagata, the Nassau County Court judge who sentenced him. Through an interpreter, Zuluaga recently pleaded guilty to second-degree possession of a controlled substance. He admitted buying cocaine in Bogota and carrying it in his stomach while traveling on the Avianca jet that crashed in Cove Neck, Long Island, killing 73.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Stuntman Missing After Going Over Niagara Falls in Kayak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with utility tried to reduce water flow of river in attempt to prevent stunt, man had attempted stunt previously on U.S. side, quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. stuntman was missing Tuesday after going over Niagara Falls in a kayak, Canadian police said. The red kayak was recovered below Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side, ``all in one piece ... in fairly good condition, all things considered,'' said Maureen Quinn, a constable with the Niagara Parks Police. But she said authorities ``found nothing else, just the kayak. No body's been found.'' The Canadian falls, the world's largest by volume, are 181 feet high, or about as tall as a 13-story building. Another constable, Kim Davis, said the 28-year-old man from Tennessee was trying to complete a stunt that had been planned for about 10 years. Police said nobody has ever tried to kayak over the Canadian side of the falls. ``Barrels, yes,'' said Quinn of other attempts to go over the falls in enclosed capsules and live. But, she said, ``it doesn't seem plausible he could do it (and survive).'' George Bailey of the Niagara Parks Commission said the man had attempted the stunt several years ago on the American side of the falls, but park police stopped him. He said the man was accompanied by a film crew and a friend who took photographs. Quinn said police received a call that the stuntman had entered the water about a half-mile above the falls but ``by the time we responded it was too late. ... (He) actually went over the brink.'' She said ``several people saw him go over. It was videotaped. There were plenty of witnesses.'' The man, whose identity was not disclosed pending notification of next of kin, was last seen at about 1:45 p.m. EDT, Quinn said. Ken Kitchen was working in an Ontario Hydro tower overlooking the Niagara River when he saw a man stripped to the waist in a kayak. He said the utility closed the dam gates, reducing the water flow to the falls in an attempt to stop him. The man's boat grounded, but he picked it up and moved it into the middle of the river, Kitchen said. ``He was gone before our help could get there. All we could do was sit and watch helplessly,'' Kitchen said. At a press conference later Tuesday, police showed reporters a videotape a tourist made of the incident. The film shows a man in a kayak successfully negotiating the rapids of the Niagara River just before the falls. Then, he disappears. ``It's beyond me why anyone would attempt this,'' said George Bailey of the Niagara Parks Commission. ``He obviously doesn't know our falls.'' Dave Munday, who went over the falls in a steel barrel three years ago, said people who try such stunts are usually not aware of the dangers of the falls. ``A lot of people underestimate what's at the bottom,'' he said. ``I did myself. It's just solid rock down there. People don't realize that.'' Bailey said 13 people have intentionally gone over the falls _ most in barrel-like structures. Ten of the 13 survived.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die When Flagpole Touches Power Lines
DOC.TEXT: Four people were electrocuted Monday when a flagpole they were setting up touched power lines. Fayette County Deputy Coroner Margie Riley said the four victims were erecting the flagpole for a church. They were burned beyond recognition, she said. The pole touched a 7,600-volt line causing a 1{-hour blackout in this town of 350 people, about 75 miles south of Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Wanted: Couch Potatoes with Right Stuff, To Simulate Space Travel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Help Wanted. Baylor College of Medicine seeks 16 good sleepers to spend a month lying down. Salary uncertain, but benefits include breakfast in bed _ lunch and dinner, too. It sounds like a couch potato's dream, but there's a catch to the deal being offered by researchers David Cardus and Wesley McTaggart. When they say the sleepers will be confined to bed, they're not kidding. The people they select won't be allowed to get up for the the entire month, and they'll spend part of their time spinning around in a space-age sleep chamber that looks like something straight out of the movie ``Aliens.'' The experiments also will require the research subjects to be hooked up to sensors that monitor a dozen bodily functions. Other than that, the job's a snooze. Cardus and McTaggart, using a $650,000 grant from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, are involved in a three-year program to see if the physical strain can be eased on astronauts making lengthy space voyages. The reseach is designed to counteract some of the physiological effects of weightlessness during space travel _ a pertinent topic in light of the nation's plans to establish a permanent space station and to send astronauts to Mars. ``What happens if you stay in bed?'' asks Cardus, a physiologist who has worked with astronauts since the beginning of the nation's manned space program. ``You get deconditioned. And why don't you get completely deconditioned? Because you spend two-thirds of the day carrying your weight around.'' Once someone gets into space, they don't have any weight to carry around. Their bodies, especially the cardiovascular systems, get deconditioned by weightlessness. Early astronauts sometimes fainted upon their return to Earth, and even now, space shuttle crews and cosmonauts on the Soviet space station must halt their work after a few hours to do exercises to keep their muscles in shape, he says. To simulate weightlessness, Cardus and McTaggart intend to decondition their subjects by keeping them off their feet for about two weeks. Then, for about another two weeks, the subjects will be put to bed again _ this time on one of four blow-up mattresses that sit under plexiglass canopies atop a centrifuge platform. From time to time, the entire platform, which fills a 30-by-30-foot room, will turn, spinning the four subjects about 20 times a minute to simulate one `G' _ or about the force of Earth gravity. The speed produces a force that travels from the head to the feet in a horizontal position. Scientists believe a regular schedule of exposure to one-G or more will have the same effect as frequent exercise. And they're hopeful that if it works, a similar machine could be included on the space station or the ship that heads for Mars. They also want to find out if the reconditioning works while the subject is either asleep or awake or both. ``We think the apparatus will meet its purposes, but of course you don't know the problems until you start to use it,'' Cardus said. Baylor has been advertising for men between ages 20 and 40 who have at least a month to spend laying around. They've received replies from all over the world. But a limited budget, and the need to retest the subjects periodically after the experiment, has them looking primarily in the Houston area. So far, they've interviewed about 10 candidates. They'd like to get 16 subjects _ four groups of four men. After the initial 16, Cardus says he may try to recruit women. ``The physiology of the male and female is a little different. This individual will be studied in considerable depth and we don't want to complicate the experimental design,'' he says. ``But the principal reason is this: Our work is complex enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Picks up 8 Cuban Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Eight men who fled Cuba in three separate groups on inner tubes, a small boat and a makeshift raft were plucked from the Atlantic Ocean Monday in good condition, the Coast Guard said. All of them were turned over to the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service, raising to 179 the total number of Cubans completing the dangerous passage across the Florida Straits this year. The first two men were picked up by a Coast Guard patrol boat from Miami Beach after the cruise ship Scandinavian Saga spotted them drifting on inner tubes about 10 miles northeast of Miami at 10:10 a.m., Petty Officer Steve Sapp said. Also, three Cubans who said they left the island 12 days ago were spotted in a small skiff by the freighter Humacao just off Cay Sal Island, about 130 miles south of Miami and 35 miles north of Bahia de Santa Clara, Cuba. The Coast Guard cutter Metompkin arrived at the scene at about 10:30 a.m. and took the men to Key West. Three more Cubans were found in a 10-foot raft about seven miles east of John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park off Key Largo at about 1 p.m., Sapp said. They told officers who picked them up in a patrol boat from Coast Guard station Islamorada that they left Cuba four days earlier and had an engine that propelled their raft for 18 hours.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, Korean Presidents Meet in Historic Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 7-8, ``The Soviet,'' with Gorbachev comment.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo said Monday that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have agreed to end 45 years of Cold War animosity by establishing diplomatic relations between their countries. ``As a result of my meeting with President Gorbachev today, normal bilateral relations between our countries will be restored,'' Roh said. The South Korean leader said discussions would continue toward that end, but that no dates had been set. The Gorbachev-Roh meeting, which took place at the end of Gorbachev's visit to the United States, was the first between leaders of the two nations since Korea was partitioned more than four decades ago. The Cold War ice on the Korean peninsula ``now has begun to crack,'' Roh told reporters. Though nothing was put in writing, he said the two countries plan to boost economic and trade ties. The Soviet president was more vague in his summation of the meeting. ``We will let the fruit grow ripe, and when the fruit grows ripe, we will eat it,'' Gorbachev told reporters outside the Soviet consul general's home, before departing San Francisco for home at the end of a five-day U.S. visit. Korean officials have called friendlier ties with the Soviet Union a cornerstone of the Roh administration. The two countries have had an unstable relationship since the formation of South Korea at the end of World War II, but the hostility began to abate in 1988 when the Soviets announced they would participate in the Seoul Olympics. Roh plans to meet with President Bush in Washington on Wednesday to brief him on his talk with Gorbachev and to discuss the U.S.-Soviet summit, which ended Sunday. North Korea became a Communist satellite state in 1948. In 1950, Soviet leader Josef Stalin promised to support North Korea's invasion of the south, an attack that led to three years of war that ended with an armistice but no peace treaty. It is estimated that the Soviet Union now supplies 70 percent of North Korea's military supplies, including advanced weapons systems. An improved relationship between the Soviet Union and South Korea could benefit the United States, by making possible an accelerated withdrawal of U.S. troops from South Korea. The United States already has announced plans to withdraw 7,000 of its 43,000 troops during the next two years. Roh met Sunday with top U.S. State Department officials, including Richard Solomon, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, who briefed him on the Gorbachev-Bush summit. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and former President Reagan also visited Roh on Sunday, the day he arrived in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Termites Unlock Coal Murder Mystery for History Buffs
DOC.TEXT: Termites discovered in a courthouse basement unlocked a mystery bugging local history buffs for nearly 70 years. An exterminator told McDowell County officials a padlocked room in the basement of their courthouse could be harboring termites, and when they opened the door last week they found more than just the pesky insects. County officials found about 3,000 documents dating to the 1870s, including a file chronicling a notorious murder trial over the shooting of a coal union organizer in 1921 that was part of the movie ``Matewan.'' Circuit Clerk Paul Lambert said the trial of C.E. Lively, Buster Pence and William Salter in the death of Ed Chambers was an important county event. The men were found innocent by a jury comprised of company sympathizers, he said. History buffs had spent years searching for the records, Lambert said. ``Out of all the records, I pulled one suspicious-looking one because it was thicker,'' he said. ``And lo and behold, it was the Lively murder trial.'' The Aug. 21, 1921, shooting was part of bloody struggles between union workers and coal companies, Lambert said. Bullet holes from the shootout on the courthouse lawn that left Chambers dead are still visible on the courthouse, he said. As for the termites, Lambert said the bug problem seems to be solved.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Cold War is Over, Calls for New Cooperation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material graf 4, ``He said,'' with Gorbachev comment.
With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Declaring that ``the Cold War is now behind us,'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday called for a more united world in which American and Soviet scientists work together to destroy nuclear weapons. Before leaving for Moscow about 7:45 p.m. PDT Monday night, the Soviet leader met with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, and Roh said afterward the two countries agreed to establish diplomatic relations. The 45-year-old Cold War ice on their relationship ``now has begun to crack,'' Roh said. He said discussions toward a resumption of ties would continue, but no date was set. Gorbachev, speaking briefly with reporters, summarized the meeting by saying, ``We will let the fruit grow ripe, and when the fruit grows ripe, we will eat it.'' It was the first meeting between leaders of the two countries, which have never established diplomatic relations since Korea was divided between victorious U.S. and Soviet forces who liberated the peninsula from Japanese rule at the end of World War II. In the last hours of his visit to the United States, Gorbachev also continued his courtship of business, telling top West Coast executives he would speed up plans to make the Soviet ruble a convertible currency, helping foreign companies take their profits out of his country. Gorbachev said Moscow wants to overcome the reluctance of Western executives who hold back from investing in the Soviet Union because they don't have enough control of their assets. In an afternoon speech at Stanford University, Gorbachev said the Soviet Union and United States should be partners in building the future, though he acknowledged that while the two societies are coming closer, ``they probably will never be fully alike. There is no need for that.'' He implored scientists in both countries to join in determining how nuclear weapons could be destroyed without harming people or the environment. He also advocated a system of international alliances that unites rather than divides the world. ``The Cold War is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it,'' the Soviet leader told the cheering audience. Gorbachev called for a ``new approach to the structures of security ... and alliance building'' that would result in a ``unity ... worthy of the life of a human being.'' Earlier in the day, Gorbachev paused for a sentimental reunion with former President Reagan, who met him five times in four years to help thaw the icy relations between the Cold War adversaries. Reagan said afterward that Gorbachev ``wants the same kind of solution we all want'' to the Soviet Union's problems, now complicated by economic crisis, secessionist drives by the Baltic republics, ethnic strife and growing political instability in the Russian heartland. ``He knows we both are together in trying to increase the closeness of our two countries,'' the 79-year-old Reagan told reporters. Mrs. Reagan, whose stiff and sometimes frosty meetings with Mrs. Gorbachev were a recurrent subplot at the superpower summits, said after a private coffee with the Soviet first lady there has been ``a great misunderstanding about our relationship.'' ``It was a very different time,'' Mrs. Reagan said. ``We were plowing new ground.'' Gorbachev's message to American business, first expressed in a speech Sunday in Minneapolis, was a Soviet version of the U.S. politician's warning that the train is leaving the station and those who don't climb aboard now are going to miss it. ``We are now watching those who maybe are risking something,'' he reiterated Monday afternoon. ``And we are watching those who stand on the sidelines.'' On Sunday, in Minneapolis, he told a gathering of corporate luminaries, ``Those who are with us at this time have a good prospect of cooperation in our great country, in our great market because of its tremendous potential. But those who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk, who want to wait and see, who don't want to risk their dollars, well, they will remain, I think observers, for years to come. We'll make sure that that is so.'' The Soviet president suggested to the California business leaders that the U.S. air and space industry could benefit from increased cooperation, specifically mentioning the Soviets' Energiya rockets, capable of lifting twice the payload of U.S. rockets. They could be used to put large satellites or pieces of a U.S. space station into orbit. He also said the vast and largely untapped natural resources of the Soviet Far East are open to development with the aid of foreign investors, and welcomed a proposal that a private U.S.-Soviet commission be established to help plan for the future. The Gorbachev-Roh session was boosted as a major event by the South Koreans, who are eager to establish ties with former Communist-bloc countries now seen as a promising new market for South Korean exports. But the Soviet side, still sensitive to the effect on its longtime Communist client in North Korea, played down talk of a get-together, refusing for days even to confirm a meeting would take place. South Korea's incredible economic success story has been watched with envy by Soviet planners who, if they can't emulate the Asian nation's rapid growth, would at least like to expand trade ties in hopes of acquiring sorely needed technology and consumer goods at relatively low cost.

DOC.HEAD: Kind Word From Gorbachev May Mean a Lot to Stanford Center
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Center for International Security and Arms Control at Stanford University is looking forward to more frequent exchanges with the Soviet Union following praise from Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In a speech Monday at Stanford, the Soviet president noted the contributions toward world peace made by the center and by university scientists. ``It was a very nice surprise. We certainly didn't program that, I can tell you,'' center spokeswoman Rosemary Hamerton-Kelly said. ``His whole speech means it will be easier for Stanford to pursue any type of cooperation with the Soviet Union.'' It was the first formal recognition of the center by the Soviet leader, said Hamerton-Kelly, assistant to the institute's director. The center has made frequent exchanges with Soviet academics, however, and last year was visited by Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, a chief Soviet adviser on arms control, she said. The center, established in its present form in 1983 and operated under the political science department, evolved out of an arms control program developed at Stanford in 1970, Hamerton-Kelly said. ``We do research and teach in the field of U.S.-Soviet relations _ international security more broadly _ and we have a practical emphasis on the Asian-Pacific region,'' she said. The institute has in the past studied former President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative and, as the thaw in the Cold War continues, is planning to study the transition from a defense-oriented to a civilian-oriented economy, Hamerton-Kelly said. ``One part of it is the economic effects it has on the local economy, but there's another whole aspect,'' she said. ``If you are going to cut back your military resources, how do you structure the forces and also the industry in such a way that would there suddenly be a threat that you could gear it up again?''

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Gorbachevs' Day
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance are some of Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev's activities during their visit to the San Francisco area:

_He met with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. Roh afterward said he and Gorbachev agreed to end 45 years of Cold War animosity by establishing diplomatic relations between their countries. _In a speech at Stanford University, he declared that ``the Cold War is now behind us.'' He called for a more united world in which U.S. and Soviet scientists work together to destroy nuclear weapons. _Appearing before some of the West Coast's most influential businessmen, he said he would speed up plans to make the ruble a convertible currency. _He held a 40-minute reunion with former President Reagan, who said afterward they discussed the independence drive of the Baltic states and other issues. _She skipped much of her official tour plans, instead dropping in for a chat at a mom-and-pop grocery store and climbing aboard a San Francisco cable car.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Conservatives Laud School Worship Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives and religious fundamentalists are hailing a Supreme Court ruling they say helps put extracurricular prayer back in public schools for students who want to worship together. The decision ``should send a message to school administrators nationally that religious speech on the high school campus is as fully protected as any other student speech,'' said Jay Sekulow, an Atlanta lawyer for Christian Advocates Serving Evangelism. In an 8-1 ruling Monday, the justices said public high schools generally must allow student prayer groups to meet and worship if other student clubs are permitted at school. Such extracurricular prayer meetings do not violate the constitutionally required church-state separation when high school religious groups are given the same access accorded such activities as chess or scuba diving clubs, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said for the court. Justice John Paul Stevens dissented. The decision upholds the Equal Access Act of 1984, in which Congress said public high schools accepting federal aid must not discriminate against groups based on ``the religious, political, philosophical or other content of the speech at such meetings.'' Liberals said the ruling was a pretext for reconsidering classroom prayer and could undermine earlier rulings that banned such activity. In other actions Monday, the court: _Ruled 8-1 in a case from Illinois that police undercover agents may seek to elicit confessions from jailed suspects without first warning them of their right to remain silent or to a lawyer's help. _Ruled unanimously in a North Carolina case that nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue their employers under state personal-injury laws. _Agreed to study the government's power to lift price controls on some natural gas, a case that has tens of millions of consumer dollars at stake. _Said it will decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for the emotional distress they allegedly suffer in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. The student prayer case stemmed from the refusal of Omaha, Neb., school officials to approve a Christian Bible-reading club at Westside High School in 1985. Bridget Mergens Mayhew, the former Westside High student whose attempt to start the club led to the ruling, said she was delighted. ``It's got to be clear to all school officials that they can't discriminate against religion any more,'' she said. Mrs. Mayhew, now 23, said group Bible study can be a source of strength when ``you're a kid and you've got all these things coming at you ... drugs, or whatever.'' Beverly LaHaye, president of Concerned Women for America, a conservative activist group, also applauded the high court. ``The Supreme Court has ruled against religious apartheid in American high schools,'' she said. ``To exclude student religious groups from meeting on campus is nothing more than bigoted discrimination.'' But atheist activist Madalyn Murray O'Hair of Austin, Texas, called the ruling tragic. ``This a major intrusion of religion into our secular public schools,'' she said. In 1962, Mrs. O'Hair filed the lawsuit that led to a Supreme Court ban of school-sponsored prayers. The court has since also banned schools from conducting daily Bible readings and from posting the Ten Commandments on classroom walls. John Buchanan of the liberal People for the American Way said, ``The court has opened wide the schoolhouse door to religious study and worship, leaving impressionable children to assume that such clubs are part and parcel of the school-approved daily instructions.'' The National School Boards Association had called the 1984 law a thinly disguised move to return prayer to the public schools. The administration defended the law as a legitimate attempt to protect religious liberty for students. In her opinion for the court, O'Connor rejected arguments that permitting Bible-study groups will mislead students into believing the school endorses religion. ``A school that permits a student-initiated and student-led religious club to meet after school, just as it permits any other student group to do, does not convey a message of state approval or endorsement of the particular religion,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Selected quotes from the final day of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United States:
``The Cold War is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it.'' Gorbachev, telling a cheering audience Monday at Stanford University that Soviet and U.S. scientists should work together to destroy nuclear weapons.
``I'm convinced that we are on the threshold of revising They divided countries and peoples much more than they united them.'' Gorbachev, suggesting to the same audience that the Soviet Union and United States should be partners in building a better world.
``I am pleased with the results and I think the reception from the American people was rather clear.'' President Bush, briefing his Cabinet on four days of talks with the Soviet president.
``We discussed the obstacles that must be overcome. ... He knows we both are together in trying to increase the closeness of our two countries.'' Former President Reagan, upon leaving a meeting with Gorbachev in which the two men discussed the independence drive of the Baltic states and other issues.
``I think there's been a great misunderstanding about our relationship. It was a very different time. We were plowing new ground.'' Former first lady Nancy Reagan, telling reporters that she and Raisa Gorbachev got along just fine at their husbands' midmorning meeting.
``People have been so much taken by their Gorbymania that I don't think many are hearing us. The people have been taken by the charm of Gorby.'' Lithuanian-born Algis Zemaitaitis, who drove six hours from Santa Monica to join a protest at Stanford University.
``As a result of my meeting with President Gorbachev today, normal bilateral relations between our countries will be restored.'' South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, after an unprecedented discussion with Gorbachev on easing tensions and developing trade between their historically unfriendly countries.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Postpone Action on Abortion, Homosexual Ordinations ^Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th, `There is ...' to UPDATE with vote dening semiofficial status to church groups. Picks up 6th graf,`A task...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Presbyterian Church, faced with potentially bitter battles over abortion and the ordination of homosexuals, decided Monday to wait until next year to tackle the issues. Commissioners to the 202nd General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A) voted overwhelmingly Monday to postpone until 1991 action on resolutions dealing with a variety of such issues. They ranged from a call for the church to withdraw from an abortion rights group to a proposal to allow local church bodies to ordain homosexuals. ``I feel that debate on this matter results in high feelings, emotion, divisiveness,'' said the Rev. Rush Otey of the Greater Atlanta Presbytery. ``There's a time for the church to speak. There's a time for the church to be silent.'' But representatives of an anti-abortion group charged the denomination lacked the ``moral courage'' to address the issues. ``There is a desire to see the issue in a political sense but a reluctance to deal with it as a moral issue,'' said Terry Schlossberg, executive director of Presbyterians Pro-Life. The assembly voted late Monday to take away semiofficial status from 21 private church organizations, including some of its severest liberal and conservative critics. Despite criticism that they were tring to reduce voices of dissent within the church, nearly 80 percent of the commisioners voted to delete a portion of the church's Book of Order that gives groups such as Presbyterians for Lesbian-Gay Concerns and Presbyterians Pro-Life the right to be officially represented at the General Assembly and church meetings. The proposal goes to the church's 177 presbyteries. A majority of the regional bodies must approve the change for it to take effect. A task force on sexuality is expected to report on both homosexuality and abortion to the 1991 General Assembly. The church supports legalized abortion, and opposes the ordination of homosexuals. In other business Monday, the assembly voted to create a church office for the environment and to call for stricter gun control laws. Two of the resolutions which were deferred called for church agencies to withdraw from the Religious Coalition on Abortion Rights and to oppose late-term abortions where the fetus could survive outside the womb. The church, embroiled in a dispute over the distribution of sexually explicit literature to a youth meeting by a church-recognized gay caucus, also postponed until 1991 a decision on whether to allow local church bodies to ordain homsexuals. The issue of homosexuality heated up in the 2.9 million-member denomination last summer when Presbyterians Lesbian-Gay Concerns distributed brochures detailing the sexual practices of homosexuals to high school and college students attending a church meeting at Purdue University. The brochures discussed both oral and anal sex, and gave explicit instructions in the use of condoms. In the resulting uproar, several regional church groups petitioned the general assemby to deny any official church status to the homosexual caucus. A vote on the overtures has yet to be scheduled. James D. Anderson, communications secretary for the homosexual group, said the reaction ``is an expression of the deep-seated homophobia in the church.'' But he said the calls for condemnation will help his group in the long run by raising the issue before the church. ``The church has to express its hate, its anger, its fear, its revulsion,'' he said. ``That's the only way to cure it.'' In approving a 93-page document entitled ``Restoring Creation for Ecology and Justice,'' commissioners voted to establish a denominational office on environmental justice, and incorporate environmental concerns into worship and preaching, education programs and community ministries. Church members were asked to be particularly involved in waste management, recycling and energy conservation programs and land-use planning. The resolution on gun violence called for more effective federal laws regulating the manufacture and sale of guns, including requiring the registration and licensing of gun buyers and owners and background checks before guns are sold.

DOC.HEAD: The Gorbachev Charm: Gorbymania Drowns Out Protests
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As the Gorbachev motorcade rolled by, demonstrators chanted, ``Out of the Baltic states!'' But a far larger crowd intent on seeing the Soviet leader countered, ``Out of the way! Out of the way!'' ``People have been so much taken by their Gorbymania that I don't think many are hearing us,'' despaired Lithuanian-born Algis Zemaitaitis, taking part in the protest at Stanford University. ``The people have been taken by the charm of Gorby.'' Indeed, demonstrators were no match for Gorbymania during President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit Monday. A beaming Gorbachev captivated thousands at the university, wading into the crowds as usual to shake hands and exchange hugs and a few words. Pro-Gorbachev T-shirts, banners, signs and cheers of ``Go Gorby!'' were seen and heard. Scalpers sold ``free'' tickets to a Gorbachev speech for a reported $1,800. The 1,700 tickets had been distributed by lottery. ``I've been in crowds that went to see Nixon and Kennedy and I've never seen anything like this,'' said John Brigham, a political science professor at the University of Massachusetts who was visiting the San Francisco Bay area. ``This is more like celebrity government. You can feel people are pulled toward Gorbachev in some way.'' Hundreds waving flags and signs staged demonstrations demanding independence for the Baltic states or raising ethnic grievances and complaints of human-rights abuses. But the protesters weren't sure they were getting through. ``The American public is so in love with Gorby they are not paying attention,'' said Vazken Mousesian, 58, who is of Armenian descent. Before entering an auditorium to deliver a speech, Gorbachev worked the crowd behind police lines. ``He was definitely just a real person. ... He was leading the pack, hoping his bodyguards could keep up,'' said Alex Levy, a 21-year-old political science major. Before the Soviet leader arrived, capitalism flourished on campus. Jeff Vierling, 19, and Marlowe Johnson, 21, sat on a curb asking for serious offers of $1,000 or more in cash for each of their two tickets to Gorbachev's speech. The tickets are ``worth a great deal to me, but the only value here is sentimental. I can probably see him better on TV,'' said Johnson, an international relations major who wants to take a trip to Europe. Earlier Monday, pro-Lithuanian groups held a protest at the Golden Gate Bridge, then moved to the San Francisco home of the Soviet consul general, where Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev had breakfast with former President Reagan and his wife, Nancy. About 100 Cambodian exiles also staked out the consul general's house, demanding an end to Soviet aid to Cambodia's pro-Vietnamese Communist government. The Lithuanian independence group hoisted an oversized Lithuanian flag and a banner that read, ``To Hell with Gorbachev: Butcher of Afghanistan.'' Protesters said President Bush's support for possible most-favored-nation trading status for the Soviet Union suggested lack of interest in the Baltic issue. ``We have to be tough. We got to this point being tough. Of course, even Reagan isn't tough any more,'' said protester West Stewart.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. May Help Soviets Destroy Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: In a sign of the Cold War's thaw, officials say the United States may lend the Soviet Union a technological hand to destroy thousands of tons of chemical weapons. As recently as three years ago the Soviets had not acknowledged having any such weapons. An agreement signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last Friday requires both sides to begin destroying their arsenals of deadly gases by 1992. Questions remain, though, about how the Soviets will carry it out. The Kremlin decided last summer to bow to pressure from domestic environmentalists and close a new plant built to destroy chemical weapons by incineration. The Soviets have disclosed no plans for building another plant and it remains unclear how they will meet the 1992 date set in the new agreement. Barry Daniel, chief spokesman for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, which oversaw negotiation of the agreement, said Monday he could not rule out the possibility that the United States might agree to destroy the Soviets' chemicals for them. He said this carried large legal risks, however, and it appeared more likely that the United States might offer to help build or operate a plant on Soviet soil. The Bush-Gorbachev agreement requires the two sides to cooperate in developing safe and environmentally sound methods of destroying their chemical stockpiles. Both sides are to have no more than 5,000 tons of weapons by the year 2002, compared with 25,000 tons now held by the United States and 50,000 tons by the Soviets. The United States plans to begin destroying some of its older chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll in the Pacific late this year, well ahead of the schedule set in the chemical agreement, Daniel said. The Johnston Atoll plant was built to meet a congressional requirement set in 1985 to destroy all existing U.S. chemical weapons by 1997 as a condition for approving a Pentagon program to produce a new generation of chemical arms. Plans call for building other destruction plants at existing chemical arms stockpile sites in Oregon, Utah, Colorado, Arkansas, Alabama, Kentucky, Indiana and Maryland. Elisa Harris, a chemical weapons expert at the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank, said U.S.-Soviet collaboration on technical aspects of chemical arms destruction would help Moscow overcome domestic environmental critics. ``They would like to have the American stamp of approval on their technology'' to persuade the critics that destruction can be accomplished safely, she said. In recognition of the technical and environmental obstacles facing both the United States and the Soviet Union, the new agreement gives each side until 1999 to destroy 50 percent of the chemicals covered by the accord. The remaining amounts would be destroyed in the final three years of the agreement. The Soviet procedure for destroying chemical weapons is to decompose the active nerve agent by mixing it with alcohol, making it non-toxic. It then is burned. The U.S. method skips the decomposition step and burns the chemicals in an incinerator that heats the agents to 2,700 degrees Fahrenheit. The chemicals, mainly nerve agents and mustard gases, are used in a variety of artillery projectiles, mortar cartridges, land mines, rockets and gravity bombs. The use of chemical weapons is outlawed by the 1925 Geneva Protocol, signed by 149 nations, but there are no international limits on possession or production.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Soviet President's Stanford Address
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECAPS five takes previous, and describes as excerpts.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are excerpts from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address at Stanford University on Monday:
Ladies and gentlemen, I'm very pleased that within the framework of my state visit to the United States I am here among you within the walls of the world-famous university. Thank you for your warm hospitality. I think that those who work or study in your university are doubly lucky it is in California and California is a special place, even by international standards. And I'm saying this not just by way of a compliment and to say pleasant things to the governor of this state, who is here with his wife. I think I am just stating a fact. It is said that only five countries in the world produce a greater gross output than your state. The ideas and technologies of tomorrow are born here in California. California is closely linked economically with Europe, Asia and Latin America. So this is a good place to live and for me an appropriate place for discussing how the Soviet Union and the United States have positioned themselves on the dividing line between the centuries and the eras on the coasts of the Pacific ... described as the Mediterranean of the future. It is appropriate now to ponder the destinies of the world since it was here in San Francisco the United Nations was founded precisely 45 years ago. I think this is symbolic, that it is this sunny city that was selected as the place where to ... proclaim the foundation, the establishment of this organization whose efficiency we all need very much. Let us look at the conclusions drawn that time, right after the horrible war. The United Nations was set up to include ... and to remove the political, economic and social causes of war, ... conforming it with the principles of justice and international law. The United Nations was set up to include ... security ... and to remove the political, economic and social causes of war ... to promote relations among nations ... on the equal rights and self-determination of peoples, with respect for human rights. ... It is only now that international politics is really starting to adjust itself to these ideologies and principles, and all of us felt how much we need the United Nations if we really are to move the world, a new world, a new kind of relationships in the world in the interest of all countries and nations. For a long time the Pacific was a center of confrontations and the arms race. ... Nations found themselves on the opposite sides of the barricades of ancient revolutions. But new winds are now blowing ... the Japanese and Koreans and Chinese and other Asian peoples have lessons for the entire world to learn. ... Let us think about the future, both of us have more than enough reasons. ... I am under no illusions regarding the possibility of faster convergence (of) societies, and they are quite different. For many years they were developing in different directions. They probably will never be fully alike. There is no need for that. ... The cold war is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it, who won the Cold War. There was a time when military procurement orders were considered, are still considered by some, to be the best incentive for economic and technological progress. ... (In the 1970s) Santa Clara County, which was the first in per-capita military contracts, began to explore ways of demilitarizing the local economy. I hope that as Soviet-American relations improve ... participation in the arms race will become a thing of the past ... not only for your beautiful state but both our great powers. Science has played a major role in the arms race. Science was the first to seek out ... and to look for a way out. ... Here we have to give credit to the joint efforts of Soviet and American scientists to which Stanford University scientists have made a very substantial contribution in their program for the development of the basic principles for such concepts as international security and strategic stability.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Americans Cutting Down on Fats, But Overweight Persists
DOC.TEXT: Americans are cutting down on fatty and high-cholesterol foods, but 61 percent still are overweight, according to a national survey. ``There is no evidence that Americans are winning the `battle of the bulge,'' says a report by Prevention magazine based on an annual poll conducted by Louis Harris and Associates. The proportion of adults who are overweight has remained close to 60 percent since 1983, when the magazine began commissioning the polls. Levels of regular strenuous exercise have also remained about the same over the past seven years. About 35 percent in the latest survey said they work up a sweat for at least 20 minutes, at least three times a week. The survey of 1,250 adults was conducted by telephone Nov. 6 through Dec. 13 last year. No margin of error was given. Among the bright spots in Prevention's report card were continued reductions in the number of people eating foods high in fat and cholesterol. Half of those polled said they ``try a lot'' to avoid eating high-cholesterol foods like eggs, dairy products and fatty meats _ up from 42 percent in 1983. And 58 percent said they avoid eating too much fat, up from 55 percent in 1983 and 54 percent in 1988. ``The evidence is overwhelming that a diet high in fat ... is a major threat to health and longevity, and it appears that the public is getting that message,'' the magazine's report said. But the survey also found a decline in efforts to get enough vitamins and minerals, down five percentage points from 1983 to 58 percent, and to avoid sugary foods, also down five points from the first survey to 46 percent. Among those who are overweight, more than half are at least 10 percent over the recommended weight range for their height and build. A quarter were within their recommended range, and 15 percent were underweight. About 35 percent said they exercise strenuously at least three times a week. By sex, that was 42 percent of the men and 29 percent of the women. The survey found that men were more likely to exercise strenuously and frequently, while women were found to be more nutrition-conscious. The survey also found: _46 percent of respondents said they avoided sugar, compared with 51 percent in 1983. _Eating fish twice a week followed the same trend, down from 34 percent in 1985, the first year the question was asked, to 28 percent in the latest poll. _53 percent said they have their cholesterol level checked at least once a year. _44 percent of women said they examine their breasts to check for possible cancer at least once a month _ down from 51 percent in 1988 but up from 37 percent in the first survey. _75 percent have a dental exam at least once a year. _28 percent said they smoked cigarettes, down from 30 percent in 1983. _Questions about alcohol and drug use found 91 percent drink moderately or not at all and 94 percent ``never use recreational drugs, such as marijuana, speed and downers.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Dialogue with PLO Said in Jeopardy
DOC.TEXT: New U.S. contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization following last week's abortive guerrilla attack along the Israeli coast reinforced the view of some officials that the U.S.-PLO dialogue may have to be suspended. The dialogue ``clearly is in jeopardy,'' a senior administration official said Monday, echoing the view of many in the State Department about the potential consequences of the raid last week by a radical PLO faction. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, Robert Pelletreau, has met three times in Tunis with PLO representatives since the raid took place. The United States is demanding that the PLO dissociate itself from the attack and condemn it as well. It also is asking the PLO to expel the faction responsible for the raid, the Palestine Liberation Front. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said last Friday the administration was dissatisfied with the responses it has received thus far from PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat. The officials said little has changed since Baker made that statement but the administration is still withholding a final decision on whether the dialogue should be allowed to continue. Meantime, Palestinian sources in Baghdad, Iraq, said Arafat has summoned the PLO's ruling body to discuss the status of the U.S.-PLO dialogue. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said PLF leader Mohammed Abbas will attend the meeting of the 15-member Executive Committee. They said Arafat also has summoned to Baghdad the secretary-generals of all factions within the PLO. The Reagan administration agreed to open a dialogue with the PLO in December 1988 after Arafat renounced terrorism. The administration had said in March the PLO was abiding by that commitment but the events of last Wednesday _ when two boatloads of PLF guerrillas were intercepted near Tel Aviv _ has produced a policy review in Washington. PLF members hijacked the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in October 1985. That incident led to the death of Leon Klinghoffer, an American whose two daughters planned to appeal in Washington today for a suspension of the dialogue with the PLO. Arafat seems eager to find a formula that would preserve the PLO-U.S. link without alienating hard-line grassroots sentiment within PLO ranks. Meanwhile, Arab countries at the United Nations are seeking ways to underscore the international isolation of the United States on the Arab-Israeli conflict. The United States last week vetoed a U.N. Security Council proposal for a fact-finding mission to be sent to the West Bank and Gaza Strip to inspect living conditions of Palestinians. The U.S. officials, insisting on anonymity, said several similar proposals may be introduced that probably will leave the administration in the uncomfortable position of having to register additional vetoes. The Arab countries also are contemplating the possibility of convening a U.N. General Assembly session in Geneva to discuss the situation in the occupied territories. If such a meeting is held, the U.S. officials said it probably would produce a resolution critical of Israel that would be approved by a lopsided margin. By holding the session in Geneva, Arafat could address the gathering. If such a meeting were held in New York, the administration could prevent an Arafat appearance by denying him a visa.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic Scramble Tries To Save Cambodian Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with diplomatic activity trying to save cease-fire. No pickup. ^By LARRY THORSON
DOC.TEXT: Chinese, Thai and American officials joined attempts Tuesday to foster progress in peace talks that were stalled on the brink of signing a cease-fire in Cambodia's 11-year civil war, Japanese officials said. Thai and Cambodian officials said a meeting would be held later in the day, but it was still not clear whether all four contending parties would be present or whether a cease-fire would emerge. The first session of the talks broke off Monday after just 25 minutes because the Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla group opposing the Hanoi-backed government in Phnom Penh, refused to attend without the right to raise issues and sign the truce pact as an equal partner.
