A flurry of diplomatic activity focused on the 16th floor of the Imperial Hotel where Prince Norodom Sihanouk and other members of his three-party guerrilla coalition _ including the Khmer Rouge _ were staying in rooms along one corridor. Chinese Ambassador Yang Zhenya was seen leaving the corridor. A Japanese Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a U.S. diplomat had visited the guerrilla delegations earlier Tuesday. The American's identity was not immediately known. Thailand's deputy prime minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, a key drafter of the proposed cease-fire, left the corridor with two high-ranking Japanese Foreign Ministry officials. It appeared progress was in the air, as Chavalit replied positively when asked if the Cambodians had accepted a proposal. But he left without giving further details. The peace conference, the first in Japan since World War II, appeared to have collapsed Monday when the Khmer Rouge nominal leader, Khieu Samphan, boycotted the opening session. But informal meetings continued, mostly in the hotel where the guerrilla delegations were staying. Pressure came from other countries including China, which backs the Khmer Rouge, the United States, which backs Sihanouk while trying to distance itself from the Khmer Rouge's harsh and even genocidal reputation, and Thailand, through which arms flow to the rebels. All four of Cambodia's warring factions had tentatively agreed to a cease-fire before coming to Tokyo, but the hard-line communist Khmer Rouge refused to participate in two-sided peace talks between the loose guerrilla coalition and the government of Premier Hun Sen. Hun Sen has refused to negotiate equally with the Khmer Rouge or allow them an equal role in a future interim government, saying that might allow them to return to power. Hundreds of thousands of Cambodians died during the group's 1975-79 brutal rule before Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and installed the moderate communist Hun Sen government. Vietnam says it withdrew all its troops in September, but there are charges that some remain in Cambodia. If a truce were signed, it would be the first time the sides actually had signed a cease-fire. But the draft agreement lacks any mechanism to police a truce. Even if a cease-fire is worked out, the sides disagree on measures to administer the country before elections can be held. Sihanouk, who once was king of Cambodia, has led the three-faction guerrilla coalition since 1982. He believes the faction must be included in any political arrangement for the country, saying its disciplined and powerful army would be the best guarantee against a return of the Vietnamese. In Bangkok, Sihanouk spokesman Roland Eng said heavy fighting was continuing and guerrilla groups had launched offensives in areas around Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital. ``We are still carrying on normally on the battlefield. Nobody knows what will happen in Tokyo, so for the time being we will continue as normally on the battlefield,'' he said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Credit Insurance-List
Consumer Groups Say Credit Life Insurance Expensive, Unnecessary
DOC.TEXT: Two consumer groups are urging states to tighten controls on credit life insurance policies they say are far too expensive and unnecessary for most customers. ``This is pervasive throughout all segments of the installment loan market,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. ``Credit life insurance is the nation's worst insurance ripoff.'' Credit life insurance is sold by banks, finance companies, auto dealers and other lenders to consumers taking out installment loans. The policies pay off the loan if the borrower dies. CFA and the National Insurance Consumer Organization released a report Monday calling on state insurance departments to require lenders to return to consumers at least 70 cents in benefits for each dollar paid in premiums. ``This would force a drastic reduction in price in almost all states,'' the report said. It said the 1988 benefits payout amounted to 43 cents on the dollar. The rest went for profits and administrative costs. The two groups also exhorted state insurance departments to launch massive education campaigns to let consumers know they don't have to buy the insurance when they buy a car, sign up for a credit card or take out a loan. ``In most cases, people need life insurance to protect against the economic consequences of early death,'' said Bob Hunter, president of NICO. He said a comprehensive life insurance policy should be extensive enough to cover unpaid loans. ``You shouldn't buy life insurance to cover your credit'' separately, Hunter said. It costs more and does not allow a spouse or other survivor to continue making monthly payments; the separate policy would pay off the loan immediately. Virginia Stafford, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association, whose members sell many credit life insurance policies, said many people do not have comprehensive life insurance policies. ``For those customers, credit life insurance may represent a good deal,'' she said. Stafford said her group does not believe consumers are being overcharged. But she agreed they should be better educated about their choices. According to the two consumer groups, more than 70 million credit life insurance policies were in force in 1988. Consumers paid $2.1 billion in premiums and received $900 million in benefits that year. Some policy holders are unaware they have bought credit life insurance, others are led to believe they need it to obtain a loan and others fall victim to emotional pitches to protect their loved ones when they die, the report said. Lenders also make it difficult to refuse the insurance by building it into the monthly payment, the report said, necessitating a rewrite of the loan papers if the policy is refused. Customers also are no able to find out if the price is fair, the report added. According to the report, all states regulate credit life insurance but only four _ Maine, New York, Vermont and New Jersey _ require payouts at or above the 60 percent recommended by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The groups said the severity of overcharges varies from state to state, with the worst in the Southeast and the best prices in the Northeast. CFA is a federation of 240 consumer groups with 50 million members and calls itself the nation's largest consumer advocacy group. NICO says it is the only national consumer group devoted to insurance advocacy and education.

DOC.HEAD: Deals Bring in Congress, Bureaucrats, Other Countries
DOC.TEXT: When is a U.S.-Soviet treaty not a treaty? When it's an agreement, a convention, a protocol, a contract, a joint statement or a memorandum of understanding. Does it make any difference? It does to members of Congress, thousands of other officials and hundreds of millions of people worldwide who may be affected. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a trade agreement often called a treaty, though it is not a treaty in the strict sense. The Constitution requires that a treaty be approved by two-thirds of the Senate. Ever since the Senate rejected the Treaty of Versailles at the end of World War I, presidents have preferred to use simpler ``executive agreements.'' These are put into effect much more easily. Charles Maechling, a former State Department official, estimated that about 60 treaties _ which had to take that form _ are awaiting ratification in the Senate now. Sometimes, when the president sees possible trouble ahead, he does not even ask the Senate to approve a treaty. President Carter held back the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty after Soviet troops invaded Afghanistan in 1979. Countries with parliamentary systems do not have this kind of complication. When their executives make major decisions their legislators either approve or face the threat of a new election. Congress has required that they review trade agreements if they are made with countries that have been under communist rule. It was busy this week ironing out a constitutional difficulty on the procedure. Such agreements need a simple majority vote in both houses. Bush has said he would wait to send Congress the agreement with the Soviets until the Supreme Soviet has passed a new law allowing all its citizens to emigrate more freely. Other accords not subject to the same law often are sent to Congress anyway. Influential members might be offended if they were not. When members of Congress are insulted they may hold back the funds to carry out agreements. ``The executive pretty well has to flash them by Congress,'' said Maechling, who has worked on many pacts. He is now a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution, a private study group on public policy. An accord between Bush and Gorbachev on chemical weapons was designed to give a push to a pact that will bring a ban by as many governments as are willing to sign. President Sadaq Hussein of Iraq emphasized the importance of that in April when he threatened to ``make the fire eat half of Israel.'' Chemical weapons are much cheaper and easier for Third World countries to make than nuclear weapons. The ban will be called a ``convention,'' which Maechling said was just a treaty under another name. One official suggested that the word ``convention'' may sound less forbidding but usually calls for the same action by the Senate as a treaty does. Some accords get negotiated far down the bureaucratic line by lower-level officials and may not go before Congress at all. ``Back in the 1970s when Henry Kissinger was secretary of state and he was trying to negotiate detente with the Soviet Union, somebody he never heard of _ the chairman of the Maritime Commission, I think _ negotiated an agreement on shipping with the Soviets,'' Maechling said. ``Kissinger was furious. He only found out about it when the agreement worked its way up through the bureaucracy.'' This time it was announced during Gorbachev's visit that Secretary of State James A. Baker III or other officials had negotiated, among a long series of accords, one that opens 42 ports in this country and 42 in the Soviet Union. The U.S. negotiator was Warren G. Leback, a former merchant ship captain who holds the title of maritime administrator.

DOC.HEAD: Young Playwright Doesn't Let Handicap `Get In My Way'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Kari Geller's struggle against crippling illness has taught her to savor the simple joys that other teen-agers often overlook _ the wonder of a blade of grass, sunlight glinting on the surf, a mother's inexhaustible love. The story of 18-year-old Miss Geller's fight to overcome a devastating muscle ailment is told in her first achievement as a budding playwright, a one-act drama that premiered Monday at the Kennedy Center. The play, titled ``The Waiting,'' was one of three winners of the 1990 Young Playwrights Award from Very Special Arts, a non-profit educational affiliate of the Kennedy Center, which provides arts programs for the mentally and physically handicapped. A central figure in Miss Geller's highly personal play is based on her mother, Karla Geller, 50, who relived her childhood bout with polio when her daughter was stricken with encephalitis, a viral infection of the brain, at the age of 15. ``She was an incredible help to me,'' said Miss Geller, a high school senior in San Clemente, Calif. ``She was such a role model. She showed me that I was not alone. She didn't once let me know she was scared. She was so strong throughout that she made me strong.'' Miss Geller's ailment, formally known as ``post-encephalitic muscular dystonia,'' involved a gradual constriction of her muscles that left her hands clenched tightly, her neck immobilized and her feet bowed and twisted inward. After three years of painful physical therapy that included horseback riding to improve her balance and coordination, Miss Geller's handicap is barely noticeable today. She walks with leg braces and has regained the use of the thumb and forefinger on each hand. She says she hardly notices, either, unless she tries something like piano playing. ``I don't let it get in my way,'' she said after receiving her award from Jean Kennedy Smith, founder of Very Special Arts, and a hug from Sabrina Le Beauf, a star of ``The Cosby Show.'' Miss Geller, a member of the Laguna Playhouse Youth Theater, plans to enter the California Institute of the Arts in Valencia this fall to pursue a drama career. She said her illness deepened her affection for her mother, a special education teacher in Los Angeles who still walks on crutches. ``We've always been best friends,'' the daughter said. ``She's the most important person in my life. It's amazing how many things we shared, the spinal taps, the therapy, the hospital nurses. When I wrote the play, we sat down and talked for hours about her feelings and the events of the past.'' Her illness taught her to ``appreciate life more, and not to take things for granted,'' Miss Geller said. ``I remember the first time I got out of the house,'' she said. ``Mother and I got salads and went down to the harbor and sat on the grass. I watched the water sparkling and looked at a blade of grass and saw how beautiful it was. I appreciated those things, finally.'' The other Young Playwrights Award winners, whose plays also were performed Monday, were Janet Allard, 17, of Honolulu, for ``Sand Dragons,'' and Karen Greco, 17, of Cranston, R.I., for ``Ritty & Jesus Came to Dinner and Enjoyed a Plate of Borscht.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Blast Sad State of Reserve Cargo Ships
DOC.TEXT: An influential House Republican says he'll tell the White House that ``heads ought to be rolling'' at the Maritime Administration for its maintenance of a rusting cargo fleet that would be activated in a national emergency. Rep. William S. Broomfield of Michigan told maritime officials Monday that the National Defense Reserve Fleet's ships were ``glorified rust buckets'' and a waste of money. Broomfield expressed his annoyance after the government's top maritime executive and a senior Navy official defended the fleet at a hearing of the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation, business opportunities and energy. Broomfield is the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, but more importantly serves as the senior GOP member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The fleet consists of 331 mostly mothballed vessels _ including 72 World War II-era ``Victory'' ships. The Maritime Administration is spending $6.7 million this fiscal year to provide minimal maintenance for the oldest part of the fleet and $89 million for the newer, 96-ship Ready Reserve portion. The agency is requesting $225 million for the Ready Reserve in fiscal 1991. ``I agree that the outward appearance of many (reserve) ships is poor to a visitor,'' Maritime Administrator Warren G. Leback testified. But the Transportation Department official said the working machinery is protected by dehumidification, the hulls are treated to slow deterioration and the ships would be able to sail again, as they did when last called to service during the Vietnam war. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of the subcommittee, joined Broomfield in protesting Leback's upbeat assessment and both lawmakers said they would sponsor legislation to have the ships sold to U.S. salvage companies. ``I wouldn't want to serve on one,'' testified Navy Cmdr. John Polley, who criticized the state of the fleet last year in an investigation he conducted for the Defense Department inspector general's office. Broomfield said Leback's defense of the fleet, ``when the Cold War seems to be ending'' and the nation faces a ``staggering budget deficit,'' convinces him that ``heads ought to be rolling'' at the Maritime Administration. He vowed to ``get to the White House'' with his complaint. Wyden said, ``The taxpayers are getting repeatedly fleeced ... for these maritime cadavers.'' He accused the Maritime Administration of ``running a subsidy program'' for foreign salvage companies, because ships leaving the fleet went to overseas scrap yards. Jonathan D. Kaskin, director of the Navy's Strategic Sealift Division, told the subcommittee that the Pentagon considers the fleet a strategic asset because modern container ships cannot carry tanks, howitzers and other heavy equipment. He said the Navy wants to build the Ready Reserve to 142 ships by 1994, but in the meantime must rely on the World War II-era vessels because ``until we get something better, this is all we've got.'' ``You're living in never-never land,'' Wyden said. A recent Associated Press inspection of some ships in the fleet, berthed in the James River at Fort Eustis, Va., revealed rusted and broken railings, paint peeling all along the exterior and even ankle-high grass growing through wooden deck boards. Below decks were mattresses on metal bunk beds, dusty lockers, old mess halls, crank-style telephones, huge ovens and steel cooking pots. The 96 vessels in the Ready Reserve part of the fleet are designated to sail on five to 20 days' notice. An additional 42 are so old they will be used as target practice for Navy gunners, sunk to become reefs or traded to salvage companies for newer ships. The remaining ships are supposed to be seaworthy on 30 to 120 days' notice. Except for the Ready Reserve, which is spread out across the country, the reserve fleet is located at Fort Eustis, near Norfolk; at Beaumont, Texas, and in Suisun Bay near San Francisco. Leback said the Maritime Administration was forced to sell its disposable ships to foreign rather than U.S. scrap yards because the agency ``has a responsibility to obtain the highest possible return on these government assets.'' He testified _ and U.S. salvage industry officials agreed _ that the domestic industry cannot outbid foreign firms because of environmental and workplace safety regulations imposed on American firms. The industry representatives said U.S. companies would bid on the jobs if a law were passed to require that the work go to domestic concerns.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Allen Ginsberg wants a parents' group to apologize for requesting that high school students have restricted access to an anthology of his poems. The group, Coalition of Concerned Minority Parents, also criticized the lack of black authors in the library of North Central High School. ``If my work were taken out of libraries, censors would have excuses to take out many other basic texts of early black cultures,'' Ginsberg wrote May 17 in a letter to Mmoja Ajabu, a group spokesman. Ginsberg, 64, said the group owed him an apology or at least an acknowledgment that his work is not in opposition to their ideas. Ajabu said he intends to reply to Ginsberg but not apologize. He said since the book described homosexual activity, ``We felt it should be under the instruction of an adult who is aware that it is not the norm.'' The school decided in November to continue to allow unrestricted student access to ``Collected Poems _ 1947 to 1980,'' an anthology recommended for independent study.

Actor Corey Feldman pleaded innocent to four felony counts of possession and transportation of heroin and cocaine. Feldman, 18, entered his plea Monday before a Superior Court judge who set a pretrial hearing for July 9. He remains free on $5,000 bail. Feldman was arrested March 9 after police allegedly found 25 balloons of the narcotics in his car during a downtown traffic stop. The actor appeared in such films as ``Stand By Me,'' ``The Goonies,'' ``Dream a Little Dream'' and ``The 'burbs.'' During a court appearance in April, Feldman read a statement urging children to stay away from drugs.

What if Mikhail Gorbachev had shown up as scheduled? Even with the Soviet president a no-show, the Brand family found its dairy farm swamped with reporters. ``It's still been very busy,'' Cecilia Brand said in between interviews Monday. ``One of the TV channels came out. We've had a couple of interviews with farm magazines. I suspect that after tomorrow things will settle down.'' The Brands said another hectic day was likely today, when plans called for a bald eagle to be set free to honor Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota. The bird was scheduled to be released during Gorbachev's canceled visit to the farm on Sunday. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, dropped the planned 25-minute visit because they were running behind schedule. But they met the Brands on the airport tarmac before their departure Sunday night.

Randy Travis, top entertainer the previous two years at the TNN-Music City News Country Awards Show, came up empty handed despite being a finalist in five categories. Ricky Van Shelton was chosen entertainer of the year and top male vocalist, and Patty Loveless was named female vocalist of the year. ``I'm shocked, really shocked,'' Shelton said Monday night after the 24th annual fan-voted awards. ``I'm really, totally in awe.'' The Statler Brothers were double winners, taking the vocal group award for the seventh straight time and copping single honors for ``More Than a Name on the Wall.'' Hank Williams Jr. and his late father also were double winners, for video and vocal collaboration for ``There's a Tear in My Beer.'' Tennessee Ernie Ford won the Minnie Pearl award for dedication to the music business and humanitarian efforts during a career that has spanned 50 years. Veteran Merle Haggard, best known for ``Okie From Muskogee,'' received the living legend award. Also honored were Clint Black, star of tomorrow honor and top album; the Judds for vocal duo; Ray Stevens for comedian; Ricky Skaggs for instrumentalist and The Chuck Wagon Gang for gospel group. The winners were chosen by subscribers to the Music City News, a monthly country music publication, and viewers of The Nashville Network, a cable station that televised the two-hour ceremony live.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Soviet President's Address to Business Leaders
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are excerpts from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address to West Coast business leaders Monday:
I would like to point out that this summit meeting with President Bush has placed our relations on a new level and I believe this is the deepest result of the summit. I think this is consistent with the wishes of the Soviet and American people. ... and with the wishes of the entire world community. ... Without any regret we are saying farewell to the Cold War and I think and hope that we have entered a long period of peace. ... Over these days, in Washington, yesterday in the state of Minnesota and today in San Francisco and at Stanford, I've been able to say quite a few things that I wanted to say to the American people. It is difficult to avoid repeating myself but in such situations ... in a way repetition results in understanding the logic of things and therefore I would like to emphasize once again our interests here and I believe that is also consistent with the interests of the American people. Also speaking of universal values and also the values of Islam, don't be surprised there is one very interesting proverb in the Islamic tradition which says, ``Repetition does not spoil the prayer.'' ... Of course, I cannot say we can be pleased as to the state of our economic relations and the scale of our economic relations. I currently foresee greater activity in this area. ... I've been advocating for many years greater economic dependence of the Soviet Union on the United States and of the United States on the Soviet Union. ... It is very difficult to expect that the dynamism that we see now for our relations maintains its momentum and gains greater impetus. I think without progress and economic cooperation this would be simply impossible. ... Now we stand on the threshold of what's called change in the history of our country for many years. We will be moving toward a new format of new economic life. We will be basing our economy on market principles. We will be creating the infrastructure that will open up the road to market relations. ... We have to decide now in our country about what kind of Soviet Union we're going to have in the years to come. The combination of political reform, of our innovations, the new distributions of functions between legislative and executive political power and party, a combination of all the other changes under way within the overall process of implementing glasnost, places our society on a whole new level. ... I believe that since the Soviet Union is moving around the path of democratization, decentralization, glasnost, greater freedom in whole areas ... I believe that a Soviet Union of this kind is what all of you need. ... We are now watching those who maybe are risking something but who are willing to cooperate and watching those who are standing on the sidelines thinking that those who cooperate with us now will in the future ... obtain ... more full cooperation in our market. ... We are already entering a world of greater trust and greater mutual understanding and interaction. We now have the trade agreement. Of course, that will not be of much practicality right now for the period of transition. In addressing most difficulties in our economy this is not of great practical significance. But it is of great political importance, which I have to think is no less meaningful. ... American business should now look for ways to enter our market, look for ways to find new forms of cooperation so that once the agreement is ratified they will be able to use all the potential inherent in that agreement. ... I think the essence of what is happening here with economic cooperation between our governments is that we are laying the foundations of stable, depoliticized and mutual beneficial co-development. ... We are moving also toward convertibility of the ruble. We used to think that this was rather for the distant future, but we now think that since we are trying to integrate into the world market and become an organic part of the world economy we will have to achieve convertibility of the ruble in a shorter period of time. ... The (Soviet) Far East today has tremendous potential. It has about one-third of the reserves of important natural resources. ... However, industry there is not well-developed, accounting for only about 3 percent of the country's industrial output. We want to enhance the potential of the Soviet Far East and to do so would be of great value. ... We could probably consider joint scientific exploration (space) missions. I decided to speak of this exactly here because I know that California is active in space projects. So I think this is a promising area for cooperation between us. ...
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: SAN FRANCISCO: between us.
DOC.TEXT: You might be worried perhaps generally by the prospects of transition into a market economy. You're asking, you're wondering, could involvement with the Soviet Union become a trap, could you lose money as a result. First of all you must be reminded that I am a person who does not like adventures. I'm in favor of change, but ... I have always battled all adventurers who like to propose change. Some people would like to propose adventuristic approaches. I think risk is good in politics and business, but adventurism is bad both in politics and in business. The current Soviet leadership is in favor of profound changes but still it fully intends to do that in the careful way. I very much hope we will find agreement with our people on all that we are doing. We will continue to move along the path that we have chosen because other people understand that this is the path on which we must move forward. ... You see some unpleasant things. You see some debate. You see there are some opponents of this change of direction. That is true and it's unavoidable. Of course, you can debate whether it is better to go to Camp David using a helicopter or taking a car. It depends on what you want. On whether you want to see the woods from the helicopter or the car but that's not a matter for much debate. But when you are changing or replacing one model of the economy with another model of an economy you have to do it very carefully. And what's happening shows we are changing in a serious way and not just sweeping the yards, as you say. ... I want to engage in an open honest and serious discussion and I certainly don't want to, as they say in Italy, put spaghetti on your head. ... Some people think that we have been changing course all the time. ... No we are not changing our course. We are on course. We're on track and our overall idea is quite clear. We looked at our society several years ago and we decided that things could not go on like this, that our society, country has to become more dynamic and needs oxygen, fresh air. ... The important thing now is just to give people a free hand and let them be creative on the basis of new economic realities to reveal their potential with their initiative, and we see that people can do a great deal. ... We have become closer to the rest of the world. People understand us better and appreciate us better, including the Americans and I think that's very important. The guarantee of our success is the powerful process of democratizing our society. We cannot turn back. And although the path that we've chosen is difficult, it is interesting and is open. And I think it is a very promising road.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Panel Says Super Rocket Not Needed
DOC.TEXT: The United States doesn't need a super rocket and can rely on its fleet of expendable launch vehicles through the end of the century, a Defense Department advisory panel says. Instead of building a heavy-lift booster, the Defense Science Board said, the military should push two technical approaches that hold promise for breakthroughs in rocket technology: the air-breathing propulsion being developed for the National Aerospace Plane, and nuclear engines. ``Although launching rockets incorporating nuclear devices presents emotional and political difficulties, the task force review leads us to recommend continued investment in this area,'' said the report released Monday. The board's finding would, in effect, leave the Soviet Union unchallenged in heavy-lift capacity. Its Energia is the world's most powerful rocket, capable of putting a 220,000-pound cargo into low Earth orbit. The most powerful cargo carrier used by the United States is the space shuttle, which can lift 52,000 pounds into orbit. The biggest expendable rocket, the Titan 4, can carry a 39,000-pound payload. In the Apollo moon landing program of the late 1960s and early 1970s, the United States used Saturn 5 rockets capable of lifting 310,000 pounds of cargo. But the assembly lines were shut down when that program ended. The science board said it was uncomfortable with a 1987 national security directive signed by President Reagan that called for development of a heavy-lift launch vehicle for the anti-missile Strategic Defense Initiative. Rather than developing a more powerful booster or a new family of expendable rockets, the report said, research should concentrate on improving rocket engines. ``If the rocket engines are in an advanced state of development, a launch vehicle can be developed faster than any payload it would be required to carry,'' it said. ``Unless there is a decision to deploy SDI, the annual national security payload to orbit averages less than 600,000 pounds,'' the report added. ``Individual payloads do not exceed 50,000 pounds. No heavy lift requirement, with the possible exception of an experiment for SDI, is evident.'' The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has talked of developing a vehicle, to be called Shuttle-C, that would substitute a cargo canister for the space shuttle orbiter. It would be able to lift about 150,000 pounds and be used to carry construction parts for the space station. The report called also for building a second pad for launching Titan 4 rockets at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. ``The single Titan 4 pad at Vandenberg is a major risk,'' it said. ``Payloads to polar orbit can only be launched from the West Coast, and the April 1986 Titan 34D accident demonstrated how much damage can be done to a launch complex by a booster malfunction.''

DOC.HEAD: Coming Attraction No Ordinary Teaser
DOC.TEXT: Beth Corey gazed forward and was surprised to see her boyfriend, Kevin O'Keefe, on the screen as they waited for the movie to begin at a theater. ``When I saw his face up there, I just turned to him and said, `What are you doing,''' Corey said. ``He said, `Just keep watching.''' In the silent short, three of O'Keefe's male friends, dressed as women, vie for his attention. But O'Keefe, 25, remains true to Ms. Corey, wooing over a photograph of the 25-year-old woman. ``Beth, I love you, and I'll do anything to have you forever. ... Will you marry me?'' say the subtitles. O'Keefe, who has dated Corey for six years, had worked for a year on the four-minute film and had secretly plotted to have it played as Corey sat by his side. He was so confident of her response that he told 40 friends and a newspaper reporter and photographer to join him in the surprise Saturday night. ``She brings up marriage about every six hours,'' said O'Keefe, a salesman for a film supply company. Ms. Corey said yes.

DOC.HEAD: Big Potential Seen for Food Ventures With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The new grain deal between the United States and Soviet Union is small compared with potential trade in agriculture and other farm products that could be developed, says a food processing executive. George Melnykovich, president of the Food Processing Machinery and Supplies Association, said Monday that the Soviets want to use the methods Americans perfected for distributing food to a large nation. ``For their own internal stability, they need to feed their people,'' said Melnykovich. ``We've solved the problem.'' But the problem American companies have with providing the solution to the Soviets is money. The ruble is virtually worthless in world trade, and U.S. business operates on the philosophy that ``if you can't get money out, don't put money in,'' Melnykovich said. He is an organizer of a three-day conference in Washington that is bringing together 55 Soviet ministers to discuss the state of the Soviet food system and with food companies here. ``It's an unprecedented meeting between leaders of one U.S. industry and top Soviet officials,'' said Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, chief executive officer of the H.J. Heinz Co., and conference chairman. ``We need all types of products,'' said Vladilen Nikitin, the Soviet equivalent to the U.S. secretary of agriculture. Speaking through an interpreter, Nikitin said the conference was a first step toward getting more U.S. agricultural commodities to the Soviet Union. He also noted that he would sign an agreement on food processing with Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher on Wednesday. He would not say how much the Soviets were willing to spend. ``We would rather have joint production,'' said Nikitin. Americans companies are skittish about that idea because it involves high economic risk, said Melnykovich. But he said he thought the Soviet government would take steps soon to back its currency with the guarantees needed to make it usable in world commerce. Meanwhile, American food companies are taking steps slowly to probe the Soviet market. Large companies such as Pepsico and McDonald's are making major investments in a gamble that the ruble will be convertible eventually. Smaller companies that don't have much venture capital are looking for other ways to start doing business with the Soviets. ``We don't have resources on our own to go after the business,'' said Tom Madsen, president of Key Technology Inc., in Walla Walla, Wash. which makes equipment used in cleaning, sorting and inspecting fruits and vegetables. ``We can act as subcontracters.'' Mel Jolly, of APV Crepaco in Chicago, said his company is converting a distillery in the Soviet Union into a bakery in a project being financed by a British firm. ``It's the ideal three-partner association,'' Jolly said. The big companies invest directly with the Soviets with an eye toward future benefits. The smaller firms hire on with the bigger ones and get immediate payment in the currency of their choice. The Soviet delegation also was looking at the conference for equipment companies to convert defense plants into food processing facilities, said Melnykovich. ``That's their peace dividend,'' he said. The United States and Soviet Union have had grain deals since 1976, but they have been virtually the only significant trade between the superpowers. The latest, five-year grain agreement, signed last Friday by President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev had been negotiated in March and came as no surprise. It replaces a 1983 agreement that expires Dec. 31. Under the pact, the Soviets agreed to annually buy at least 10 million tons of U.S. grain, an increase from the current 9 million tons. Soviet grain purchases in most years have exceeded the required minimums. In 1988-89, for example, sales were more than double the specified minimum. The Kremlin will have some greater year-to-year flexibility under the new arrangement by being allowed to choose between wheat and feed grains, although over the life of the pact the minimums will be met, officials said. The Soviets will be committed to buying at least 4 million tons each of wheat and feed grains. However, in any one year Moscow may substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. For the first time, the pact includes barley and sorghum as feed grains. Additional flexibility also was provided by giving Moscow automatic permission to buy up to 14 million tons of grain annually without further discussion with Washington. The automatic limit under the current pact is 12 million tons, although the United States has routinely increased that to fit Soviet needs. As of May 31, the Soviets had bought more than 16.7 million tons of U.S. wheat and corn under the current agreement for delivery this year. Last year's sales totaled a record 21.7 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett, Other White House Aides, Give Up Money to Enter Public Service
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett knew he was going to be giving up the big bucks when he returned from private life to public office, and new financial disclosure forms indicate he got what he expected. During the first 2{ months before he became director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy March 10, Bennett earned $80,246 from speeches and consulting work plus $25,962 in salary as president of The Madison Center, a private policy research group he created. If the $106,208 income from the early months had held up throughout 1989, he could have earned about $550,000, not including interest on savings. Instead, the government started paying him after March 10 at the rate of $99,500 for a full year, or about $80,000 for the rest of 1989. Adding that salary to the earnings of the first couple of months plus his declared interest earnings gave Bennett an approximate income of $191,209 to $201,208 for 1989. His interest earnings totaled between $5,001 and $15,000. ``I was told it would have been a very good year for me,'' Bennett said shortly before taking office, reflecting on his expected nose dive in take-home pay. Some other White House aides have managed to remain wealthy in public service, while others, such as Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, have not. Bennett, known as one of the poorest members of President Reagan's Cabinet when he was education secretary, ``turned down $1.5 million in lectures in 1989,'' when President Bush nominated him to the drug policy job, a lecture-circuit industry source said at the time. The financial disclosure forms indicate Bennett's cash assets suffered somewhat as a result of his new employment. In 1988, Bennett's assets ranged from $301,003 to $356,002 and up, according to the forms, which only require broad ranges to be reported and do not require listing such personal items as homes or cars. Bennett told the Senate Judiciary Committee in early 1989 that his net worth was about $432,600. For 1989, Bennett's assets ranged from $150,002 to $350,000. When Bennett resigned as Reagan's education secretary on Sept. 20, 1988, he reported having a savings account worth less than $1,001. The former philosophy professor had been chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities for four years before becoming education secretary in 1985. While Bennett was out of office in late 1988, he signed a contract with Simon & Shuster publishers in New York to write two books, neither of which has yet been published, and he received advances of $187,500. Bennett's form also said he resigned from positions as consultant or member of the board of several foundations or public policy research groups. Sig Rogich, who orchestrates President Bush's public appearances, remains a multimillionaire from his advertising business and holdings in radio, real estate and other ventures, according to financial disclosure reports released Monday by White House general counsel Boyden Gray. Rogich reported assets of at least $3.9 million to $5.5 million or more, and net income on his holdings in the range of $180,549 to $238,544 or more. His interests included an advertising firm, radio stations, mobile billboards and a bar in Truckee, Calif. At the other end of the spectrum, Marlin Fitzwater, Bush's press secretary, listed assets ranging from $17,005 to $55,000 and outside income of $2,722 to $4,520. Rogich, in a telephone interview from California where he was traveling with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said he had put his holdings in a blind trust and ordered his trustee to sell his stocks. White House chief of staff John Sununu is still on leave from Tufts University as an engineering professor, but he reported he will not accept tuition breaks or other faculty benefits for his children while he works in Washington. Sununu, a former governor of New Hampshire, reported assets ranging from $422,008 to more than $1 million, and income apart from his White House salary ranging from $15,506 to $55,000. He also drew $9,151 from New Hampshire for his final weeks as governor. Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser to the president and former career CIA man, reported assets ranging from $33,005 to $115,000 and outside income of $2,305 to $8,000.

DOC.HEAD: Break-up of First Family Intrigues Argentines
DOC.TEXT: The marriage of President Carlos Menem and his wife Zulema had the trappings of a fairy tale. Children of Syrian immigrants, they met during a visit to the old country, married after a whirlwind courtship and raised a son and daughter while Menem's political star took him from a jail cell to a governor's mansion to the presidency. Now, as they are on the verge of a very public break-up, their actions are the stuff of soap operas. Mrs. Menem denounces the father of her children as a ``womanizer'' and fires political broadsides at her husband. Menem's social policies are inhuman, she says, his economic plan doomed and his staff corrupt. After complaining earlier this year that telephones at the presidential residence were tapped, Mrs. Menem walked out. Last month, Menem did the same and has since slept in government offices and the apartments of friends. Magazines and newspapers have had a field day covering the story, with juicy facts and rumors splashed on covers and front pages. Menem is laying legal groundwork to boot Mrs. Menem from the residence if she won't leave on her own. The whole affair is ``grotesque,'' says Menem, 59. He usually refuses to comment on developments, but said ``I don't know whether to get mad or laugh'' when asked about her claim he has been ``kidnapped'' by his aides. Mrs. Menem, 46, declined through her press secretary to be interviewed on the subject. Residents of this nominally Roman Catholic nation seem intrigued but hardly scandalized by the marital feud. Menem-watchers say it hasn't affected his policies, public image or relations with the church. ``Everyone knows their last reconciliation was a political act to help him win the election'' in May 1989, said Nolberto Fernandez, editor of the celebrity magazine ``La Revista.'' ``It's not a political `problem' for him,'' said pollster Manuel Mora y Araujo. ``That's what she would like it to be, but so far she hasn't been successful in making it one.'' The Menems have had a stormy relationship for years. Both are ambitious, determined, quick-tongued and hot-tempered. An avid sportsman who races speedboats and rally cars, Menem has made no secret of his attraction to other women. Mrs. Menem, a striking blonde, has been linked with other men. By some accounts, their marriage in October 1966 was arranged by their Moslem parents. Menem was reported to have been in love with a young divorcee he continued to see for years after the wedding. Following the March 1976 coup that toppled President Isabel Peron, Menem, a provincial governor and leading member of the populist Peronist Party, was jailed for three years, then put under house arrest. The couple did not get together immediately after his release. When they did, they split up again in 1984. A second reconciliation, at the urging of papal nuncio Ubaldo Calabresi, came four years later on the eve of a crucial primary election. Politics, not love, seems at the heart of their conflict. ``She wants a formal political position and he refuses to give her one,'' said a Peronist official, who commented on condition his name not be disclosed. During the election campaign, the First Lady-to-be tried to evoke comparisons with Evita, the wife of Juan Peron who helped him win election as president in 1946 and endeared herself to millions of poor Argentines with her charitable works. Menem did not help; the effort flopped. Mrs. Menem, a Moslem who has hinted her husband's conversion to Catholicism _ the state religion to which all presidents must adhere _ was something less than an act of faith, also said during the campaign: ``I support Carlos Menem, but I want people to know I'm not here just as a symbol. I'm going to act. I'm going to do things. I'm going to work.'' During the 11 months of Menem's presidency, Mrs. Menem has raised funds for schools and hospitals. But while her sister and cousin have been appointed to high posts, she has not. Asked whether Mrs. Menem's connections with labor leader Saul Ubaldini, retired army rebel Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin and other influential critics of her husband eventually might force Menem to see things her way, the Peronist official said: ``Not at all. It's not just that Menem has stood up to tougher opponents as much as he never `gives' anything to anybody. Sometimes, he seems to. With her, he's not even pretending.''

DOC.HEAD: Former House Speaker Seems Content With Life After Washington
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Jim Wright expresses little bitterness or remorse over his downfall as House speaker after 34 years in Congress and spends his time a year later with gardening, lecturing and family. ``I didn't get everything done that I wanted to, but for three and a half decades I was able to ... apply my wits and my intellect and my physical strength to some of the most intractable problems and see if I could make them budge,'' Wright said. ``That was a great gift. Not many people are given that. So, why shouldn't I feel fortunate?'' he said in a recent interview. A relaxed, suntanned Wright, 67, reflected on the benefits of his resignation, which be blames on political enemies, as he sat in his cluttered Fort Worth office May 31. Exactly a year earlier he gave his resignation speech, and he formally relinquished the speaker's post on June 6, 1989. ``Now I'm home, among people whom I know, who know me,'' Wright said. ``I am able to do a lot of things that I denied myself during those years when I was trying to be a leader.'' Wright stepped down after the House Ethics Committee said he violated House rules 69 times involving sales of his book, ``Reflections of a Public Man,'' and in business deals with his friend George Mallick of Fort Worth. He is fatalistic about his resignation, which came when the longtime Democratic leader had been speaker for about two years. ``There were so many peculiar circumstances that fell together to create this jigsaw puzzle out of which there was no escape, none of them logical, none of them, to my mind, predictable ... that I'm inclined to think that that's what was supposed to be,'' Wright said. Wright's office is cluttered with memorabilia and boxes from 34 years on Capitol Hill, along with notes for a book he is writing on Central America. Wright donated congressional memorabilia to Texas Christian University for a memorial library. Wright said he's happier now than he has been in years. His wife, Betty, whose job in a company formed by Wright and Mallick was questioned by the ethics committee, said there are deeper feelings. ``I think that it leaves scars. I don't think there's any way to get away from it,'' she said. Wright maintained that the ethics charges were falsely brought by his enemies and that he never knowingly violated House rules. He said the behavior of his nemesis, Republican Rep. Newt Gingrich, and special prosecutor Richard Phelan amounted to ``character assassination.'' And Wright also blames the media for ``a voracious thirst for scandal,'' saying reporters never gave him a chance to tell his side of the story. Wright assigns scant culpability to himself. ``It is altogether possible that I may have been too insistent, too demanding, too firmly determined to achieve the maximum'' in pushing for legislation, he said. Wright said he didn't do enough to protect himself once the ethics allegations started flying. ``I thought I could ... let the other guy wear brass knuckles if he wanted to, and I could still win,'' he said. ``Maybe that's hubris. It turned out that it didn't work that way.'' Nevertheless, he insists he's not bitter. ``I'm happy. I'm as busy as I want to be,'' he said. Wright has time for things that had been squeezed out by his busy schedule, such as having dinner with his wife and spending time with his children and grandchildren. He still works long days writing, giving speeches or guest lectures at colleges and appearing at fund-raisers for fellow Democrats. Wright recently attended a gathering for the man who filled his House seat, Pete Geren, who often seeks his advice. Wright won't criticize Tom Foley, his replacement as speaker, saying it would be ``ungracious,'' but he does say the House today seems to lack ``clarity and direction.'' As for history, Wright said he doesn't worry how his life will read. ``I'm at peace with myself,'' he said. ``I intend to rest my case on the things that I was able to achieve.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,921.62, down 3.75 points, or 0.01 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Problems Now Strike at Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Discovery became the latest space shuttle to encounter trouble when a crane yanked one of its payload bay doors. A hydrogen leak somewhere inside Columbia has that shuttle's astronomy mission on hold. NASA plans a fueling test Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to find the leak without having to roll the shuttle back to its hangar _ a move that would mean a month's delay. Discovery sustained possible damage Monday when a corner of a payload bay door was snagged by an overhead bridge, which acts as a crane, NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said. The open door flexed 10 to 12 inches upward, then snapped back into position when the bridge operator moved back. ``There is no visual damage. However, the orbiter has some very critical components that aren't meant to be bent,'' Buckingham said. Workers were checking for damage to the 60-foot door and the bridge, which enables the door to open and close on Earth. The accident occurred in a hangar while Discovery was being prepared for its October flight with the Ulysses satellite, which will explore the Sun's poles. Discovery has been at the hangar since its April flight with the Hubble Space Telescope. That mission was delayed two weeks by a malfunctioning power unit. Columbia's flight with the $150 million Astro observatory was two weeks behind schedule because of cooling system repairs when last Wednesday's launch was scrubbed. NASA plans to fill about a tenth of Columbia's external tank with liquid hydrogen to try to duplicate the conditions that existed when the leak was detected. Additional sensors will be placed around the 17-inch-diameter valve where the leak is believed to be. The area will be cleared of workers during the test. Hydrogen is highly combustible. ``The longer we can't find it, the better the chances of moving back'' to the hangar, Buckingham said. ``Right now, the chances of not moving back are getting slimmer and slimmer.'' The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has moved a shuttle from the launch pad back to the hangar because of problems three times, in 1983, 1984 and 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet and Korean Presidents Talk of Diplomatic Ties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New graf 7, ``Lee Soo-young,'' with comment on timetable.
DOC.TEXT: In a dramatic finale to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's U.S. tour, South Korea's president said he and the Soviet leader agreed to move toward normal relations between their two long-hostile nations. The Cold War ice on the Korean peninsula ``now has begun to crack,'' President Roh Tae-woo told reporters after a historic meeting with Gorbachev at a San Francisco hotel Monday evening. ``President Gorbachev and I share the view that efforts to normalize bilateral relations between South Korea and the Soviet Union have already been started and will lead to the establishment of permanent relations,'' Roh said. The Soviet president was more vague in his account of the meeting. ``We will let the fruit grow ripe, and when the fruit grows ripe, we will eat it,'' Gorbachev said in a brief interview outside the Soviet consul general's home, before flying back to the Soviet Union at the end of a five-day U.S. visit. Although no date was set for further talks and nothing was put in writing, the unprecedented meeting appeared to set the stage for significant change on the divided peninsula, where for four decades U.S.-allied South Korea has confronted Soviet-allied North Korea in one of the world's longest-running military showdowns. Lee Soo-jung, an aide to Roh, was quoted by Korean reporters as saying the two leaders agreed to develop full diplomatic relations ``in the not-distant future.'' Officials of Roh's governing party have said since March that such relations would be established by year's end. Roh said that in their private discussion he and Gorbachev ``agreed to further expand economic, scientific, technical and cultural exchanges and cooperation between our two countries.'' Trade between the Soviet Union and South Korea doubled to $600 million last year and was expected to surpass $1 billion this year. South Korea's dynamic, fast-growing economy could offer the Soviets investment and technology intheir quest to develop their own resources. The South Korean leader described the talks as the beginning of a lasting dialogue. ``As a result of my meeting with President Gorbachev today, normal bilateral relations between our countries will be restored,'' he said. The two countries have had an unstable relationship since the division of the peninsula and the formation of South Korea after World War II. In the 1950-53 Korean War, the Soviets helped supply the North Koreans, whose invasion of the south touched off the conflict. The animosity began to abate in 1988 when the Soviets announced they would participate in the Seoul Olympics, even though Communist North Korea opted to boycott. Earlier this year, the Moscow and Seoul governments opened consular-level offices in each other's capitals. Roh and top aides had arrived Sunday morning to prepare for the first meeting between leaders of the two nations since the partition. Restored ties with the Soviet Union have been a cornerstone of the Roh administration, Korean officials have said. Roh said he hopes to restore diplomatic ties to North Korea and induce that country to share the outlook of ``glasnost,'' or openness, that Gorbachev has instilled in the Soviet Union. ``North Korea is no longer our rival or adversary,'' Roh said. ``It should be our partner in the quest for common prosperity.'' South Korea has called on the Soviet Union to urge North Korea to reduce its ``offensive military structure.'' Roh received a string of impressive visitors at his Fairmont Hotel residence after arriving in San Francisco, including former President Reagan and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He met early Monday with top U.S. State Department officials, including Richard Solomon, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, who briefed him on the summit meetings between Gorbachev and President Bush in Washington last week. Roh is to meet with Bush in Washington on Wednesday to brief him on the talks with Gorbachev and to discuss more details from last week's summit talks. In a noisy demonstration outside the Fairmont, Korean-American protesters complained that improved relations between the Soviet Union and South Korea would only contribute to continued separation of the two Koreas. ``If the Soviet Union forms full diplomatic ties with South Korea without any change in the current policy and actions of South Korea and the U.S., it will amount to recognizing the status quo of the Korean division,'' the group, Mobilization for Peace and Reunification of Korea, said in a statement. An improved Soviet-South Korean relationship could lead to an accelerated withdrawal of U.S. troops from South Korea. The United States already has announced plans to withdraw 7,000 of its 43,000 troops from South Korea during the next two years.

DOC.HEAD: Raisa Junks Official Itinerary, Takes Impromptu Tour of City
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev inspected a corner market's supply of Russian vodka and a fishmonger's giant crab after junking her planned itinerary in favor of a little ``people's diplomacy.'' ``I'm overwhelmed by this beautiful city,'' the Soviet first lady said shortly before she and her husband, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, left San Francisco for the Soviet Union on Monday. In the morning, Mrs. Gorbachev and Nancy Reagan renewed old acquaintances, and anyone expecting a sudden frost by the bay saw only warmth. ``Very nice,'' Mrs. Reagan said afterward. Later, after visiting Stanford University with her husband, Mrs. Gorbachev was supposed to go to the residence of the Soviet consul general and visit the Bank of America building to admire the city from atop the skyscraper. Instead, she took off on her own whirlwind tour of San Francisco, bewildering Secret Service men, public relations staff and reporters. In the space of an hour, her limousine cruised through Chinatown, the Financial District, Fisherman's Wharf and the Marina district, damaged in last October's earthquake. ``It seems while I was busy in session, she was doing the sightseeing _ people's diplomacy,'' joked her husband. Mrs. Gorbachev's first stop was in the Twin Peaks neighborhood. Hea Kim, who runs the New Terrace Market with her husband, Jin Kim, was watching TV coverage of the Soviet president's visit when in swept Mrs. Gorbachev. ``I didn't know about it at all,'' Mrs. Kim said. ``I was surprised.'' Mrs. Gorbachev spent about 10 minutes asking about Mrs. Kim's merchandise. ``I think she wanted to know if we carry Stolichnaya,'' Mrs. Kim said of the popular imported Soviet vodka. ``Then she looked at the Smirnoff, the kind made in the U.S.'' Mrs. Gorbachev smiled when she learned Stolichnaya was the store's best-selling brand, Mrs. Kim said. At Fisherman's Wharf, Joe Rosquites, who sells crab, was saving a ``champion crab'' for Mrs. Gorbachev. As the motorcade approached, he held up a crustacean, and the limousine stopped, the door open, for a moment. ``I held a crab up and shook it, and she looked at it and her face lit up,'' Rosquites said. ``I am kind of upset she didn't stop, though. I was looking for a decent-size tip.'' Elsewhere, Mrs. Gorbachev sat in a cable car, chatting with the driver and an assistant and ringing the bell. ``The cable car operator suggested he had a friend who could do Mrs. Gorbachev's hairstyle for free,'' the Gorbachevs' interpreter said later. The limousine also drove through the Marina district, where damage from last year's quake can still be seen. Earlier, Former President Reagan and his wife joined the Gorbachevs for about an hour at the consul general's home, and Mrs. Reagan later denied suggestions she and Mrs. Gorbachev once were uncomfortable with each other. ``I think there's been a great misunderstanding about our relationship,'' Mrs. Reagan said. ``It was a very different time. We were plowing new ground.'' There was no mention of Mrs. Reagan's complaint, in her book, ``My Turn,'' that Mrs. Gorbachev ``never stopped talking. Or lecturing, to be more accurate.''

DOC.HEAD: West Coast Businessmen Impressed by Gorbachev's Sales Pitch
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer chief John Sculley led the cheers for Mikhail Gorbachev's new dogma: Invest in the Soviet Union now or regret it later. ``It's a big market out there and I think we all want to be part of it,'' Sculley said Monday after the Soviet president implored the West Coast's business elite to help transform Soviet society through capital and technology. ``If you're sitting on the sidelines and you think you can wait a few years just to see how things turn out, don't plan on being in,'' Sculley said. His remarks echoed Gorbachev's at a luncheon at the plush Fairmont Hotel, attended by billionaires like McDonald's heiress Joan Kroc, the governors of California, Oregon, Washington and Hawaii, and numerous top executives. Their reviews of Gorbachev were overwhelmingly positive. Gorbachev said the Soviets desperately need investment now and will remember those who provide it. The transition to a market-based economy will continue, if haltingly at times, he said. And he promised to make it easier for Western businessmen to function in the way to which they are accustomed. ``Our society, our country, has to become more dynamic. It needs oxygen, fresh air,'' he said to loud applause. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union has tempting investment opportunities, especially in the rich, largely untapped natural resources in the nation's easternmost regions. He also said California aerospace companies should undertake joint ventures to build airplanes and spacecraft with the Soviets as both sides produce fewer weapons. Richard Matzke, president of Chevron Overseas Petroleum, which just struck a deal to study developing the vast Tengiz oil field in a joint venture with the Soviets, was impressed by Gorbachev's commitment to making the ruble convertible into other currencies. That would remove one of the biggest obstacles to freer trade with the West. ``He said they intended to move towards the convertibility of the ruble faster rather than slower,'' Matzke said. ``Of course, he didn't give any specifics about that, and we all recognize that it's a tremendous task for the Soviet Union.'' In Minneapolis, where Gorbachev issued a similar warning to about 100 business leaders that those who ``stand on the sidelines'' will remain there for years, a businessman said making the ruble convertible is critical. ``Everything is the money problem,'' former Control Data Corp. chief executive Robert Price said Monday. ``He can't wish it to go away. He can't and we can't.'' Many of the executives at the lunch already have struck deals with the Soviets that would have seemed unusual or impossible not long ago. Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications filmed the Sean Connery spy movie ``The Russia House'' there _ one of a spate of U.S. movies lured recently by the Soviets. Those kinds of ventures have created huge pressures to upgrade Soviet telephone systems _ and more work for American Telephone & Telegraph, said Rhea G. Serpan, an AT&T vice president. Sculley said the foundations of Western-style business _ phone systems, good hotels, good airlines _ are slowly falling into place. ``Add to that the stability and vision of President Gorbachev and what he is talking about and I think you've got the makings of what can be a very exciting decade for businessmen,'' Sculley said. He cautioned that it will probably take 10 to 20 years ``to build the real sort of entrepreneurial infrastructure that we're accustomed to.'' But he added, ``Those who want to be a part of it better start playing now.'' Sculley said he was surprised at how detailed Gorbachev was in emphasizing radical economic changes under way in the Soviet Union: efforts to help get profits out of the country; allowing foreign business people to head joint ventures; encouraging entrepreneurs; low tax levels during investment years. Such detail suggests Gorbachev is highly knowledgeable about such issues and considers them important, Sculley said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0478 to fix category code
Soviet Leader Winds Up U.S. Tour Proclaiming End to Cold War
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, celebrating the end of the Cold War, embraced former arch-enemy South Korea, thrilled crowds of ordinary San Franciscans, won the applause of businessmen and then flew home to his own deeply troubled nation. In a major speech on the last day of a five-day U.S. visit, the Soviet president proclaimed, ``The Cold War is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it.'' Later Monday, speaking to leaders of more than 100 major U.S. companies, the Kremlin chief earned praise with promises to speed up the exchange of rubles for dollars, streamline the Soviet bureaucracy, and turn his land into a new frontier of capitalism. Apple Computer Inc. Chairman John Sculley said Gorbachev's presentation also reassured executives wary that the Soviet Union's course depends only on Gorbachev's political fortunes. ``He has indicated ... that maybe his personal future is uncertain, and he's been quite honest about that,'' Sculley said. ``But I think he's also said he's got to stand up to adventurism, that he believes in profound change, that he is on a steady course, that he is not going to deviate from that.'' In the earlier speech at Stanford University, where thousands of students hailed him with chants of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' the Soviet leader touched on global themes, advocating a system of international alliances that unites rather than divides the world _ an apparent bid for security arrangements broader than the U.S.-led North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He called for a ``new approach to the structures of security ... and alliance building'' that would result in a ``unity ... worthy of the life of a human being.'' He also implored scientists in both countries to join in determining how nuclear weapons could be destroyed without harming people or the environment. It was bravura performance by Gorbachev, despite his obvious fatigue after four days of summitry, a dash to Minnesota, and a 22-hour spin around the San Francisco area that featured a brief reunion with former President Reagan. The clamor of thousands of protesters _ Armenians, Lithuanians, Estonians, Latvians, Palestinians, Koreans, Eritreans from embattled Ethiopia _ competed with the cheers of thousands of others crowded behind police barriers and craning for a glimpse of Gorbachev. But in all the din and pomp of the long day, a historic moment occurred quietly behind closed doors when the Soviet leader stepped into the tower of the posh Fairmont Hotel and shook hands with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. That simple gesture and the one-hour talk that ensued symbolically ended 45 years of enmity and heralded a possibly huge shift in the political landscape of Asia. Gorbachev and Roh, in agreeing to work toward establishing full diplomatic relations, put pressure on North Korea to reconcile with the South and announced to a reluctant Japan that the Soviets are serious about doing business with Asia. ``As a result of my meeting with President Gorbachev today, normal bilateral relations between our countries will be restored,'' Roh said. ``The Cold War ice on the Korean peninsula has now begun to crack. Though nothing was put in writing, Roh said the two countries plan to boost economic and trade ties. Soviet-South Korean trade doubled to $600 million in 1989, and is expected to surpass $1 billion this year. The Soviet president, cautious not to offend longtime ally North Korea, was less exuberant in his assessment of the meeting, although he did not deny Roh's interpretation of the importance of the discussion. ``We will let the fruit grow ripe, and when the fruit grows ripe, we will eat it,'' Gorbachev said cryptically at a separate meeting with reporters. He and his wife, Raisa, then wound up their first cross-country U.S. trip and flew home to the Soviet Union. The Soviet president had business on his mind most of the day in San Francisco, especially when he spoke to the gathering of prominent executives. He acknowledged some early failures of the Soviet system to open up its markets, but declared the country was on an irreversible path toward free trade and called for greater cooperation with the United States. If the current trend toward economic cooperation were to falter, he said, U.S.-Soviet relations would suffer. He also warned U.S. businessmen they could be left behind if they are slow to react to the changes in the Soviet Union. ``We are now watching those who maybe are risking something but who are willing to cooperate, and watching those who are standing on the sidelines,'' he said. ``American business should now look for ways to enter our market, look for ways to find new forms of cooperation so that once the (U.S.-Soviet trade) agreement is ratified they will be able to use all the potential inherent in that agreement.''

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Reopen Tiananmen Square, Campuses Quiet
DOC.TEXT: Authorities reopened Tiananmen Square to the public today after closing it for four days that coincided with the first anniversary of the bloody military suppression of a massive pro-democracy movement. At the same time, the Foreign Ministry issued a ``serious warning'' to foreign journalists, accusing some of collaborating with opposition activists involved in ``illegal anti-government activities.'' The warning came after numerous foreign reporters were detained or beaten by security forces while covering the anniversary of the June 3-4, 1989 army attack that crushed the student-led pro-democracy movement. Tiananmen Square, the focal point of last year's seven-week pro-democracy movement, had been closed since Friday and sealed off by armed police to prevent any anniversary commemorations. Although the square was reopened, armed police still patrolled adjoining streets. In the university district in northwest Beijing that was the scene of a daring anti-government protest on Sunday night, all was quiet. During the night, helmeted police with automatic rifles set up roadblocks in the district, checking identification papers and searching cars. They were withdrawn by dawn. Many students had said they wanted to stage demonstrations to pay tribute to the hundreds and perhaps thousands of people who were slain by the army last June. But plans for an overnight candlelight vigil, a day of fasting and even a commemorative march to Tiananmen Square were abandoned after school officials issued stern warnings and convoys of security vehicles circled campuses with their lights flashing. ``Just seeing the convoys terrified me,'' said a People's University sophomore. On Sunday night, students at Beijing University threw bottles and debris at police vehicles patrolling the campus and up to 1,000 students later marched through the campus and held a rally. At both Beijing and Qinghua universities, there was a sense of expectation Monday night, but nothing happened other than some shouting, singing and the smashing of beer bottles. ``Bottle'' in Chinese sounds much like the name of senior leader Deng Xiaoping, who approved the crackdown. The official Beijing Daily today ran a long front-page article extolling the progress made in the country since the crushing of what Communist authorities call ``the counter-revolutionary rebellion.'' ``It's not that the orioles sing and swallows dart everywhere and all is praises and appreciation, but one year after the baptism of blood and fire, it seems ... that spring is very much in the air,'' it said. Security in Beijing the past three days was the heaviest since martial law was lifted in January. The few people who attempted protests near Tiananmen Square were quickly arrested. More than a dozen foreign journalists were either detained, roughed up or had guns pointed in their faces by police while attempting to cover events Sunday and Monday near Tiananmen Square and the university campuses. Jim Munson, the Beijing bureau chief of Canadian TV and president of the Foreign Correspondents Club, said he was summoned to the Foreign Ministry today for a warning talk about the activities of foreign journalists. Liu Rucai, division chief of the Information Department, told Munson that a small number of journalists ``have connections with some Chinese people who have engineered illegal activities and even engage themselves in activities incompatible with their status as journalists.'' He also accused foreign journalists of entering university campuses without authorization and ``conducting illegal press coverage activities,'' according to an excerpted transcript of the meeting provided by Munson. Liu did not specify what he meant by ``illegal activities'' involving Chinese citizens or foreign journalists. Liu also said any protest by the Foreign Correspondents Club, presumably about police harassment, would be ``utterly unreasonable.'' He warned Munson that as head of the foreign correspondents group he would be held responsible for any consequences arising from a protest. Foreign journalists say the harassment was unprovoked and took place in public areas where there are no restrictions on press coverage. U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler on Monday expressed displeasure over the harassment of journalists in Beijing, and Chinese diplomats in Washington were reportedly called in over the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Slightly Lower, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange erased its morning gains and closed marginally lower Tuesday, while the dollar ended slightly higher against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 152.43 yen, up 0.01 yen from Monday's 152.42-yen finish. The dollar opened at 152.36 yen and ranged between 152.15 yen and 152.58 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 3.75 points, or 0.01 percent, ending the day at 32,921.62. The index gained 84.21 points at the end of the morning session before falling back in the afternoon. Traders said the index fell in the afternoon because market players stepped off to the sidelines while the yen remained weak against the dollar. Currency dealers said the dollar-yen rate was moving narrowly in the absence of market-affecting news. ``Participants generally think the U.S. economy is not doing very well, which should discourage their interest in the dollar. However, the dollar is not falling that much because there is no reason to buy the yen against the dollar, either,'' said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Unless there is a specific reason to buy the yen, the dollar will stay around the current level, and market players will continue to make small position adjustments, he said.

DOC.HEAD: NBC News Chief Predicts Resurgence for ``Today''
DOC.TEXT: NBC News President Michael Gartner admitted to affiliates that changes he approved in the ``Today'' show put it in a slump, but he predicted it will be back on top in the morning ratings. Gartner also announced Monday the start in January of a 24-hour NBC News channel for the network's 208 affiliates. Affiliate executives were heading to Capitol Hill today to seek help on cable issues and urge that NBC and its network rivals be free from federal bans on financial interests in shows the networks don't solely own. At the start of NBC's annual affiliates convention, Gartner frankly addressed the decline in ``Today'' ratings since Jane Pauley left as co-host in December. ``That's got to be the starting point, the willingness to admit _ in this case _ the obvious,'' said Eric Bremner of King Broadcasting in Seattle, the new chairman of the NBC affiliates board. ``I think it was well-received,'' he said. Once first in ratings, ``Today'' has been second to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for 21 weeks. Its slide started in January after Pauley's replacement by Deborah Norville as co-host with Bryant Gumbel. The popular Pauley, who was unhappy with other changes on the show and asked to leave, had been on ``Today'' for 13 years. To get the show moving again, Gartner brought in a new executive producer, Tom Capra, and is bringing back former ``Today'' host Joe Garagiola on June 11 as third co-host. Without mentioning specifics, Gartner told affiliates that ``we know we screwed up the `Today' show ... he (Capra) knows what the show needs and he knows how to provide it. ``Now, with the dust settled, he'll make it, we'll make it, another winner.'' Garagiola appeared on stage with the ``Today'' cast and kidded with weatherman Willard Scott. But the affiliate executives greatest affection was for Pauley, who got a standing ovation. ``I have never been happier in my work,'' said Pauley, now preparing a series of prime time specials for NBC. She is the substitute evening news anchor when Tom Brokaw is away. Gartner predicted better times ahead for the ``NBC Nightly News,'' third in ratings for seven straight weeks. He introduced the show's new executive producer, Steve Friedman, calling him a ``show doctor'' who will make the newscast ``sparkle.'' Friedman ran ``Today'' when it rose to first in ratings. He left NBC in 1987 to create what proved a costly syndicated flop, ``USA Today on TV.'' The normally brash producer made no promises of a fast ratings rise, but said there would be changes to make the newscast a contender. He declined to announce the changes citing competitive reasons. Network newscasts can ``no longer just index the day's events,'' he said. ``We can't come on and say, `These are the top stories.' People have heard them already. ``We are going to do a show of interest, not the show of record,'' he said. The 24-hour news service announced by Gartner will provide affiliates with international, national, regional and breaking news for use in their own newscasts, said Robert Horner, in charge of the service. Although at first glance similar to Cable News Network, the NBC service won't have anchors and won't transmit stories on a non-stop basis, as CNN does. It is intended to help NBC stations compete with CNN's newscasts, and to ward off further encroachments by CNN on NBC stations. CNN says it has 216 broadcast affiliates, of which 52 also are NBC affiliates. NBC's convention will end Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Offer U.S. Servicemen Opportunity To Send Families Home
