DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is offering to evacuate the families of American servicemen at government expense following the recent slayings of Americans and rebel threats of more attacks. A military spokesman said today that U.S. service personnel have until Thursday to tell officials whether they want their families sent home. ``We have asked those who have families to tell us when they would like to ship their dependents back before their tour ends,'' said Lt. Col. Ronald Rand, spokesman for Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. Rand did not say what would happen if service members decided later to return their dependents. Adm. Huntington Hardisty, commander of U.S. forces in the Pacific, authorized a program which allows a serviceman at any of the six U.S. bases in the Philippines to send members of his family home at government expense before his tour of duty ends, Rand said. Rand said a U.S. government-sponsored transfer of dependents of U.S. servicemen is usually done when only on exceptional cases, such as illness. But he said a large number of requests and letters of concern about their families forced them to adopt the program. A total of 40,000 Americans _ servicemen, civilian workers and dependents _ are stationed at Clark, Subic and four other American bases in the Philippines. At Clark alone, there are over 10,000 dependents, Rand said. Last month, Communist rebels killed two American airmen near Clark and vowed more attacks until all U.S. troops leave the country. Rebels also are suspected in the May 4 shooting death of a Marine sergeant near Subic. At least eight Americans have been slain in political attacks since April 1989. Six of the victims were servicemen or associated with the military. Another American serviceman was killed Saturday night, but American and Filipino officials said robbery _ not politics _ was the motive this time. Since Friday, U.S. Defense Department civilians and military dependents who live on Clark have been barred from leaving the base because of Communist threats. Those living off-base have been ordered to limit travel to essential business. Rand said the restrictions would last for at least two months depending on U.S. assessment of the threat. The New People's Army, the military wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, has waged a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor, Patient Say AIDS Treatment Promising; Experts Cautious
DOC.TEXT: AIDS experts are noncommittal, even skeptical, about reports that a man's AIDS infection disappeared after his blood was heat-treated, but that hasn't stopped hundreds of patients and physicians from trying to learn more. Dr. Kenneth Alonso and Dr. William Logan performed the ``hyperthermia'' procedure on a 33-year-old AIDS patient with Kaposi's sarcoma, a skin cancer commonly occurring with AIDS. The man's blood was heated for two hours in hopes of attacking the cancer, Alonso said. Soon after, the patient's raised, red skin lesions ``flattened to scars,'' and tests for the AIDS virus have remained negative since, Alonso said. ``We changed the disease. It's obvious that we did,'' Alonso said. ``What the long term prognosis is, we have no idea.'' Alonso said Monday he is getting some 700 calls a day from anxious patients and doctors, following a Cable News Network report last week. Hospitals and AIDS services organizations also are reporting numerous inquiries. Alonso is quick to note that he is not claiming an AIDS cure: ``This is just what we did in a single case.'' The patient, at least, is claiming victory. ``I'm convinced I'm cured of AIDS,'' Carlton Crawford told the Daily Citizen News in Dalton, his former hometown. AIDS specialists are reluctant to speculate about the reports. Officials of the Centers for Disease Control and the National Infectious Disease Institute declined to comment. ``A lot of us are real cautious about this,'' said Alice Trinkl, spokeswoman for AIDS research at the University of California at San Francisco. ``There have been so many promises made in the AIDS area.'' ``It is important that a scientifically balanced evaluation be given to the situation,'' said a statement from Project Inform, a patient advocacy group and information clearinghouse in San Francisco. ``Over the years, far too many patients and their doctors have loudly announced miracle cures, raising the hopes of other patients.'' Alonso stressed that he submitted his findings to the journal Molecular Oncology and Tumor Pharmacotherapy, for ``normal peer review.'' But the patient disclosed his treatment, prompting Alonso to discuss his work publicly. He said he intends to perform the procedure on several more patients, ``and see if we have made a difference.'' ``Some researchers have told me the results replicate what they have found in the lab,'' he added. ``That's very exciting to hear.'' Hyperthermia, commonly used to treat infections before the advent of antibiotics, is still used against some cancers. Alonso and Logan determined that the patient's sarcoma might respond to heat treatment, then performed the hyperthermia process at Atlanta Hospital. In February, the patient's blood was run in a loop out of his body, through a 115-degree heater and back in, for two hours. Atlanta Hospital covered the costs _ $35,000 in the average case, Crawford said. The patient's body temperature rose to 107-108 degrees throughout the procedure, Alonso said. Such a high fever could cause severe complications under routine circumstances, but the patient's pH, oxygen, mineral and fluid levels were carefully monitored and maintained. ``That's why you can go through this,'' Alonso said. ``We treated this gentleman with Kaposi's sarcoma with heat,'' Alonso said. ``He went into complete remission.'' Blood tests and viral cultures have remained negative for human immunodeficiency virus since, he said. But Project Inform said the patient might have been ``overmedicated'' with AZT prior to the procedure, and simply stopping the drug could have produced some improvement. The group also called viral cultures ``notoriously unreliable'' in determining whether a patient is infected from one day to the next. ``Hyperthermia deserves serious discussion by researchers,'' Project Inform said. ``But far more needs to be known about the obvious potential for toxicity inherent in raising a patient's core temperature as high as that.''

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Down Slightly, Dollar Up Marginally
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index closed marginally lower today after early gains disappeared, and the dollar was almost unchanged against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 3.75 points, or 0.01 percent, closing at 32,921.62. The index was up 84.21 points at the end of the morning session but fell back in the afternoon. The decline came as market players stepped off to the sidelines ahead of Thursday's final trading for June issues on the futures market, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. ``Participants were reluctant to buy as they were afraid of a rush of arbitrage selling to take profits from price gaps between the spot and futures markets for June issues before Thursday,'' he said. The dollar's stability above 152 yen also was sending market players to the sidelines, he said. Kazuyuki Suzuki, a stock trader with Daiwa Securities Co., said, ``Trading was rather quiet because participants were unable to figure out in which direction the yen and interest rates would move.'' Trading was moderate, with first section volume estimated at 600 million, down from 650 million Monday. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 152.43 yen, up 0.01 yen from Monday's 152.42-yen finish. It opened at 152.36 yen and ranged between 152.15 yen and 152.58 yen. The dollar now has gained 2.98 yen in the last six trading days. Market participants were torn between expectations of a slowdown in the U.S. economy and optimism over the U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington, where the two sides agreed on nuclear arms reductions, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``They are now waiting for new market-affecting news,'' he said. Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said there was no reason to buy the yen against the dollar, either. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 88.11 points at 5 p.m. from Monday's close of 88.36. The yield stood at 6.945 percent, up from 6.895 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Rivals Sign Agreement, But Stop Short of Truce
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Cambodian Premier Hun Sen signed a communique today that called for an end to hostilities but stopped short of announcing a cease-fire in Cambodia's 11-year-old civil war. The powerful communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas, who are part of a three-faction rebel coalition Sihanouk heads, boycotted the session. The statement said the factions ``should refrain from all offensive actions'' and there should be measures to ensure a ``military standstill.'' But it said an ``actual cease-fire'' should be realized through agreement on forming a so-called supreme national council. The council has been proposed as a body joining representatives of the resistance coalition and the Hanoi-backed Phnom Penh government. It would administer the country in the period before a national vote to determine Cambodia's future. The communique said a supreme national council should include equal numbers from the resistance coalition and from the Phnom Penh government and be formed by the end of July. It mentioned a future role for the United Nations in monitoring the withdrawal of foreign forces, the end of foreign military supplies and a cease-fire agreement. The impact of the declaration on fighting in Cambodia was hard to judge. Combat intensified in the days preceding the Tokyo conference as the contenders sought to extend their areas of control. In Bangkok, Sihanouk spokesman Roland Eng said heavy fighting was continuing and guerrilla groups had launched offensives in areas around Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital. The Khmer Rouge nominal leader, Khieu Samphan, did not attend the signing ceremony. He also boycotted the opening session Monday when the Tokyo peace conference started. A statement from the Khmer Rouge was expected later. The group had said it declined to join the conference unless it was an equal member, rather than a part of Sihanouk's resistance coalition. After the Khmer Rouge boycotted the conference, informal meetings continued, mostly in the hotel where the guerrilla delegations were staying. Pressure came from other countries, including China, which backs the Khmer Rouge; the United States, which backs Sihanouk while trying to distance itself from the Khmer Rouge; and Thailand, through which arms flow to the rebels. Thailand's deputy prime minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, who helped arrange the talks, held separate meetings with Hun Sen and with Sihanouk's guerrilla factions. Chinese Ambassador Yang Zhenya was seen leaving a corridor where informal talks were held. U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson called on Son Sann, the U.S. Embassy said. Lambertson was in Tokyo for consultations and to observe the Cambodian talks. The less than full success of the meeting seemed certain to disappoint Japan, which was acting as host to its first international peace conference since World War II. The meeting was heralded as a stepping-stone to a conference set for Paris in July. Before the Khmer Rouge boycotted, the conference was expected to be one of the rare instances in which all four contending factions would be present. Sihanouk, 67, had said he intended to sign an agreement with Hun Sen whether the Khmer Rouge came along or not, but he had to stay a rocky course to reach that point. As he left for the signing ceremony with Son Sann, the conservative leader of a guerrilla faction in his coalition, Sihanouk said they had worked hard to move toward peace and reconciliation ``and I am happy to be able to sign.'' Son Sann said he had agreed to the arrangement. The guerrilla coalition is fighting moderate communist Hun Sen's government, which was installed by Vietnam in 1979. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and ended the brutal 1975-79 rule of the Khmer Rouge when hundreds of thousands of Cambodians were killed. Hun Sen has refused to negotiate equally with the Khmer Rouge or allow them an equal role in a future interim government. Vietnam says it withdrew all its troops last September, but there are charges that some remain.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says Woman Used His Drug-Injecting Suicide Device
DOC.TEXT: The inventor of a suicide device says he hooked an Alzheimer's disease victim to the drug-injecting apparatus and watched her die. Dr. Jack Kevorkian said Janet Adkins of Portland, Ore., used the device inside his van in a park about 40 miles north of Detroit on Monday afternoon. She pressed a button to trigger the machine, which injected her with a lethal dose of chemicals. ``The last thing Janet Adkins said was, `You just make my case known,''' said Kevorkian, a retired pathologist. ``We have planned birth, why not planned death?'' he asked. Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said he was aware Adkins had died in his county. He has said in the past that he believes that assisting suicide is a crime under Michigan law; others have interpreted the law differently. ``There is an ongoing investigation and I don't want to discuss it any further,'' Thompson said. State police in Pontiac confirmed the woman's death and said they are investigating. Kevorkian said he notified police after Adkins' death. Kevorkian said the 54-year-old woman, her husband and a friend flew to Michigan because supplying the means to commit suicide is a felony in Oregon. ``She is a remarkable woman,'' Kevorkian said. ``She was a housewife who traveled extensively. She taught English part-time. She played the piano. But the disease took away her ability to read music. She couldn't even spell any more.'' Alzheimer's disease is an irreversible degeneration of the brain cells that can lead to severe memory loss and dementia. ``She told me she wanted to take her life while she was still clear in her mind and knew what she was doing,'' Kervorkian said. She contacted Kevorkian in October, he said. Kevorkian said he persuaded her to try an experimental drug treatment in Seattle in an attempt to put the disease into remission. ``At first, I was not going to let her use the device,'' Kevorkian said. ``But the Seattle treatment didn't work. She told me she had pills and she was going to do it (commit suicide) anyway.'' Neither the husband nor the family friend wanted to be near when the woman committed suicide, so they flew back to Oregon earlier Monday, he said. The device involves hooking a person to an intravenous saline solution. The person can press a button that stops the saline solution and injects the drug thiopental, which causes unconsciousness. Within a minute, potassium chloride is injected automatically, at a dosage high enough to stop the heart and cause death within minutes. Jim Baughman, chief of the Wayne County prosecutor's appellate division, said last fall that helping someone die with the device wouldn't be a crime under Michigan law because the patient, not the doctor, would inject the drugs. Baughman said his opinion was based on a 1982 Michigan Court of Appeals decision in which it overruled a lower court conviction of a man who gave a gun to a friend, knowing the friend was going to commit suicide. ``If you actually take part in the act, that's criminal,'' Baughman said. ``If you provide the means to do it, that's not.''

DOC.HEAD: War Crimes Bill Defeated by House of Lords
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to include reaction, government options, additional quotes; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Dismayed Nazi hunters today denounced defeat in the House of Lords of a government bill that would have allowed prosecutions of suspected war criminals. They said some of ``Hitler's worst henchmen'' live in Britain. The 207-74 vote by the unelected upper chamber to throw out a measure that had been overwhelmingly adopted by the elected House of Commons also set off a constitutional conflict. The vote just after midnight, following nine hours of emotional debate, left Britain the only one of the World War II Allies without laws to prosecute suspected war criminals. Canada and Australia have changed their laws to allow trials, and the United States has deported suspects for trial. The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which submitted a list of suspects to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government in 1986, said it was ``deeply upset.'' ``I think it is unthinkable that this country, which suffered so much at the hands of the Nazis, continues to give a haven to some of Hitler's worst henchmen,'' said Ephraim Zuroff, head of the Israeli section of the Los Angeles-based Wiesenthal Center. Zuroff, in London for the debate, said he will submit more names of British-resident suspects to the government this week. The Lords' action was a rare break with the popularly elected House of Commons. The Lords' powers are limited to delaying bills for a year, and the government now must decide whether to reintroduce the bill in the autumn and force it through the Lords under a rarely used parliamentary rule. Traditionally, the Lords only revise clauses, and never rejects outright legislation passed by the House of Commons. The Commons passed the bill by a 270-60 majority in December. The vote followed an inquiry by a government-appointed commission that said there was enough evidence to prosecute three suspects for murder and investigate another 124. The suspects allegedly helped round up and murder thousands of Jews in Nazi-occupied Soviet republics. ``I am not only dismayed, I am disgusted,'' said Lord Cocks, a member of the opposition Labor Party. ``With all the problems facing this country, the House of Lords has gratuitously stirred up this constitutional issue of the Lords vs. the Commons. It is wrong and unnecessary.'' The Lords, a mostly elderly body of hereditary peers, judges, bishops and politicians given lifetime titles, argued that it was wrong to make retroactive laws, that fair trials would be impossible because of the age of witnesses and that the legislation would lead to ``show trials.'' The archbishops of the Church of England and Methodist leader Lord Soper, who sit in the upper chamber, all voted against prosecutions. Soper said Christian charity meant letting ``bygones be bygones.'' Some Lords cautioned against stirring anti-Semitic prejudice by prosecuting old Nazis. But others said defeating the bill was the wrong message to send to Europe at a time of renewed anti-Semitism. Concentration camp survivor Lord Kagan, 75, rejected arguments that witnesses' memories could be faulty. ``Anybody who was in a concentration camp, he knew his guard's face, he knew every muscle ... it was etched into his mind, into his memory and into his heart,'' said Kagan. Government ministers battled to save the bill from defeat. ``Murder is murder in any language, in any country,'' said Earl Ferrers, a hereditary peer and Home Office minister in Mrs. Thatcher's government. ``Other countries who were faced with the evidence that now confronts us have changed their law,'' he said. ``It would be unfortunate if the United Kingdom with all its international standing for justice and integrity should ... be tainted with the slur of being a haven for criminals.'' The bill was designed to become law by July, partly because of the age of three prime suspects and the age of witnesses. Opponents of the bill included peers whose World War II units were the first British troops to enter the Belsen concentration camp as the Nazis were pushed back in 1945. Legislators in the Commons, most of whom were children or not born during the war, have accepted overwhelmingly a government-appointed commission's recommendation to prosecute suspected war criminals. Britain's chief rabbi, Lord Jakobovits, a refugee from Nazi Germany who was nominated for the Lords by Mrs. Thatcher in 1981, said a no vote would give the ``wrong signal'' amid renewed signs of anti-Semitism in Europe. ``Some opponents of this bill ... are among the staunchest friends of the Jewish people,'' declared Jakobovits, 69. ``But I have got to add that so were some of those who were appeasers of the Nazis in the 1930s.''

DOC.HEAD: Former President Sees Lithuanian Issue as Continuing Irritant
With PM-Gorbachev Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 5, The Soviet Legislature, with Soviet developments.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ford says he believes President Bush is being firm enough with Mikhail Gorbachev about Lithuania for now, but he predicts the issue will continue to complicate U.S.-Soviet relations. In an appearance Monday at the National Press Club, Ford also said he believed Bush and the Soviet president established a warm and useful relationship during their summit in Washington, which ended Sunday. Before the summit, Bush said he would ask Congress to approve a liberalized trade agreement with the Soviets only if Moscow dropped restrictions on emigration and ended its partial economic blockade of Lithuania. After meeting with Gorbachev, however, he announced such an agreement and said it was linked only to emigration. He made no mention of the embargo on Lithuania, which Gorbachev imposed in retaliation for the Soviet republic's declaration of independence. The Soviet legislature today postponed until at least September adoption of a new emigration law that the United States says must be passed before Washington will give Moscow preferential trade status. Ford was asked whether he would have dealt more firmly with Gorbachev on the Lithuanian question. The former president said he had great admiration for the people of Lithuania and the other Baltic republics, noting that about 10,000 Latvians emigrated after World War II to the Michigan congressional district that he represented before becoming vice president and then president. ``So I start out with a sympathy for their desire to regain their independence,'' Ford said. ``At the same time, we have to have a reasonable and balanced approach in the overall global context of what this issue might be. So for the time at least I am going to take the point of view that President Bush is handling it properly.'' He said members of Congress ``very likely'' would try to block the trade agreement, but he did not know whether they would succeed. ``The problem of the Baltic nations is going to be a very difficult one for Mr. Gorbachev to solve, and it will be a continuing problem between the government of the United States and the Soviet Union,'' Ford said.

DOC.HEAD: Covenant House Cuts Budget, Makes Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Covenant House program for runaway youths has reduced its budget and laid off 111 employees in anticipation of a loss of income because of the controversy surrounding its founder. The Rev. Bruce Ritter resigned earlier this year amid allegations he had sexual relations with shelter residents and lent charity funds to two former board members. He has denied wrongdoing. ``We haven't had a severe drop-off in funding yet, but we're monitoring the money situation closely,'' George Wirt, a Covenant spokesman, said Monday. Private donations have fallen and risen ``like a roller coaster'' since the controversy erupted late last year, according to Wirt. The Covenant House corporate board cut its budget for the next fiscal year, beginning July 1, to $72 million from $86 million last year, according to Wirt. The organization also plans to shut down two centers in Manhattan and consolidate them at its main shelter, Wirt said. In addition to the 111 layoffs out of the staff of 420, 64 vacancies will not be filled in New York, he said. Covenant House provides shelter for 25,000 youths in the United States, Canada and Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Tornado-Ravaged Indiana Counties Federal Disaster Areas
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Jeff Jarrett, whose church's pews are stacked with clothes for tornado victims, was relieved to hear that federal disaster money was coming to Petersburg. ``That's great news,'' Jarrett said after President Bush declared a federal disaster area Monday in 19 southern Indiana counties hit by flooding, tornadoes or both. The Petersburg Church of Christ was a clearinghouse for clothing, blankets and batteries Monday night. At least half of the homes were still without power, and temperatures dipped into the 40s. ``I would say right now as far as their financial needs, they're just beginning to find out,'' Jarrett said. ``Most of them feel lucky just to be digging out their possessions.'' The American Red Cross said 384 Petersburg homes were damaged or destroyed by tornadoes Saturday night. Six people in the area were killed. The disaster designation makes residents eligible for low-interest loans and other federal assistance. In addition, the Red Cross planned to begin distributing vouchers today for food, clothing, shelter and medical expenses. ``Sometimes the problem is convincing people to take the money,'' Red Cross spokesman Steve Small said. ``They're not going on the dole; it's a gift from the American people to the American people when they need it.'' The tornadoes, which killed eight people, hit Petersburg and Bedford in southern Indiana the hardest. Two more people in Indiana died Sunday in a second wave of storms that spawned one tornado. The weekend storms also were blamed for two deaths in Wisconsin and one each in Illinois and Missouri. Tornadoes also were reported in Minnesota, Kentucky and Michigan. Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh said at a news conference Monday that the ``magnitude of this disaster is almost impossible to comprehend,'' adding that there was hundreds of millions of dollars of damage. ``My message today to the citizens of our state is we have suffered some severe damage, we mourn our losses, but we're not ready to give up,'' Bayh said. Residents and business owners may be eligible for temporary housing, up to $10,500 in grants, low-cost loans to cover uninsured property losses and other programs. State and local governments may be eligible for money to repair or replace damaged public facilities. The American Red Cross estimated that more than 800 homes were damaged in Indiana, including 240 that were destroyed. In Petersburg alone, 114 homes were destroyed and 270 sustained damage. In Kentucky, 47 homes were damaged and a spokesman for the state Department of Disaster and Emergency Services said storm destruction could total as much as $5 million statewide. In Ohio, at least 1,600 homes and businesses in three southwestern counties were damaged. All of Petersburg's 3,000 residents were without water Monday. About 5,000 homes and business in Petersburg and Bedford, which also was heavily damaged, were still without electric service Monday, said Pamela K. Chapman, a spokeswoman for PSI Energy. She said power would be restored to most areas by today. For the third consecutive week, Petersburg residents were urged to boil all drinking water once service was restored. The city lost its fresh water supply two weeks ago when floodwater broke the main water line. Meanwhile, Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson got a firsthand view of some of the storm devastation in his state. On Monday, he flew over over two of the 10 counties he had declared disaster areas and said: ``Since it was declared a state disaster area, that will make it easier to become a federal disaster area, and that will make federal money more available.''

DOC.HEAD: Father Says He Wishes He Had Sought Medical Advice for Ailing Son
DOC.TEXT: A Christian Scientist on trial for his son's death testified that he now wishes he had sought medical help for the ailing 2{-year-old. David and Ginger Twitchell are accused of recklessly causing the boy's death because they treated him with prayer, instead of conventional medicine. Robyn died from a bowel obstruction in April 1986. ``If medical science could have saved my son, I wish I had turned to it,'' Twitchell said Monday during his trial for manslaughter. Twitchell said that after hearing the previous weeks' testimony, he now wishes he had sought medical care for Robyn. The couple has said they rely on spiritual healing to cure physical ailments according to Christian Science principles. Defense attorneys have sought to show that Robyn's symptoms resembled the flu. An autopsy showed the boy had a birth defect that caused the obstruction. Prosecutor John Kiernan asked Twitchell about his assertion during a network television broadcast two years ago that he still did not wish he had called for medical treatment for his son's condition. Twitchell said his conversations with medical professionals at that time did not convince him that medicine could have saved his son. But now, he indicated, he is of a different mind. ``My present state of mind is that if they had diagnosed it properly, if we had gone to them early enough, if there were not complications, they could have saved him,'' he testified. Today, if prayer did not seem to be working in a similar circumstance, ``I would give medical science a chance to try their hand,'' he said. Kiernan repeatedly questioned Twitchell about dental work he had done. He indicated that Twitchell relied on medication by accepting a painkiller during the procedure, but denied similar relief to ``his little child.'' ``I did not refuse to provide it to him but I did not provide it to him,'' Twitchell responded. He acknowledged that his reliance on a dentist was a failure of spiritual healing and that ``Robyn's death was a failure of spiritual healing.'' Officials from the Christian Science Church, which is based in Boston, contend the state of Massachusetts has put the religion itself on trial. Prosecutors have denied that they are attacking the Christian Science religion, but say they are trying to protect children from parents who put their children at risk by relying solely on spiritual healing.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Jack Gilford Remembered for His Love of Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT age to 81.
DOC.TEXT: Jack Gilford, who scratched his way back from a blacklisted decade during the McCarthy era with commercials for Crackerjack and potato chips, was remembered by friends as an unselfish actor who loved to work. Gilford, whose 55-year career spanned vaudeville, Broadway, television and movies, died Monday of stomach cancer at age 81. ``Jack Gilford was one of the most talented and dear actors that I ever had the good fortune to work with,'' Jack Lemmon said. ``More importantly, though, he had an innate sense of grace, style and selflessness that was unflappable,'' he said. Gilford died at his Manhattan home, said Merle Debuskey, a family friend and publicist. Gilford's wife of 41 years, actress-writer Madeline Lee, was with him. To Gilford, work was everything. ``What else is there?'' he once said. ``My creed is this _ if you can find something better than being wanted, call me any time of the day or night, call me collect and tell me what it is. Because whatever it is, it's very important.'' Gilford's droopy face and distinctive, raspy voice were known to generations. He had worked recently on television, sweeping salty-tongued Sophia of the ``Golden Girls'' off her feet. To stage aficionados, Gilford was Hysterium, the slave who ends up in drag in ``A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' or Herr Shultz in ``Cabaret.'' He collected Tony nominations for both roles. Television buffs may remember Gilford's dramatic appearance on the 1960s series ``The Defenders,'' in which he played a man who shoots a policeman, or as the pitchman in commercials for Crackerjack and Lays potato chips. Gilford's work for Crackerjack earned him a Clio award and a winged statuette, courtesy of the Cannes Film Festival. The commercials also helped Gilford rebuild his career after work in front of cameras dried up during the McCarthy era. Gilford, like other show-business people on the political left, was blacklisted for a decade. ``One day the phone just stopped ringing and I didn't do TV or films for 10 years,'' Gilford said. His wife and Zero Mostel, his best friend who starred in ``Forum,'' also were blacklisted. ``It was a hard time and I don't like much to talk about it now,'' Gilford once said, adding, ``I'm not ashamed of my feelings at that time.'' Gilford's death ``saddens me greatly,'' said actor Michael Crawford, who also appeared in ``Forum.'' ``It was a wonderful experience to watch him work with Zero. He was a wonderful artist,'' Crawford said. Gilford was the quintessential garment manufacturer in the 1970s movie ``Save the Tiger,'' which earned him an Academy Award nomination for supporting actor. Lemmon starred in the film. Movie audiences also knew Gilford as the oldster who decided against being rejuvenated by aliens in ``Cocoon'' and ``Cocoon II.'' Born Jacob Gellman and raised in Brooklyn, Gilford liked to tell people his career was financed by his mother's illegal liquor-making. ``She was the only woman in our part of Williamsburg who was arrested three times for bootlegging,'' he said in a 1987 newspaper interview. She urged him to quit his job in a cosmetics store and audition at amateur nights. Soon he was plucked from obscurity by Milton Berle. Gilford played second banana to the future Uncle Miltie for 2{ years before moving on.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die When Flagpole Touches Power Line
DOC.TEXT: The town's president, two of his sons, and a councilman were electrocuted when a flagpole they were taking down touched a high-voltage line, state police said. The men were removing the flagpole Monday night for painting and repairs when it touched a 7,200-volt power line. The pole was outside the community center in this mountain town of 350 people, 75 miles south of Pittsburgh. Screams from the mother of one victim drew Kathy Lawson to the scene. ``They were still on fire and I held onto his mother to keep her back,'' Lawson said. ``The whole town was running over to them, but nobody could get to them because the pole was right over them and electricity was still running through it.'' An emergency crew eventually shut off the power. Killed were Borough President Robert Friend, 59; his sons Randall Friend, 23, and Robert Friend II, 22; and Councilman Keith Coppett, 35, said Trooper Richard Veil of the Uniontown barracks. Another of Friend's sons, Doug, 27, was injured. He was treated at Uniontown Hospital and released, nursing supervisor Tammy Swoger said today. A sixth man who was helping take down the flagpole was not injured, Veil said. State police identified the victims using reports from witnesses. Fayette County Deputy Coroner Margie Riley said identifications would be made through dental records because the bodies were so badly burned.

DOC.HEAD: South Koreans See Turning Point in Roh-Gorbachev Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more protests, foreign ministers to discuss ties; EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev-Roh, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The first meeting between a South Korean and Soviet leader accelerated efforts toward full diplomatic ties and was greeted in South Korea today as a turning point in the nation's foreign relations. President Roh Tae-woo said that as a result of Monday's meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in San Francisco, ``normal bilateral relations between our countries will be restored'' after 45 years. No dates were announced for establishing diplomatic relations, but a Roh aide said it could be expected in the ``not-distant future.'' The South Korean newspaper Dong-a Ilbo said Roh agreed to send Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong to Moscow by July. It quoted high-ranking officials as saying full diplomatic ties could be established by September. ``We are convinced that the summit meeting has not only been a turning point in relations between the two countries, but has also been an epoch-making event which will see an end to the Cold War legacy on the Korean peninsula and will pave the way for a peaceful reunification between South and North Korea,'' said Lee Soo-jung, a government spokesman traveling with Roh. Lee's statement was released in Seoul today. Roh's announcement was welcomed by most South Koreans, who want to see an easing of hostilities with Communist North Korea. The Koreas were divided in 1945, fought a bloody civil war in the early 1950s and remain bitter enemies. North Korea is a long-time ally of the Soviet Union. But not all South Koreans welcomed the improvement in Seoul-Moscow ties. Scattered violent protests erupted at several campuses, where radical students denounced Roh's diplomatic overtures to Communist nations. In southern Kwangju, about 2,000 militant students yelling anti-government slogans fought riot police with firebombs and rocks, said Yonhap, the national news agency. In Seoul, several hundred students throwing firebombs and rocks clashed with police firing tear gas outside Korea University and Hankuk University of Foreign Studies. Wall posters at two schools denounced the talks and warned Moscow ``your diplomats arriving in Seoul will be driven out by the Korean people.'' Radical students say Roh wants to establish relations with Moscow to delay unification of the peninsula. They say Moscow's recognition of the Seoul government will perpetuate the division. In a statement issued today, a major alliance of dissident groups said Roh's diplomacy was subservient to the superpowers. Afternoon newspapers devoted their entire front sections to the talks. Both KBS and its rival Munwha Broadcasting Co. devoted five hours of live satellite and local coverage to Roh's visit in San Francisco. Roh has been pursuing a policy of establishing ties with current and former Communist countries to isolate North Korea. South Korea now has relations with all countries in East Europe except Albania and East Germany. The government says it is working toward ties with China and East Germany. South Korea also hopes diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union and China, the two largest Communist nations, will enhance its international prestige and gain acceptance for Seoul as an Asian and world power. South Korea, the 10th-largest trading country in the world, also hopes to expand economic and trade relations with Moscow. But some South Koreans expressed disappointment that the talks apparently did not result in concrete agreements on pursuing peace on the divided Korean peninsula or a timetable for normalizing relations with Moscow. The Party for Peace and Democracy, the main opposition party, welcomed the prospect of normalizing Soviet-South Korean relations, but criticized Roh for taking a low profile during the talks. ``The fact that the two met face to face is very important to us,'' said Dr. Rhee Sang-woo, a government adviser and dean at Seoul's Sogang University. ``Regardless of the subjects discussed, the fact they met is most important.'' North Korea has criticized the Roh-Gorbachev meeting. The border between the Communist North and capitalist South is the most heavily fortified in the world. More than 1 million armed soldiers are on either side behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire. Dissidents have called for independent talks between the Koreas, saying both the Soviet Union and the United States were responsible for the division of the peninsula at the end of World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Conference Opens
DOC.TEXT: A summit of 35 East and West bloc nations will be held in Paris in December to discuss ``the reconciliation of Europe,'' French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said today. The summit proposal was the first item of business at a human rights meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, esablished by the 1975 Helsinki accords. A preparatory committee will meet in Vienna July 10 to set the agenda for the summit, which Dumas suggested for Dec. 19-21. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze reported on the results of the weekend U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington and announced that the Soviet Union would cut its short-range nuclear arsenal in central Europe by year's end. U.S. Secretary of State James Baker was to address the meeting Wednesday. Albania was granted observer status at the four-week human rights talks. The hard-line Communist country has begun to seek greater contacts following years of isolation. Lithuania, which also had sought permission to attend the meeting, ``was politely turned down,'' said a statement from the Lithuanian World Community. Max Kampelman, head of the U.S. delegation, said the group would consider establishing a body to mediate disputes involving ethnic minorities. ``As the East-West conflict reduces in importance and confrontations, we are seeing some of the old pre-World War II tensions developing again,'' Kampelman said in an interview. ``One of the subjects we will discuss is whether the CSCE process can provide some mediation role here,'' he said. Kampelman, a veteran diplomat and arms negotiator, said one such conflict could be the alleged discrimination by ethnic Hungarians living in Romania. They say they are unable to develop their own culture. ``Frankly, there is no other mechanism'' to deal with minority questions, he said. ``We're going to see if we can evolve one.'' The 15-year-old international organization has no enforcement power, and its mediation in any dispute could by applied only voluntarily, he said. Kampelman said he expected the Copenhagen meeting to endorse the principles of free elections and rule of law, meaning ``that those who govern also are subject to the law and not arbitrariness.'' The Conference on Security and Cooperation is comprised of the United States, Canada and all European countries except Albania, which now wants to join. It was established by the Helsinki accords, which eased security tensions and set standards for cooperation and human rights. The Copenhagen conference was the second of three planned on human rights. The first, in Paris last June, failed to approve a final document because of Romanian opposition. The third is scheduled for Moscow next year.

DOC.HEAD: President Seen Banning New Drilling Off California, Florida
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Fitzwater saying announcement not expected this week; picks up 4th graf pvs, The dates ...
DOC.TEXT: cicomment

President Bush is likely to block new offshore oil activity along the California and Florida coasts while calling for environmental impact studies, administration officials say. The long-pending decision would ease Republican election-year concerns in the environmentally conscious states if Bush's decision follows the officials' expectations. However, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said today that Bush ``has not decided this issue yet'' and he ruled out the possibility of an announcement this week. The option Bush is said to be leaning to would bar new drilling off Florida until the year 2002, off Northern California until 1997 and off Southern California until at least 1992, according to officials who spoke Monday on condition of anonymity. The dates reflect the years when the government's five-year leasing plans are up for review. The current one expires in 1992. The officials cautioned that the president still could change his apparent course and open the way for some drilling, but they said that appeared unlikely. A task force Bush appointed last year to study effects of potential drilling in the three areas concluded that there was not enough information to go ahead with the new offshore activity. The Florida congressional delegation has unanimously urged Bush to bar offshore drilling, as has Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who is seeking re-election to a second term. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, seeking the governorship of California, wants a total ban on new oil activity along the coast and opposed the Reagan administration's efforts to expand leasing areas. A postponement would fall short of the decision sought by environmentalists, who contend there have been enough studies to show the environmental harm and warrant a permanent ban in both states. ``The public has moved far beyond where delays are going to satisfy people. It's time to move to protect some of these areas permanently,'' said Lisa Speer, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. The broadest set of options initially drawn by the president's staff ranged from opening the study areas for leasing and drilling to permanently banning such activity. Bush has expressed the most interest in options involving postponement of new oil activity pending new studies and more specific options were developed accordingly, the officials said. The president named a task force last year, headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, to work with the National Academy of Sciences in studying the environmental impact of opening the three areas to oil leasing. The regions under consideration are: a 6.7-million acre section of ocean off Southern California, 1.2 million acres off Northern California and 13 million acres in the Gulf of Mexico near the Florida Everglades. A policy initiated by former President Reagan's interior secretary, James Watt, opened the entire 1.4-billion-acre Outer Continental Shelf. But leasing has been blocked over the years by congressionally imposed moratoriums. In Florida, the government sold 73 leases in the affected area in the early 1980s for $108 million. The cost of buying the leases back could be closer to $200 million, Interior Department officials say. Southern California is the only region of the country other than the Gulf of Mexico where offshore oil development is under way; 22 oil platforms are operating. The Interior Department's current five-year program had anticipated new lease sales last September, but they were put off pending Bush's decision. The northern California leases, about 90 miles north of San Francisco and off Eureka, had been scheduled for sale early last year, but the sale was postponed.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Duel in California Highlights Nine-State Lineup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf to UPDATE with quote from NC race; SUBS 18th graf to show no South Dakota Democratic primary
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein and John Van de Kamp sweat out the voters' verdict today in California's Democratic gubernatorial primary, the featured contest on a nine-state election day that stretched from New Jersey to New Mexico. North Carolina's Democrats were picking an opponent to face conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms in the fall. The choice in a runoff primary was between prosecutor Mike Easley and former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt, bidding to become the first black nominated for statewide office in his state. ``I'm ready to get into this fight'' with Helms, Gantt said as he cast his own ballot today. ``I'm ready to get it on with him.'' In all, five states had primaries for governor on the ballot. The tally of Senate races ran to eight states. Dozens of members of Congress sought nomination for new term, and waited to learn the names of their opponents for the November election. In one statewide referendum of note, Californians were deciding whether to accept a doubling in the statewide gasoline tax, from nine cents a gallon to 18 cents over five years. The first year's increase would be a nickel. Seven incumbent senators were on the ballot, facing token opposition at most. They included Democrats Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Howell Heflin of Alabama, Max Baucus of Montana and Tom Harkin of Iowa; and Republicans Thad Cochran of Mississippi, Pete Domenici of New Mexico and Larry Pressler of South Dakota. Helms already has secured the GOP nomination in North Carolina. Cochran was assured of a new term, since no Democrat filed candidate's papers for the primary. The statehouse races were in Iowa, New Mexico, South Dakota, Alabama and California, where Republican Gov. George Deukmejian is retiring after two terms. GOP Sen. Pete Wilson and his $3.5 million war chest awaited the winner of the contest between Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor, and Van de Kamp, California's attorney general. The Democratic race was nothing if not expensive, as both Feinstein and Van de Kamp raised more than $6 million for their candidacies. Both candidates underscored their support for abortion rights in the final hours of their campaign. Feinstein campaigned to the end as tough on crime, trying to seize an issue that seemed more likely to belong to her opponent, the attorney general. She ran a late-campaign commercial on television criticizing Van de Kamp for declining to prosecute a suspect in the Hillside Strangler case in which 10 people were killed. Van de Kamp was the Los Angeles district attorney at the time, and the suspect, Angelo Buono, was later convicted of murder after the state attorney general stepped into the case. Van de Kamp called the criticism ``baloney.'' New Mexico had four-way races in both gubernatorial primaries. Republican Govs. Guy Hunt of Alabama, George Mickelson of South Dakota and Terry Branstad of Iowa were seeking new terms. Iowa's Democratic primary race was being watched for any significance on the national debate over abortion. Democrats there chose among three contenders _ abortion-rights supporters Don Avenson and John Chrystal and a third contender who opposes abortion, state Attorney General Tom Miller. California's statehouse race was the one drawing the most national attention. The state is expected to gain at least five seats in the congressional redistricting based on the 1990 census. Republicans are hopeful that Wilson can gain the governor's chair, and give them a check against the heavily Democratic legislature when it comes time to draw legislative district boundaries. The race for the Democratic nomination for governor of Alabama was headed for a runoff, with none of the five contenders likely to get the 50 percent needed to win outright in the first round. The top two finishers would be on the ballot for a runoff June 26 to decide the challenger to Republican Gov. Guy Hunt. In the Senate contests, Republican Rep. Tom Tauke was on the Iowa primary ballot to take on Harkin in the fall in what is expected to be one of the nation's hottest races. Alabama's Heflin and South Dakota's Pressler also are under challenge from potentially strong opponents. Heflin's foe in November will be Republican Bill Cabannis and Pressler will come up against Democrat Ted Muenster. In the North Carolina Senate race, Helms is running commercials attacking both Democrats on the runoff primary ballot. Gantt led a six-candidate field in the May 8 primary but failed to reach the 40 percent needed to avoid a runoff. Only one House incumbent has been defeated for renomination this year, Republican Donald ``Buz'' Lukens of Ohio. He was convicted of contributing to the unruliness of a minor after being accused of having sex with her. A few other House members have had closer-than-expected primary races, though, and such races are closely watched for signs of voter dissatisfaction over a large congressional pay raise approved late last year. In one House race, former professional football player Phil McConkey in New Jersey is running for a House seat as an anti-abortion Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Puts Off Emigration Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to include interpretations of action. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature today tentatively postponed until September adoption of a new emigration law that Washington says is necessary before it will give Moscow preferential trade status. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush signed a trade agreement at the Washington summit, but Bush said he won't press the U.S. Congress to grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trading status until the emigration legislation is passed. Soviet restrictions on emigration have for decades been a major impediment to improved U.S.-Soviet relations. Millions of dollars of trade and the fate of Soviets hoping to emigrate are riding on approval of the law. The Soviet legislature, by acclamation, adopted a new agenda that dropped consideration of the emigration law before the body adjourns June 14 for the summer. Fyodor Burlatsky, a member of the legislature's International Affairs committee, had said in a television interview recently the law would be considered May 31. The decision drew immediate criticism from lawmakers who said it opened the Soviet Union to accusations of duplicity. ``We will turn out to be cheats. We won't be trusted. They will say, `Well, they made a promise and again the Soviet Union is deceiving,''' Nikolai Medvedev, a Supreme Soviet member from Lithuania, told the session. In response, Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov held out the possibility that the decision would be reviewed and the law taken up earlier. ``The president will arrive. We will look it over and if there is a possibility, we will include this issue. We will look it over with the president,'' Lukyanov said. It was not clear whether the postponement was made with Gorbachev's approval, whether it was a mistake, or whether other Kremlin leaders engineered the decision. It could be an embarrassment to Gorbachev, who was returning from the summit today. Lukyanov is a close ally of Gorbachev, carrying out the leader's will in the legislature, and he did not explain why he allowed what appeared to be such a radical shift so soon after the Soviet commitment in Washington to enact the legislation. Medvedev said Soviet officials had promised U.S. senators during the just-completed summit that the new emigration bill would be approved during the current Supreme Soviet session. The proposed legislation, which was given preliminary approval in November, would allow emigration of virtually anyone who has entry permission from another country and no outstanding alimony obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Leaders Say Gorbachev Must Lighten Up on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-10, Presidential spokesman, with Fitzwater quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders told President Bush today that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev must lighten up on Lithuania if he expects Congress to go along with trade benefits to Moscow. ``Call it linkage or call it reality,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said after Bush briefed top House and Senate leaders on his private conversations with Gorbachev during the summit. Lawmakers said Bush told them he had received no assurances from Gorbachev, even in private, that the Soviet Union would lift its economic boycott of the rebellious Baltic state. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Bush ``made it very clear'' that he had presented a strong case to Gorbachev for easing up in Lithuania. ``When the president sends us the trade agreement ... there will be many in Congress who will want to see some progress on Lithuania before approving it,'' Foley said. ``I asked the president if he thought President Gorbachev understood there might be such reaction from Congress; he said he did.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that, despite the lack of a commitment from Gorbachev on Lithuania, ``the president is persuaded that he (Gorbachev) wants to resolve the issue.'' At the same time, the president is mindful of congressional sentiment against granting the benefits to Moscow in absence of progress on Lithuania. ``The only linkage is on the emigration reform law, but we will never dismiss our concerns about Lithuania,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Fitzwater said that Bush continued the process of conferring with allied leaders that he began on Sunday, calling Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu Monday night and French President Francois Mitterrand this morning. The spokesman said Gorbachev's aircraft, as it cleared U.S. air space at 1:39 a.m. EDT today, beamed a message to the White House hailing the fruits of the summit and relaying the Soviet leader's ``sincere gratitude.'' ``I'm not going to assess whether his pressing (Gorbachev) was adequate or not,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``He said he made the case.'' But, the Senate leader said, nothing the president said made him feel any more optimistic that a Lithuanian settlement was near. Dole said Bush told lawmakers at the 45-minute session that ``he felt comfortable with Gorbachev, that they could speak with complete candor and without rancor.'' After a strong lobbying campaign from Gorbachev, Bush signed a trade agreement with the Soviet leader last Friday without a return commitment on Lithuania. However, Bush said he would not send the agreement _ which would open the way for granting Moscow most-favored-nation trade status _ to Congress until the Soviet legislature passes a liberalized emigration law. The Soviet legislature today postponed until at least September adoption of such a law. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., who flew to California with Gorbachev on Sunday, said he had a chance to have a ``relaxed, intimate'' conversation with the Soviet leader on Lithuania and other subjects. He said he told Gorbachev that use of violence to block Lithuanian independence would wreck Moscow's chances of getting most-favored-nation trade status. It could also torpedo hopes of getting a long-range nuclear weapons treaty this year, Cranston said he told Gorbachev. ``He indicated very clearly that (violence in Lithuania) is not going to occur,'' Cranston said. ``I thought that was reassuring.'' In addition to congressional skepticism over the Soviet trade pact, the administration also faces broad opposition for Bush's recent decision renewing trade benefits to China. China flared as an issue before lawmakers left the capital on May 24 for the Memorial Day holiday. Bush announced then that he would extend for one year the most-favored-nation trade status that grants China lower tariffs on goods exported to the United States. Mitchell, who opposes the trade benefits because of China's human rights practices, said he would meet with other lawmakers this week to map out a course to try to reverse Bush's decision. In the legislative arena, meanwhile, the Senate is taking up a wide-ranging crime-fighting bill. More than 250 amendments were stacked up when Congress recessed, and the Democratic leadership will seek a vote to curtail debate. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, urged his colleagues to curb the debate, saying ``this legislation should not be killed by delay.'' Amid this jockeying, former White House Press Secretary James Brady, felled by John Hinckley Jr.'s March 1981 assault on President Reagan and now a gun-control lobbyist, announced a ``Brady Bill Blitz.'' Brady's campaign seeks support for a provision requiring a seven-day cooling-off period for the purchase of handguns. The provision is designed to give police more time to conduct a record check of would-be handgun buyers. House members were expected by Wednesday to try to override Bush's veto of a bill authorizing $2 billion for Amtrak. The president objected to one provision in that measure that would expand federal oversight of railroad acquisitions in a way he said would be ``a step backward for the entire rail industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Redistricting Decision Hailed as End of Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6-7th grafs, `For 115...', to add that ACLU, Justice Department were plaintiffs. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Representatives of...'.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that top elected officials in the nation's most populous county systematically discriminated against Hispanic voters to protect their own positions in office. The plaintiffs called Monday's ruling a landmark civil rights decision that will end more than a century of white domination of politics in the county of 8.7 million people. An estimated 35 percent are Hispanic, but no member of any minority group has been elected to the Board of Supervisors since 1875. The ruling by U.S. District Judge David Kenyon charged that Los Angeles County's five-member board conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and that of their allies'' when they redrew the county's five voting districts in 1981. The judge said the redistricting violated the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act and the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment to the Constitution. The decision immediately throws the results of today's balloting in two supervisorial districts into question. Plaintiffs urged that the results be thrown out, and Kenyon said he would hold a hearing Thursday to determine how the election results should be handled. ``For 115 years, the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors has been an exclusive male, all-white club,'' said Marc Rosenbaum, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Southern California, which was one of the plaintiffs. ``Today that club membership is open to everyone.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh called the ruling a ``victory against discrimination.'' The Justice Department had joined in the suit. Representatives of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, another plaintiff, said they would demand that county officials immediately redraw boundaries and create a largely Hispanic district. ``We want a remedy now. We want a remedy that encompasses a fair opportunity for our community to represent itself and to elect representatives who will represent its interests,'' said Antonia Hernandez, president and general counsel for the legal fund. Disputing the county's claims that creating a Hispanic-majority district was impossible, Kenyon found that the Hispanic community was ``large and geographically compact such that a five-district plan can be drawn in which Hispanics comprise a majority of the citizen voting-age population in one of the five districts.'' Kenyon also recommended expansion of the board, saying the districts are too large for one person to represent constituents adequately. Supervisor Kenneth Hahn said he will introduce a motion at Tuesday's meeting to expand the board to seven members. Such proposals have been introduced before and would be subject to voter approval. Pete Schabarum, a supervisor who decided not to seek reelection, said the timing of Kenyon's ruling confused elections. ``I continue to believe that district lines should not be based on ethnic factors,'' he added. Supervisor Michael Antonovich predicted the county would appeal. County Counsel DeWitt Clinton would not comment on that possibility. The lawsuit, filed in August 1988, charged that the supervisors deliberately spread the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they redrew voting boundaries following the 1980 federal census. ``The explosive and continuous growth of the Los Angeles County Hispanic community was evident at the time of the adoption of the 1981 redistricting plan, as was the steady decline of the county's non-Hispanic white population,'' Kenyon wrote. The judge also concluded that Hispanics and non-Hispanics are widely polarized when it comes to voting trends. Hispanics vote in large numbers for fellow Hispanics, he said, and non-Hispanics rarely vote for Hispanics. Attorneys for both sides have said they believe the judge will allow the supervisors to redraw district boundaries, which he could accept or reject.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Warships Arrive off Liberia as Rebels Close in
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to update with church leaders to mediate, rebels overrunning plantation; EDITS to trim. no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government said today its forces still held the country's main international airport, but diplomats said rebels had overrun an American-managed rubber plantation on its outskirts. The government acknowledged that airlines had halted flights to Robertsfield International Airport, 35 miles from Monrovia, the capital. Fearful residents fled the city and some government soldiers abandoned key posts before the rebel advance. Off the West African nation's coast, a U.S. Navy flotilla carrying 2,000 Marines stood ready to evacuate Americans and other foreigners. President Samuel Doe remained at his presidential mansion in Monrovia, shielded by about 1,000 Israeli-trained troops. Doe continued last-ditch efforts to end the 6-month-old civil war, meeting with church leaders who have offered to act as intermediaries. The Liberian president begged the United States and other friendly countries ``to come to the aid of the Liberian people.'' ``It is the wishes of the people of this country that America can do something to stop the bloodshed,'' he said Monday. In Monrovia, people of the Mandingo and Krahn tribes loyal to Doe _ himself a Krahn _ packed their belongings to flee the city. They said they feared reprisals by rebels, who appeared to be closing in on the city of about 400,000 residents. A U.S. State Department spokeswoman said 71 Americans, including 33 U.S. Embassy officials and their families, were evacuated Monday on a chartered flight. The spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler, said in Washington that about 70 U.S. officials and 1,200 private American citizens remained in Liberia. Today, diplomatic sources said rebels lobbed mortars and fired machine guns as they poured into the American-managed rubber plantation from across the Farmington River, the last natural barrier between the rebels and Monrovia. The Bridgestone@Firestone Inc. rubber plantation adjoins Robertsfield airport, diplomats said. About 15 or 20 government soldiers remaining in the area returned rebel gunfire and then fled toward the capital, sources said. Expatriates living in the area said there was a lot of shelling and shooting between the plantation's riverside marina and the Robertsfield Hotel, a three-minute walk from the airport. Although rebels were believed in the hotel, they made no effort to capture the airport by midday today. They also occupied the management offices of Harbel, the town owned by and operated by Bridgestone@Firestone, a subsidiary of the Japanese company Bridgestone Corp. Rebels surrounded the plantation's factory late Monday, stopping production, sources said. Trevor Hoskins, Bridgestone@Firestone's executive director of public relations, said in Ohio that he talked Monday with the plantation's managing director, ``who indicated ... everything was quiet.'' Hoskins said the plantation, which produces 100 million pounds of rubber a year, covers 120,000 acres and includes 8,500 employees and about 90,000 residents, mostly dependents. About 10,000 Liberians reportedly also moved onto plantation land seeking refuge from the fighting. Family members of the plantation's 30 foreign staffers were evacuated two to three weeks ago. Rebels now control every major industrial concern in Liberia with the possible exception of Bong Iron Ore Mine, which has been cut off from the capital for days and is believed behind rebel lines. Airlines suspended flights to Robertsfield on Monday, effectively closing the airport, after government troops fired on some of their own men, believing them to be rebels. Diplomats and other sources who monitor military radio said that after the shooting incident the government soldiers deserted the checkpoint at Owensgrove, seven miles from the airport. Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar, Doe's military commander, admitted to reporters that soldiers have been deserting their posts. ``The firing starts and they run away. They have to learn to stop panicking,'' he said. Dubar said Monday that he hoped U.S. Marines would save Monrovia from the rebel incursion. The U.S. State Department has accused rebel leader Charles Taylor of receiving support from the radical North African nation of Libya, but it also has said Marines will not intervene in support of Doe's government. The rebels belong mostly to Liberia's Gio and Mano tribes and invaded this nation of 2.5 million people from neighboring Ivory Coast in December. About 2,000 Gios and Manos overflowed the compound of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Monrovia on Monday, where they were put under protection of the International Committee of the Red Cross. The rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia has demanded Doe's ouster, accusing his administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor was a close aide of Doe who headed the government agency responsible for disbursing public funds. He fled the country after Doe accused him of stealing $1 million from state coffers. Liberia, founded in 1822 by descendants of freed U.S. slaves, in 1847 became the first independent country in black Africa.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev
Bush Gets Thank-You Message from Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: President Bush got a thank-you message this morning from his recent guest, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, expressing ``deep satisfaction'' with the results of his summit visit. At 1:39 a.m. EDT, a telephone message was received in the White House situation room, the 24-hour basement communications center, from Gorbachev's aircraft. The message reported he was leaving U.S. airspace after departing from San Francisco. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater read the message to reporters. ``Having completed my stay in your great country, once again I wish to express my deep satisfaction with the results of my visit,'' Gorbachev said. ``The work we have done together during these days will bear good fruit. I would like to express to you and to all Americans my sincere gratitude for the respect shown to the Soviet people and for your hospitality and warm reception.''

DOC.SECOND: PM-New Jersey Schools, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0536,0855
DOC.HEAD: N.J. Supreme Court Declares Public School Financing Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with further details of ruling, quotes, reax from governor's spokeswoman, background. Picks up 13th graf pvs: `The governor ...'
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey's Supreme Court today declared the state's 15-year-old system of financing public schools unconstitutional because it hurts poorer, urban school districts. In the unanimous ruling, the court said the system left such districts without the money and resources they need to give their children the education that the state Constitution requires. ``The dilemma is that while we spend so much, there is absolutely no question that we are failing to provide students in the poorer urban districts with the kind of education that anyone can call thorough and efficient,'' said the ruling, which was written by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz. The justices ordered lawmakers to begin fixing the problem by the 1991-92 school year. They said the state must assure that disadvantaged districts spend about the same amount of money on each child that is spent in richer, suburban districts. The court estimated it would have added about $440 million to the $3.5 billion the state spent this year on public school aid to boost funding in poor districts to the required levels. It said more money is particularly needed to meet the special education needs and address the ``extreme disadvantages'' of schoolchildren in poor communities. The court said it is not ordering equalized financing statewide. Richer districts may choose to spend more on education, but the state would be required to increase its aid to poorer districts if the education in those school systems continues to be lacking. Lawmakers may devise any remedy they wish to correct the disparities between wealthy and poor districts, but they may not do it by forcing poor districts to raise property taxes, the court ruled. Capping a decadelong legal battle, the justices repeatedly said education financing cannot depend on the decisions of local schools boards, and districts must be guaranteed a certain amount of money every year. They also rejected the state's argument that money will not solve the problem because many urban districts will simply mismanage and waste the additional money. ``Money can make a difference if effectively used. It can provide the students with an equal educational opportunity, a chance to succeed. They are entitled to that chance, constitutionally entitled,'' Wilentz wrote. New Jersey is among more than a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems in recent years. The others are Texas, Kentucky, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. The latest conflict pitted the state against the Newark-based Education Law Center. The center, which brought the lawsuit in 1981, charged that New Jersey's $3.5 billion system discriminates against poor districts because of its heavy reliance on property taxes. It contended that poor and urban districts are unable to raise the money needed to provide a quality education and that the system has allowed the gap between rich and poor districts to widen. The lawsuit was brought on behalf of 20 school-age children from four New Jersey cities. After a similar legal battle fought throughout the 1970s, the court ordered the Legislature to overhaul New Jersey's school financing system, and lawmakers enacted a state income tax to pay for more state education aid. In today's decision, the court found that those reforms did not fully solve the problem. ``It's a victory for the schoolchildren of New Jersey, and the courts' proposed remedy strives to do essentially, but in a more modest way, what the governor has proposed himself,'' said Emma Byrne, Gov. Jim Florio's spokeswoman. This latest ruling comes barely a week after Florio unveiled a sweeping plan to overhaul the financing system. The governor wants to spend more state money on poor and middle-income districts and reduce or eliminate aid to wealthier school systems. He also wants to increase the income tax to provide $1 billion more in state education aid. His plan establishes a minimum amount of money that districts should spend on each child and determines how much the community should be required to raise on its own, based on property wealth and the wealth of a community's residents. The state would then provide aid to make up the difference. In 1988, Administrative Law Judge Steven Lefelt ruled that the financing system, as reformed in the 1970s, had failed because poorer districts still fell behind wealthier districts. ``I do not believe in fixing what is not broken. However, plaintiffs have proven the system is broken,'' he said in his ruling. He said more money may not be the only solution, but that it is a start. Administrative law decisions are subject to review by state officials. Education Commissioner Saul Cooperman rejected Lefelt's findings, agreeing with the stand that then Gov. Thomas H. Kean's administration took for the eight years it fought the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Mayor Faces Prosecutor in N.C. Runoff for U.S. Senate
With PM-Primaries Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, `In last-minute ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Gantt quotes after voting today. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `Easley, in ...'
DOC.TEXT: A former mayor seeking to become North Carolina's first black candidate for statewide office this century faced a prosecutor in a Democratic runoff today for the right to challenge Sen. Jesse Helms. Harvey Gantt, the 46-year-old former two-term mayor of Charlotte, and 39-year-old Southport District Attorney Mike Easley avoided attacks on each other during the campaign, instead saying their priority is unseating the Republican Helms. Helms already has the GOP nomination and has been running commercials attacking both Democrats. Gantt led a six-candidate field in the May 8 primary but failed to reach the 40 percent needed to avoid a runoff between the top two vote-getters. Easley, who received 30 percent to Gantt's 37 percent, demanded the runoff despite Gantt's pleas to avoid one for the sake of Democratic unity. After voting today in Charlotte, Gantt said: ``We'd like to carry the West. And we'd like to carry the East, just to prove a point.'' And he said he was eager to campaign against Helms. ``I`m ready to get into this fight,'' he said. ``I'm ready to get it on with him.'' Easley, in Greenville, accused Helms of running far more ads against him than against Gantt because the senator ``would rather beat me in the last five days of the primary than face me for five months in the election.'' Beth Burrus, a spokeswoman for the Helms campaign, said that there is no attempt to single out Easley and that Helms doesn't care who wins the runoff. ``The polls show that it's going to be a very close race whoever wins,'' she said. ``Both candidates lead Helms at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Tries to Overcome Soviet Objections to NATO Membership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze comment on weapons, Baker reaction: EDITS to trim; Pickup 9th pvs, `In addition...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said today it plans to withdraw 1,500 nuclear warheads and other tactical short-range nuclear weapons from Central Europe by the end of the year. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who made the announcment, said later that ``a very small amount, relatively,'' of Soviet battlefield nuclear weapons will remain in Europe after the withdrawals. ``This is going to be a very substantive amount,'' said Shevardnadze, who is in Copenhagen for a 35-nation human rights conference. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, also at the conference, was cautious in his assssment of the announcement. ``We are still in the process of taking a look at it, analyzing it,'' Baker said. He said the extent of the withdrawal was not clear, nor whether the Soviets would destroy or simply remove the weapons. Also, Baker said, it was not clear whether the arms Shevardnadze spoke about would have been withdrawn in any event with the Soviet troops currently being pulled out of Eastern Europe. Shevardnadze and Baker are meeting during the human rights conference to push ahead with issues discussed during the Washington summit between Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush. A central issue was the military future of a united Germany. Europe and the United States want Germany as part of NATO but the Soviet Union has balked at that idea. Speaking to the conference, Shevardnadze said a compromise could be found in Soviet differences with Washington over Germany. He said the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact would begin a ``transformation'' at its next meeting and that NATO should do the same. ``This is the way, as we underlined in the past, that we can find a compromise on the German issue,'' Shevardnadze said. Baker planned to assure Shevardnadze at a meeting tonight that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would undertake a review of its mission in light of easing East-West tensions. Bush and the heads of 15 other allied governments will meet in London next month. The occasion is expected to mark a lowering of NATO's military profile and a shift to more of a political profile. In his speech, Shevardnadze said the Soviet withdrawal of nuclear weapons from central Europe would ease tensions and ``give more latitude to man.'' In addition to the nuclear warheads, he said his government will withdraw 60 tactical missile launchers, more than 250 units of atomic artillery and 3,200 atomic guns.
