West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher welcomed the announcement but said the Soviets enjoyed a superiority in short-range missiles. ``The unilateral steps from the Soviet Union are going to make negotiations on weapons easier. So we welcome it as a positive step,'' Genscher said. In his efforts to gain Mosocw's suppport for NATO membership for a united Germany, Baker carried with him to Copenhagen promises of Western economic help and nuclear and territorial assurances. The possibility that West Germany would build houses for returning Soviet troops was even included in a nine-point program. Baker told reporters on his flight from Washington that building houses for troops withdrawn from Eastern and Central Europe ``fits right in'' with the economic cooperation plan. His problem is selling the package to Shevardnadze. The Soviet people harbor deep mistrust of Germany. Memories linger of World War II in which the Nazis were routed from Russian soil after more than 20 million Soviets were killed. The foreign ministers are in Copenhagen for a European Security Conference meeting on human rights. One of Baker's nine points is to expand the conference's functions _ a long-held Soviet goal. The issue would be taken up by the 35 member nations instead of just NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Other key points include: _Assurances by the Germans they would not try to expand their territory beyond the lands now controlled by West Germany and East Germany. _A pledge by the new Germany not to acquire nuclear or chemical weapons. _West German economic assistance for the Soviet Union. _Keeping Soviet troops in what is now East Germany for a transitional period. _Keeping Western forces out of the territory. _An acceleration of negotiations to ban short-range nuclear weapons in NATO and the Warsaw Pact _A revision of NATO military doctrine to reflect the easing of East-West tensions. _A prompt second round of negotiations to make deeper cuts in troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe once the treaty is concluded to reduce U.S. and Soviet manpower and weapons. This would give Moscow a chance to seek limitations on the German army.

DOC.HEAD: Census Count Nearing 90 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Census has counted 87 percent of American households, an official said Tuesday. Spokesman Ray Bancroft said the households had been counted in the mail and door-to-door portions of the census, which is continuing. Bancroft said the 90 percent level could be reached within a week, but that ``the last 10 percent is the hardest to count.'' People who mailed back their census forms in March were the easiest to tally, and census workers have added to that total by visiting the homes of those who didn't get forms in the mail or failed to send them back. Now they are trying to count people who are reluctant to cooperate with government officials, are away from home or are so busy working that they are hard to find. The census, mandated every 10 years by the Constitution, is used to redistribute seats in the House of Representatives and to divide billions of dollars in federal aid among state and communities. Nearly 100 million forms were mailed in April. Bancroft said census maps of local communities were being sent to about 39,000 local governments. By the end of August, each community will receive a count of the number of housing units on each block and the total population of the community. Local officials will have 15 days to report any discrepancies between their counts and the census report. Meanwhile, processing is running well ahead of the rate set 10 years ago, Bancroft said. The 1980 census forms were kept at local offices until the area count was complete, then shipped en masse to processing centers. That meant computer processing didn't begin until August 1980. This year, forms are shipped to the seven processing centers as they are collected. Microfilming and computer processing has already begun. The first official census report is expected to be delivered to President Bush on Dec. 31, listing the population of the country and of each state as well as how many House seats to which each state is entitled.

DOC.HEAD: Professor Says He's Solved Mystery Of Sensational `Piltdown Man' Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A City University professor says he has solved the mystery of who was behind the 1912 ``Piltdown Man'' fraud, which rocked the scientific community and provided fodder for a decades-long whodunit. Dr. Frank Spencer, anthropology professor at Queens College, a branch of City University, said in a telephone interview today that the names of many prominent scientists, and even mystery maven Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, had been mentioned as ``suspects'' through the years. But his research, bolstered by that of Australian historian Ian Langham, points the finger at Sir Arthur Keith, a well-respected anatomist and conservator of the Hunterian Museum of the Royal College of Surgeons. Spencer lays out the premise for the fraud in two new books to be published this fall by Oxford University Press. Piltdown, a small village in England, made international news in 1912 when a skull and jaw of what became known as the ``Piltdown Man'' were discovered in a gravel pit. ``It was sensational because it offered a completely different view of evolution at the time,'' Spencer said. But in 1953 the discovery was completely debunked when it was learned the remains were actually a human skull _ only a couple of hundred years old _ with an orangutan's jaw fused to it. Still, the larger question remained _ who did it? Fingers immediately pointed to Charles Dawson, the country lawyer who made the discovery, but the scientific community believed someone else had to be involved. The names of scientist William J. Sollas, philosopher Pierre Teilhard de Chardin and even Doyle, the Sherlock Holmes inventor who lived nearby, kept coming up. But there was never any proof and often no motive. ``The general feeling was that Piltdown was contrived to bring somebody down, make someone in the scientific community look silly,'' Spencer said, but that theory didn't work because ``if that was the case, why didn't anyone ever do that?'' Spencer said once he began looking at the evidence with the viewpoint that Dawson's co-conspirator was someone who had something to gain intellectually, not monetarily, he began to look at Keith. But his search for documents collided with the efforts of Langham, a professor at the University of Sydney in Australia, and Spencer said he ``backed off'' and allowed Langham to continue his research alone. When Langham died in 1984 without concluding his research, Spencer said, Langham's widow asked him to continue her husband's work. He said the turning point was entries in Keith's diary ``in which he indicates he had information about the site and events at Piltdown ... which he wouldn't have had unless he was an inside member of the group. This was really the crux of the thing.'' Spencer said he and Langham also uncovered the fact that Keith, a scientist who backed the theory of evolution that came out of Piltdown, had met with Dawson a year before the discovery and again just several months before. Though Spencer believes he and Langham have cracked the Piltdown mystery, doubting Thomases still abound. Dr. Fred H. Smith, a paleontologist at the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, told The New York Times that Spencer makes a ``good case'' but ``it's not ironclad.'' Dr. William Ball, a former keeper of paleontology at the British Museum, said until someone comes up with a signed confession, questions surrounding Piltdown will remain.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Approve First Statement of Faith in 122 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with today's vote on a statement of faith, quotes, details, background. DELETES outdated material. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `The issue ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) today approved a statement of faith that mixes traditional Christian beliefs with environmental concerns and images of God as both mother and father. Commissioners stood and cheered after approving the statement _ the church's first since a 1983 merger of its northern and southern branches following a 122-year split over slavery _ in a 499-to-25 vote. ``I think the statement of faith is a reflection of the church's ability, even in the face of considerable diversity, that we are still capable of forming a unified statement of Christian belief that is consistent with our tradition,'' said the Rev. John Mulder, president of Louisville Presbyterian Seminary. The statement must be sent to the denomination's 177 presbyteries. If two-thirds of them approve, it will come before the 1991 General Assembly for a final vote. It would then become the 11th statement in the 2.9 million-member denomination's Book of Confessions. The statement upholds centuries-old church teachings that Jesus Christ was both fully human and fully God, and that God raised Jesus from the dead to offer eternal life. Reflecting more recent church developments, the statement also declares that God calls women and men to all ministries of the church, ``and makes everyone equally in God's image, male and female, of every race and people, to live as one community.'' The statement refers to God like a mother who will not forsake her nursing child and like a father who runs to welcome the prodigal home. It also says that human beings have exploited nature, ``and threatened death to the planet entrusted to our care.'' On Monday, the assembly, embroiled in a dispute over the distribution of sexually explicit literature to a youth meeting by a homosexual caucus, decided to take away semiofficial status from both some of its severest liberal and conservative critics. Despite criticism that it was trying to reduce voices of dissent within the church, commissioners voted to delete a part of the church's Book of Order that gives groups such as Presbyterians for Lesbian-Gay Concerns and Presbyterians Pro-Life the right to be officially represented at church meetings. If a majority of the regional presbyteries agree, the organizations will no longer ``be attached officially to the church,'' said Marj Carpenter, news director of the church. The 202nd General Assembly also Monday decided to postpone until 1991 action on several issues related to abortion and the ordination of homosexuals and voted to create a church office for the environment. The issue of homosexuality heated up last summer when Presbyterians for Lesbian-Gay Concerns detailed in brochures the sexual practices of homosexuals to high school and college students attending a church meeting at Purdue University. The brochures discussed both oral and anal sex, and gave explicit instructions in the use of condoms. In the resulting uproar, several regional church groups petitioned the General Assemby to deny official church status to the homosexual caucus. The assembly Committee on Worship and Diversity recommended that all organizations with the same semiofficial status, including the homosexual caucus and the Witherspoon Society and conservative church critics such as the anti-abortion group and the Presbyterian Lay Committee, no longer be accorded official representation within the denomination. The Rev. Robert Butcher, committee moderator, said the sexually explicit brochures may have served as a ``lightning rod'' for the discussion. There were concerns within the church that the private organizations were perceived as having official standing while operating outside the governing bodies of the denomination. ``Many of these groups are, in fact, lobbying groups, but outside the constitutional system of the church,'' he said. But in a minority report, committee member Nancy V. Rodman said if the resolution passed, ``We are saying we no longer welcome the dissent of our members.'' The Rev. Robert Davidson of New York City said the church should not be appearing to back away from defending the right to dissent at a time when freedom of speech is breaking out all over the world. Faced with potentially volatile battles, the church voted to wait until next year to take action on resolutions dealing with a variety of issues on abortion and homosexuality. The postponed resolutions included one calling for the church to withdraw from the Religious Coalition for Abortion Rights and one that would have allowed local church bodies to ordain practicing homosexuals. A Special Task Force on Human Sexuality is expected to report on both homosexuality and abortion to the 1991 General Assembly. The church supports legalized abortion, and opposes the ordination of practicing homosexuals. In approving a 93-page document called ``Restoring Creation for Ecology and Justice,'' commissioners voted to establish a denominational office on environmental justice, and incorporate environmental conceketing will continue into the Chapter 11 reorganization. ``We're not surprised about the filing because we've been expecting it all along,'' said Gary H. Daughrity, executive board member of Local 1313, Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Dallas. ``A lot of us can't figure out why it took so long for Greyhound to seek bankruptcy court protection.'' One reason that Greyhound's financial woes worsened was that fewer striking drivers crossed picket lines than company management had anticipated, Daughrity said. The company has hired about 3,000 replacement drivers and claims to have restored service to locations that provided 98 percent of revenues last year. But the drop in ridership and the cost of fighting the sometimes violent strike drained the company's cash, including a strike fund estimated at more than $54 million. Greyhound blamed the strike for much of its $56 million first-quarter loss. The company also has missed more than $17 million in interest, lease and principal payments, putting it in default on many financial agreements. ``In the past few days, there has been a lot of pressure by creditors'' who own buses and terminals and lease them to Greyhound, said President Frank Schmieder. Under the lease agreements, those owners can repossess buses immediately after a missed payment. Spokesman George Gravley said the company was concerned about possible action by owners of leases on 500 to 1,000 of the company's 3,800 buses. ``While most (creditors) have been cooperative, we were faced with the threat of a `run on assets' that would have crippled our ability to operate,'' Doyle said. Greyhound filed its petition in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Brownsville. The filing also includes five affiliated companies: Eagle Bus Manufacturing Co., GLI Bus Operations Holding Co., BusLease Inc., Trailways Commuter Transit Inc. and GLI Food Services Inc. Greyhound's parent, GLI Holding Co., was not included. Greyhound has reported scores of shootings, bomb threats and incidents of vandalism since the strike began. A striking driver in Redding, Calif., was killed on the second day of the walkout after being crushed by a bus driven by a replacement. Talks stalled under the company's demand that a week pass without violence first. The two sides did meet on May 5, but the union balked at Greyhound's insistence on retaining its newly hired drivers and changing from a mileage-based to an hourly wage scale. On May 7, Chairman Fred G. Currey said the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. Two weeks later, however, the company proposed repurchasing $225 million of its junk bonds at a steep discount to avert bankruptcy. Schmieder said negotiations are continuing on a debt buyback, but ``it will take longer now because the courts will have to approve any financial restructuring.'' The company's total debt stood at $384 million at the end of March. The debt is the legacy of a $270 million leveraged buyout led by Currey three years ago that took the company private. A few months later, the group paid $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fighter Crashes off Okinawa, Pilot Rescued
DOC.TEXT: An American F-86F jet fighter crashed off Okinawa on Tuesday, but the pilot was rescued by a Japanese military helicopter, defense officials said. A Japanese defense force official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, refused to identify the pilot but said he was not injured. U.S. military officials could not immediately be reached for comment. The official said the helicopter picked up the pilot about one hour after the plane crashed in water 80 miles northwest of the U.S. Kadena Air Base on Okinawa, where the plane was based. The official said the plane was used as a target in training for U.S. military planes. Kyodo News Service quoted Lt. Col. R.W. Winkelmann, chief of public affairs of the Okinawa-based 313rd Air Division, as saying the plane developed engine trouble during a training exercise. It quoted Japanese defense force sources as saying the plane was owned by Tracor Flight System Inc., a civilian company based in California.

DOC.HEAD: Man With Dagger Attempts to Attack Political Leader
DOC.TEXT: A man with a dagger tried to attack the chairman of a political party during a rally, but other people stopped him and he was in police custody, a newspaper said Tuesday. The target of the attack was Josef Bartonick of the Czechoslovak People's Party. The party is one of three that makes up the Christian Democratic Union, which polls say is the second-strongest political force in the country. Bartonick escaped unhurt after the incident Sunday in Cikhaj, east of Prague. ``As I was speaking on stage, a young man armed with a dagger tried to climb up toward me. Thanks to the fast action of the organizers and participants in the rally the man was stopped and handed over to the police,'' Bartonick was quoted by the daily Lidova Demokracie as saying. The motive of the attempted attack was not known. The man was not identified, but his age was given as 25. It was the second violent incident in the generally quiet campaign for Friday's national elections. A bomb went off on Prague's central Old Town Square on Saturday and injured 19 people. Police have launched a probe into the explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Government Claims 98 UNITA Rebels Killed
DOC.TEXT: Angolan government forces killed 98 U.S-backed UNITA rebels during recent fighting near the southeastern town of Caiundo, the Angolan state news agency reported Tuesday. The ANGOP report, monitored in Lisbon from the Angolan capital of Luanda, said seven rebels and six anti-tank misiles were captured and seven government soldiers wounded during the clashes Friday. UNITA representatives contacted in the Portuguese capital refused to comment on the ANGOP dispatch. Meanwhile, Lisbon's TSF radio station Tuesday cited unnamed Angolan officials as saying 5,000 government troops had withdrawn from the Caiundo area in southeastern Cuando Cubango province. According to the TSF report, Luanda decided to withdraw the soldiers because UNITA had adopted a more flexible attitude toward peace talks with the government. In December, the Angolan government launched one of the biggest offensives of the 15-year civil war against rebel strongholds in Cuando Cubango. Recently government troops have pulled back from some positions captured in that advance. UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ has been fighting to force the Marxist government to share power since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975. A cease-fire sealed by Presdient Jose Eduardo dos Santos and rebel leader Jonas Savimbi in June 1988 broke down within weeks. Although peace talks restarted in April in Portugal, heavy fighting has continued.

DOC.HEAD: Vending Machine Glut Prompts Coca-Cola Boycott by Cafe Owners
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of cafe and restaurant owners in Bordeaux are waging a boycott against Coca-Cola to protest what they view as unfair competition from vending machines. Christian Sauvage, president of the main hotel and restaurant owners' association in the region, said Tuesday the soft drink company had flooded Bordeaux with about 850 vending machines as part of a test marketing program. Sauvage said his association had accepted Coca-Cola's proposal to place the vending machines inside business premises but objected when machines also were placed in the streets. ``In the machines, a bottle costs five francs (90 cents),'' said Sauvage. ``At our places, taking into account expenses, we sell it at 10 to 15 francs. The young people aren't crazy _ they rush over to the machines.'' The boycott began two months ago in Bordeaux, France's fifth-largest city, and now involves about 500 establishments, Sauvage said. A spokesman for Coca-Cola, who declined to be identified, said the company hoped to negotiate a resolution to the dispute. The spokesman contended that the vending machines catered toward a different clientele than the regular patrons of cafes.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Student Released After Year of Detention
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities have released a Hong Kong student detained for almost a year for his alleged role in the pro-democracy movement in Shanghai last year, a Hong Kong government spokesman said Tuesday. Yao Yongzhan, a Hong Kong resident who had been studying at a Shanghai university, was taken off a Hong Kong-bound flight after the June 3-4, 1989, military suppression in Beijing of the pro-democracy movement that swept China last spring. ``The Hong Kong government has received confirmation from the British Consulate General in Shanghai this afternoon that Yao Yongzhan has been released,'' the spokesman said. Local television reports said Yao was released along with another 21 dissidents. It gave no details on the others.

DOC.HEAD: One Miner Killed, 10 Others Feared Dead in Mine Accident
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and subsequent flood in a western Siberia coal mine killed one miner, and 10 others were feared dead, an official said Tuesday. The accident occurred Sunday morning in the Dimitrov mine near Novokuznetsk in the Kuznetsk Coal Basin, 2,100 miles east of Moscow, said Andrei H. Schmidt, director of the mine shaft. The body of one of the miners, Alexander Mitrokhin, was found Tuesday under thick mud, Schmidt said in a telephone interview. A search was under way for the others. ``There isn't a chance that they are alive,'' Schmidt said. ``We can say this for sure judging by the situation. ... The best thing we can do is find their bodies.'' Officials did not know what caused the explosion, which triggered a cave-in and flood.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed in Shantytown Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire raged through a shantytown for about two hours Tuesday, destroying 500 huts and killing at least seven people, police said. The cause of the fire, which erupted in Sunder Nagri in eastern New Delhi, was not immediately known, said a police spokesman who cannot be identified under briefing rules. He said scores of people were injured but did not give an exact figure. Hundreds of homeless people huddled together, watching silently as firefighters battled the blaze. It was the latest in a series of fires that have erupted in New Delhi's numerous shantytowns this summer. At least 20 people have been killed and more than 10,000 huts destroyed in fires during the last two months.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Tokyo Area
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the Tokyo area Tuesday night, but police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake, at 10:43 p.m., measured 5.3 on the Richter scale. The agency placed the epicenter of the quake roughly 72 miles underground in Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. The Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake at its epicenter, according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Glance at Soviet Ethnic Hotspots
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at ethnic hotspots in the Soviet Union's republics:

KIRGHIZIA, UZBEKISTAN: Ethnic groups in the neighboring republics are involved in a land dispute that led to violent clashes in the Kirghiz city of Osh, on the border with Uzbekistan. The dispute reportedly centers around land claimed by both sides near the city. Soviet media said Tuesday at least 11 people were killed in rioting that flared Monday night between the two predominately Moslem ethnic groups in Osh.

TADZHIKISTAN: At least seven people were killed in February and more than 100 injured in ethnic rioting. The unrest began after rumors spread that Armenians fleeing ethnic violence in the Armenia and Azerbaijan would receive priority for new housing in Tadzhikistan.

ARMENIA-AZERBAIJAN: Soldiers remain in both republics to control a renewal in January of ethnic violence that has wracked the Caucasus region for the past two years. More than 200 people have been killed since Jan. 13 in fighting between heavily armed groups of Armenians and Azerbaijanis. Their dispute focuses on the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is populated mainly by Armenians but located within Azerbaijan. Armenia wants to annex the land.

GEORGIA: Nationalists want independence from the Soviet Union, and the republic's parliament has condemned Georgia's forcible annexation to the Soviet Union in 1921. Georgians vote for a new Supreme Soviet legislature on June 17, and independence will be a key campaign issue. The opposition groups remain badly splintered, however.

MOLDAVIA: The Moldavian People's Front, an independent political movement, is the main challenger to the Communist Party. The front initially wants political sovereignty from the Kremlin, followed eventually by full independence. Moldavia was once part of Romania. The overthrow of Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu has increased the passion for independence or a return to Romania.

UKRAINE: A nascent nationalist movement is emerging in the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second-largest republic. Rukh, the organization of progressive nationalists, is the most vocal of several movements demanding an independent Ukraine.

LITHUANIA: Lithuania's parliament declared the republic of 3.8 million independent March 11. The Kremlin has since imposed an economic embargo of oil, natural gas and other raw materials. Lithuanian officials say the partial blockade has cost thousands of jobs. They are pressing for negotiations with the Kremlin.

ESTONIA: The parliament on March 30 declared the Soviet Union an occupying power and pledged to restore full independence gradually. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at first offered Estonia, a republic of 1.5 million, ``special status'' in a revamped Soviet federation if it would drop its independence bid. But Estonia persisted, and Gorbachev issued a decree declaring the Estonian declaration of March 30 invalid.

LATVIA: Latvia proclaimed itself independent May 4, but its measure calls for a transition period of unspecified length. About 54 percent of the republic's population of 2.7 million is Latvian. The rest are mainly Russians, many of whom oppose independence. Like Estonia, Latvia first got an offer from Gorbachev of special status in a renewed federation, but its declaration of independence amounted to a rejection of that offer. Gorbachev also declared Latvia's declaration of independence invalid.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Resumes in Barry Drug and Perjury Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-6 to UPDATE with questioning of potential jurors; picks up 5th graf pvs, In addition ...; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion Barry entered its second day today as the defense said it may call the mayor's campaign manager and two members of his round-the clock security detail as witnesses. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy made the disclosure in court as the judge in the case began individual questioning of the 250 potential jurors summoned to U.S. District Court. Barry joked with reporters as he arrived on a brilliant spring day, asking one whether he wanted to play tennis. Once inside the courtroom he chatted with artists, asking them how long it takes to draw their sketches for television. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to all 14 of the charges against him. Sources close to the case say plea bargaining efforts so far have left the two sides far apart. By early afternoon, a half-dozen potential jurors had been questioned by the judge and lawyers, including an FBI clerk who said she could be a fair and impartial juror and an art teacher who said she would have trouble presuming Barry's innocence. Others included a lawyer, a city housing department employee and a man who was excused after he said he was preparing to move out of the city and that his mother was dying. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he would rule at the end of the day whether those questioned would be sent into the jury pool. In addition to the campaign manager and security guards, Monday said he may call 14 others to testify in support of the mayor. The names of the two security guards, James Stays and Fred Gaskins, were already included in a questionnaire being given prospective jurors in the case. Mundy said he wanted the names of Anita Bonds, the campaign manager, and the others added to the list. Law enforcement and city government sources have said that prosecutors were on the verge of questioning Bonds about a number of issues when a grand jury returned a 14-count indictment against the mayor on May 10. Bonds has said she had not received a subpoena to testify but was informed by police officials working on the case that prosecutors wished to speak with her. Among those Mundy said he may call is Daniel Butler, a neighborhood activist who city government sources say has been a late-night companion of the mayor's for a number of years. Also on the list is David Rivers, a former top city official and close friend of Barry's who is currently on trial in the same courthouse for allegedly steering city contracts to friends and business associates. The city government sources have said that Rivers and his co-defendant, city contractor John Clyburn, both frequently socialized with the mayor. Mundy did not mention Rivers by name and he is not on the list provided to jurors, but when Jackson read back a list of possible defense witnesses, the judge mentioned Rivers. Jackson said he hoped to evaluate by the end of the day 50 of the 250 potential jurors who spent Monday filling out a 69-question form designed to determine whether they can view the case impartially. The trial is expected to last about a month, while jury selection could take at least a week. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of lying to a grand jury and one count of conspiracy. The three perjury charges are felonies. Sources close to the case have said Barry's lawyers have been conducting plea-bargain talks with federal prosecutors, but one source said the two sides are at an impasse. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. A top city official said Barry is unwilling to consider pleading guilty to a felony perjury charge, since that likely would send him to jail. Such a development would bar him from governing or running for re-election this November. ``That's something he just won't do,'' this source said. ``The mayor can read the statute too. Why sign off on part of a worst-case scenario?'' ``There is not a feeling, on either side, of being under any kind of time constraint,'' the source said. Barry has acknowledged he suffers from alcoholism, and the potential panelists were asked whether they think that could be used to excuse criminal activity. The questionnaire also included a section asking the respondents to give their feelings about undercover sting operations, the method used to produce Barry's arrest. In addition, they were asked whether they thought the case against the black mayor was racially or politically motivated.

DOC.HEAD: Late Frost Threatens White House Tree Planted by President Bush
DOC.TEXT: The 12-foot American elm taken from White House grounds and planted by President Bush near the state Capitol last year is fighting for its life. Bismarck forester Paul Blumhardt says the tree was hurt by a late frost that hit after unseasonably warm March weather brought out its buds. The top of the tree appears lifeless, but buds can be found on lower branches and foresters are waiting to see whether they will bloom. ``It is our intent to do everything we can, if the tree can be saved, to save it,'' Blumhardt said. Bush planted the tree in April 1989 at a ceremony attended by an estimated 10,000 people celebrating North Dakota's centennial. The elm, descendant of a tree planted by John Quincy Adams, was taken from the White House grounds. Bush has planted other ceremonial trees around the nation during his presidency.

DOC.HEAD: 10-Year High School Reunion Turns Into Impromptu Marital Union
DOC.TEXT: Tim Newton did more than show off his fiancee at his 10-year high school reunion. He married her. Newton told a friend at the weekend gathering of 1980 Star City High School graduates that he and Tracy Byford had their wedding rings and marriage license. He joked that if a minister were present they'd tie the knot. Then the friend revealed that he was an ordained minister. That was all it took, said the new Mrs. Newton, 20. ``Everybody just kept on going, `Y'all ought to get married,''' she said. She said Newton, 27, stood dumbfounded ``with a weird look on his face'' before agreeing to the impromptu wedding. Women at the banquet started grabbing flowers from wall and table arrangements to make a bridal bouquet. Newton picked a best man and his intended chose a bride's maid. Another classmate played the wedding march on a handy piano. After the ceremony, there were cheers, and then the 75-or-so classmates rustled up some cake and champagne for the reunion-turned-reception. There even was a band to serenade the newlyweds.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen Can't Wear Earrings On or Off-Duty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs from court decision on why even off-duty earrings may be banned.
DOC.TEXT: Earrings may be fine on pirates and punk-rockers, but not on policemen in rural Peotone, an appellate court ruled. The 7th U.S. Court of Appeals ruled Monday patrolmen Gary Zybak and Marvin Rathert cannot wear their ear studs _ even when off duty. ``I really shouldn't comment about the appellate court ruling without talking to my attorney, but one thing is certain _ I'm not quitting the force or leaving Peotone,'' Zybak said Monday night in a telephone interview. ``I'm very happy here, I've been here since 1968, and I consider it my hometown.'' Hometown values prevailed in the appellate decision, which upheld an earlier ruling by U.S. District Judge James Holderman in favor of Police Chief Gary N. Bogart and other officials in Peotone, 45 miles south of Chicago. ``The record shows that even some family members and officer colleagues were disturbed by the ear studs as much as were the city officials,'' wrote Appeals Judge Harlington Wood Jr. ``It is obvious from the record that the plaintiffs not only caused an adverse impact on police discipline, esprit de corps and uniformity ... but caused great public dissatisfaction as well,'' Wood added. Zybak and Rathert bought the studs and had their ears pierced in December 1986 at a jewelry store in Matteson. Zybak said he and Rathert were just trying to make an off-duty fashion statement. ``We didn't mean to wear them on duty, but unfortunately, when you first get your ears pierced, you have to keep the studs in for about six weeks so they won't close up,'' he said. ``On-duty, we kept Band-aids over them, but that wasn't good enough, I guess.'' Officials in the town of about 3,000 received complaints from some of Peotone's four other full-time officers, residents and even Rathert's wife. ``We both received a strong reprimand about the earrings in January 1987, and Officer Rathert _ he was a sergeant then _ was demoted and suffered a pay cut,'' said Zybak, explaining why the two men filed a federal lawsuit. The lawsuit contended the village's real motive was to promote ``conservative or narrow-minded views.'' Wood disagreed. ``The important responsibilities of these police officers do not include attempting to change the village's political and social outlook, whatever it may be, by wearing ear studs,'' he wrote for the three-judge panel. The court said the ban on ear studs should apply even when the men are off duty because the community is small and most people know who the officers are even when they are out of uniform. ``There is little difference in the way the village's police officers are publicly viewed, whether their objectionable conduct as police officers occurs on duty or off, whether they wear the ear stud on duty or off,'' the ruling said.

DOC.HEAD: Memories of Soviet Leader's Trip to America's Heartland
DOC.TEXT: Under a cloudless sky at high noon, the motorcade of Mikhail S. Gorbachev purred smoothly over roads lined with palm trees on the campus of Stanford University. And the children of an unfettered capitalism, wearing Sony Walkmans and riding mountain bikes, clamored after it in loud pursuit: ``Gor-bEEEEE. Gor-bEEEEE. Gor-bEEEEE.'' Under a low, angled roof in the Ukrainian-American Center on Minneapolis' northeast side, a few graying immigrants ate eggs and pyrohy (dumplings), drank strong coffee and gathered up their materials to make angry signs. Then, bundled up against unseasonably cool June temperatures, they headed for neighboring St. Paul to meet the same motorcade. And when they caught up with it, some chanted less flattering things: ``Wrecker! Destroyer! Out of the Baltic States!'' Coming or going, conciliatory or sharp-tongued, in the sun-drenched Bay Area on Monday or the cold drizzle of the Upper Midwest on Sunday, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev never failed to draw a crowd. He could be unpredictable. He accommodated knots of screaming protesters and smiling families with equal aplomb, lingering longest among those crowds whose adulation swelled until the Secret Service agents guarding him were red with frustration and the elected officials squiring him were green with envy. In San Francisco, his wife, Raisa, bolted from the motorcade at one point and swooped down unannounced on Fisherman's Wharf, stepping out of the car just long enough to ring the bell on a cable car. The Gorbachevs gave the impression that they went where they wanted, saw what they wanted and said what they wanted to say. Though many of the impromptu jaunts no doubt were conceived as photo opportunities rather than getting-to-know-you excursions, their skill and savvy at every turn earned them respect _ even if it sometimes came grudgingly. At about 3 p.m. Sunday, Gorbachev nixed a scheduled visit to a family farm outside Minneapolis. Inside the Hubert Humphrey Metrodome, which had been converted into a media center for the visit, a harried Secret Service agent put down his radio and threw up his hands. ``The guy is a nightmare, jumps out of the car when he wants to and strolls any place he feels like. You've seen the things in the newspapers about us not knowing what's going on? Well,'' he said, ``they're true.'' If that was the case, a reporter asked, who was calling the shots? The agent looked toward the oversized TV screen high above the wall in left centerfield. On it, the Gorbachev motorcade was pictured zooming back toward downtown. ``I'd bet it's him,'' the agent said. ``The guy in the car.''

Halfway down Palm Drive, his wheelchair braced against the curb, John Looper sat patiently Monday and scanned the slowing string of black Zil limousines. Ten years ago, Looper lost the use of his legs in a motorcycle accident, but it slowed him very little; two hours ago, he'd parked at the edge of the Stanford campus and unceremoniously wheeled two miles to reach this vantage point. When the 30-year-old software engineer told colleagues why he was taking the day off, a few chuckled and a few others told him to catch the traveling Gorbachevs on TV. But Looper would not be dissuaded; this bit of history he was determined to catch himself. In the span of a breath, the familiar face appeared at the open window, caught his eye, waved, and just as quickly, moved on. As the roller skates and bicycles, skateboards and motor scooters rumbled past on the sidewalk, Looper began the two-mile trip back. ``It was worth it,'' he said. ``We watch TV so much that so many of the things you see just don't seem real any more. ``I felt like I had to see the man. This is a pivotal point in history. Who knows what's going to happen in the future? I support what Gorbachev is doing and with public opinion what it is back home, I figure he could use the help. ``But there are selfish reasons, too. When I see him in the history books 20 years from now,'' Looper said, ``I'm going to be able to tell my kids that we exchanged waves.''

At Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich's residence two blocks down on the auspiciously named Summit Avenue, chefs were making final preparations for Gorbachev's lunch while pacifist Jean Remke and several of the women with whom she shares a mansion were stringing together quilted panels for a ``peace ribbon'' to wrap around the outside of their home. Many of the panels, with their pastoral scenes of nature and families, had been part of the peace ribbon unveiled in Washington in 1985 and, in one of the more creative protests against the arms race, used to encircle the Pentagon. Several subsequently were presented to the Gorbachevs at a U.S.-Soviet summit. ``Some people laughed then, but I think it's done good,'' Virgina Hessian Mulvaney said. ``Gorbachev is here and nuclear weapons are on the way out.'' She went on to explain that her daughter was born on the same day of a Sputnik launch by the Soviets, and how that fateful coincidence inspired her to conceive a poem about peaceful coexistence even as she lay on a delivery table in the labor room. Ever since, she remained convinced that this day of cooperation between the superpowers would come. And last week, she was the first caller on a radio show taping messages to forward to the Gorbachevs. She recited as much of the poem as time would allow. But Ms. Mulvaney admitted a moment later that she was discouraged to learn not all Minnesotans were viewing the historic visit with the same serious-mindedness. The second caller simply joked about cleaning his house if Gorbachev agreed to stop by. ``And the third,'' she added, more disheartened, ``only talked about taking him fishing.''

Some people were doing more than talking about capitalism Monday at Stanford; an opportunistic few were out practicing. At 11 a.m., Marlowe Johnson lowered his ticket-for-sale sign and brushed his long bangs back over the top of wire-rimmed glasses. The ducat he held was won in a lottery conducted among Stanford students for a chance to hear Gorbachev speak. He was hoping to convert it into a meal ticket. ``The highest price I've heard,'' he said, ``is $1,800. I got an offer for $500 earlier this morning and turned it down. Might have been a mistake.'' And who, he was asked, was laying out that kind of money? ``Rich, kooky people,'' Johnson said. ``Maybe alumni.''

DOC.HEAD: Wright Seems Happy With Life Away From Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 16-17, `During the ...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY bankruptcy status of company
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN1
DOC.TEXT: If Jim Wright has any regrets about resigning as House Speaker, he's not saying so. And they aren't showing. He looks tanned and relaxed in his Fort Worth office, which is cluttered by papers and memorabilia from 34 years in Congress, along with notes for the book he is writing on Central America. Wright says he hasn't been happier in years, and talks without bitterness about his resignation a year ago during an ethics investigation. ``I have a sort of predestinarian's view of things, almost a religious conviction, that things happen for the better. And I just accept it that way,'' Wright said in a recent interview. Wright delivered his resignation speech to the House on May 31, 1989. Six days later, he officially gave up the post he had held for about two years. He left Congress on June 30. He stepped down after the House Ethics Committee said Wright violated House rules 69 times involving sales of his book, ``Reflections of a Public Man,'' and in business deals with his friend George Mallick of Fort Worth. Wright maintains the charges were false and brought by his enemies. He insists that he never knowingly violated House rules. He said events leading to his resignation ``fell together to create this jigsaw puzzle out of which there was no escape.'' But Wright said his fall from power did allow him an escape of sorts: he's now free to do things that were impossible in Washington, such as having dinner with his wife, Betty, and spending time with his children and grandchildren. The 67-year-old Wright still works long days, writing, giving speeches or guest lectures at colleges, and appearing at fund-raisers for fellow Democrats. He recently attended a gathering for his replacement, Pete Geren, who often consults Wright for advice. An avid gardener, Wright spent a recent weekend planting 52 rose bushes in his back yard, ``and had a few sore muscles.'' ``I'm happy. I'm as busy as I want to be, and I'm not nearly as busy as I used to be. I'm very glad I'm not,'' he said. ``During my last 12 years in Congress I was running to catch up. It was a constant choice between most urgent and merely urgent, and the simply important never got done.'' Wright's study in his new, three-bedroom home contains few signs of his tenure in Washington, which he says at times was ``oppressive, hectic, harried, harassing.'' He refuses to criticize his successor Speaker Tom Foley or the House, except to say it's not moving ``with any discernible clarity or purpose.'' He still believes actions by his nemesis, Republican Rep. Newt Gingrich, and special prosecutor Richard Phelan amounted to ``character assassination.'' And Wright blames the media for ``a voracious thirst for scandal.'' He says reporters didn't give him a chance to tell his side. During the past year, Mallick went to bankruptcy court and liquidated the company that was under House investigation. Mrs. Wright, whose job with the company, Mallightco, was questioned by the ethics committee, is less circumspect than her husband in assessing the investigation. ``I think that it leaves scars. I don't think there's any way to get away from it,'' she said. Wright said he sometimes yearns to be involved when he sees reports about such things as the crumbling of the Berlin Wall or Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to the United States. ``But there are other people who can do those things. I had my chance. I had 34 years, and that's plenty. I did everything I could do and the best I could do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Formally Launches Re-Election Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from governor's acceptance speech. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `Although he...'.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, often mentioned as a potential 1992 presidential contender, formally launched his campaign for another term as governor today by promising ``to work as hard as anybody can in this job.'' ``This has been one great big Democratic celebration and we're going to have another one on Election Day, Nov. 6 when we win everything in sight,'' said Cuomo, accepting Monday's unanimous nomination from delegates to the New York state Democratic convention. To cheers and standing ovations, Cuomo said he was seeking election to a third four-year term because ``New York has arrived at the edge of a new century and a new millennium'' that held ``new obstacles.'' ``I'm here today because I am committed to helping the people of the State of New York meet these new challenges,'' said the governor. Cuomo's address served as the rhetorical finale for the carefully orchestrated two-day gathering. Although he wasn't at the state Democratic convention when he gained the nomination by acclamation, he appeared Monday night at a reception put on by his campaign committee. ``The ideas, the emphasis, the commitment that brought us this far are the ideas, the emphasis and the commitment that will carry us the rest of the way, no matter how far that is,'' said Cuomo, 57. At a subsequent news conference, Cuomo said the campaign's overriding issue would be ``the future. What do you do about the 21st century and how do you get us there? Who has the capacity to get us there?'' Asked if that didn't have a presidential ring to it, Cuomo scoffed. ``You're so full of baloney,'' said the governor. Last week, New York Republicans chose Manhattan economist Pierre Rinfret, a 66-year-old political unknown, to challenge Cuomo. The governor announced his re-election plans Sunday during a visit to campaign workers preparing for the convention. Former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro told reporters that if Cuomo wanted it, he could get the Democratic nomination for president in 1992. She said Democrats she has talked to ``believe that he can be the person who can carry the Democrats to the White House in 1992.''

DOC.HEAD: 13 Extremists, 22 Others Killed in Sikh Separatist Violence
DOC.TEXT: Police shot to death 13 suspected Sikh extremists, and at least 22 other people were killed in a renewed bout of separatist violence in the northern state of Punjab, news reports said Tuesday. The killings occurred in separate incidents during a 24-hour period ending Tuesday night. They were reported on the sixth anniversary of an Indian army raid on the Sikhs' holiest shrine, the Golden Temple. At least 1,200 people were killed when troops backed by heavy artillery attacked the temple in Amritsar on June 3, 1984, to flush out Sikh militants entrenched inside. The assault lasted four days. The government increased security around the Golden Temple on Tuesday and prohibited a special congregation planned for inside the shrine to mark the anniversary of the raid, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. In a dispatch from the Punjab state capital of Chandigarh, PTI said the 13 Sikhs killed by police included three who were about to set fire to a railroad station building in Punjab early Tuesday. Police found two AK-47 assault rifles, kerosene cans and matchboxes with the victims, PTI said. It said the three men belonged to the Khalistan Commando Force, one of the several militant groups in Punjab fighting for a separate Sikh homeland. Khalistan is the name of the Sikhs' proposed homeland. PTI said among the other militants killed were Harcharan Singh of the Khalistan Liberation Front and Kashmira Singh, a self-styled lieutenant general of Babbar Khalsa, or the Pure Lion. The two groups and the Khalistan Commando Force are among the top Sikh militant organizations in Punjab, a rich farming state bordering Pakistan. In other violence blamed on the Sikh campaign, Press Trust said five armed youths raided a house in Chogwan village, 230 miles north of New Delhi, and fatally shot a couple and their daughter late Monday. In another incident, a man and his daughter were burned to death by unidentified assailants, PTI said. It did not say where or when it happened. It said extremists killed 17 other people in separate incidents in the state but did not give details. The deaths raised to 1,036 the number of people killed this year in the Sikh separatist violence. Many of the victims have been from the state's minority Hindu community, but militants have also targeted Sikhs who do not support their cause. Sikh militants have been fighting since 1982 for an independent homeland in Punjab, where Sikhs are in a slight majority over Hindus. The Sikhs claim they are discriminated against by the Hindus, who make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Legislators Move On School Finace Overhaul Measures
With PM-New Jersey Schools
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate today approved a $528 million compromise plan to overhaul the school finance system, and the House passed a sales tax increase to pay for the reform bill. The school finance reform bill was sent to the House on a 29-1 vote. The money-raising measures go to the Senate for consideration, including a quarter-cent sales tax increase and boosts in the levies on tobacco, that passed the House on a 117-23 vote. Lawmakers are in the second day of a record sixth special session, and state leaders have predicted quick passage of the school finance overhaul. ``We're going to put it on the fast track and hope we can get it out of here within the next four or five days,'' House Speaker Gib Lewis, a Democrat from Fort Worth, said as lawmakers convened in special session Monday. The compromise plan for the 1990-91 school year was worked out among Democratic legislative leaders and Republican Gov. Bill Clements on Friday in response to a Texas Supreme Court order to make more money available to poor school districts. A similar order was issued today in New Jersey; and 11 other states also have been under court order to overhaul their school financing to make sure children in poor districts don't get shortchanged. In addition to addressing financing, the Texas education bill would make a number of changes designed to improve education performance and accountability. Among other items, it would allow expansion of the pre-kindergarten program to 3-year-olds in 1992; increase testing of students; and give the governor the authority to appoint the state education commissioner who would have the power to appoint new management for problem school districts for up to three years. Clements killed two previous school finance reform plans after objecting to lawmakers' plan to help pay for them with a half-cent increase in the sales tax. The new compromise calls for a quarter-cent increase, to 6\ from 6 cents per dollar. When he agreed to the tax increase Friday, Clements said there was no other way to enact a school reform plan without court intervention. He called lawmakers into their fourth consecutive special session on school finance reform, following two last year on workers' compensation.

DOC.HEAD: Art Historian McElroy Dies From Embolism
DOC.TEXT: Guy C. McElroy, an art historian who organized an exhibition on the portrayal of black people in American art, died last week of a pulmonary embolism, it was learned Tuesday. He was 44. McElroy conceived the show titled ``Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940,'' four years ago and was guest curator at the Corcoran Gallery of Art, where the exhibition opened last January. The show is now appearing at the Brooklyn Museum in New York. McElroy had held curatorial posts in museums and public galleries on the East and West coasts since the mid-1970s. When he died Thursday at George Washington University Hospital here, he had nearly completed work toward a doctorate in art history from the University of Maryland and had begun work on an exhibition on black educator Mary McLeod Bethune for the Bethune Museum-Archive in Washington. A native of Fairmont, W.Va., McElroy held master's degrees in art history from the University of Cincinnati and in mass communications from Emerson College in Boston. He was a former Rockefeller fellow in museum studies at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``Tonight Show'' producer Fred De Cordova was listed in stable condition in a North Carolina hospital following surgery for an aneurysm, NBC said. De Cordova, 79, who has produced ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' for two decades, underwent the surgery Friday for an aneurysm of the aorta, network spokeswoman Merry Aronson said Monday. She said he was taken to an undisclosed hospital Friday from his hotel in the Winston-Salem area, where he was playing golf. Ms. Aronson didn't specify what type of aortic aneurysm De Cordova had. She also didn't elaborate on his condition, saying only that he was stable. After a stint as a stage director that ended with ``Ziegfeld Follies'' in 1943, De Cordova signed with Warner Bros. He directed about 50 films, including ``Bedtime for Bonzo,'' starring Ronald Reagan and a chimpanzee. In 1953, De Cordova moved to television, directing or producing ``My Three Sons,'' ``Burns and Allen'' and ``The Jack Benny Show,'' before joining Carson in what he has called ``the best job in television.''

Garrison Keillor returned home and told former neighbors they didn't inspire whimsical Lake Wobegon, the fictitious town made famous in his radio show, ``A Prairie Home Companion.'' ``Lake Wobegon is not about Anoka,'' he said Monday. ``It's a romance, a comic romance, and Anoka is a real place and it's infinitely more complicated and interesting.'' He also delivered the commencement address at Anoka High School, telling students: ``Graduation is a graceful and sweet old ceremony. What it means is that it's time to gather your stuff together and get out.'' The author and humorist thanked his hometown for helping spawn the insecurity he says he needed to become a writer. ``On the off chance that Anoka might feel bad, might feel guilty for making me feel inferior, I came back to say it's all right,'' he said. Keillor, 47, has written four books. He lives in New York and is host of a new public-radio show, ``The American Radio Company of the Air.''

Actress Judy Carne, who delivered the slapstick straight line ``Sock it to me'' on ``Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In,'' pleaded guilty to a contempt of court charge and was fined $250. A prescription forgery charge was dismissed in the court action Monday. Both charges date to 1979, when Miss Carne was accused of heroin possession and prescription forgery while appearing at a Cincinnati-area dinner theater. She was acquitted of heroin possession but the jury could not reach a verdict on the prescription forgery charge. The contempt charge was filed when Miss Carne failed to appear for her forgery retrial. Miss Carne, who divides her time in England and the United States, faced renewed prosecution after a routine computer check by customs agents at a New York airport May 19 revealed the warrant.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version of this item also moved on sports lines.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle congratulated Michigan fans on the Detroit Pistons' repeat appearance in the NBA finals, but reminded them the team was born in the nation's basketball heartland. ``I want everyone to know the Detroit Pistons came from Indiana,'' the native Hoosier said Monday at a fund-raising luncheon. The remarks by the former U.S. senator from Indiana came on the eve of Game 1 of the seven-game series between Detroit and the Portland Trail Blazers. The defending National Basketball Association champion Pistons originated as the Fort Wayne Pistons, and moved to Detroit in 1957. Quayle picked Detroit to repeat as NBA champs in ``more than four, perhaps not seven'' games. Hinting that a politician's sports picks should be taken with a grain of salt, Quayle said jokingly, ``Now, tonight, I'm flying to Oregon.''

Beach volleyball king Sinjin Smith is the quintessential Californian _ tall, blond, tan and toothsome _ and People magazine just tagged him one of the world's most beautiful people. ``Looks are really a subjective thing. Among my peers it's a joke,'' Smith said of the honor. ``They don't know how to react. I mean, I'm one of the guys, and then all of a sudden there I am with other people like Paul Newman and Tom Cruise.'' Smith is part of People's ``photo spectacular extra'' issue, now on the stands, which lists 50 people picked as the world's most beautiful. The 33-year-old spiker joins the likes of Newman, Cruise, Michelle Pfeiffer and Isabella Rossellini. Smith credits the flourishing popularity of professional beach volleyball for his sudden rise to fame. ``What other sport can you see guys without shirts running around diving, doing all this stuff, showing their rippling muscles and the fans can sit five feet away?'' he asks. Smith, dubbed the ``King of Beach Volleyball,'' is the most successful player in the sport's history with more than 100 tournament wins. He has appeared on TV in ``Magnum, P.I.'' and the recent ``Sideout'' beach movie. ``Some people may see me as the male equivalent of a bimbo, a beach bum, you know, sitting around the beach all week waiting for the tournaments to come around so I can make some dough,'' Smith said. ``They don't realize there's so much more involved than just what they see.''

DOC.HEAD: Uzbek-Kirghiz Clashes Flare in Soviet Central Asia
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: New ethnic rioting surged through the Central Asian city of Osh on Tuesday, and the Soviet media reported a state of emergency was imposed after 11 people were killed. Houses and cars were burned and and more than 200 people were reported injured in the clashes between Uzbeks and Kirghiz in Osh, a Kirghizian city on the border with Uzbekistan. The fighting began Monday over a land disupte between the two predominantly Moslem ethnic groups. Soviet troops were unable to control the situation. It was the latest outbreak of ethnic fighting in the Soviet Union and occurred as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was concluding his summit in the Unites States and returned to face an array of domestic troubles. Battles continued Tuesday between groups numbering between 200 and 600, the Interfax news agency reported. It said among the dead were a master sergeant of the Interior Ministry troops and a police cadet. ``The situation is very grave and it's getting worse,'' said Khalil Tashmatov, head of the Osh branch of the Interior Ministry, in a telephone interview. ``There are cases of pogroms and houses being burned down,'' he said. He said Soviet troops were trying to maintain order but ``there aren't enough of them.'' At least seven houses were set ablaze along with eight cars Monday night in the city of about 210,000, according to reports from Tass and Interfax, which is affiliated with state-run Radio Moscow. At least 51 people were arrested, and a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew was in force in Osh. Interior Ministry troops patrolled the streets, setting up roadblocks and guarding industrial sites, Tass and Interfax said. Maj. Gen. Viktor Goncharov, the interior minister of Kirghizia, was appointed military commander of the region, they said. The dispute reportedly centered on plots of land claimed by both sides near the city, which has Central Asia's largest silk factory. Kirghizia lies in the Tien Shan and Pamir mountains and borders western China. A group of Kirghiz who wanted new housing occupied the land to begin constructing houses. Uzbeks, who make up 30 percent of the population, demanded they also receive land for housing, Tass said. Tashmatov accused activists of a group known as Osaimagy, the Kirghiz word for circle, of claiming the land illegally and sparking the dispute. Housing is critically short in the republics of Central Asia. Earlier violence in the region was triggered in part by fears that the government had plans to give apartments to refugees fleeing ethnic unrest in other parts of the country. Interfax and Tass said about 10,000 Uzbeks gathered Monday to protest in the field of a collective farm and faced off against about 1,500 Kirghiz. Premier Apas Dzhumagulov of Kirghizia, Communist Party Secretary Medetkan Sherimkulov and other officials spoke to them and tried to calm the situation. But at about 6 p.m., a large group of Kirghiz came to the site, the news services said. A group of about 900 Interior Ministry troops and local police fired blanks to disperse the crowd, they reported, but groups rampaged through the city, setting fires and trying to attack Interior Ministry headquarters. Of the 200 injured, 111 were hospitalized, some with bullet wounds, Tass and Interfax said. Among the injured were 21 police officers. Emoldened by Gorbachev's reforms, residents of Central Asian republics such as Kirghizia and Uzbekistan have been expressing their religious, ethnic, political and economic concerns. Some have vented their frustrations through violence. There has been ethnic violence in Tadzhikistan, and Soviet soldiers remain in the republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to control ethnic violence that has wracked the two republics for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Golf Tourneys, Conferences Lure Lawmakers With Free Trips
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dan Burton is a popular figure at charity golf tournaments, where he's among a small circle of lawmakers who get free flights, meals and lodging for being a celebrity player. Tournament sponsors and airlines pay for the tickets, food and hotel rooms. Lawmakers who love golf get the perk even if they're not the national celebrities charity tournaments like to attract. House financial disclosure records released last week showed that Burton, an Indiana Republican without a national following, participated in six tournaments in 1989. Others with multiple appearances at such tournaments include Rep. Marty Russo, D-Ill., Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee, and Minority Leader Bob Michel, also from Illinois. The trips are examples of the lifestyle that members of Congress may live _ partially at others' expense _ within the rules of the House and Senate. House members last year got free trips, lodging and meals for going conferences at Florida's five-star Boca Raton Resort, the island of St. Croix, Palm Springs, Calif., Montego Bay, Jamaica, and a mountain retreat in Switzerland. ``Members of Congress who like to play golf _ when they're not in session and there's no business in the district _ can help charity and have fun,'' Burton said. ``It's a respite we really enjoy.'' Burton had a busy golf schedule in 1989: the Bob Hope Classic in Palm Springs in January; the Kemper Open in Washington in May; the Larry Bird Youth Links tournament in Indianapolis (his district) in June; the Arte Johnson golf tournament in Chicago in July; the Danny Thompson Memorial tournament in Sun Valley, Idaho, in August; and the Sugarloaf Invitation tournament in Maine in September. Burton said he paid his own way to the Hope tournament and stayed with friends. All the tournaments, he said, donated profits to charity. The financial disclosure records showed that Burton participated in six golf tournaments in 1989, Rostenkowski in five, Russo in three and Michel in two. Russo's disclosure showed he received round-trip air transportation from Chicago to West Palm Beach, Fla., five days lodging and travel expenses to take part in the Chrysler Team Championship Golf Tournament. The records show that golf outings, and more traditional trips to conferences sponsored by special-interest groups, often appear more valuable than the $2,000 per speech that lawmakers may earn for addressing those organizations. The free perks will become even more precious to House members Jan. 1, when honoraria will be banned in return for a hefty pay raise. This year, House members are allowed to earn the same amount of honoraria as last year, $26,850. Senators are still allowed honoraria and may keep it until the figure reaches 40 percent of their salary. The remainder is donated to charity. Rostenkowski played in the Hope Classic, the Kemper Open, the Helene Curtis Pro Am, the J.C. Penney tournament in Largo, Fla., and the Chrysler Team Championship in Wellington, Fla. Rostenkowski, led the House in honoraria, earning $285,000 and giving $258,150 to charity. Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., was among the congressional guests at the four-day Securities Industry Association conference at the Boca Raton Resort in Florida. The resort has 29 tennis courts, a 23-slip marina, rooms that range from $195-$340 per night and suites that start at $380 nightly. Association spokesman Art Samansky said lawmakers ``discuss industry conditions and trends or areas of legislation which may be of interest to the securities industry.'' Farleigh Dickinson University, with its main campuses in New Jersey, invited 11 House members and 10 members of the British Parliament to a four-day conference in the U.S. Virgin Islands. While conferees used the school's St. Croix campus to promote understanding between the two nations' legislators, the school paid for rooms at the Divi Resort, which had a major water sports facility. The entire complex later suffered extensive damage from Hurricane Hugo. ``There are junkets and there are more legitimate things. This was legitimate and an important conference,'' said university spokeswoman Alice Olick. The school paid for lawmakers' rooms, meals and transportation. The Aspen Institute, a Colorado-based research group, arranges retreats around the world for lawmakers who serve on its advisory panels. The lawmakers discuss U.S. relations with the Soviet Union, southern Africa and Indochina. When former Sen. Dick Clark launched the institute's congressional retreats five years ago, he chose a site not too far from Washington _ North Carolina's Eastern Shore. ``It was just a ... disaster to be honest,'' he said. The invited lawmakers came late and left early because of changing events in Washington, just a short flight away. Even when they attended the seminars, Clark said, they spent half their time on the phone. So Clark literally searched the globe for a solution. The itinerary last year was: Jamaica in January; Bermuda in March; a mountain retreat in Switzerland in August, followed weeks later by several days in Dubrovnik, Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Benny Goodman Orrchestra Singer Dies
DOC.TEXT: Art Lund, a singer and actor who was the first male lead singer with the Benny Goodman Orchestra, has died. He was 75. Funeral services were held Monday in this Salt Lake City suburb for Lund, who died Thursday. Burial is scheduled for Wednesday at the Hollywood Hills Forest Lawn in California. The cause of death was not available. Lund, who was born in Salt Lake City, joined Goodman's orchestra after a band member heard him sing in Kentucky and asked him to audition. While with the orchestra, Lund earned five gold records, including for ``Blue Skies'' and ``My Blue Heaven.'' In 1942, he joined the Navy and rose to lieutenant commander, serving in the Pacific for four years. After the war, he rejoined Goodman's band. He also starred in several Broadway productions, playing the original Joey in ``Most Happy Fella.'' Lund's movies included ``The Molly Maguires'' and ``The Last American Hero.'' He appeared in television programs such as ``Gunsmoke,'' ``The Rockford Files'' and ``Little House on the Prairie.'' In the 1960s, Lund was honored by the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Lund's first wife, Kathleen Virginia Bolanz, died in 1969. In 1989, Lund married Janet Burris Chytraus in Solvang, Calif. The couple moved to Holladay in April.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises GI Bill at Rose Garden Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs `Among those ...' to CORRECT Montgomery's party affliation to Democrat, sted Republican
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX12
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid tribute Tuesday to the peacetime GI Bill, saying the college benefits are helping the armed forces attract better recruits than ever. The Rose Garden ceremony honored the program as the number of participants reached the 1 million mark. Bush, who was among the first wave of veterans to head off to college on the original GI Bill, said the version enacted in 1984 is ``an important component in the success of America's all-volunteer forces.'' It allows recruits on active duty or the reserves to draw a basic benefit of up to $10,800 for college, in part by having their pay reduced by $100-a-month for 12 months. Among those attending were Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., the chief sponsor of the legislation, Secretary of Transportation Samuel Skinner, top military brass. A dozen enlisted men and women from the Army, Air Force, Navy, Marines, Coast Guard, National Guard and the reserves joined Bush on stage as representatives of the 1 million program participants. The Montgomery GI Bill provides up to $300 a month in benefits for full-time students, but Montgomery wants to raise the monthly stipend to $400. Bush, a close friend of Montgomery's, said the GI Bill ``ranks among the most practical and cost-efficient programs ever devised.'' Cheney called it crucial for recruitment and retention. He said reserves were ``twice as likely to stay in the reserves'' in 1985-88 if they were saving for college. ``The size of our force may come down in the future, but quality must remain at the absolute top,'' Cheney said. ``The GI Bill will help us do that.'' Bush, a Navy torpedo bomber pilot in World War II, said he was among the first 40,000 veterans to use the GI Bill when he went to Yale in 1945. ``The GI Bill changed the lives of millions by replacing old roadblocks with paths of opportunity. ... Really it changed the life of our nation,'' Bush said. The Pentagon says 71.2 percent of all active-duty service members have chosen to participate in the Montgomery program over the past year. It will cost $412 million in fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Police: Air Force Jet in Apparent Collision With Glider, One Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with police saying civilian aircraft apparently a glider, and its pilot was killed; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force jet fighter collided Tuesday with what police said appeared to be a glider, killing the civilian pilot. The F-16 fighter jet returned safely to base and its two-man crew was not hurt, the Air Force said. The accident occurred about 4:30 p.m. near Unkenbach, 62 miles southwest of Frankfurt, the Air Force said in a statement. ``The F-16 returned to Hahn Air Base with minor damage,'' the statement said. ``The condition of the civilian aircraft is unknown,'' it said. Local police said the civilian craft ``was in all likelihood a glider,'' and that the pilot was killed in the collision. A glider is a small plane without a motor that rides air currents. No further information was immediately available. The F-16 was on a training mission at the time, the Air Force said. Hahn Air Force base is near the western city of Trier.

DOC.HEAD: Root Pleads Guilty to Five Felony Charges
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing throughout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer rescued from the Atlantic with a gunshot wound after a mysterious flight down the East Coast pleaded guilty today to five felony charges that he misrepresented clients. Thomas Root, 37, a communications attorney, pleaded guilty to submitting a counterfeit Federal Aviation Administration approval form for a radio tower a client was seeking to erect in Missouri. Root also admitted giving a forged Federal Communications Commission license application for a radio station he was representing in North Carolina, and failing to inform another client that he had accepted a settlement for one-fifth the amount his client authorized. The guilty plea came a day after a North Carolina grand jury returned a 455-count indictment charging Root with securities fraud and other charges. The Alexandria, Va., attorney also pleaded guilty to a charge that he submitted a phony lease option to a Long Island radio station seeking a site to build a radio tower. Root also admitted deceiving a client by falsely telling the radio station that he would get its FCC license renewed. Root would not comment after entering his pleas. His attorney, Eugene Propper, said Root ``feels he's getting a lot more attention'' than he would if he had not made his plane flight, which ended in the waters off Bermuda after Root allegedly passed out with the plane on autopilot. Root has said he was unconscious the entire time, but Navy fighter pilots flying near Root's plane said they saw him moving in the cockpit. Still unexplained is a bullet wound Root suffered from a gun that he had stored in a glove box in the single-engine plane. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said an investigation by federal officials in Florida is ongoing. In Raleigh, N.C., a Nash County grand jury issued indictments against Root and others Monday that totaled 2,695 counts. Indicted were Root, Sonrise Management Services, Telemedia Inc. and three other men identified as co-owners of the two businesses. Root handled radio license applications for investors of Sonrise Management before the Federal Communications Commission. The indictments allege the companies violated securities laws by not registering securities, failing to register sales agents, engaging in false and deceptive sales practices and conspiring to violate securities laws. ``I really don't have any reaction until I see the indictment, except to say that my client is not guilty of any securities fraud,'' said Eugene Propper, Root's Washington attorney. The Columbus, Ga.-based Sonrise Management, which touted Christian principles in sales literature and issued business cards inscribed with crosses, went out of business several months ago. In announcing the indictment, North Carolina Secretary of State Rufus Edmisten said only a handful of Sonrise Management investors ever received FCC licenses. ``In all, 1,018 people in North Carolina contributed more than $8 million to this organization,'' Edmisten said. ``Nationally, more than $16 million was invested by people from 25 states.'' Edmisten said there is little chance investors will recoup their money. ``I wish I could say to all the victims, `We'll get your money back,''' he said. ``But I don't know that we'll ever get a penny back. At the present time, I don't know of any money available to make restitution.'' The other men indicted, Sonrise Chairman Ralph Savage and company President Eugene White, live in Phenix City, Ala. They joined with Carl Hurlebaus, who also was indicted, to form Telemedia in Maryland. Root filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors in October 1989, claiming he had $1.6 million in liabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Postpones Emigration Law Consideration
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature on Tuesday tentatively postponed adoption of a law to ease restrictions on emigration, possibly jeopardizing a summit deal that would vastly increase trade with the United States. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed the trade agreement during this week's Washington summit with President Bush. Bush's only condition for implementing the trade agreement was that the Soviet legislature give final approval to the long-awaited emigration law. But the Supreme Soviet on Tuesday approved an agenda that does not include consideration of the law in its current session, which ends June 14. The Supreme Soviet does not convene again until September. The proposed law would permit emigration for virtually anyone who has entry permission from another country and no outstanding obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets. It would set a basic limit of five years on the length of time a citizen can be kept from emigrating because of access to secrets. There was no explanation for the decision to omit the item from the agenda, and legislators held out the possibility it could still be added during the current session. ``We will look it over and if there is a possibility, we will include this issue.
