We will look it over with the president,'' said Anatoly Lukyanov, the chairman of the legislature's executive committee. Gorbachev returned to Moscow on Tuesday. Reform has allowed lawmakers to criticize the leadership, but Gorbachev and Lukyanov _ his close ally _ almost without exception have managed to bend the legislature to their will. It was not clear whether postponement of the law was made with Gorbachev's approval, whether it was a mistake, or whether other Kremlin leaders engineered the decision, possibly to embarrass the absent leader. The unexpected step could signal that Gorbachev intends to make good on his warning that he might curtail Jewish emigration if Israel continues to settle emigres in occupied territory. Jewish activists in Moscow issued a statement Tuesday protesting the threat, which Gorbachev made at a news conference in Washington on Sunday. ``Soviet authorities have no moral or legal right to dictate to a sovereign government where Jews who have lost their Soviet citizenship should live,'' said the statement read over the telephone by spokesman Oleg Nesterov. The statement called the threat ``one of a series of attempts to use Jews as an object of trade in a political game.'' Another possible reason for the delay might be that the Soviets are not prepared to handle the number of people wanting to emigrate and the demands they will place on transport and visa workers. The government may also be hesitating because an embarassingly high number of people could choose to leave their country. Passage of the emigration law would affect an unknown number of Soviets, including Jews and other ethnic groups. Without it, the Soviet Union will not have access to million dollars in trade with the United States under the summit agreement. The decision to delay consideration angered some Soviet lawmakers. ``We will turn out to be cheats. We won't be trusted. They will say, `Well, they made a promise and again the Soviet Union is deceiving,''' said Nikolai Medvedev, a legislator from Lithuania. He said Soviet officials had promised U.S. senators during the summit that the new emigration law would be approved before the legislative session ends this month. Fyodor Burlatsky, a member of the legislature's International Affairs committee, said in a television interview recently the law would be considered May 31. The law passed on its first reading in November, but final action has been delayed repeatedly by crises over other economic and political reforms. Referring to potential lost trade with the United States, Supreme Soviet member Igor Griazin of Estonia said, ``There are fairly serious economic consequences to not adopting the law on entry and exit.'' Rudolf A. Kuznetsov, head of the visa-issuing agency UVIR, has predicted 5 million to 6 million of the 287 million Soviets would emigrate or travel abroad this year. Last month alone, Soviet authorities issued about 20,000 exit visas. The bill under consideration would codify many changes that have already been put into practice here. For example, procedures required to obtain travel documents and permission to emigrate have been eased tremendously in the last two years. Soviet officials acknowledge that the main obstacles to travel have become the heavy workloads of emigration authorities, shortages of plane and train tickets and problems with currency exchange. Currently, Soviet citizens are allowed to exchange about $300 when they go abroad on a guest or tourist visa, and this puts a strain on the financially strapped Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fighter Jet Collides With Glider; Civilian Killed
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force jet fighter collided in the air Tuesday with a glider, and the pilot of the glider was killed, police said. The F-16 fighter jet returned safely to base, the Air Force said. The accident occurred about 4:30 p.m. near Unkenbach, about 60 miles southwest of Frankfurt, the Air Force said in a statement. ``The F-16 returned to Hahn Air Base with minor damage,'' and the two-man crew was not injured, the Air Force said in a statement. Local police said the civilian aircraft ``was in all likelihood a glider,'' and that the pilot was killed in the collision. No further information was available. The F-16 was on a training mission at the time, said the Air Force.

DOC.HEAD: Unprecedented Soviet-Korea Talks Might Lead to Full Ties
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said Tuesday he hoped his unprecedented talks with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev would lead to full diplomatic ties between the nations and peace on the divided Korean peninsula. The meeting Monday between Roh and Gorbachev in San Francisco was heralded by many as a boost to South Korea's international prestige. But radical students denounced Roh's diplomatic overtures to Communist nations. In a statement, Roh called the encounter, the first between a South Korean and a Soviet leader, ``the greatest diplomatic event'' in South Korea's modern history. Roh said he hoped ``normal bilateral relations between our countries'' would follow. Moscow is a long-time ally of Seoul's archenemy, Communist North Korea. No dates were announced for establishing diplomatic relations, but a Roh aide said that could be expected in the ``not-distant future.'' The South Korean newspaper Dong-a Ilbo said Roh agreed to send Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong to Moscow by July. It quoted high-ranking officials as saying full diplomatic ties could be established by September. Roh said South Korea would also devote efforts to establishing ties with China, also a major ally of North Korea. Roh's announcement was welcomed by most South Koreans, who want to see an easing of hostilities with the Communist north. The Koreas were divided in 1945, fought a bloody war in the early 1950s and remain bitter enemies. ``The summit meeting has not only been a turning point in relations between the two countries, but has also been an epoch-making event that will see an end to the Cold War legacy on the Korean peninsula,'' Roh said in the statement. The nation's two television networks devoted five hours of live satellite and local coverage to Roh's visit. Roh's opponents, however, were critical of Roh's diplomatic maneuver and dissidents said he was trying to escape an internal crisis by diverting attention to foreign affairs. A major alliance of dissident groups said Roh's diplomacy was subservient and that the talks failed to present ``substantial measures'' for peace. Radical students on Tuesday staged scattered protests against Roh. They called for free contacts across the heavily fortified border and unification with North Korea. In southern Kwangju, 2,000 students fought police with firebombs and rocks outside five campuses, according to Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Roh has been pursuing a policy of establishing ties with current and former Communist nations to isolate North Korea. South Korea now maintains relations with all countries in East Europe except Albania and East Germany. South Korea hopes diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union and China will greatly enhance its international prestige and gain acceptance for Seoul as an Asian and world power. The governing Democratic Liberal Party called the Roh-Gorbachev talks, ``the historic first chapter of normalization of relations'' with the Soviet Union. ``The fact that the two met face to face is very important to us,'' said Dr. Rhee Sang-woo, a government adviser and dean at Seoul's Sogang University. ``Regardless of the subjects discussed, the fact they met is most important.'' The Party for Peace and Democracy, the main opposition party, welcomed the prospect of normalizing relations with Moscow, but criticized Roh for taking a low profile. ``It's regrettable President Roh did not bring up (other) issues,'' including a Soviet apology for shooting down a South Korean passenger plane in 1983, a party statement said. Korea was divided when Soviet and U.S. troops ended Japan's colonial rule. The division deepened after the 1950-53 Korean war. Technically, the two Koreas are still at war, with no peace treaty signed. The border is the most heavily fortified in the world. It is sealed by more than 1 million armed soldiers on either side stationed behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Some Minorities Succeed, Many Others Don't
DOC.TEXT: The size of the black middle class has nearly tripled over the past 30 years, but living standards and opportunities for minorities still need much improvement, a group of corporate and academic leaders said Tuesday. A report released by the Business-Higher Education Forum said also that while more than one-third of American blacks and Hispanics would be considered middle class, about 30 percent of minorities live in poverty and that percentage is growing. It said also that minorities are still much more likely to be poor than whites. Forum leaders called for comprehensive efforts to improve living conditions and opportunities for minorities. ``I think we have to work at a variety of ways to do this and if it finally comes down to higher taxes are the only answer, I think we've got to deal with that issue,'' said Steven Mason, a co-chairman of the task force that prepared the report. The report, ``Three Realities: Minority Life in the United States,'' said racism, poor educational attainment, restricted business opportunities and ``the stranglehold of the inner city'' limit minorities' hopes for improving their economic lots. The report called for restructuring public assistance programs such as public housing, food stamps and job training, as well as changing student financial aid programs. It also proposed a number of other reforms. The changes, said the group of more than 90 heads of Fortune 500 corporations and leading colleges and universities, should bolster the country's growing minority middle class and improve living standards and opportunities for unskilled blacks, Hispanics and other poor people. Mason and co-chairman Clifton Wharton, said the majority of the forum members would accept a tax increase to pay for the proposed changes but acknowledged ``it is unclear'' whether the majority included most of the corporate members of the forum. ``I can't speak for all the top executives in the country, I can only really speak for one,'' said Mason, president of The Mead Corp. ``My conviction is that these issues are important enough that they have to be funded.'' Wharton, head of Teachers Insurance Annuity Association of America and the College Retirement Equities Fund, said the forum's report focuses on three categories of blacks and Hispanics _ those in the middle class, those ``at the margin,'' and those living in poverty. The report found: _More than one-third of all blacks and Hispanics would be considered middle class. The study said 60 percent of whites fit that category. Nearly half of all blacks own their homes. About 1.5 million blacks work as managers, business executives and professionals. Nearly 7,000 blacks are elected officials. In 1987, 36 percent of black families had annual incomes of at least $25,000. Among Hispanic families, 40 percent were in that income bracket and owned their homes. More than 3,700 Hispanics hold elective office. _Between 25 and 30 percent of all minorities are living ``at the margin.'' Most of them are either semiskilled or unskilled workers who, while holding jobs, earn minimum wage, moonlight, qualify for some public aid, cannot afford health insurance but do not qualify for Medicaid and rarely receive adequate help from food stamps and unemployment programs. _About 30 percent of minorities live in poverty and that percentage is growing. The poverty rate for blacks was nearly three times that for whites in 1986. Between 1970 and 1980, the poorest population in the five largest cities grew 161 percent. To help the working poor and impoverished move up the ladder, the report recommended that the purchasing power of public employment and training programs keep pace with inflation. The forum also called for full teenage employment by the turn of the century, and full funding of the popular preschool programs Head Start and Chapter One for poor youngsters. Officials said low-income families should be informed when their children are young of financial assistance opportunities for college, and institutions and the federal government should use grants instead of loans to pay for the first two years of college. In addition, the forum said corporations should expand minority recruitment for all positions. ``We argue that the civil rights issue in the United States has changed profoundly in the last 25 years,'' Mason said. ``We are walking on new ground. A generation ago our concern was primarily political equality. Today, the primary issue is economic equity.''

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Soviet-Emigration Law Would Ease Restrictions
With AM-Soviet-Emigration, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The proposed Soviet emigration law would allow emigration for virtually anyone who has permission to enter another country and no outstanding obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets in the Soviet Union. It would also set a basic limit of five years on the length of time a citizen can be kept from emigrating because of access to secrets. Complete details of the proposal are not known. But the bill, which was given preliminary approval by the Supreme Soviet in November, codifies many changes already put into practice in the Soviet Union. The procedures required to obtain travel documents and permission to emigrate have already been eased a great deal in the last two years, releasing a flood of visitors and emigrants across the Soviet borders. Soviet officials acknowledge that the main obstacles to travel have become the heavy workloads of emigration authorities, shortages of plane and train tickets and problems with currency exchange. The financially strapped country can ill afford to allocate hard currency for citizens to spend abroad, officials say. Now, Soviet citizens are allowed to exchange rubles for about $300 when they go abroad on a guest or tourist visa. Before the current liberalization of travel regulations, tens of thousands of Jews and other Soviets were refused exit visas, becoming known as ``refuseniks.'' Their plight brought repeated censure from the West. Because there has been no legal limit on how long a person could be denied exit on the grounds he knew state secrets, there have been cases of refuseniks being denied visas for up to 20 years. Activists say there are still dozens if not hundreds of refuseniks, held because of state secrets or because relatives have refused to sign papers giving them permission to leave. But most former refuseniks have left, and less than 1 percent of applications to emigrate are currently being turned down, according to visa officials.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Trucker Strike Temporarily Isolates US Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Vote scheduled to begin around 10 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: They were running out of gasoline and milk but not imagination in Point Roberts, a tiny finger of the United States whose lifeline was temporarily severed by a western Canadian truckers' strike. Point Roberts, on the tip of a peninsula, can be reached only by boat or by roads through British Columbia. It's about 25 miles from the Canada-U.S. border crossing at Blaine, about 100 miles north of Seattle. So when striking truckers set up border blockades on Friday, gasoline, grocery and other delivery trucks from the United States couldn't get through to stores that serve its 750 residents. A tentative settlement was announced Monday in the strike by 3,000 independent truckers that began May 27. But strikers said it doesn't meet their pay demands. A vote on the agreement was scheduled for late Tuesday. The blockade was lifted Tuesday morning after Royal Canadian Mounted Police using a court order cleared the trucks. ``Beer trucks are rolling and the milk truck hopefully is en route,'' said Lisa Jackson, co-owner of Ben's Department Store, a 62-year-old institution that once was Point Roberts' only business. At the Marketplace supermarket, manager Mike Schouten said suppliers were rushing up meat, produce and dairy products. ``I will try to carry a little extra on hand, but you can't put two weeks worth of milk in the cooler,'' Schouten said Tuesday. The days without deliveries brought out ``Out of Gas'' signs at service stations. Schouten was limiting milk to one gallon per customer. ``Some people were hoarding eight to 10 gallons at a time,'' he said. The store had hired private fishing boats to bring limited supplies of perishable goods and Schouten said he planned to keep those channels open in case the border closed again. ``I'm crossing my fingers and really hoping for the best but when you're dealing with this type of situation you never know what will happen,'' he said. Point Roberts residents can drive a few miles to the suburbs of Vancouver, British Columbia, to buy supplies, but the prices are higher. In Point Roberts, gasoline costs half as much as in Canada, and cigarettes and other products are also generally cheaper, said Cindy Hammer, another owner of Ben's Department Store. The store ran out of gas, and many of its customers, on Sunday, she said. The local Chevron station closed Saturday and reopened Monday when owner Jack Graham purchased 9,000 gallons of gasoline from a Canadian supplier. The blockade highlighted the difficulties for town's residents who live in isolation from the U.S. mainland and have to cross one border into Canada and another back into the United States to reach the rest of their country. The treaty establishing the 49th Parallel as the border between Canada and the United States left the tiny town to the United States. There is no school, so students are bused across the borders to Blaine for classes each day. Residents rely on tourists, drawn by a beautiful coastline, and Canadians looking to save money by shopping in the United States. ``Some like it and some don't,'' said Postmaster Dean Nelson. ``It gets to them sitting in the (border) lineups.'' Even local government becomes complicated. Point Roberts is in Whatcom County. The county seat of Bellingham is about 50 miles and two borders away. ``It took us two years to get a blinking light'' at a busy intersection, said Shelley Damewood, who works at the post office. ``Now we're trying to get a stop sign.'' The proposed settlement covering 60 of 180 trucking companies involved in the dispute was announced Monday by Bryan Williams, the strike's chief mediator for the government of British Columbia. Williams did not disclose terms of Monday's agreement. But Bruce Butler, a member of the Western Owner Operators Association, which represents the independent drivers, said it would boost hauling rates to $35 an hour (Canadian), or $5 less than the strikers sought.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Blames Shifting River Bed In Bridge Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials on Tuesday blamed a shifting river channel for the 1989 collapse of a Tennessee highway bridge that killed eight motorists, but investigators said state officials should have corrected the problem a decade ago. The National Transportation Safety Board, expressing concern about thousands of other bridges throughout the country, also cited the 54-year-old structure's simple design as a contributing factor in the April 1, 1989, collapse. The bridge carried the two northbound lanes of U.S. 51 over the Hatchie River, 45 miles north of Memphis. The board cited the Tennessee Department of Transportation for failing to evaluate and correct problems found in inspections dating back to 1979. The river channel has moved 83 feet since the bridge was constructed in 1936, investigators said. The board voted 3-1 on the probable cause and 4-0 on a set of recommendations to federal and state officials. Board member Jim Burnett said he would not support the conclusion until further inspection after missing bridge parts are recovered. The board's investigation remains open, said Chairman James Kolstad, and could be revised if evidence surfaces that points to further deficiencies in the bridge. Investigators told the board that bridge parts might be raised from the water in about two weeks. Kolstad said Tennessee officials ``need to improve their inspections and maintenance procedures. They recognized the problem but they did not evaluate it; they did not take action to correct the situation,'' Kolstad said. He said recent flooding in the South increases the danger of bridges being undermined. ``I'm concerned that some of these bridges may be put back into service without adequate inspection,'' Kolstad said. The board said it was unlikely that a fracture in any of the concrete columns of the Tennessee bridge triggered the collapse. It said the bridge failed ``most likely'' from the deterioration of timber piles that were originally buried and not designed to be in water. The fact that the piles were improperly exposed to the river channel was known as early as 1979, inspectors said. The NTSB staff also had blamed the accident partly on construction of an adjacent bridge in 1974 to carry U.S. 51's southbound lanes, which their draft report said accelerated the shift in the river channel. But the board said the collapse would have occurred eventually, even without the new bridge and deleted the southbound bridge as a contributing factor. The final report said, however, ``Enough information and guidance was available for the designers of the southbound bridge to have discovered the natural channel meander of the Hatchie River, and to have anticipated that further migration would undermine ... the northbound bridge.'' The report said the drivers of passenger cars and trucks on the bridge had no way of avoiding the accident. It also said emergency crews could have done nothing more to reduce its severity. Board members also cautioned Tennessee authorities against allowing so many exemptions to vehicle weight restrictions on bridges _ about 70 a month for the Hatchie bridge before it collapsed _ and called for closer scrutiny of overweight trucks and their impact on bridge safety.

DOC.HEAD: Government Under Pressure to Rescue War Crimes Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The government came under fierce pressure Tuesday to rescue Nazi war crimes legislation thrown out by the House of Lords. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, facing angry lawmakers in the House of Commons, said she recognized ``the extremely strong feelings because of the hideous nature of these crimes.'' However, she made no commitment to invoke a rarely used parliamentary act and force the bill through the unelected House of Lords, which consists of hereditary peers, judges, church leaders and politicians given lifetime titles. The bill, which would have allowed prosecution of elderly, suspected war criminals living in Britain, was passed in the Commons in December. Mrs. Thatcher voted in favor of the legislation. The War Crimes Bill was supposed to become law in July, but the Lords voted 207-74 on Tuesday to defeat it. ``We will be considering very carefully ... how best to proceed bearing in mind the size of the majority in this House on a free vote,'' Mrs. Thatcher told lawmakers. ``It may be that the House itself will wish to discuss the matter.'' The government's options are to abandon the bill, have the House of Commons vote on whether to reintroduce it, or simply reintroduce it in the fall. The government has not revived a bill voted down in the House of Lords since 1949. It is rare for the Lords to vote against proposed legislation. Traditionally, it revises clauses in legislation but does not reject outright Commons' bills. The Lords' powers are limited to delaying measures for a year and they could not reject the bill a second time. The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which submitted a list of Nazi suspects to the government in 1986, said it was ``deeply upset'' at the Lords' vote. ``I think it is unthinkable that this country, which suffered so much at the hands of the Nazis, continues to give a haven to some of Hitler's worst henchmen,'' said Ephraim Zuroff, head of the Israeli section of the Los Angeles-based Wiesenthal Center. Opponents of the bill in the House of Lords argued that it would be impossible to hold fair trials after 50 years and that prosecutions would amount to ``show trials'' of old men and stir up old hatreds. The vote left Britain the only one of the World War II allied powers without laws to prosecute suspected war criminals. ``Australia, Canada and the United States, countries with legal systems not dissimilar to our own, who do not take second place to us with regard to human rights, have legislated long ago,'' legislator Sir Bernard Braine declared in the Commons. Jewish groups also demanded revival of the bill. A government-appointed commission that investigated the Wiesenthal list of Nazi war criminals recommended speedy prosecutions for three suspects and said another 124 cases should be investigated. The suspects allegedly helped round up and murder thousands of Jews in Nazi-occupied Soviet republics. The commission kept the suspects' names confidential. The only one repeatedly identified in the British media, Lithuanian-born Antanas Gecas, 74, acknowledges serving in an auxiliary police battalion, but says he took no part in atrocities and claims to be the victim of a Soviet smear campaign. A $1 million libel suit brought by Gecas, a retired mining engineer who lives in Scotland, against the Times of London was settled Tuesday before going to trial in Edinburgh. The Times said it had wrongly identified Gecas as an officer of Hitler's notorious SS and as the member of a specialist murder squad. The Times said it agreed to make a contribution to Gecas' legal fees but was not paying him any damages. ``I am not only dismayed, I am disgusted,'' said Lord Cocks, a Labor peer, who supported the bill. ``... the House of Lords has gratuitously stirred up this constitutional issue of the Lords vs. the Commons.'' Lord Mayhew, 74, a leading opponent of the bill, said, ``It's a good day for the House of Lords. Frankly, I don't think the government are going to bring it (the bill) forward again.'' Like many of the lords opposed to prosecution, Mayhew served as an officer in World War II. He helped liberate the Belsen concentration camp as the Nazis retreated in 1945, saw top Nazis sentenced to death at the postwar trials in Nuremberg and screened other war criminals for deportation and death in Communist countries. ``I don't regret it,'' he said in the debate Monday night. ``But it was plain then, plain beyond any doubt, that this grim process of retribution could not go on forever.''

DOC.HEAD: King's Condition Improves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with king's condition being upgraded, statement by hospital; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: King Olav of Norway improved Tuesday from a stroke that left him suffering from partial paralysis and pneumonia, his doctors said. The national hospital in Oslo upgraded the condition of the 86-year-old monarch to stable on Tuesday. Olav suffered a stroke Saturday while in the hospital for treatment of a mild infection of the pericardium, the sac around the heart. Well-wishers flooded the palace with flowers, telegrams and letters. The hospital bulletin said new tests showed very limited damage to his brain from the stroke. ``There is still some paralysis in the left side of his body but there has been even more improvement so that he can, to a certain extent, move his arm and hand,'' doctors Rolf Nyberg-Hansen and Erling Brodwell said. The hospital statement said the king ``has no fever and his pneumonia has receded even further. His majesty was able to drink liquids today.'' Olav has reigned since 1957.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Returns from Triumph Abroad to Tumult at Home
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned from the United States on Tuesday triumphantly bearing trade and arms deals but facing ethnic bloodshed in Central Asia, an impasse with the Baltic republics and trouble in the Kremlin. In Gorbachev's absence, his nemesis Boris N. Yeltsin was elected president of Russia, the largest Soviet republic. Yeltsin immediately called for the resignation of the Soviet Cabinet and a new constitution that would vastly reduce the powers of the central government. In the distant reaches of Soviet Central Asia, two Turkic groups clashed Tuesday for the second day along the border between Uzbekistan and Kirghizia. Authorities declared a state of emergency and said 11 people were killed. Along the Baltic coast, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of the secssionist republic of Lithuania reassured her compatriots that American sympathizers would try to block Congress from endorsing a U.S.-Soviet trade deal signed at the summit. And within the ancient red brick walls of the Kremlin, the Supreme Soviet legislature unexpectedly postponed consideration of the emigration law that President Bush set as a precondition for implementing the trade pact. It was not clear whether the postponement was instigated by Gorbachev, who warned Sunday that he might curb emigration of Soviet Jews if they continue to settle on lands occupied by Israel during the 1967 Mideast War. The trade deal, which drew immediate criticism from members of the U.S. Congress, was an unexpected summit triumph for the Soviet president. Bush had said previously he would not sign the agreement until Gorbachev lifted the economic sanctions he imposed against Lithuania after it declared independence March 11. American lawmakers chided Bush for stretching too far to help Gorbachev, who has left the sanctions in place and refused to negotiate with Lithuanians until they suspend their declaration. The Soviet leader also has decreed that the other two Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia, violated the Soviet Constitution by taking less bold steps toward independence, but he has not been able to bring them back into the fold. State-run Soviet television and centrally published newspapers gave blanket coverage to Gorbachev's trip, hailing the agreements he signed to eliminate superpower chemical weapons and complete a treaty to slash long-range nuclear arsenals. The official media also stressed Gorbachev's personal rapport with Bush and with the crowds of Americans who cheered and applauded the Soviet leader at every stop. ``What we would like to have a special say about is the establishing of good personal relations between the Soviet and American presidents, the importance of which could hardly be overestimated,'' reported Pravda, the organ of the Communist Party. The newspaper, devoting nearly its entire front page to Gorbachev's U.S. visit, emphasized the ``purely human compatibility'' evident between Gorbachev and Bush and said it made it possible ``to create a favorable atmosphere for searching together and finding constructive solutions.'' Central television continued its upbeat coverage of Gorbachev's swing across the United States, showing the Kremlin chief meeting with a beaming former President Ronald Reagan and bantering with jubilant American crowds. The main evening television new program Vremya opened at 9 p.m. Tuesday with footage of Gorbachev's presidential airplane touching down at Vnukovo 2 airport. It then broadcast the speech the Soviet leader delivered to cheering students in California on Monday. In Moscow, the mood of rebellion was spreading to the very center of Soviet power. The Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian Federation met in the Kremlin and elected Yeltsin as its president May 29, the day Gorbachev departed Moscow. Gorbachev had opposed Yeltsin's election, saying his plan to shift economic and political decision-making from the central government to the Russian republic could lead to the disintegration of th Soviet Union. But Gennady Gerasimov and Vitaly Churkin, spokesmen traveling with Gorbachev, tried to put the best face on Yeltsin's election, saying it could help the Soviet leader accelerate the pace of reforms. Gorbachev's latest reform package was foundering during his absence, as shoppers continued the rush on stores they began after Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov announced an economic reform package that would triple the price of bread on July 1 and double the cost of most other food starting Jan. 1. Yeltsin, in a Kremlin news conference Wednesday, called for Ryzhkov's resignation, criticized the price hikes and demanded faster transition to a market economy. Gorbachev may have a chance to regain the initiative in domestic affairs in an address he is scheduled to deliver on his trip to the two houses of the Soviet legislature sometime this week. The day for the speech has not been announced.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Root Plea,520
Mystery Pilot Pleads Guilty to Five Felony Charges
DOC.TEXT: Lawyer Thomas Root, plucked from the Atlantic after a mysterious six-hour solo flight during which he was shot, pleaded guilty in federal court Tuesday to five felony charges of misrepresenting clients. Root faces up to 35 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines. In North Carolina, a grand jury Monday returned a 455-count indictment against the Alexandria, Va., communications attorney. The federal charges involved five clients who had been seeking broadcast licenses from the Federal Communications Commission. A federal grand jury returned a 33-count indictment against Root in March. Root, 37, declined comment after entering his plea at U.S. District Court. His attorney, Eugene Propper, said Root ``feels he's getting a lot more attention'' that he otherwise would because of the July 13 flight. Root told authorities that he blacked out during the flight and that the plane continued on autopilot. However, Navy fighter pilots who intercepted the flight said they saw Root moving in the cockpit. The Cessna 210 crashed into the Atlantic off Bermuda. When Root was rescued, he had a gunshot wound to his stomach. The wound has not been explained. Root, who in October filed for bankruptcy court protection from his creditors, has denied that financial and legal troubles were connected with the flight. On Monday, a Nash County grand jury in Raleigh, N.C., returned a 455-count indictment charging Root with securities fraud and other charges. Also indicted were Sonrise Management Services, Telemedia Inc. and three other men identified as co-owners of the two businesses. Root handled radio license applications for investors of Sonrise Management. The indictments allege the companies violated securities laws by not registering securities, failing to register sales agents, engaging in false and deceptive sales practices and conspiring to violate securities laws. In the federal case, Root on Tuesday admitted giving the FCC a counterfeit document stating that the Federal Aviation Administration had approved a proposed Missouri site for a radio tower. He also said he gave a North Carolina client a forged FCC document indicating its license application had been reinstated and defrauded another North Carolina client by settling a claim against a competitor for one-fifth the authorized amount. Root pleaded guilty to giving a false document to a New York client seeking a site on Long Island for a radio station, and falsely telling another client he would get an FCC application reinstated when he had sought the dismissal. The Columbus, Ga.-based Sonrise Management, which touted Christian principles in sales literature and issued business cards inscribed with crosses, went out of business several months ago. North Carolina Secretary of State Rufus Edmisten said only a handful of Sonrise Management investors ever received FCC licenses. ``In all, 1,018 people in North Carolina contributed more than $8 million to this organization,'' Edmisten said. ``Nationally, more than $16 million was invested by people from 25 states.'' Edmisten said there was little chance investors would recoup their money. Root said in his petition for bankruptcy court protection that he had $1.6 million in liabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Scientific Sleuth Says He Reveals Piltdown Perpetrator
DOC.TEXT: Scientific sleuths can rest easy. A Queens College professor says he's solved the decades-old mystery of who masterminded the 1912 Piltdown Man fraud. And it wasn't Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. The Sherlock Holmes author was one of the more colorful ``suspects'' named over the years as perpetrating a hoax that threw many paleontologists off the trail of what is now recognized as the course of human evolution. Others included several noted scientists, a counterfeit jeweler and a philosopher-priest. But Frank Spencer, an anthropologist who has worked on the famous whodunit since the 1970s, said in a telephone interview Tuesday there was never any proof linking the usual suspects. He says diary entries and other information uncovered independently by himself and Australian historian Ian Langham points the finger squarely at Sir Arthur Keith, a well-respected English anatomist. The Langham-Spencer theory is laid out in two books to be published this fall by Oxford University Press. Langham, who worked at the University of Sydney, died in 1984. His widow asked Spencer to continue his work. Piltdown, a small village in England, made international news in 1912 when a skull and other artifacts were discovered by Sussex lawyer Charles Dawson in a gravel pit. ``It was sensational because it offered a completely different view of evolution at the time,'' Spencer said. For those who believed that humans with already enlarged brains evolved earlier than had been supposed, the Piltdown Man was supreme proof. Spencer says Keith, conservator of the Hunterian Museum of the Royal College of Surgeons who died in 1955, was one of the chief cheerleaders of the theory before Piltdown was unearthed. The discovery was debunked in 1953 when scientists learned the remains were a human skull only a couple of hundred years old with an orangutan's jaw joined to it. ``The general feeling was it was contrived to bring somebody down, make someone in the scientific community look silly,'' Spencer said. ``But if that was the case, why didn't they do that?'' Instead, the theory floated around the scientific community for 41 years. ``It makes far more sense when beginning to look at the evidence that Piltdown was something made to withstand scientific scrutiny.'' Spencer says the Piltdown bones were stained to make them look prehistoric and the orangutan teeth were filed down to make them look more like those of a meat-eating human, a ruse Keith had the knowledge and wherewithal to accomplish. But the crux of the Langham-Spencer proof lies in Keith's diaries. In them, Spencer says, Keith ``indicates he had information about the site and events at Piltdown ... information which he wouldn't have had unless he was an inside member of the group.'' Spencer said Keith also had met with Dawson a year before the discovery and again, just several months before. ``In reconstructing the Langham thesis and other evidence I found, I think we've come up with a substantial case,'' Spencer said. Others may disagree. ``Is this the end of the Piltdown affair?'' Dr. William Ball, a former keeper of paleontology at the British Museum, said when asked by The New York Times to respond to Spencer's claims. ``Until such time as an unequivocal, signed and detailed confession comes to light, and one that can be shown to fit the facts as we now know them, I rather doubt it.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Visit a PR Triumph, But No Quick Fix for Soviet People
DOC.TEXT: It was another stunning public relations triumph for Mikhail S. Gorbachev abroad: He won a trade deal, some bank credits and new friends in business. But Gorbachev's weeklong visit to North America yielded no quick fix for the Soviet economy and won't translate soon into tangible improvements in the lives of a frustrated and angry Soviet people. ``Changing a system means changing people, intelligent people,'' Gorbachev told business executives in Minnesota. ``It's not just some kind of layout that you see on a piece of paper and you can just tear up that piece of paper. A system is people, people who live, people who have their own interests, who have their own lives.'' He acknowldged also that people are afraid of change, which he said is why the first five years of perestroika have had such limited results. Referring to his signing of a new trade pact with President Bush in Washington, Gorbachev said the agreement to establish normal trade ties ``is of great political importance.'' But he said it will not have much practical effect ``right now, for the period of transition'' to a market economy. What's more, Bush made very clear during the summit last week that he will not send the trade agreement to Congress for approval until the Soviet Union passes a new emigration law liberalizing restrictions on Soviet citizens who wish to leave the country. The Supreme Soviet legislature Tuesday put off further consideration of the emigration bill at least until its next session, which begins in September. And even if Gorbachev gets the issue back on the calendar, U.S. congressional leaders have said they intend to tie passage of the trade bill to settlement of the Lithuanian crisis, an even thornier dispute over the Baltic republic's declaration of independence from Soviet rule. During Gorbachev's overnight stop in Ottawa at the start of his trip across North America, Canada agreed to extend a $500 million line of credit to the Soviet Union over the next two years to help the Soviets purchase Canadian technology and consumer goods. But last year, when the Soviets decided to spend substantial hard-currency reserves to buy consumer goods abroad in order to show the Soviet people some tangible benefits of reform, the transportation system broke down, and trainloads of such hard-to-find items as toothpaste and laundry soap stacked up on the border because there was no place to unload them. Now, in a classic demonstration of the failure of central planning, the logjam has broken and a glut of imported detergent is stacked on otherwise empty store shelves. Gorbachev repeatedly mentioned during his trip the signing of an agreement with Chevron Corp. to help explore and develop the vast Tengiz oil field in a joint venture with the Soviet government. The field is believed to contain more than twice the petroleum reserves of Alaska's great Prudhoe Bay. But Chevron officials, having already learned the difficulties of doing business with the Soviet Union in a much smaller and less ambitious project, say they expect long and complicated negotiations before any work begins. And it will be years before the Soviet economy or the American oil company begins to reap any reward. A central theme of Gorbachev's visit was that he wants to improve the climate in the Soviet Union for Western business. He not only encouraged captains of industry to invest their capital in his country and cited concessions his government has made to encourage them, he warned that if they don't move now, their reluctance will be remembered later. ``You're wondering could involvement with the Soviet Union become a trap, could you lose money as a result,'' Gorbachev said. Seeking to reassure them, he said, ``Risk is good both in politics and business, but adventurism is bad in both.'' ``The current Soviet leadership is in favor of profound changes, but still it fully intends to do that in a careful way,'' he said. The Soviet president reminded Americans that market systems have been evolving in Western countries for centuries, and he is trying to put one in place practically overnight. He could offer no guarantee that the troubled climate will clear anytime soon. The reforms already introduced have so upset the old system, he said, ``our ship has lost anchor, and therefore we're all a little sick.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Crime Bill a0644
California, 8 Other States Vote in Busiest Spring Primary Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 3rd graf that Gantt would be first black nominated for Senate in NC, not any statewide office; Polls close beginning at 7:30 p.m. EDT in North Carolina; matter below the dash should stand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Covering
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein and John Van de Kamp brawled to the wire for one of 1990's biggest political prizes, the Democratic nomination for governor of California, and voters set lineups Tuesday for fall contests in eight other states. The busiest primary night so far this campaign year saw North Carolina Democrats deciding whether former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt or county prosecutor Mike Easley would get the formidable task of challenging Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. Gantt was bidding to become the first black nominated for U.S. Senate in North Carolina this century. ``I'm ready to get into this fight'' with Helms, Gantt said as he cast his own ballot. ``I'm ready to get it on with him.'' Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, and Van de Kamp, the state attorney general, have spent millions of dollars battling each other and now the winner will plunge into an even more costly and just as nasty general election race against Republican Sen. Pete Wilson. He is trying to keep the California governor's office in GOP control. Voters also were choosing nominees in New Jersey, Alabama, Iowa, South Dakota, Montana, New Mexico, and Mississippi. As usual, California voters also were making decisions on ballot propositions, including two that would strip the legislature of most of its power to redraw legislative, including congressional, district lines. California is likely to gain six U.S. House seats as a result of the 1990 Census. Another California ballot proposal would double the gasoline tax over the next five years and was being watched as a signal of a shift in sentiment in the state where the anti-tax revolt began in the 1970s. Seven senators and three governors were on ballots, none with serious primary opposition. The senators were Democrats Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Howell Heflin of Alabama, Max Baucus of Montana and Tom Harkin of Iowa. The Republicans were Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Pete Domenici of New Mexico and Thad Cochran of Mississippi. Long in advance of their formal nomination in the primary, Harkin and Republican Rep. Tom Tauke began campaigning against each other in what looks like one of the tightest Senate races of the year. Alabama Republican Bill Cabannis was geared to challenge Heflin and Democrat Ted Muenster was taking on Pressler in South Dakota. In Montana, Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad and businessman Bruce Vorhauer were the leading contenders for the Republican nomination to challenge Baucus. Scores of primaries also were deciding the lineups for elections to the House. One incumbent who faced a strong challenge was Democratic Rep. Jim Bates of San Diego, who was rebuked by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harassment of women employees. One of the hottest primaries for a congressional seat was in the New Jersey district represented by James Courter, the unsuccessful GOP candidate for governor in 1989. Courter is not seeking re-election to the House and the Republican contenders to succeed him include Assemblyman Rodney Frelinghuysen, state Sen. Richard A. Zimmer and professional football player Phil McConkey. Marguerite Chandler was unopposed for the Democratic nomination. Gov. Guy Hunt of Alabama, the first Republican elected to that office this century, was bidding for a second term and a crowded field of Democrats was vying to challenge him. Former Gov. Fob James, educator-lobbyist Paul Hubbert, Rep. Ronnie Flippo, and Attorney General Don Siegelman were the leading contenders. No one was expected to get the clear majority needed to avoid a June 26 runoff. In a race in which abortion was a major issue, Iowa Democrats were choosing among Attorney General Tom Miller, House Speaker Don Avenson and banker John Chrystal for the nomination to challenge Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. Avenson and Chrystal support the pro-choice position, while Miller and Branstad are abortion opponents. Republican Gov. Garrey Carruthers of New Mexico was ineligible to seek re-election. Four Democrats, including former Gov. Bruce King, and four Republicans were competing to succeed him. The next governor will be the first allowed to serve two consecutive four-year terms.

South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson had no GOP primary opposition as he seeks a second term. In November he will face former Democratic state Sen. Bob Samuelson. Contrary to political tradition, President Bush and other top GOP officials have not hesitated this year to intervene in party primaries on behalf of candidates they believe would run strongest against Democrats in the fall. The White House helped persuade Wilson _ who didn't need much persuading _ to enter the California governor's race a year after he won a $13 million campaign for re-election to the Senate. Control of the governor's office in California is the highest priority for the leaders of both national parties. After the 1980 Census, Democrats had complete control of the redistricting process in the state and Republicans claim it cost them at least five U.S. House seats. Wilson already has $3.5 million in his campaign bank account and there is speculation the GOP will spend close to $20 million in the race to succeed Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, who decided against seeking a third term. The White House recruited Kolstad to take on Baucus in Montana, but the effort backfired when three other Republicans also entered the race. The latest round of primaries saw no change in the issues mix that has marked other races this year. Nor was there any diminution in the negative tone of campaign commercials. The roughest rhetoric was in the Feinstein-Van de Kamp race and it left some Democrats concerned about prospects for uniting the party in time for the fall campaign. The death penalty, abortion and the environment were common themes. In Iowa, the National Abortion Rights Action League endorsed Avenson out of concern that a Democratic primary victory by Miller would mean the choice in November would be between two abortion foes. Feinstein and Van de Kamp argued over which was more reliably pro-choice. Van de Kamp campaigned over the weekend with Norma McCorvey, who was the ``Jane Roe'' in the Supreme Court's landmark abortion decision. McCorvey endorsed the California attorney general because ``I trust John Van de Kamp to defend the right I fought so hard to win.'' Feinstein countered that as a woman she would be the most reliable guardian of the pro-choice position.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide Says U.S. Making Progress In Improving Environment
DOC.TEXT: An environmental adviser to President Bush said Tuesday that the nation has made remarkable progress in improving the environment over the past two decades ``but we have a long, long way to go.'' Michael Deland, chairman of the president's Council on Environmental Quality, said the next major strides in improving the environment will depend on industries voluntarily preventing pollution because doing so is in their economic interest. The government should not walk away from ensuring that industry complies with environmental laws, Deland told reporters, but he added that ``pollution prevention will not happen by federal or any other level of government fiat.'' Instead, industries and businesses will find ways to reduce pollution because it will be economically beneficial to do so, said Deland, a former regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency. Deland made his remarks in releasing the Council on Environmental Quality's annual report, which this year reviewed environmental progress made over the last 20 years. The 494-page report, which the government sells for $17, provides a generally upbeat review of the country's environmental record since 1970. The document suggested that while environmental problems persist, ``remarkable improvements'' have been made in some areas such as overall air quality. It noted, however, that progress in dealing with pollution in major cities and the protection of wetlands and coastal waters has come slowly. The summary did not deal significantly with such concerns as global warming and the destruction of the ozone layer by manmade pollution, which are relatively new areas of environmental concern. Deland, whose appointment to the president's council was hailed by environmentalists, said a review of the last 20 years show the time ``has been largely a period of success.'' He acknowledged, however, that there are major environmental problems yet to be addressed. ``We are less energy efficient than are the West Germans and the Japanese. We produce more waste, both hazardous and solid, than any other country. ... We recycle at a deplorable rate _ less than 10 percent, the West Germans close to 40 percent and the Japanese approaching 50,'' he said. ``We have without any question,'' he continued, ``a long, long way to go and we recognize that.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Won't Dismiss Any McMartin Molestation Charges
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case on Tuesday refused to dismiss any of the charges in defendant Raymond Buckey's retrial, saying there was no double jeopardy. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg acknowledged that some testimony may not have matched exactly the charges against him. But he said the accounts by three young girls provided sufficient evidence to justify continuing the trial. Defense arguments concerning inconsistencies in testimony can be made to the jury when the case is submitted for decision, the judge said. Under the Constitution, people cannot be subjected to double jeopardy _ being tried a second time on charges for which they wre found innocent. But people can be tried a second time if there is a mistrial rather than an acquittal. Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, argued that the counts on which Buckey was being retried must be presented in the same way as they were in the first trial or it isn't really a retrial, but ``a completely distinct and novel trial proceeding.'' He sought dismissal of five of the eight counts by arguing the testimony didn't match the allegations detailed in the charges. But the judge said, ``I don't find there is a double jeopardy problem. I find this is an erroneous analysis of double jeopardy.'' In the case of one child who testified, Davis said, the prosecution alleged she was molested while seated on Buckey's lap during a ``horsey game.'' On the stand, the child said Buckey was lying prone on the floor and she was on top of him. She denied she was seated on his lap. Another child specifically denied being raped and sodomized with a foreign object, Davis noted, although she alleged other acts of molestation. The other acts are not specified in the charges. The 32-year-old Buckey is being retried on eight molestation charges unresolved by the jury at his first trial _ the longest and costliest criminal case in U.S. history. The first Buckey trial ended in January with Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation and his mother acquitted of 12 charges. But the jury deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey, and the district attorney decided to retry him on eight of those charges involving three girls, now 12 and 13 years old. The girls have testified to assorted acts of molestation but pleaded poor memories on events that are alleged to have occurred when they were toddlers. The McMartin case has been in the courts for seven years. Initially seven defendants, all staff at the now-defunct school, faced molestation charges. Buckey, a former aide at the school, is the remaining defendant. The prosecution rested its case in the second trial Friday after only three weeks of testimony from 12 witnesses, the majority of them children and parents.

DOC.HEAD: No One Injured, Car Dented, Train Gets Towed
DOC.TEXT: When an Amtrak engine slammed into Gifford Austin in his '83 Buick on Tuesday, Gifford was able to walk away, the car suffered some damage to a fender _ and the locomotive was dead in its tracks. Austin, 69, who lives in Peekskill, said he had left his wife at the train station and was driving home when he found himself trapped between crossing gates on the tracks. He said the gates had risen to let him cross, but then came down around his car when he was on the tracks. Then the five-car train came bearing down at 44 mph, police said. Austin said he hard no warning and was unable to get out of the car in time. But after the impact, which pushed the car a distance, he walked away and the two golden retriever puppies who were with him were OK, too. His car's front fender was damaged. The locomotive, however, had to be towed away. The turbo-charged train, which is supposed to be one of the most sophisticated and powerful, ended up with a damaged transmission. The 155 passengers heading to Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan had to board another train. There were no injuries. Traffic wasn't affected on the Metro-North Commuter railroad, which shares tracks with Amtrak. Metro-North spokesman Dan Brucker said train-car collisions usually leave the car obliterated and the train barely nicked. He said the cause of the accident was being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Says Cambodian Accord Will Leave Khmer Rouge Alone
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk said the agreement he signed Tuesday with the government will leave the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas fighting alone. The accord, which fell short of a hoped-for cease-fire in Cambodia's civil war, ended a two-day Tokyo peace conference. The accord said a so-called Supreme National Council, comprised of guerrilla and government representatives, should be formed by the end of July, the same month a timetable for a cease-fire should be established. Sihanouk called the talks a ``50 percent success.'' The powerful, Communist Khmer Rouge, part of a three-faction rebel coalition headed by Sihanouk, boycotted the sessions. The group declined to join the conference unless it was an equal member in the two-sided talks, rather than a part of Sihanouk's resistance coalition. Japanese officials said the Khmer Rouge also refused to sign any accord that linked a cease-fire with the proposed governing body. ``The Khmer Rouge was ready to accept a cease-fire or statements about the desirability of a Supreme National Council, but not a linkage between them, particularly a time linkage,'' a Foreign Ministry official said on condition of anonymity. A second Foreign Ministry official said Khmer Rouge nominal leader Khieu Samphan ``had a rather limited mandate'' for the talks. ``Anything beyond that mandate he had great trouble accepting.'' The conference was heralded as a stepping-stone to a Cambodia peace conference set for Paris in July. The final documents arrived late for the signing ceremony Tuesday evening, drawing an apology from Masaharu Kohno, a Southeast Asia division chief in the Foreign Ministry. Sihanouk signed the communique with Hun Sen, premier of the Phnom Penh government, and Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama acted as chairman. The two Cambodians embraced, then drank a champagne toast to peace in Cambodia. At a news conference, Sihanouk said fighting would continue in Cambodia, but not involving the guerrilla force headed by his son, Prince Ranariddh, or that of his conservative partner, former Premier Son Sann. ``From now on, the Ranariddhists and the Son Sannists will stop fighting,'' he said. ``I can predict that there will be continuation of war in my country between the Khmer Rouge on one side and the Viets and Hun Sennians on the other.'' But a Thai official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was one thing for Sihanouk to say his forces should stop and another thing for the commanders in the field to heed the call. Western observers in Bangkok have long noted a division between Cambodian political figures like Sihanouk, who spend little time in the field and live comfortably elsewhere, and their followers who have a steady flow of munitions to use as they see fit. Fighting was reported to be increasing in Cambodia before the Tokyo conference started. If Sihanouk's prediction is borne out, the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge would be isolated on the battlefield as well as in international opinion. Many have rejected the idea of the Khmer Rouge participating in any future government. During the Khmer Rouge's 1975-79 rule hundreds of thousands of people were killed, or died of starvation. The group was ousted by the Vietnamese. The Khmer Rouge is militarily the strongest guerrilla faction fighting the Phnom Penh government, installed by Hanoi. The 67-year-old Sihanouk has headed the resistance since 1982. He says the Khmer Rouge killed five of his children but still believes the group's force is the strongest barrier to Vietnamese encroachment on Cambodia. The Sihanouk-Hun Sen communique calls for all factions to use ``voluntary self-restraint'' on force, to refrain from offensive actions and to impose a military standstill. The Khmer Rouge said in a statement it was ready to attend the Paris conference.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Cambodian Communique
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Errors in syntax are in the original text.
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the communique signed Tuesday by Cambodian resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Cambodian Premier Hun Sen. It was issued in English.

The delegation of H.R.H. Samdech Norodom Sihanouk and the delegation of H.E. Mr. Hun Sen met in Tokyo June 4-5, 1990, to discuss various issues, with a view to achieving the earliest solution to the Cambodian problem. After intensive deliberations, both sides agreed on the following points. 1. An urgency of implementing a voluntarily self-restraint use of force by all factions. 2. Actual cease-fire must be implemented as a step toward the pending acceptable solution. Furthermore, such undertaking can be realized through a cessation of hostilities and the agreement on the creation of a Supreme National Council (SNC). 3. It is essential for all factions to refrain from all offensive actions including all military operation during the transitional period. This will include a clarification of measures to ensure military standstill and military in place. Such measures would at least ensure that the troops under control remain in their respective positions and refrain from any actions which lead to an extension of territory. 4. The Paris International Conference on Cambodia shall be called upon, with a proper participation of the U.N., to take necessary measures to monitor, supervise and verify the withdrawal of all foreign forces and the cessation of all foreign military assistance, including an implementation of a cease-fire agreement. These measures should be functioned through the ICM. 5. The establishment of an SNC is essential in order to symbolize Cambodia's neutrality, national sovereignty and national unity following the agreement in the Joint Communique signed by H.R.H. Samdech Norodom Sihanouk and H.E. Hun Sen on Feb. 21, 1990, in Bangkok. The SNC shall be composed of equal numbers of prominent personalities from both parties to represent all shades of opinions among the people of Cambodia. The SNC shall be convened and chaired in its first meeting by a member chosen by the SNC. 6. Both sides represented at the Tokyo Meeting hereby declare that the historic monument of Angkor is a non-hostility area. Both sides welcome international community to enlarge its scope of cooperation for the preservation and restoration of this common heritage of mankind. Done and signed by both sides on the Fifth Day of June Nineteen Ninety.

Annex I Pursuant to the Joint Communique agreed on the Fifth Day of June, 1990; it is hereby declared that voluntarily self-restraint use of force shall be implemented by all Cambodian parties on the day when the first meeting of a Supreme National Council is convened. Annex II Pursuant to the Joint Communique agreed on the Fifth Day of June, 1990; it is hereby announced that a Supreme National Council shall be convened not later than the end of July 1990. Annex III Pursuant to the Joint Communique agreed on the Fifth Day of June, 1990; both parties took note of the result of the latest meeting of the five U.N. Security Council permanent members meeting, which had been released on May 26, 1990. Both parties express their willingness to brief the members in the meeting of the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council at appropriate time in the future. Annex IV Pursuant to the Joint Communique agreed on the Fifth Day of June, 1990, both parties called upon the Co-Chairmen of the International Conference on Cambodia to reconvene as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Ship's Slip Nixed
DOC.TEXT: Jan and Henry Cashette waited more than 10 years for their ship to come in. Then when it did, it was too big. The ship's slip was nixed. The Keewaydin State Park where the Cashettes had left their names on a waiting list 10{ years ago called last week with news there was a slip for their 42-foot boat. It was great news for the couple who had kept their boat _ and the two they've bought since _ in private marinas. Then, the couple told the marina operator from Keewaydin near Alexandria Bay about their new 42-foot boat. Sorry, said the marina operator. At the start of the week, the marina stopped taking anything longer than 36 feet. At Keewaydin, which sits on the St. Lawrence River, the marina has 275 people waiting for about 125 slips. That's up from 133 people waiting last year. The top three people signed up in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Lugar Sees Floor Fight With Democrats Over Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Richard Lugar, ranking Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee, said Tuesday he would not compromise with the Democrats to raise target prices and loan rates in the 1990 farm bill. He also said he was not willing to take more acreage out of production or accept shifts in finances to create the illusion of deficit reduction without real cuts. ``I've been infinitely flexible in other things (in the bill),'' he said. But he said these four areas were not negotiable and would lead to a floor fight if the Democratic majority on the committee insists in keeping them in the bill. ``The Democrats have to decide, `Do we want an issue or do we want a bill?''' said Lugar. ``If an issue is what they want, then my guess is we will have a one-year extension.'' Congress passes a farm bill every five years to set agriculture policy, including the degree to which the federal government will subsidize farmers through target prices and loan rates. Current law expires in December, but the Bush administration has said repeatedly that it would accept a one-year extension of existing policies. That is viewed by many in Congress as a strategy that would help U.S. negotiators at international trade talks at which the United States is trying to get other countries to remove subsidies from agricultural products that distort world market prices. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who is actively involved in those talks, has said that U.S. subsidies may have to be adjusted to comply with whatever agreement develops. Lugar mentioned the trade talks in a session with reporters, but said his main objection to the Democrats' proposal for increasing target prices is budgetary. ``At a time when it is fairly likely people may be asked to pay more taxes, for the farm program to be asking for more money is not prudent,'' he said. Lugar said, however, he did not know for sure if a tax increase was going to be proposed by President Bush or congressional leaders who are discussing solutions to the government's spending problems. Lugar's comments preceded a meeting of a Senate Agriculture Committee task force that is trying to compromise the Republican and Democratic proposals on price supports. The Democrats want to increase target prices 1 percent with other increases possible in the last four years of the program, depending on inflation. The House Agriculture Committee, meanwhile, has voted to freeze target prices.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Battle Ground Moved to Louisiana Legislature
DOC.TEXT: State lawmakers lined up what they hope will be high-powered testimony as they begin their to effort write a law that will reach the U.S. Supreme Court and result in strict national limits on abortion. Award-winning geneticist Jerome Lejeune of the Faculty of Medicine of Paris is being flown to Baton Rouge for hearings that start Wednesday. He will testify that life begins at conception. His testimony in a Tennessee case was instrumental in a ruling last year that seven frozen embryos were human beings with constitutional rights. An appeals court is still considering that ruling. Lejeune achieved international recognition for his discovery of the genetic roots of Down's syndrome. Also scheduled to testify: the daughter of a rape victim and a former abortion clinic operator ``who has recanted,'' said Rep. Woody Jenkins. Abortion-rights advocates promised a low-key campaign. ``We will have more home-grown folks to testify because we don't want this to be another Vietnam where you bring in outside resources to fight in our land on this issue,'' said Robin Rothrock, director of an abortion-rights coalition and president of the state League of Women Voters. The fight shifted to Louisiana after the governor of Idaho vetoed a restrictive abortion bill that had been written to go to the Supreme Court. Anti-abortion forces hope the court will overturn its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that allowed for abortion. Those hopes were roused last year when the court ruled in a Missouri case that states have some leeway in restricting abortion. Although most of the focus in Louisiana was on the scheduled eight hours of testimony in the House Criminal Justice Committee, a separate anti-abortion bill was moving through the Senate with less fanfare. A Senate committee approved a bill on Monday that would ban abortions except to save the mother's life. Violators would face maximum 10-year prison sentences. ``That's like my bill and it's good to have two vehicles,'' Jenkins said. ``But we need extensive hearings on the legal, medical and social questions to use in the record for our challenge of Roe vs. Wade. That's what makes the House hearings so important.'' Rothrock said the hearings are designed to stir emotions, rather than shed light. ``A large part of what is going on at this point is a circus atmosphere,'' said Rothrock. ``The issue is whether these bills amount to a legitimate challenge to Roe vs. Wade. With no exceptions and with a criminal penalty, they are blatantly unconstitutional and are not legitimate. We would be wasting up to $3 million in appeals battles at a time when this state has a $600 million shortfall. ``But, with the Legislature, it may be impossible to overcome the emotionalism. That means we have a circus and Louisiana will be made a spectacle.'' A majority of the House Criminal Justice Committee said it wanted an amendment making exceptions for rape, incest and to protect the health and life of the mother. Gov. Buddy Roemer, an abortion foe, said he will veto any bill without those exceptions.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Territorial Dispute, Tokyo Welcomes Soviet-South Korea Meeting
DOC.TEXT: While South Korea's political and trade relations with Moscow develop, Japan's ties to the Soviet Union are tied up in a longstanding dispute over Tokyo's demand for the return of islands seized by the Soviets in World War II. The dispute has prevented the nations from signing a peace treaty since the war ended in 1945, and it was brought up during the superpower summit in Washington. President Bush told Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan that he raised the issue with Mikhail S. Gorbachev during their talks, government spokesman Misoji Sakamoto said. But Sakamoto said Gorbachev did not show a forthcoming attitude on the Kuril Islands, which lie off the northern tip of Japan. Meanwhile, Gorbachev ended his U.S. trip Monday by meeting in San Francisco with President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea. South Korean officials predicted the unprecedented meeting would lead to diplomatic ties between Seoul and Moscow, which were on opposite sides in the Cold War. The Soviets are allies with Communist North Korea, South Korea's archenemy, and they supported the North during the Korean war. But economic and political relations have warmed in recent years, particularly since 1988, when the Soviets participated in the Seoul Olympics despite a boycott by North Korea. Many in Seoul see improved ties with Moscow as a means of easing tensions with the North. Japan on Tuesday also welcomed the Roh-Gorbachev meeting as a way of contributing to stability on the Korean peninsula. ``The summit between the two countries is quite important. We welcome the meeting itself,'' said acting Foreign Ministry spokesman Makoto Yamanaka. ``We hope both countries would further relations so that a relaxation of tension could be obtained on the Korean peninsula.'' ``If South Korea could have stable relations with China and the Soviet Union, that would contribute to the stabilization of the situation on the Korean peninsula,'' Yamanaka said. But he said the North Korean reaction to the talks would be an important factor in determining the effect of Soviet-South Korean rapprochement on stability on the peninsula, which was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945. ``The Japanese government has been trying to engage in a dialogue with North Korea, but so far hasn't received any favorable response at all,'' he added. On the question of the Kuril Islands, Yamanaka said: ``We haven't sensed any sign of flexibility from the Soviet side.'' He added, ``Maybe it's too early.'' The Soviet side has sought increased trade with Japan. But its efforts have been handicapped by the territorial dispute, coupled with wariness among Japanese businessmen toward what they view as risky, often unprofitable investments. Soviet officials have suggested their overture to South Korea was intended to worry Japanese businessmen, who still view the Soviet Union as a potentially vast market for Japanese goods. Japanese officials earlier scoffed at such ideas, saying they were not desperate enough for investment opportunities to compromise their stand on the territorial issue. Despite the diplomatic standoff, Gorbachev said Sunday that he planned to visit Japan sometime next year to discuss increasing economic ties.

DOC.HEAD: Foretich Says He's Not Giving Up Fight To See Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An oral surgeon who waged a bitter court battle over the right to visit his daughter said Tuesday he has not stopped fighting to see the child, who now lives in New Zealand with her mother. ``I just feel it's better for her that I don't engage in a full-blown court battle,'' Dr. Eric Foretich said of his 7-year-old daughter Hilary. ``Let the immigration officials in New Zealand decide.'' ``The case is proceeding in the family court,'' Foretich's New Zealand attorney, Rodney Hansen, told the New Zealand Press Association Tuesday night. NZPA earlier quoted Foretich as saying he was giving up his battle and was resigning himself to Hilary living in New Zealand with her mother, Elizabeth Morgan. Morgan, a plastic surgeon, hid Hilary in New Zealand to evade a Washington judge's 1987 order allowing continued visits by her father. Morgan was imprisoned for 25 months for defying the order. She has accused her former husband of sexually abusing Hilary, a charge he strenuously denies. Foretich rushed to New Zealand in February to see Hilary for the first time in three years after learning the child was living in Christchurch with maternal grandparents. Foretich maintains the girl should be returned to the United States. Morgan has sought permanent residence in New Zealand to stay with her daughter. ``Frankly I'm putting my daughter's interest before my own now and she needs to be out of the paper and out of confrontation,'' Foretich told NZPA.

DOC.HEAD: Distributors Recalling Toys
DOC.TEXT: A major toy distributor on Tuesday recalled 16,000 musical instruments because the paint on them contains too much lead. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said New Jersey-based Toys ``R'' Us was voluntarily recalling its multicolored plastic Music Master Xylophone toys because they contain ``lead in excess of the allowable limit established by federal law.'' The instruments were sold nationwide since 1988 and are labeled ``SX-305, SKN 421944, Shinnihon,'' the commission said. The agency said also that General Toys of Los Angeles was recalling approximately 2,400 windup plastic toys because they may pose both a fatal choking or puncture wound hazard to small children. The second recall includes: The Happy Flapping Car, models 8668 and 8228; The Happy Tricycle Police & Thief Motorcycle, model 636; Cycling Bear, model 6968; Naughty Bear, model 6976 and Ice Cream Van, model 6973. The toys were sold nationwide before March of this year. The CPSC said there had been no reports of injuries involving any of the toys. Consumers should take them away from children and return them to the store where purchased for a refund, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Quayle Criticizes Media for Campaign Coverage; Seeks Fairness
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle said Tuesday that at times during the 1988 campaign the media made her feel ``very angry and terribly vulnerable.'' However, Mrs. Quayle said she had learned much since Dan Quayle was George Bush's vice presidential running mate. ``Let's meet halfway,'' she told an audience of reporters at the National Press Club. ``I only ask for fairness and accuracy.'' Mrs. Quayle said the campaign was a ``baptism by fire for all the Quayles.'' ``Before it was all over, I felt a least a little singed,'' she said. ``It hurt reading stories or seeing reports about a man bearing almost no resemblance to the one I love deeply. ``At times I felt misunderstood, misrepresented, very angry and terribly vulnerable,'' she said. During the campaign, Mrs. Quayle bristled but spoke little except to defend her husband against what she said were unfair attacks, including questions about his decision to join the National Guard during the Vietnam War and his academic performance. ``I put on my armor to do battle for my family, and in the process I froze some of you out,'' she said. ``I regret that. Chalk it up to inexperience or to protectiveness.'' Asked why she decided to talk about the campaign, she said: ``I was hoping that this talk would put it all to rest. ``Every interview I give ... every place I go, I get the same questions _ it's all about the campaign and what we went through in our trial by fire. And I really wanted to move on,'' she said. She said that while she was hurt by some of the coverage of her husband, ``the vice president and I are never people to lay back and let folks trod on us. We fight back, and we fought back as best we knew how.'' Mrs. Quayle said her husband has ``done a fabulous job'' since he took office and ``I'm having the time of my life.'' She said she doesn't want to dwell on the past. ``I want to move forward with the things that are important ... and not talk any more about what I really think was an ugly chapter in journalism and an ugly chapter in my own personal life,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Shoot and Kill Two Palestinian Youth
