DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed an 8-year-old Arab boy Tuesday during a confrontation in a West Bank refugee camp and a 14-year-old Palestinian in the nearby city of Nablus, local reports said. Troops clamped curfews on Nablus and the Askar refugee camp after the shootings. The army confirmed a boy from the Askar Camp was killed when troops fired rubber bullets at Palestinian stone-throwers, but said the boy was 10, not eight. The army spokesman's office said the military commander in Nablus, the West Bank's largest town, was investigating the circumstances. The victim, Ahmad Salama, died at Al Ittihad Hospital in Nablus after being struck by a rubber bullet that penetrated his skull, hospital officials said. The fatality quickly triggered more unrest in Askar as several hundred angry Palestinians gathered for the boy's funeral and some unfurled the outlawed Palestinian flag. Soldiers clamped a curfew on the camp of 9,000 to contain the disturbances, the army said. Salama was the second 8-year-old killed in clashes the past month. According to the Israeli human rights group Betselem, 43 Palestinian children ages 12 and younger have been killed from the December 1987 start of the uprising through May 31. It said 110 other youths, ages 13 to 16, have also been killed by Israelis. The army claims small children frequently are placed at the front of Arab protests, while Palestinians accuse the army of firing without caution and sometimes hitting children who are not demonstrators. In Nablus, a 14-year-old youth was killed Tuesday when troops encountered a group of masked Arab activists carrying axes. Arab journalists said the youths were carrying a loudspeaker and calling for protests to mark the 23rd anniversary of the start of the 1967 Middle East War in which Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt. Army officials said soldiers ordered the Arabs to stop, fired in the air and at then at their legs before shooting directly at the group and killing one of the activists. Arab hospital officials identified the youth as 14-year-old Rami Farid Kamhieh, and said another youth was wounded in the shooting. The violent outbreak came as Palestinians held a general strike throughout the occupied lands to mark the anniversary of Israel's capture of the terrritories. Tuesday's deaths raised to 716 the number of Palestinians killed during the nearly 30-month-old rebellion against Israeli rule in the occupied territories. At least 218 Palestinians have also been slain by fellow Arabs as alleged collaborators with Israel. Forty-five Israelis have been killed in the unrest. In Israel, meanwhile, a magistrate's court judge ordered an Israeli suspected of massacring seven Gazan workers near Tel Aviv last month held an additional 14 days while an investigation continues. The shooting suspect, Ami Popper, 21, of Rishon Lezion near Tel Aviv, had been dishonorably discharged from the army. He was turned in by friends shortly after the attack and is undergoing psychiatric tests by court order. Popper's attorney, David Ofek, contends his client is not psychologically fit to stand trial.

DOC.HEAD: New York City Most Popular Destination With Senators Taking Free Trips
With House Trips, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress sometimes earn speaking fees at fancy resorts, but a survey of privately financed Senate trips found Tuesday that the top destination in 1989 was New York City. All told, senators took at least 506 trips last year paid for with privat funds, primarily to speak before corporate and trade groups, Public Citizen's Congress Watch said Tuesday. There were 44 trips to New York, 28 to Los Angeles, 28 to Chicago, 19 to West Palm Beach, Fla., and 15 to Miami, according to the survey of financial disclosure records released last week. Other cities frequented often were St. Louis, Dallas, Orlando and San Francisco. There were nine trips each to Jamaica and Switzerland. Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., had the most privately paid travel last year with 20 trips. He was followed by Sens. Orrin G. Hatch, R-Utah and James Jeffords, R-Vt., with 14 trips each. Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., had 13 trips, the same as Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va. Tied with 12 trips were Sens. Joseph Biden, D-Del., John Breaux, D-La., Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, Don Nickles, R-Okla., and Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. Public Citizen found that the groups financing the trips often invited senators from committees that regulated their industries. For instance, Durenberger's 20 trips included 10 with health-related interests. The Minnesota Republican sits on subcommittees of the Senate Finance Committee that deal with health issues. The group suggested that congressional travel be financed by the taxpayers and that free trips from private sources be banned. ``Members of Congress should be subject to the same travel rules as Cabinet secretaries: If a speech is worth making to advance the public interest, and some of them certainly are, the government should pay,'' said Public Citizen President Joan Claybrook. Records for a half-dozen senators could not be checked because they were granted filing extensions.

DOC.HEAD: Barry May Call Campaign Manager; Nine Sent Into Jury Pool
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with 9 in jury pool, Bonds sitting next to Barry, subbing 5 grafs for grafs 2-4 pvs, and subbing 7th graf pvs, Defense attorney
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry's lawyers said Tuesday they may call his campaign manager and an indicted former city official as defense witnesses at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Lawyers and U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson spent the day in face-to-face questioning of a dozen prospective jurors. Nine were deemed sufficiently impartial to be sent into a pool from which a jury will be seated to hear the case against the mayor. The nine include an FBI clerk, two lawyers, a government worker, a journalist, two retirees and a 70-year-old woman who said she thinks politicians are dishonest. One woman, an art teacher at a private school, initially said she had formed an opinion about the case after Barry's January arrest on drug charges at a Washington hotel, an incident which forms the basis of one of the charges. But after prolonged questioning, she said she could presume Barry's innocence and listen impartially to the evidence if she sat as a juror. Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, said the woman shouldn't be sent into the jury pool, but the judge rejected Mundy's request. Barry joked with reporters as he arrived on a brilliant spring day, asking one whether he wanted to play tennis. Once inside the courtroom he chatted with artists, asking them how long it takes to draw their sketches for television. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of lying to a grand jury and one count of conspiracy. The three perjury charges are felonies. Mundy said in court that he wanted the name of Anita Bonds, Barry's campaign manager, added to the list of possible witnesses. Bonds sat next to Barry at the defense table during much of the day's proceedings. Law enforcement and city government sources have said prosecutors were on the verge of questioning Bonds when a grand jury indicted the mayor on May 10. Bonds has said she had not received a subpoena to testify but was informed by police officials working on the case that prosecutors wished to speak with her. Also added to the list is David Rivers, the former director of the city's Department of Human Services and a close friend of Barry. Rivers is currently on trial in the same courthouse, accused of steering city contracts to friends and business associates. Drama was slight in Tuesday's questioning of possible jurors. Under questioning from Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts, a man who works as a chauffeur said his only arrest had been for a traffic violation. Roberts then confronted the man with a document showing he had been arrested and accused of breaking into a men's clothing store. The chauffeur said the matter had been ``thrown out'' and said he had forgotten about the incident. ``I never went to court,'' he added. Others questioned included a lawyer whose firm represents one of the government witnesses in the case. The lawyer said she knows nothing about the firm's representation of the anticipated witness, James McWilliams, a longtime friend of the mayor.

DOC.HEAD: It's the Law: You'll Have to Bring A Toilet to This Cape Cod Beach
DOC.TEXT: If you want to spend the day at Sandy Neck dunes, you'll soon have to pack a portable toilet with your picnic basket and towel. A regulation adopted last month requires sunbathers to bring a portable toilet. As things are now ``you kind of have to watch where you step,'' said Brenda Bell, chairman of the governing board for the Cape Cod beach. ``You go to the dunes, when there's no rain, and you can smell human waste on hot, sunny days in summertime,'' Ms. Bell said. Board member Ellen McBarron said the plan was passed as an environmental measure. She said placing portable toilets on the six-mile sandspit was not a viable alternative because high tides would sweep them out into Cape Cod Bay. Ms. Bell said 600 vehicles are on the beach each day, plus people who come to the beach from cottages. ``You're talking about a lot of vehicles packed with an average of five people. Where are they going to go to the bathroom?'' Ms. Bell said. There is some relief for beachgoers, however. The new rule won't go into effect until next year because 800 beach passes have already been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Considering Dismissing Secord Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A federal district judge is considering whether to dismiss a $38 million libel suit filed against two journalists by Iran-Contra figure Richard V. Secord. Lawyer Dean Ringel told Judge George H. Revercombe on Tuesday that Secord's suit against Leslie and Andrew Cockburn and the Atlantic Monthly Press should be dismissed because no actual malice has been proved. But W. Michael Kramer, attorney for the former Air Force major general, contended the authors, in a 1988 book, falsely linked Secord to narcotics trafficking as part of the effort to finance the Contra rebels. Kramer asked the judge for additional time to take depositions and search for further evidence in the case. Revercombe took both motions under advisement. Kramer contended that the clear intent of the book, ``Out of Control: The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua,'' was to exploit the Iran-Contra affair by putting the administration and its key players in the worst possible light. But Ringel, appealing for dismissal, said: ``Mr. Secord seems to assume that since the book takes a political position opposite to that of the previous administration that is evidence of malice. ``One of the consequences of letting this go on is the concern that this could go on endlessly,'' he said. ``Every nook and cranny of the Iran-Contra affair becomes open for discussion. There's no need for that.'' Kramer said Secord's attorneys have no intention of doing that and want only ``a limited period of focused discovery.'' Secord's libel suit was filed in March 1988, the same day he was indicted for his Iran-Contra role. He was sentenced to two years probation on one of 12 original counts after a plea bargain. But he is appealing, alleging that independent counsel Lawrence Walsh lacked jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's congressional Iran-Contra testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to restore cycle designator
Foretich Says He's Not Giving Up Fight To See Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An oral surgeon who waged a bitter court battle over the right to visit his daughter said Tuesday he has not stopped fighting to see the child, who now lives in New Zealand with her mother. ``I just feel it's better for her that I don't engage in a full-blown court battle,'' Dr. Eric Foretich said of his 7-year-old daughter Hilary. ``Let the immigration officials in New Zealand decide.'' ``The case is proceeding in the family court,'' Foretich's New Zealand attorney, Rodney Hansen, told the New Zealand Press Association Tuesday night. NZPA earlier quoted Foretich as saying he was giving up his battle and was resigning himself to Hilary living in New Zealand with her mother, Elizabeth Morgan. Morgan, a plastic surgeon, hid Hilary in New Zealand to evade a Washington judge's 1987 order allowing continued visits by her father. Morgan was imprisoned for 25 months for defying the order. She has accused her former husband of sexually abusing Hilary, a charge he strenuously denies. Foretich rushed to New Zealand in February to see Hilary for the first time in three years after learning the child was living in Christchurch with maternal grandparents. Foretich maintains the girl should be returned to the United States. Morgan has sought permanent residence in New Zealand to stay with her daughter. ``Frankly I'm putting my daughter's interest before my own now and she needs to be out of the paper and out of confrontation,'' Foretich told NZPA.

DOC.HEAD: Four Electrocuted While Renovating Flag Pole
DOC.TEXT: Shaken residents of this tiny mountain hamlet wept Tuesday near a charred patch of ground outside the town hall where four men, including a father and two sons, were electrocuted while moving a flag pole. The four men, two of whom served on the town council that met Monday night, died when the 38-foot pole they were holding fell against high-voltage power lines. Killed were Borough Council president Robert Friend, 59; his sons Randall Scott Friend, 23, and Robert Friend II, 22; and Councilman Keith Cuppett, 35, all of Markleysburg, said state Trooper Richard Veil. Many who live in this community of 400 stood along the main route of town Tuesday, mourning their fallen neighbors. Some walked to the accident site and several turned away weeping. The Rev. Peter A. Malik of Uniontown consoled relatives at the Friend home in the Fayette County town near West Virginia and Maryland. ``Their last name sort of says it all,'' he said. ``They were friends to everybody. If you needed a friend, you called a Friend.'' The men were removing the flagpole from its base for renovations. ``They had got a new flag and they were going to paint the pole,'' said Mary Ann Frazee, a neighbor. Many in Markleysburg saw the electrocution. Screams from the mother of one victim drew Kathy Lawson to the scene. ``They were still on fire and I held onto his mother to keep her back,'' said Lawson. ``The whole town was running over to them, but nobody could get to them because the pole was right over them and electricity was still running through it.'' ``It's a loss. It's a great loss,'' said Andy Sember, manager of the G.W. Superette. Robert Friend II worked at the grocery store during high school and college, Sember said. The market will be closed Thursday, when funeral services are scheduled. The two younger victims recently graduated from nearby California University of Pennsylvania, Sember said. They had planned to start a computer business with their 27-year-old brother, Doug, who suffered minor injuries in the accident. The elder Friend worked as a carpenter in Morgantown, W.Va., Malik said. His wife, Nancy, works for the same company. ``They were very much a team,'' the minister said. Malik said he has known the Friend family for more than seven years through a youth ministry organization. ``I think they're just going to lean on the Lord Jesus Christ and let him handle it,'' he said. ``All of them have very strong Christian faith, the kind that goes beyond Sunday morning and is practiced all week long.'' Cuppett lived across from the town hall with his wife, Linda, who also is a council member. She was home when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Conservationists Claim a Victory in Protecting Elephant
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. market for ivory has virtually collapsed since President Bush banned imports a year ago to help protect the African elephant, and sales have dropped in some other countries, the World Wildlife Fund said Tuesday. But the group was worried that ivory carvers may turn to using hippopotamus teeth and suggested instead that they ply their art on the tusks of extinct mammoths being dug from the frozen tundra of Siberia. Bush announced a moratorium on ivory imports June 5, 1989, and Japan, the world's biggest market for ivory, has also been enforcing a ban. ``Dealers report that wholesale prices for jewelry and simple carvings, which historically accounted for most of the U.S. market, have been discounted by 40 to 70 percent,'' the Wildlife Fund's report said. ``One major ivory trader on New York stated firmly that price is irrelevant in the current U.S. market, since demand does not exist,'' the report said. Results in other areas are mixed but the report saw encouragement for the fund's efforts. It estimated that Africa's elephant population went down from 1,194,331 in 1981 to about 610,000 last year. One substitute for elephant ivory: the tusks of pre-historic mammoths dug up by the Soviet Union. ``We don't try to protect the mammoth _ it's been extinct for 10,000 years,'' said Michael Sutton, one of the authors of the report. He said he was more concerned about carvers who are shifting to hippopotamus teeth. A lot of hippos have to be killed to get the same weight in teeth as comes from the tusks of one elephant. ``In 1989 Japan imported about 1,991 kilograms (4,380 pounds) of mammoth ivory and 1,235 kilograms (2,717 pounds) of hippo teeth,'' the report said. ``The declared value of hippo teeth is about $60 per kilogram (2.2 pounds) mammoth ivory is valued at $180 to $240 per kilogram, according to Japanese customs data.'' One price that has been going up: plectra for the samisen. According to the report, the strings of this Japanese instrument are played with a pick that must be carved from a raw tusk weighing at least 57 pounds. That size is rare these days as poachers turn to younger and younger elephants. In Hong Kong the report said the number of ivory shops has declined and up to 75 percent of the carvers have found other jobs. The government has promised them a subsidized course in carving ox bones. China refused to go along with an internationally agreed ban, but the report said the ivory trade there has nearly collapsed and the number of carvers has gone down. It quoted U.S. government sources as saying that the Chinese government may ban ivory imports from Africa. But South Korea imported 28.8 tons of carved ivory in 1989, more than in the previous five years combined. The report suggests traders may have established the country as a new carving center or a base for smuggling. Illegal slaughter of elephants was reported to have declined considerably in Kenya, the Central African Republic and Gabon, though not in Malawi or Tanzania. ``The poacher is at the low end of chain,'' said Sutton. ``It takes a while for the effect of lower prices to trickle down to him.'' The report pointed out that Africans in the elephant areas are so poor that even $1 to $5 a kilogram may be an attractive price.

DOC.BYLINE: Colombia to Continue Drug Fight ^By RITA BEAMISH
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing Colombian President Virgilio Barco on Tuesday promised that his successor will continue the fight against narcotics trafficking and asked U.S. backing for his efforts. Barco, who leaves office Aug. 7, met with Bush in the Oval Office for 40 minutes and told reporters later that his drug-plagued nation will continue its efforts to stop the flow of cocaine northward. ``We will continue that because we believe in that. And the next president of Colombia, the president-elect, also has been ... stating that he would continue to fight drugs, and I'm sure that he will receive the backing of the United States,'' he said. Barco, who has met with Bush several times on the issue of illegal narcotics, was prohibited by the country's constitution from seeking re-election. He came to the United States to give the commencement address at Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Monday. Barco's successor, Cesar Gaviria, was the only candidate in last month's election to take a hard-line stand against drug traffickers who use Colombia as a major processing and transport center. Gaviria has complained that Colombians are dying in the drug wars while other nations do little. In his victory speech, Gaviria called on developed countries to cut cocaine consumption and to work harder to control arms trafficking and money-laundering by cocaine traffickers. He also said the United States to drop trade impediments against Colombian exports and to increase aid to his country. Barco, in his meeting with Bush, also raised trade questions, said White House spokesman Bill Harlow. Gaviria has said exports likes coffee and flowers should receive preferential treatment, but Harlow said Barco did not directly raise the coffee or flower issue. After the meeting, Barco brushed aside questions on flowers and coffee agreements, indicating those were matters yet to be resolved. He said little about the meeting except that it was pleasant and that they ``talked about the cooperation that Colombia needs.'' However, the Colombian embassy had released a statement urging the United States to take the lead in restoring an international coffee cartel, whose collapse last year without U.S. support has led to a drop in coffee prices cost the Colombian government more than $500 million in 1989, according to the Colombians. The 74-nation International Coffee Agreement abandoned production quotas for member nations in July when the United States withdrew. The United States had complained that some coffee-growing nations taking part in the agreement sold coffee surpluses secretly to East bloc nations at lower prices than those charged in the United States. U.S. officials also wanted an increase in export quotas for higher-quality coffees sought by American consumers, a position favored by many Central American countries growing those grades who were unhappy with what they saw as overly restrictive production quotas. Rep. Charles Rangel, chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse, said in a statement Bush must do more to address Colombia's requests on such matters as the coffee agreement and banning U.S. exports of weapons popular with drug lords. ``If we want to see this battle continue we will have to give more than moral support for courage,'' Rangel said. ``We will have to address the specific requests of the elected Colombian leaders.'' Harlow said Bush briefed Barco on his recent summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Seize Headquarters of World's Biggest Rubber Plantation
LaserPhoto MON1
DOC.TEXT: Rebels seized the headquarters of the world's largest rubber plantation on Tuesday, then gathered for action at the adjoining gates of Liberia's international airport, plantation sources said. President Samuel Doe pursued a last-stand attempt at peaceful negotiations to end a six-month insurgency that has evolved into a tribal war. He met with Christian church officials and Moslem leaders who have offered to act as intermediaries. In Akron, Ohio, a spokesman for the Bridgestone@Firestone Inc. company that runs the 120,000-acre plantation referred to the rebels as ``freedom fighters'' and said the company wants to keep the plantation operating _ even with rebels. Insurgents now control every major industrial concern in this West African country of 2.5 million residents, except possibly the Bong iron ore mine, cut off for days from Monrovia and believed behind rebel lines. Plantation residents said rebels fired mortars and automatic weapons Tuesday as dozens crossed the Farmington River _ the last natural barrier before Monrovia _ and moved onto the plantation. One shell fell into the garden of an expatriate plantation employee, but no one was hurt, the sources said. Robertsfield International Airport, 25 miles from Monrovia, was built to serve the plantation. It was effectively closed on Monday. Off Monrovia, four U.S. warships carrying 2,000 Marines remained ready to evacuate Americans and other foreigners. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Monday in Washington that about 70 U.S. officials and 1,200 private American citizens remained in Liberia. Most of the rebels belong to Liberia's Gio and Mano tribes and entered Liberia from neighboring Ivory Coast in late December. Doe belongs to the Krahn tribe, which is loyal to him, as is the Mandingo tribe. The rebels accuse Doe's administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Plantation sources said they were told troop reinforcements were en route to the plantation to try to recapture it. None of the people interviewed by telephone in the Firestone company town of Harbel would agree to have their names published. A Harbel resident said many people were celebrating in the marketplace, welcoming the ``freedom fighters'' distinguished by their red bandanas. A receptionist at Robertsfield Hotel, a three-minute walk from the airport, said he saw perhaps 15 soldiers in all guarding the airport. He said sounds of mortars and gunfire in the morning died down by afternoon. Diplomatic sources in this capital city of about 400,000 people said they had no reports of casualties in fighting Tuesday. They said about 15 or 20 soldiers on the plantation briefly returned rebel fire, then fled toward the capital. It has become a familiar story in the war. Diplomats say about 50 percent of a soldiery they describe as ill-trained and poorly paid have deserted. Government forces now are believed to number about the same as the rebels _ between 3,000 and 4,000. Monrovia residents were fleeing in fear and some soldiers abandoned key posts before the rebel advance. Doe has asked the United States to help end the civil war convulsing Liberia. Washington has accused Charles Taylor, leader of the rebel National Patriotic Front of Liberia, of getting support from Libya, but it also has said Marines will not move to support Doe's government. Bridgestone@Firestone spokesman Trevor Hoskins said in Akron that Americans managing the plantation did not plan to evacuate despite the rebel advance. He said the rebels occupied the management offices of Harbel after surrounding the plantation's factory late Monday, stopping rubber production. The plantation turns out about 100 million pounds of rubber a year. Hoskins said he spoke Tuesday with plantation managing director Don Ensminger. ``Ensminger has told the freedom fighters that Bridgestone@Firestone wishes to continue operating its plantation and keep jobs available to the 8,500 Liberian employees ... and their more than 85,000 dependents. They have told him the fight was not with him or the plantation employees and they do not intend any destruction,'' Hoskins said. A plantation cook, however, told The Associated Press by telephone that rebels had ``blown apart'' a house where soldiers lived in Harbel, adding, ``We don't know if anyone was in there, or was killed.'' As he spoke, he said about a dozen rebels arrived at the house where he worked. They could be heard over the telephone line, shouting at the cook. He returned to the telephone after a few minutes saying he was ``full of fear. They said they going to blow me up.'' He said the rebels accused him of lying when he said the plantation manager was not home, but he finally convinced them and they left in a commandeered van. Descendants of freed U.S. slaves founded Liberia in 1822. In 1847 it became black Africa's first independent country.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Refuses to Stop Debate on Crime Package
DOC.NOTE: EDs: First 8 grafs new with Senate setting second vote, partisan breakdown; picks up 5th graf pvs, The bill. Deletes last 3 grafs pvs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate refused to limit debate Tuesday on wide-ranging anticrime legislation containing curbs on semiautomatic weapons. Sponsors warned that the threat of a filibuster could doom the measure. Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., futilely urged the chamber to limit debate to 30 hours, saying, ``Americans want something done about these godawful assault weapons.'' The bill's backers said they would make a second attempt at curtailing debate later in the week. Biden said the National Rifle Association was behind Tuesday's vote and said that if the time limit fails on the second try, opening the door to a filibuster, ``it will be the end of the official crime bill.'' Both he and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said they thought they could find enough votes to cap the debate at 30 hours. On the roll call, 54 senators voted in favor of limiting debate while 37 senators opposed such a curb. Sponsors needed 60 votes to impose the time limit. Forty-four Democrats and 10 Republicans voted for imposing cloture on the debate while 31 Republicans and six Democrats wee opposed. Mitchell said, however, that Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas was among those calling for a second vote on the measure, whose death penalty as well as gun-control provisions are likely to figure in some fall reelection campaigns. The bill would bar imports and domestic manufacture of nine semiautomatic rifles and pistols. Other provisions would impose the death penalty for 30 federal crimes, overhaul the appeals system and sanction the use of evidence gathered with faulty warrants if the police acted in good faith. Sponsors said they needed to limit debate if they were to have any hope of passage. As of noon, more than 230 proposed amendments were in the hopper with the promise of more to come. They ranged from mandatory life sentences for rapists with AIDS to commemorative medals for the Yosemite National Park centennial. The bill's supporters said debating each of them would guarantee critics the power to stall of any final vote. ``If cloture is invoked, the crime bill will pass, if cloture is not invoked the crime bill will die,'' Biden said. But he added that there could be a second attempt to choke off debate within a few days. No senators stood up to speak against limiting debate, although in fiery floor exchanges two weeks ago western lawmakers declared that many of their constituents were hunters and gun collectors and considered any restriction on ownership to be a violation of their rights. Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., recalled how his grandmother used to ``pack a little iron'' in the frontier era. Efforts to curb military-style semiautomatic weapons, sometimes called assault weapons, got under way in earnest in January 1989 after a deranged man with such a rifle sprayed a Stockton, Calif., schoolyard, leaving five people dead and 30 others wounded. The Bush administration has been pressing for the death penalty provisions as part of the president's crime package. It also sought a far more stringent overhaul of the habeas corpus review process, under which defendants can appeal their convictions on constitutional grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ships Make First Visit to West German Port
DOC.TEXT: Two ships from the Baltic Fleet docked here Tuesday in the first visit by the Soviet navy to West Germany. The port call by the destroyer ``Bistry'' and the frigate ``Neukrotny'' was aimed at improving relations between the Soviet and West German navies, said Rear Adm. Viktor Litvinov, commander of the 650-sailor detachment. A 21-gun salute greeted the ``Bistry'' and ``Neukrotny'' as they pulled into this northern port city. The West German navy paid its first visit to the Soviet Union in October, docking at Leningrad. The environmental organization Greenpeace said it had been assured by the Soviet naval attache in Bonn, Anatoly Solotaryev, that the ships were not carrying nuclear weapons. The ships are normally fitted with nuclear cruise missiles and torpedos, Greenpeace said.

DOC.HEAD: Spokesman: Bush Believes Gorbachev Wants to Ease Lithuania Tension
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed the trade agreement with Mikhail S. Gorbachev believing the Soviet leader wants to resolve tensions with Lithuania but without receiving concrete assurances, the White House said Tuesday. Bush summoned congressional leaders to the White House for a post-summit briefing and told them that before putting his name on the agreement, he repeatedly expressed concern to Gorbachev about the economic blockade against Lithuania. ``I accept that,'' said Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. The lawmakers did not fault Bush for approving the trade pact. Nevertheless, they emphasized that Gorbachev will have to ease up on the Baltic republic before Congress approves any of the benefits described by the agreement. The agreement is not an ordinary treaty, which must be ratified by a two-thrids vote of the Senate. Under special trade legislation applying to Communist countries, the agreement must be approved by a majority vote in both the House and the Senate. ``Call it linkage or call it reality,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``There will have to be some moderation of Soviet policy with respect to Lithuania before the agreement is approved and most-favored-nation status granted,'' said Mitchell. The most-favored status would give Moscow the lowest-possible tariffs on its exports to America. Bush has acknowledged that the fate of Lithuania will be a big factor in the decision of Congress whether to ratify the trade agreement. However, the only price he has set for sending the agreement to Capitol Hill is the passage of a law by the Soviet legislature protecting emigration. Such an emigration law, and a trade agreement, must be in operation before the president may grant most-favored-nation trade status. Bush has said he intends to grant that status once the emigration legislation passes. Moscow announced Tuesday a tentative postponement of any action on emigration until September, and the White House seemed to breathe a sigh of relief. ``That may not be bad in the sense of, it gives them a little time to work on the emigration issue ... and (take) action on Lithuania,'' said Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. ``It might well be that by the time the emigration law was passed and we were ready to go forward with this (trade agreement) that there would be action on Lithuania,'' Fitzwater said. The signing of the trade agreement was the biggest surprise of the four-day superpower summit. And Fitzwater said Bush's decision to sign came only a half hour before the two leaders put their names on the document. The spokesman said Bush and Gorbachev had long discussions about Lithuania on at least three occasions during the summit, and ``there were no private assurances or conditions.'' He said there was a ``general kind'' of assurance by Gorbachev but ``there was no specific `I'll-do-this' kind of thing.'' Still, Fitzwater said, ``We have the feeling that he wants to resolve the issue. ``The president believes his (Gorbachev's) motives are, that he wants to resolve the issue. ... We're persuaded that he wants to resolve the issue.'' Fitzwater said Bush's decision was the result of ``the accumulation of conversation over the two days about understanding that they knew our position and knew our concern, a feeling that he was interested in solving this problem, a belief that there were commitments to deal with this.'' The agreement was an important trophy for Gorbachev, seeking improved trade relations with the West to help cope with a deepening economic crisis at home. Bush and other administration leaders had hinted that the agreement would not be signed until Gorbachev ended his economic stranglehold on Lithuania, which is struggling for independence from the Kremlin. However, after impassioned pleas by Gorbachev to Bush _ and also to congressional leaders _ the president decided to go ahead. House Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois said Gorbachev made a remarkable presentation to the lawmakers. ``Here was the first time a Soviet leader (was) telling us, `I've got real problems at home and we'd like to establish a market economy,' which ought to give us all a measure of hope,'' Michel said. Gorbachev, flying back to the Soviet Union, sent a farewell message to Bush as his jetliner cleared U.S. airspace at 1:39 a.m. EDT Tuesday. It was received at the White House situation room, the 24-hour communications and crisis center in the basement of the White House. ``Having completed my stay in your great country, once again I wish to express my deep satisfaction with the results of my visit,'' Gorbachev said. ``The work we have done together during these days will bear good fruit. I would like to express to you and to all Americans my sincere gratitude for the respect shown to the Soviet people and for your hospitality and warm reception.'' In addition to earlier-announced post-summit telephone calls to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and German Prime Minister Helmut Kohl, the White House said Bush had phoned Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and French President Francois Mitterrand.

DOC.HEAD: No More Free Cigarettes, Says NYC City Council
DOC.TEXT: Free cigarettes? No more! The City Council voted 33-to-0 Tuesday to ban tobacco companies from giving out free cigarettes to potential customers or smokers. The main target, according to the bill's sponsor, Councilman Sal Albanese, was to stop young people age 18 or younger from being tempted to smoke. Albanese said cigarettes are distributed free on street corners and other places and that youngsters can get them. ``In ending this reprehensible practice,'' he said, ``New York City will not only become the largest jurisdiction in the nation to ban the free distribution of tobacco products to the public, but as large as the next six jurisdictions combined.'' Albanese said at least 15 other cities, including Boston, Atlanta, Austin, Texas, and Cincinnati also bar the free distribution of cigarettes. Chairman of the Council's Committee on Youth Services, Albanese said the legislation would bar individuals and businesses from distributing tobacco products in public places or at public events for free or at any price less than the combined cost of the required taxes. The state tax on cigarettes is 39 cents. The bill still needs the approval of Mayor David Dinkins.

DOC.HEAD: Police Detain Passenger, Release Jet after Bomb Scare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with police blowing up suspicious luggage and detaining passenger. CORRECTS day in lead to Tuesday sted Thursday. Pickup graf 5 pvs, `The Strathclyde...'
DOC.TEXT: A Pan Am jet carrying 208 passengers and crew from West Germany to Washington made an emergency landing in Scotland on Tueday following a bomb scare. Police took one passenger into custody and, as a precautionary measure, blew up two pieces of suspicious luggage. There appeared to be no explosives in the luggage, said police sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Police refused to identify the man taken into custody or disclose his nationality. They also declined to say if he owned the luggage that was blown up. The Boeing 747, Flight 61 from Frankfurt to Washington, resumed its journey Tuesday night, according to controllers at Prestwick airport, five hours after making the emergency landing. ``The crew received an allegation that there was possibly an explosive device on board,'' said a statement issued by Strathclyde police, based in Glasgow. ``A full search of the aircraft has been carried out, items of baggage were removed form the hold and a controlled explosion was carried out by the Explosive Ordinance Depot,'' the statement said. The Strathclyde police force contributed much of the personnel for the investigation of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over the Scottish town of Lockerbie in December 1988. That bomb killed 259 people on the New York-bound flight and 11 people on the ground.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Supreme Court Rules School Funding Plan Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey is failing miserably at educating poor urban students, the state Supreme Court ruled Tuesday in a decision that declared unconstitutional the way aid is distributed to public schools. The high court ruled, in effect, that determining school funding based on property tax revenues is unfair. ``The evidence compels but one conclusion: the poorer the district and the greater its need, the less the money available, and the worse the education,'' Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz wrote. ``These students simply cannot possibly enter the same market or the same society as their peers educated in wealthier districts.'' The justices in the unanimous decision ordered lawmakers to begin reforms by the 1991-92 school year. The state must assure poor urban districts spend about the same amount of money per child as richer suburban districts, the court ruled. The court estimated that the state needs to add $440 million to its $3.5 billion public schools budget to remedy disparities in the state's 28 poorest districts. ``Today's ruling is a clear victory for the children of New Jersey,'' said Gov. Jim Florio, who last week unveiled a plan to raise the state income tax. The tax hike would raise $1 billion for more aid to middle-income and poor districts, while aid to wealthier school systems would be reduced or eliminated. ``The court has recognized that the current school funding system is leading us to be two New Jerseys _ where some youngsters head for the best colleges, and others go down a road to nowhere,'' Florio said, predicting his reform proposal will satisfy the court. New Jersey is among more than a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems in recent years. ``I think there absolutely is a trend evident. In the last two years, we have seen four state supreme courts strike down their school finance systems _ Montana, Kentucky, Texas and now New Jersey,'' said Arthur Wise, director of the Washington-based RAND Center for the Study of the Teaching Profession. Other states involved in funding disputes include Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming and Arkansas. ``Since 1980, the gap between rich districts and poor districts has been increasing, that's why we have this trend. The poor are more hard-pressed than they were during the 1970s,'' Wise said. A new school funding system will take effect in Montana on July 1, passed by lawmakers after the state's highest court declared the former system unconstitutional. In October, the Texas Supreme Court declared its system unconstitutional. The state Senate on Tuesday approved and sent to the House a $528 million education reform bill. A funding bill that would hike sales taxes by a quarter-cent and increase taxes on mixed drinks and tobbacco products was passed by both the Texas House and Senate on Tuesday. The Kentucky Supreme Court delivered a similar ruling last year, forcing lawmakers to raise taxes to pay for $500 million more in education aid. The New Jersey decision does not place a cap on spending and rich districts can continue to increase spending if they choose. But the state must increase aid to poorer districts if sub-par education standards continue, the court said. Lawmakers may devise any remedy they wish to correct the disparities, but they may not force poor districts to raise property taxes, the court ruled. The court also ruled unconstitutional the politically popular ``minimum aid'' program that gives money to affluent districts regardless of need. The rulings stem from a 1981 lawsuit filed by the Newark-based Education Law Center, which brought the court action on behalf of 20 school-age children from Camden, Jersey City, East Orange and Irvington. The ruling culminated a decade-long battle during which former Gov. Thomas H. Kean fought the lawsuit and defended the funding system. In 1984, the court said, school districts spent an average of $4,030 per pupil, while the poorest school systems spent only about $2,860 per pupil. Statewide, an average of $3,329 per pupil was spent.

DOC.HEAD: `Nightwatch' Anchor Charlie Rose Moves to Fox Broadcasting
DOC.TEXT: Charlie Rose, who has burned the midnight oil as anchorman of the CBS interview series ``Nightwatch,'' is leaving to head a daily interview show for the Fox Broadcasting Co., officials said Tuesday. Rose, an Emmy Award winner who has headed ``Nightwatch'' since it began in 1984, will join the syndicated series ``Personalities'' as its anchor. ``Charlie and `Personalities' are a perfect match,'' said Michael Lambert, head of Fox's domestic syndication division. ``His skill as an interviewer has single-handedly attracted an amazing list of newsmakers to the `Nightwatch' set.'' ``Personalities'' is the first daily syndicated magazine show focusing solely on people in the news, and will interview newsmakers from entertainment, politics, sports, business, communications and the arts. Rose also has anchored ``Face the Nation,'' ``CBS Morning News,'' ``CBS This Morning'' and ``Newsbreak.'' He was en route from Washington, D.C., to Los Angeles on Tuesday evening and could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Company Makes Last-Minute FCC Bid for Testing Digital HDTV System
DOC.TEXT: An ``all-digital, all-American'' high-definition television system developed by a U.S. company has made a last-minute entry in the race to become the U.S. national TV broadcast standard, officials said Tuesday. ``We are leap-frogging state-of-the art technology,'' said Mike Walker, a spokesman for the VideoCipher division of General Instruments Corp. showcasing the new ``DigiCipher'' technology in San Diego. High-definition TV, or HDTV, provides vastly sharper TV pictures and compact disc-quality sound; however, its signal requires a wider broadcast channel _ about 30 megahertz _ rather than conventional TV's 6 megahertz. The Federal Communications Commission set a June 1 deadline for proposals on a ``simulcast'' system that works on today's TV sets and fits onto the existing broadcast spectrum. On June 1, General Instruments filed its proposal. ``The technologies that we've developed are proprietary technologies that digitize and compress the video signal,'' Walker said. ``We reduce the amount or data that is transmitted, but maintain or enhance the quality of the picture.'' Conventional TVs would receive the standard signal, while the second signal would be broadcast and received on HDTV equipment whose manufacturers pay lucrative royalties to the owners of the technology. Other proposals before the FCC are from NHK, the Japanese broadcasting system; Zenith Electronics Corp., an international consortium of NBC with Dutch and French electronics companies, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The systems would be tested for 12 to 18 months before the government chooses the standard sometime in 1993. Walker said the technology grew out of VideoCipher research for its core market, satellite and cable systems, into a digital compression system that would let multiple TV signals move through a single satellite relay. It is a ``seamless technology,'' Walker said. The same system of coding, compression and decoding can be used by satellite and cable systems as well as terrestrial TV broadcasting. The VideoCipher division of General Instruments, which is 263rd on the Fortune 500, specializes in satellite encryption systems, plans to have its HDTV prototype system before the FCC in February 1991. Walker said the digital system will have the advantages of error correction circuitry already familiar to compact disc owners. Electronic noise, snow, interference and ``ghost'' images would canceled out. ``You can send that signal through noise, take it out of correction and wind up with a perfect signal, an exact duplicate of what was transmitted,'' he said. The digital compression technology will increase the number of signals handled by a single satellite relay, or transponder, Walker said. ``We could send two high-definition signals on one transponder, or we could send up to 10 high-quality (standard) signals to a single transponder,'' he said. The same technique would apply to a cable channel or a broadcast signal. The company plans to develop the compression technology for overseas markets, he said, lowering costs for satellite time and increasing available channels. ``Ultimately, what we're looking for is video on demand: the video store in the sky,'' Walker said. ``You can see the day where there'll be 10 movies on 10 channels on 10 transponders 24 hours a day.''

DOC.HEAD: Showers, Thunderstorms in Midwest; Record Lows in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms packing winds up to 65 mph stretched over sections of the Midwest on Tuesday, and the mercury dipped to record lows in 16 cities in the Northeast and the Midwest. Showers and thunderstorms extended from extreme northeast Kansas to northern Missouri and southern Iowa, and showers and a few thunderstorms fell from northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana to western Upper Michigan. Thunderstorm-generated gusts of 65 mph were recorded in Douglas County, Neb., and 60 mph near Manson, Iowa. A few showers and thunderstorms also dampened Florida and southern Louisiana. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies from California through the southern and central Rockies to the central Gulf Coast states. Strong southerly winds prevailed from the southern Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley, and strong northwesterlies blew over Nebrasak and the Dakotas. Overnight temperatures dropped into the 30s and 40s in the northern and central Rockies and the Great Basin of Nevada, as well as New England, the Great Lakes region and the Ohio Valley. Low-temperature records for the date were set in 10 cities and tied in six. It was 33 degrees in Akron, Ohio, where the record of 38 had stood since 1945. Other cities where records were set included Albany, N.Y. (39 degrees, 40 in 1978); Huntsville, Ala. (52, 54 in 1988); Louisville, Ky. (45, 46 in 1945); and Pittsburgh (37, 38 in 1945). In Wilmington, Del., it was 46 degrees; the last time the temperature was that low was 1925. The low for the Lower 48 states was 30 degrees in Butte, Mont.; Alpena, Mich; and Bradford, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: Texas House, Senate Act on School Finance Reform Compromise
With AM-School Financing
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature moved quickly Tuesday on a $528 million compromise school finance reform plan by easily passing the tax and fee increases needed to pay for it _ including a quarter-cent state sales tax hike. The Senate passed a separate bill outlining school finance reforms with a 29-1 vote, and a measure making budget cuts and state budget transfers with a 30-0 vote. The reform and budget-cutting bills were sent to the House. Increases in the state sales tax, mixed drink and tobacco levies and some state fees were passed by the House and Senate and sent to Gov. Bill Clements. ``I am extremely happy because there is light at the end of the tunnel and it's not a freight train this time,'' said House Speaker Gib Lewis. Democratic legislative leaders and the Republican governor agreed on the school finance reform package Friday after a three-month deadlock on how to address a state Supreme Court order to give more money to poor school districts. The funding package would pump extra money into the $13.5 billion-a-year school finance system and would raise an extra $100 million to bail out financially strapped social service programs. Clements killed two previous plans because they each required a half-cent increase in the sales tax, but he compromised at the quarter-cent level Friday, saying he wanted to fend off court intervention in the school system. The House could take up the school finance reform bill Wednesday, Lewis said. The House Public Education Committee endorsed the measure with a 6-1 vote Tuesday. Beyond funding changes, the reform bill would make changes designed to improve education performance and accountability. It would allow expansion of the pre-kindergarten program to 3-year-olds in the 1991-92 school year, increase testing of students, and give the governor the authority to appoint the state education commissioner presently appointed by the State Board of Education. The tax measure approved 117-23 by the House and 30-0 by the Senate would: _Raise the sales tax to 6\ cents on the dollar. _Raise the cigarette tax by 15 cents a pack, to 41 cents. _Increase the tax rate on chewing tobacco, snuff and smoking tobacco from 28.125 percent to 35.213 percent of the factory list price. _Increase the gross receipts tax on the sale of mixed drinks from 12 percent to 14 percent. Two other measures approved would double the fees for obtaining a duplicate driver's license from $5 to $10 and raise by 50 percent the state fees for highway permits to transport items that exceed size and weight limits. Al Kauffman, an attorney for poor school districts, said he expects to challenge the reform plan in court. Critics say the bill does not go far enough. Clements said the reaction was expected and typical of hard-fought compromises. ``I don't know anybody that's happy with the bill. The fact that everybody's unhappy about it makes it probably a pretty good bill,'' Clements said.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Bound and Bullet-Riddled Bodies Found in Mass Grave
DOC.TEXT: A mass grave believed to have been used by the rightist military has yielded 15 bound and bullet-riddled bodies and could conceal as many more, officials said Tuesday. The corpses in the Atacama desert are believed to be those of leftists rounded up and killed by army troops after a 1973 coup, human rights officials said. The discovery prompted renewed calls by relatives' groups for the new civilian government to prosecute officers. Digging continued Tuesday under judicial supervision at the long-secret grave, outside the fishing village of Pisagua on the Pacific coast 1,185 miles north of Santiago. Rights activists and government officials said the body count had risen from eight on Sunday to 15 late Monday. Digging began Saturday. Belisario Velasco, an Interior Ministry subsecretary, told reporters in Santiago that ``there may be an equal number of cadavers yet to be uncovered.'' Sergio Hevia, a lawyer for the Roman Catholic Church's human rights agency, said in a telephone interview that all of the bodies showed signs of having been executed. He said the bodies had bullet wounds, the hands were tied and many were blindfolded. All the bodies were wrapped in tightly bound sacks, he said. Digging so far has been limited to a single trench, but Hevia said authorities planned to open two more possible gravesites. After taking power in a violent coup on Sept. 11, 1973, the military ran a detention camp for leftists in Pisagua. About 30 prisoners were executed, or shot while allegedly trying to escape, but their bodies were never handed over to relatives, according to rights groups. The right-wing military regime, headed by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, handed over power on March 11 to an elected government headed by President Patricio Aylwin. At a news conference Tuesday in Santiago, a national organization made up of the relatives of victims of military repression called for the government to show ``firmness in clearing up the truth and doing justice.'' ``A healthy, solid and stable democracy is based on investigation, prosecution and proper criminal sanction, within a state of law, of those responsible for human rights violations,'' the group declared in a written statement distributed to reporters. They called on a retired army general, Carlos Forestier, to hand over information on the Pisagua deaths. Forestier was then division commander and military judge for the area. He now works for a private Santiago-based arms manufacturer. Pinochet decreed a blanket amnesty covering all human rights violations that occurred from the time of the coup through March 1978. Pinochet remains commander of the 60,000-man army, and has said he will not permit prosection of his men. The mass grave was discovered by a church-sponsored human rights agency, the Solidarity Vicariate. Local newspapers said the agency was led to the site by a doctor, Alberto Neumann, who recently returned from exile in West Germany. The doctor had been imprisoned at the Pisagua camp, and was forced to witness the execution of five fellow prisoners and to confirm the victims' deaths before they were buried in a trench already containing six other bodies, the Santiago daily Fortin Mapocho reported. Neumann was set free by mistake, and sought asylum in the West German Embassy, the newspaper reported. The bodies are being taken to a police lab for tests to determine their identities. Authorities said the remains are well preserved because of the area's extremely dry climate.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Home Needed, and Still Needs, a Lot of Work
DOC.TEXT: The $200,000 that Congress appropriated for renovations of the vice president's official home ``did not come near covering'' the cost of the project, Marilyn Quayle said Tuesday. Mrs. Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, also said the electrical wiring on the third floor was so old that the house had become ``a firetrap.'' Renovation of the third floor of the 19th-century mansion should be finished in about three weeks, she said. The project _ including new wiring, updated plumbing, new heating and air conditioning, new walls and new plaster _ will cost about $320,000, said Denise Balzano, an aide to Mrs. Quayle. The federal funds are being supplemented by private contributions. So far, close to $250,000 has been raised, Balzano said. Some of the contributions will also be used for furnishings, she added. The third floor of the house on the Naval Observatory grounds is being renovated to accommodate the Quayle's three children. When President Bush lived in the house as vice president, the third floor had been used as Barbara Bush's office, a maid's bedroom and for storage. During the renovations, the Quayles have been sleeping in the two second-floor bedrooms. Mrs. Quayle said the building was the ``most charming house in the world,'' but had major safety problems. When the family returned from a spring vacation this year, the construction crew showed Mrs. Quayle charred timbers behind a ceiling light in the room where one of the children had slept. The workers told her that when they took out the light, the charred timbers were still warm. ``We were living in a fire trap,'' she said. ``The wiring had not been replaced. When you touched it, the covering crumbled, it was so old.'' When the heating and air conditioning units were removed, ``big sheets of crumbling asbestos'' were found. ``This is where the air was being sucked in to blow into my children's rooms,'' she said. ``Believe me, the appropriation from Congress did not come near to covering what you have to do for an old building,'' she said. A study by the General Services Administration and the White House office of administration found the house needed about $1.4 million in repairs. For this fiscal year, Congress appropriated $200,000 for the third-floor project and $120,000 to make the house accessible to the handicapped. The White House is seeking $320,000 to continue the work in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, Balzano said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Compromise Talks on Meech Lake Report Little Progress
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney emerged from talks aimed at salvaging the Meech Lake accord to report ``a little progress'' Tuesday. It was his third day of closed-door constitutional meetings with the 10 provincial premiers, known collectively as ``first ministers.'' Mulroney, who backs the accord, said the others had asked him to leave the meeting briefly to report small but unspecified advances. ``I want to make sure that no one misunderstands,'' he said, before returning to the downtown conference center. ``This is a small degree of progress as opposed to an enormous degree of progress.'' ``There's a great deal of work left to do and we'll continue this work.'' The Meech Lake accord, signed in 1987, was designed to win Quebec's approval of the 1982 constitution. It recognizes largely French-speaking Quebec, with 6.7 million of Canada's 25 million people, as a distinct society. It also gives all provinces expanded powers _ including a veto on Senate changes. The process began to unravel when provinces that originally approved the agreement reneged following elections which instituted new leadership. The dispute over reforming the upper chamber proved to be the main sticking point. All 10 provinces must approve the accord by June 23 or it will expire. Manitoba and Newfoundland are the two holdouts. New Brunswick Premier Frank McKenna agreed on Monday after intense discussions to go along. Together, premiers Gary Filmon of Manitoba and Clyde Wells of Newfoundland have three years in office and represent only 1.5 million Canadians. ``I'm not sure you'd call it a common front, we're just discussing common concerns,'' Wells said after a meeting with Filmon on Monday. Wells is fundamentally opposed to Meech Lake. He takes particular exception to the distinct society status the deal would grant Quebec, and the prospect of a Quebec veto over Senate reform. Filmon wants assurances the distinct society clause won't take precedence over Canada's Charter of Rights and Freedoms and recognition of the rights of women and natives.

DOC.HEAD: Post-Summit Session Produces Headway
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union on Tuesday edged closer to an understanding on the military future of Germany, but kept the results of their post-summit deliberations secret. ``The area of mutual understanding on these complex issues seems to be broadening,'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said after a two-hour session with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Asked if they had made progress, Baker said: ``I think we did.'' On the table at the Soviet embassy were a nine-point Western package of assurances against German aggression and a Soviet proposal to enhance trust between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Baker will take the results to a NATO council meeting in Scotland on Thursday and Shevardnadze to a Warsaw Pact session in Moscow at the end of the week. The Western assurances include a promise that a unified Germany would not acquire nuclear or chemical weapons and that NATO forces would not move into what is now East Germany after the merged country joined the Western camp. The Soviet proposal, meanwhile, involves an exchange of political statements between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, which Shevardnadze said is governed by a ``defensive doctrine'' that does not threaten the West. Baker, who first heard about the idea during superpower talks in Washington last weekend said he knew ``a little bit'' more about the Soviet proposition. Shevardnadze declined to provide any details to reporters. ``Not for the time being, it's too early,'' he said. ``We need to do some more work on that.'' He said the two superpowers, along with Britain, France, West Germany and East Germany, would explore the subject at their next ``two-plus-four'' session. Shevardnadze was referring to the meeting of the foreign ministers of the four World War II allies and the two Germanys tentatively scheduled to be held in Berlin on June 21. The German issue also is the central topic at the North Atlantic Council meeting in Turnberry, Scotland, that begins Thursday and at the the Warsaw Pact meeting in Moscow at the end of the week. Additionally, Shevardnadze said, ``we discussed future contacts. We set no dates or venues. But we concluded we need those future contacts.'' The stepped-up pace of East-West discussion of Germany's military future reflects a decision by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to pursue a settlement even though none was reached at their Washington summit, which ended Sunday. ``We need to do some homework,'' Shevardnadze said. ``We need to explore some options.'' He described his meeting with Baker as ``very useful'' and that he was ``pleased'' with their discussion.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged In Son's Death Said He Thought Prayer Was Helping Boy
DOC.TEXT: A Christian Scientist accused of manslaughter for not seeking medical help for his son's fatal ailment testified Tuesday that he had believed prayer was helping the boy. Special Prosecutor John Kiernan cross-examined David Twitchell in an effort to uncover inconsistencies in prior testimony about the severity of the five-day illness of Twitchell's 2{-year-old son Robyn, who died four years ago of a bowel obstruction. Both Twitchell and his wife, Ginger, both 34, are accused of manslaughter. The Boston-based Christian Science Church teaches that disease, like sin, can be healed by spiritual means alone. Twitchell testified he was concerned over his son's health but believed that prayer was working for Robyn, even during the last few hours of his life. Kiernan again questioned Twitchell on whether he made a mistake in not taking his son to doctors when he began vomiting and gesturing at his stomach. ``If they could hawhy you didn't call a doctor for Robyn, because you wanted to maintain your spiritual purity?'' Kiernan asked Tuesday. ``Absolutely not,'' Twitchell replied. Under questioning by defense attorney Rikki Klieman, Twitchell testified about his knowledge of legal obligations for a Christian Scientist. For example, he said, Christian Scientists were not exempt from required prenatal blood tests, such as one given to his wife, but that school children did not have to be immunized. Prosecutors have emphasized they are not putting the Christian Science faith on trial, but that they are seeking to protect children placed at risk by parents who rely solely on spiritual healing.

DOC.HEAD: Late Millionaire's Secretary Reveals Gifts Given to Other Women
DOC.TEXT: An elderly businessman who gave more than $1 million to twins who posed for Playboy also lavished other young female companions with expensive gifts, his former secretary testified Tuesday. Shirley Schlodter, secretary for David Kritzik from 1972 to 1988, said her late boss provided money and costly gifts, such as a condominium, to at least five others. Ms. Schlodter testified during the second day of former Playboy model Leigh Ann Conley's trial in U.S. District Court on four misdemeanor counts of failing to file federal income taxes. The government alleges Ms. Conley, 35, failed to pay taxes on $398,000 she received during a four-year relationship with the suburban Milwaukee businessman who died last year at age 89. The charges carry a maximum penalty of four years in prison and $325,000 in fines. The trial, which opened Monday, is expected to last a week. Ms. Conley's twin sister, Lynnette Harris, was convicted May 5 of evading taxes on $686,000 she received from Kritzik in a case the prosecution described as a sex-for-pay scheme. Ms. Harris, who faces sentencing July 25, could receive a maximum of 12 years in prison and a $625,000 fine. Her lawyer, Dennis Coffey, said the verdict will be appealed. The identical blondes, who grew up in Milwaukee, appeared nude in Playboy magazine and in two films, ``I, the Jury,'' and ``Sorceress.'' The government alleges Kritzik paid money to the twins for arranged relationships and the twins were obligated to report the money as taxable income. Ms. Schlodter testified that 36 checks presented as government evidence were written and deposited by Kritzik but endorsed with Ms. Conley's name. Kritzik also wrote checks to other female companions, but Ms. Schlodter said she did not know if he similarily endorsed those checks. Ms. Schlodter's testimony came after Lee A. Jones, a claim representative for State Farm Insurance, testified that Ms. Conley told him in 1988 she had filed income taxes the previous three years. Jones said Ms. Conley also estimated her income at $30,000 to $35,000 a year. Much of Tuesday's morning proceedings was held outside the jury presence as defense and prosecution wrangled over the admissibility of government evidence. Kritzik, who reputedly gave both sisters more than $1.1 million, founded General Merchandise Co. in the 1930s. The company became one of the world's largest mail order companies. As part of the company, Kritzik later founded Treasure Island Discount Store Chain. He sold General Merchandise to J.C. Penny Co. in 1962 for $11 million.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Terminally Ill Man Killed Self and Handicapped Son
DOC.TEXT: A terminally ill man fearful no one would care for his handicapped son killed himself and his son, police said Tuesday. The bodies of Raymond S. Short, 82, and Raymond S. Short Jr., 58, were found in a family car outside their home, police said. A hose was rigged from the exhaust to the car's interior. State Police Trooper D.L. Kidd said they apparently died of carbon monoxide poisoning but autopsy results were incomplete. The elder Short propped a bar against the passenger door to keep his son from getting out of the car, said State Police Sgt. B.R. Lester. ``We believe the father did it because he was terminally ill and was afraid no one would care for his son,'' Lester said. ``The son wasn't aware of what was happening and would not have been capable of recognizing he was in danger.'' The younger Short had a mental illness, never worked and had always lived with his parents, police said. The elder Short's wife died several years ago and the couple had no other children. Their bodies were found Sunday by neighbors in this small town 40 miles southwest of Charleston. The car's engine was still running. ``You won't find a person who has anything bad to say about Raymond,'' said Larry Lowe, a refinery supervisor at Huntington Alloys, where Short worked.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvians Flee Villages After Volcano Spews Ash
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of families abandoned their homes near 21,000-foot Sabancaya volcano in the southern Andes when it started rumbling and spewing gray ash, a Lima newspaper reported Tuesday. The El Comercio said the volcano began shooting out smoke and ash on Sunday, prompting peasants to evacuate six mountain villages the following day. It quoted a nearby resident as saying Sabancaya was producing sounds ``like explosions,'' but that no earth tremors were felt. Geologists went to the site, 690 miles southeast of Lima, to install seismographic equipment to monitor the volcano, the report said. Geologist Roberto Kosaka told the paper a violent eruption was unlikely. Kosaka said if the volcano did enter an eruption phase, lava would flow out slowly, giving residents time to evacuate. Elsewhere in Peru, Shining Path guerrillas briefly took over a radio station in Cuzco, Peru's tourism center, and broadcast a message urging people not to vote in Sunday's presidential elections, police said. They said two men and a woman with submachine guns broke into the downtown studio Monday night, locked eight station employees in a bathroom and broadcast the 25-minute prerecorded message. In Sunday's presidential election, center-right novelist Mario Vargas Llosa opposes Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer and son of Japanese immigrants. Fujimori maintains a slight lead, according to recent voter polls. The Maoist-oriented Shining Path has been fighting Peru's elected governments for 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Canine the Target of Dogged Pursuit
DOC.TEXT: A missing pooch named Buford was at the heart of a dogged custody battle Tuesday as town officials waited for its master to return the mutt that apparently fled new owners who claimed it at the dog pound. James Murdock lost ownership of Buford when he failed to pay required fees and fines within 10 days of the stray's capture, said town Dog Officer Robert Battistoni. ``My opinion is that the man doesn't want to pay,'' Battistoni said. ``Everyone else has to pay.'' Man and dog were reunited Saturday when Murdock said Buford leaped into the back of his pickup truck outside a doughnut shop. Now neither can be found. The short-haired pointer apparently ran away from its new owners, who officials declined to identify, but not everyone accepted that theory. ``To me it's amazing that a dog gets loose and jumps in the truck,'' said town spokesman Karl Stinehart. ``I don't know if it's like Lassie (and) it has a homing signal.'' After Buford was picked up by authorities in mid-May, Murdock was told would have to pay dog pound boarding fees and a fine for violating town leash laws, Stinehart said. An exact bill had not been computed, but it would amount to about $100, officials said. When the new owner reported the dog missing, authorities visited Murdock, who initially denied having Buford. He was ordered to return the dog, but no deadline was given, Stinehart said. Murdock was contacted by the the Springfield Union-News after the weekend reunion, but had little to say beyond his account of their reunion. ``It's our dog,'' he said. Telephone calls by The Associated Press to Murdock's home rang unanswered Tuesday and an official at his workplace said he was not there. Town officials said they want to reach a settlement rather than seek any criminal charges against Murdock. Battistoni said the dog's new owners are willing to give Buford back to Murdock if they are reimbursed the adoption charge they paid. Stinehart questioned Murdock's attachment to Buford because he didn't claim the dog while it was at the pound. ``If someone really wants a dog or if it's as important to them as a child, then they're going to get it within the time period,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rotary Club Launched in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Rotary International, the worldwide service organization, opened its first club in the Soviet Union on Tuesday, expanding its network to 169 nations. The Moscow club has 25 members, including businessmen, a theater manager and the head of a translation agency, officials of the group said. The organization has never had a club in Moscow. It was evicted from Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after those independent states were annexed by the Soviet Union during World War II, said Rotary President Hugh Archer. It was also evicted from 19 other countries ``where heavy socialist ideology was the one selected by the government,'' said Archer, of Dearborn, Mich. ``In the U.S.S.R., being a socialist country, it too had that impression that Rotary was not a welcome member in its society,'' he said. In the past three years, Rotary began receiving inquiries from Soviet officials and citizens. The political changes that have occurred in Eastern Europe ``opened the door even wider,'' and the organization was invited this year to open a Moscow club, he said. Rotary also plans to open branches in Leningrad, Kiev and Irkutsk, the official Tass news agency reported. Viktor Mozolin, a lawyer and business law professor who is president of the Moscow club, said its opening was ``connected to the whole process of democratic reform in the Soviet Union.'' When asked whether the Communist Party and other Soviet agencies did not already perform the humanitarian and service activities that Rotary sponsors, Mozolin said there would be the ``duplication of some functions which belong in this country to the Communist Party, as well as our Komsomol and the unions and maybe some other humanitarian organizations .... But I don't think this will be a repetition of the functions.'' Komsomol is the Communist youth league. The club is seeking to ``join together people from different professions and various political views,'' Mozolin said. Rotary, which brings together community and business leaders to build international goodwill, opened clubs this year in East Germany and Czechoslovakia, Archer said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Predicts Important Announcement
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Tuesday he expects President F.W. de Klerk to make an important announcement during the black leader's six-week tour of Europe, North America and Africa. There has been strong speculation in South Africa that the government intends to end the national state of emergency within days. Mandela said he hopes the four-year-old state of emergency will be lifted and added that he expects ``a very important statement from Mr. de Klerk in my absence.'' Mandela was speaking at a news conference at the end of his two-day visit to Botswana, before flying to Paris via London. State-of-emergency regulations restrict reporting about unrest, security force actions, treatment of detainees, some forms of protest, and a broad range of statements the government considers subversive. Enforcement of the regulations has not been comprehensive. Mandela reiterated his ``very favorable impression'' of De Klerk, but said the government has not yet approached the black majority's demand of ``one person, one vote.'' It was the ANC leader's first visit visit to Botswana since his release from prison on Feb. 11 after spending 27 years in jail for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Mandela, 71, reiterated his call for economic sanctions against South Africa. He also insisted there was ``no question'' of establishing specific protection for the rights of whites and other minorities when a new constitution is drawn up. Mandela's 13-nation tour includes visits to the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland, Italy, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys General Take up Dispute Over Location of Shipyard
DOC.TEXT: A ``border war'' sparked by a politician's claim that Portsmouth Naval Shipyard is in New Hampshire spilled over into Maine on Tuesday, as the states' attorneys general met to discuss the skirmish. ``We had an excellent meeting, but I certainly saw nothing that would indicate that the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard is not in Maine,'' Attorney General James E. Tierney said after a closed-door session with his New Hampshire counterpart, John P. Arnold. Arnold stopped short of saying he believes the shipyard is in New Hampshire. But he said evidence produced a day earlier by U.S. Rep. Bob Smith, a Republican running for the Senate, was serious. ``From New Hampshire's standpoint, I would not view it as a carnival issue,'' Arnold said. The two states agreed to continue negotiations as they try to resolve the dispute. Tierney and Arnold refused to disclose specifics of their discussions. Critics have said Smith brought up the issue to gain publicity in his GOP primary campaign. Tierney requested the meeting with Arnold a week before a contested primary election in which he hopes to become the Democratic nominee in Maine's 1st Congressional District race, but he disputed the suggestion that he might trying to bolster his own ambitions. ``I would be delighted if Congressman Smith had not had his press conference'' a day earlier in Portsmouth, N.H., Tierney said. Should New Hampshire take Maine to court, the case would go directly to the U.S. Supreme Court. Tierney asked Arnold to refrain from doing so, but Arnold was not ready to surrender New Hampshire's potential claim to Seavey's Island in the Piscataqua River, the shipyard's location. New Hampshire residents who work at the shipyard pay Maine income tax, and they are particularly angry over a so-called spousal tax that Maine levies on joint returns. That taxes the income of the spouse who works in Maine based on the entire household's income, even if some comes from New Hampshire, which has no personal income tax.
