According to Victor Bourre, a shipyard worker and New Hampshire resident who started exploring the question in 1987 because he was tired of paying the Maine income tax, the territory now known as Maine originally included all land beyond _ north and east of _ the Piscataqua River. King George II's 1737 ruling settled a border dispute between New Hampshire and Massachusetts, then both British colonies. That ruling moved the boundary between New Hampshire and Maine, then part of Massachusetts, to the middle of the river, he said. Tierney and Arnold said their staffers would meet within the next few weeks to discuss the issue further. The next meeting will be in New Hampshire. Arnold brought documents purporting to show that the shipyard is really in New Hampshire because of boundaries that were set up in colonial days. Tierney said he would review New Hampshire's evidence, but he plans to stick to boundaries that were in place when Maine became a state in 1820. If the states end up slugging it out before the Supreme Court, the case could take years to resolve and cost each side millions of dollars, Tierney said. Lawyers might have to go to England to research documents dating back centuries and expensive expert witnesses would have to be assembled, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Approve New Statement of Faith
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th and SUBS final graf with 4 grafs to UPDATE with call for normalization of US-Cuba relations
DOC.TEXT: Presbyterians on Tuesday adopted a new statement of faith that mixes traditional Christian beliefs with environmental concerns and images of God as both mother and father. Commissioners to the 202nd General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) stood up and cheered after voting 499-25 for the confession that represents the first statement of faith since a 1983 merger healed a Civil War-era split over slavery. ``We must agree on what we believe before we can agree on much else,'' assembly Moderator Price Henderson Gwynn III said after the vote. If the document is approved by two-thirds of the denomination's 177 regional presbyteries and again by the 1991 General Assembly, it will become the 11th statement of faith in the denomination's Book of Confessions. In other business, the assembly voted to allocate $1 million for a five-year program to aid American black men and to advocate normalizing relations with Cuba. Some observers said the confession is particularly important for the 2.9 million-member denomination, which has lost a third of its members during the past quarter-century amid some criticism that it lacked a strong identity. ``The theological integrity of the Presbyterian Church depends on the statement of faith,'' said the Rev. Jack Stotts, chairman of the committee that developed the statement. Stotts, president of Austin Theological Seminary in Texas, said the confession was designed to retain the historic faith while ``speaking both in the idiom of the contemporary world and to the concerns of the contemporary world.'' The statement upholds centuries-old church teachings that Jesus Christ was both fully human and fully God, and that God raised Jesus from the dead to offer eternal life. Reflecting more recent church concerns, the confession states human beings deserve God's condemnation for the way they exploit nature, ``and threaten death to the planet entrusted to our care.'' Among other contemporary elements, the statement declares that God calls women and men to all ministries of the church, and likens God to both a mother who will not forsake her nursing child and a father ``who runs to welcome the prodigal home.'' In a denomination where slavery led to a 122-year split between its northern and southern branches, the new statement affirms God ``makes everyone equally in God's image, male and female, of every race and people, to live as one community.'' The Rev. John Mulder, who helped direct a three-year study of the church involving 55 research projects, said one of the findings was that the increasing diversity of beliefs and moral behavior within the church placed the denomination at risk ``of losing a clear and well-defined identity.'' But he said the new confession is a hopeful sign for the church. ``I think the statement of faith is a reflection of the church's ability, even in the face of considerable diversity, that we are still capable of forming a unified statement of Christian belief that is consistent with our tradition,'' said Mulder, president of Louisville Presbyterian Seminary in Kentucky. ``The striking thing to me about the confession, No. 1, is that it got written at all.'' The church, whose membership is less than 2 percent black, voted to spend $1 million over five years to develop and implement outreach and self-help programs for black men. ``I felt good when it passed,'' said Connie A. Allison, a black elder from Kings Mountain, N.C. He said the church needs to address issues of job training and providing equal opportunities for blacks. On U.S.-Cuba relations, the assembly voted 395-52 to work toward normalized relations, including reducing trade and travel restrictions, cooperating on controlling drug traffic, and postponing plans for direct television broadcasts to Cuba. A resolution calling for free elections in Cuba was defeated by 359-85.

DOC.HEAD: School Officials Issue `Ninja Turtle Alert' After Kids Lift Manhole Cover
DOC.TEXT: Stop, kids! Don't lift that manhole cover! You won't find Raphael or Donatello or any of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles down there. They're just make-believe. That message from Champaign school officials came as a surprise to some first graders, found peeking into a sewer in search of the fictional crime-fighters. The result was a ``Ninja Turtle Alert'' sent last week to all elementary schools by Arlene Blank, assistant superintendent. ``Somehow, two first-grade girls managed to lift a manhole cover off,'' said Blank. ``By the time the adults got there, they had been joined by two first-grade boys. ``One of the boys was about to climb down into the manhole.'' Their motive was simple. ``They said they were looking for the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' said Blank. ``They were very serious about it.'' Worried that other children might try the same thing, Blank issued the alert. Her memo asks staff members to talk with pupils from pre-kindergarten through third grade and explain that the pizza-eating reptiles are not real. Blank said the youngsters could have been injured or drowned if they had fallen into the rain-swollen sewer system. ``I think some kids think they exist,'' said Kevin Fletcher, 8. ``I don't think they're really alive. I like to think of them as make-believe.'' Originally comic book characters, the half-turtle, half-human ninja warriors are the hottest kid craze since Batman, particularly since the release of a motion picture featuring them in March. The premise: dimestore pet turtles are dropped down a sewer manhole, fall into radioactive slime, grow to be 6 feet tall and are trained by a giant ninja rat to defend liberty. ``The Ninja Turtles are a nice story, but that's all they are,'' said Blank.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Accused in Stomping Death Should Be Tried as Adult, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager accused of leading a mob that stomped a man to death in a racial attack police likened to ``sharks in an eating frenzy,'' should be tried as an adult, the state Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. Justices agreed with a juvenile court finding that the brutality of the attack and sentencing limits that would have forced his release at age 21 made trial as adult necessary. Joseph Taylor, 17, was indicted in March 1989 on charges of murder and robbery in connection with the Sept. 24, 1988, death of William J. Roberts, 35, of North Kingstown. Taylor was 16 when Roberts was killed while allegedly trying to buy drugs at a Providence housing project. He turns 18 on June 26. Police officials at the time likened the attack to ``sharks in an eating frenzy'' and said it had racial overtones. A witness testified that Taylor, who is black, told Roberts, who was white, ``I'll kill you. This is what I think about white people.'' Up to a dozen people joined in the attack, witnesses said. Five were charged. Three youths pleaded guilty in juvenile court. In its ruling, the Supreme Court said there was evidence to conclude that Taylor ``repeatedly jumped up and down on the face and chest of the victim.'' Taylor has denied being the mob leader and wanted to be tried as a juvenile. Taylor's public defender, Chris O'Neill, declined to comment on the ruling, citing office policy. The high court also denied Taylor's appeal of a ruling that he be held without bail at an adult lockup. Trial was scheduled for June 18. If convicted of first-degree murder, Taylor could face a mandatory life prison sentence. Second-degree murder carries possible penalties ranging from a minimum 10-year term to life imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Captured Guerrilla Says Civilians Were Target of Raid
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian guerrilla leader captured in last week's failed sea raid said Tuesday his squad had orders to spray the Tel Aviv hotel district with machine gun fire and ``kill any person we encountered.'' He also said his Palestine Liberation Front squad was trained by Libyan instructors in that North African country for 18 months, carried out joint exercises with the Libyan navy and was accompanied en route to Israel by a Libyan lieutenant colonel. The captured guerrilla, identified as Ahmed Mohammed Yusuf, the squad's deputy commander, spoke on Israel television's Arabic-language nightly news. The curly haired, heavy-set Yusuf, 28, wore olive green military-style clothing and spoke calmly. His remarks, if proven accurate, provide the most detailed account of the May 30 raid in which two guerrilla boats sped toward the Israeli coast. One was intercepted at sea, and a second one landed near a beach south of Tel Aviv. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. Asked what orders he had, Yusuf said: ``The target area was the hotel district. First to bombard the area from the sea with Katyusha rockets ... after shelling and machine gun fire, to go ashore and storm (the target). They asked me to enter the Sheraton Hotel, to kill everyone inside.'' When asked to clarify, Yusuf added: ``The targets of the operation were civilian and not military. We were asked not to have mercy on anyone and to kill any person we encountered.'' His account contradicted statements by the Palestinian faction's leader Mohammed Abbas, who has said the attack was aimed at military targets, not civilians. The remarks could cast a further shadow on the U.S.-PLO dialogue that was launched by Washington after PLO chief Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism in December 1988. A senior U.S. administration official said in Washington on Monday that the dialogue was ``clearly in jeopardy'' following the attempted raid on Israel. The United States is demanding that the PLO disassociate itself from the attack and condemn it. Washington is also asking the PLO to expel Abbas, who is part of the PLO's 15-member Executive Committee. Yusuf said Libyan instructors taught the squad how to swim and operate small rubber boats and gave lessons in navigation and naval tactics. ``A frigate accompanied us and participated in an exercise with us,'' he said. ``The man from the Libyan navy responsible (for us) would give us orders.'' The Libyan officer, identified by Yusuf as Lt. Col. Zuheir, also accompanied the guerrillas on the civilian Libyan vessel that carried the squad toward Israel. Also aboard was Abu-Al-Az, the deputy leader of the PLF, said Yusuf. If captured, ``the instructions were that no one was to admit where we trained, who helped us and who gave us weapons and boats,'' Yusuf said. Yusuf, who was born in Kuneitra, Syria, said he was a member of Arafat's mainstream Fatah group before joining the Abbas faction in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Recurring Chest Pains Keep Michael Jackson Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Persistent chest pains delayed necessary tests to determine if stricked pop sensation Michael Jackson has heart troubles, his spokesman said Tuesday. Cardiologist Mark Zatzkis says a ``temporary setback'' in Jackson's condition Monday forced him to postpone tests that may keep the singer-songwriter hospitalized an additional day or two, said Bob Jones. ``In the meantime, Mr. Jackson remains under observation. His condition is stable and he is resting comfortably,'' said Jones, vice president of communications for Jackson's MJJ Productions. Zatzkis wasn't available for direct comment. The 31-year-old Jackson had been ill several days when he suffered chest pains Sunday night at his Los Angeles home and was taken to St. John's Hospital and Health Center. It wasn't believed Jackson, described by Jones as ``a health nut,'' had a heart attack. The singer has been under stress due to the recent deaths of people close to him and pressure to complete an album, he said. ``Michael Jackson's very close friend and mentor Sammy Davis passed; within the last four weeks his grandmother passed; Ryan White, a young man he was very close to, passed; and the pressure of the album; all of these things could be stressful,'' Jones told a news conference. Jackson's friend Elizabeth Taylor, reported ``doing well'' after a near-fatal bout with pneumonia in April, has a suite on the same hospital floor.

DOC.HEAD: Children's TV Programs Honored
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Michael in 9th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty TV programs were cited for excellence Tuesday by Action for Children's Television and will be honored in a ceremony dedicated to the memory of Muppets creator Jim Henson. Among the programs noted for both their diversity and their lack of commercial abuses aimed at children were: ``CNN Newsroom,'' an episode of ``Murphy Brown'' and ``Wonderworks.'' Except for special award for CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' no other award went to a commercial network series. The awards will be presented at a luncheon Wednesday. ``Particularly depressing is the extent to which marketing to children has replaced creativity, with products embedded in TV programs and ads introducing and even interrupting kids' videos,'' said the group's president Peggy Charren. Commercial stations in only two cities, Pittsburgh and Boston, won awards from the group. ``It's a nationwide contest so it says that kids across the country are not getting enough choices from television,'' said Charren. ``Pittsburgh and Boston are doing nifty local programs but for the country as a whole, local programs for children are kind of an extinct dinosaur.'' Charren said she dedicated the ceremony to Henson because his creations ``will continue to inspire television producers who care about children.'' Action for Children's Television was formed 22 years ago in part to push for legislation to limit the number of television advertisements directed at children. KTVU in San Francisco and a statewide campaign in Alaska header by the governor's wife, Michael Cowper, were honored in the public service announcement category. And a special award went to ``I Want My FYI,'' an episode of the Murphy Brown series on CBS focusing on the need for TV news for children. The awards were as follows: Public Television: _ WGBH, Boston for ``Long Ago and Far Away.'' _ WNET, New York and Quality Family Entertainment for Shining Time Station. _ WQED, Pittsburgh for ``Wonderworks.'' _ Maryland Public Television for ``TimeLine.'' Commercial Television: _ WCVB, Boston for ``A Likely Story.'' _ KDKA, Pittsburgh, for ``Let's Read a Story.'' _ WTAE, Pittsburgh for ``Cappelli and Company.'' _ WHDH, Boston for ``Ready to Go.'' Cable Television: _ CNBC for K-TV, ``features for kids on a lively magazine show.'' _ CNN for CNN Newsroom, a daily, commercial-free newscast offered in schools. _ Showtime for ``Familytime.'' _ Nickelodeon for ``Make the Grade.'' _ HBO for Babar. _ The Disney Channel for ``Lunch Box.'' Home Video: _ SVS Inc. and Rabbit Ears Productions for ``How the Leopard Got His Spots.'' _ Media Home Entertainment and Joshua Greene for ``Noah's Ark.' _ Media Home Entertainment for ``Madeline.'' _ Fries Home Video for ``Lamb Chop's Sing-Along, Play-Along.'' _ CC Studios for ``The Amazing Bone and Other Stories.''

DOC.HEAD: `Mystery Witness' Backs Off Account of Bensonhurst Attack
DOC.TEXT: A ``mystery witness'' in the Bensonhurst racial attack who emerged after the case went to court admitted Tuesday she made up her story, prosecutors said. ``It is now clear that she was not a witness to events of that tragic night as she had claimed,'' Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said in a statement after the woman was interviewed by prosecutors. Several weeks ago, the woman identified variously as ``Iris'' and ``Maria'' told reporters she watched as a white mob surrounded Yusuf Hawkins and that she saw Joseph Fama fatally shoot the black teen-ager through the chest. However, she canceled several scheduled meetings with prosecutors, and was interviewed by them for the first time last week, only after she was located by the police. During that meeting last Thursday she repeated to prosecutors the story she had told newspapers and television stations. ``Earlier today, the woman, accompanied by her husband, gave a statement retracting all her previous accounts,'' Hynes said. He said she would not be charged for making the false statements to prosecutors. ``Her motives remain unclear. ... It can't be explained or accounted for,'' a law-enforcement source said. The woman was unable to pick defendants yet to be tried out of a photo array and said her account ``came to her in a dream,'' the source said. Prosecutors had said that if her account of the Aug. 23 slaying was true she could have been a witness in future Bensonhurst trials and in a possible federal investigation into civil rights charges against Keith Mondello. Mondello, the alleged ringleader of the white mob that chased and surrounded Hawkins, was acquitted May 18 of murder and manslaughter, but convicted of several lesser charges. A day earlier, Fama was convicted of murder. The two men, both 19, are to be sentenced Monday. Fama faces up to 25 years to life, and Mondello faces eight to 24 years, according to prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: `Kiss of the Spider Woman' Opens New Musicals Project
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Kiss of the Spider Woman'' is nothing if not ambitious, an attempt to stretch the American musical theater beyond such landmark concept musicals as ``Cabaret,'' ``Company'' and ``Follies.'' If its ambition sometimes overwhelms its execution, well, that is why there is New Musicals, a for-profit laboratory for the development of new shows at the State University of New York in Purchase. The show, playing at the school's Performing Arts Center, runs through June 24. But ``laboratory'' is not the word to describe this production directed with remarkable fluidity by Harold Prince. ``Kiss of the Spider Woman'' is of Broadway size, scope and quality. And that's why it may be so difficult to really change the show without a major overhauling of its production values. The musical is based on the Manuel Puig novel that later became a movie starring William Hurt and Raul Julia. It tells the story of two men jailed in an unnamed Latin American country. Valentin is a political prisoner. Molina is a sexual offender, a flamboyant homosexual charged with molesting a minor. ``Spider Woman'' chronicles their time together in a cell _ from hostility to acceptance to understanding to love. What cements their relationship is Molina's retelling of old movie plots, particularly a hoary, 1940s movie musical called ``Man Overboard.'' Numbers from this Technicolor song and dance alternate with grim prison scenes. If the idea sounds familiar, it's similiar to what Prince and the songwriting team of John Kander and Fred Ebb did in ``Cabaret,'' their first collaboration nearly 25 years ago. In that show, set in the late 1920s, a Berlin cabaret became a symbol for Germany's ominous embrace of Hitler. In ``Spider Woman,'' the symbolism is not as obvious. The movie musical numbers pale in comparison to the story of two men who gradually gain mutual self-respect through the telling of this hokey celluoid tale in which Molina and the movie heroine become one. The Kander and Ebb score contains some of the team's most complex and challenging work. Kander's melodies are among the best he has ever written, and they are showcased effectively in Michael Gibson's evocative orchestrations. Ebb's lyrics don't settle for the obvious or glib. Their numbers range from sweet love songs _ there's a stunning quartet called ``Dear One'' _ to stirring political anthems to exotic tropical dance numbers. The musical actually contains a score within a score, one set of songs being part of the movie musical Molina is spinning for Valentin. It's here where the musical falters, not so much in the songs but in the conventional staging by choreographer Susan Stroman. Molina is enraptured by these movie musical scenes, and theatergoers should be, too. But more often than not, the numbers just mark time, making one question Molina's taste and obsession with the silver screen. One particularly athletic number makes the male dance ensemble look like the cast of ``Mister Roberts'' doing aerobics. Not until nearly the end of the evening when the movie and real life merge in the driving, rhythmic title song does Stroman's work come together. Playwright Terrence McNally, who provided the book, has more success, particularly with the quiet, intimate scenes between the two prisoners. John Rubinstein, never stooping to caricature, makes a credible, even moving Molina. Kevin Gray is more enigmatic as the mysterious political prisoner Valentin, although he has the show's best voice and uses it well. Lauren Mitchell, who plays the show's title character, is saddled with most of those mediocre movie production numbers. But her personality is not forceful enough, making one wish for the sensual and hypnotizing Sonia Braga who galvanized the movie version of ``Spider Woman.'' The physical production of the show, designed by Thomas Lynch, is huge, filling the stage of a theater that has the ambiance and charm of an airplane hangar. The supposedly tiny prison cell for Molina and Valentin looks bigger than most Manhattan apartments. The distance between the playing area and the audience puts any meaningful character development at a disadvantage, although the wide spaces allow lighting designer Peter A. Kaczorowski to splash some stunning displays of light, symbolizing prison bars, across the stage. Prince and his creative team have work to do, despite their strong, uncompromising story and wonderful score, if the show eventually is to make its way to Broadway. ``Kiss of the Spider Woman'' knows what it wants to say. Now it just has to find a more effective way to say it.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound-Bankruptcy: No End to Strike, Union Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Greyhound Dial...' to CORRECT sale price to $270 million sted $350 million. Longer version moved on financial wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SUC1
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. on Tuesday promised to continue service despite a bankruptcy reorganization filing that delighted striking drivers and raised questions about the future of the nation's only intercity bus carrier. Listing liabilities of almost $540 million, the Dallas-based company filed Monday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors while it tries to reorganize its finances. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Richard Schmidt scheduled a hearing for Thursday morning in Brownsville. ``Passengers won't see any changes at all,'' said Liz Hale, a Greyhound spokeswoman. There were no reports of riders flocking for refunds after the filing, but those who wanted refunds should contact local customer service representatives, she said. All tickets were being honored, she said. Greyhound Dial Corp., which leases some buses and buildings to the bus company, set $100 million aside from after-tax earnings to establish a reserve for possible losses related to Greyhound Lines. Greyhound Dial sold the bus lines in 1987 for more than $270 million, but still holds preferred stock and notes from Greyhound Lines. ``The bankruptcy (filing) action is a positive, stabilizing move which should help solidify the troubled position of Greyhound Lines and go a long way to ensuring the long-term survival of the bus lines,'' John W. Teets, Greyhound Dial's president and chief executive officer, said in a statement. Greyhound has seen ridership and revenue fall since most of its 6,300 drivers walked out March 2 in a sometimes violent dispute over wages and job security. On May 7, Greyhound Lines chairman Fred G. Currey said the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. The company claims it now is serving communities that provided 98 percent of its revenue last year. The bankruptcy filing had been widely expected. Greyhound lost $56 million in the first quarter and has missed more than $17 million in interest and lease payments, putting it in default on some agreements. The company recently proposed buying back $225 million of its high-interest junk bonds at a steep discount. Greyhound's Chapter 11 petition listed more than 1,800 pages of creditors, assets of $508.78 million and liabilities of $539.78 million. Union officials, who maintain that Greyhound has not been operating anywhere near as many of its routes as it claims, cheered the bankruptcy filing. ``It illustrates the point that Fred Currey has been lying about the company's finances, lying about ridership and lying about the ability of scab drivers to serve the public,'' said Michael Holden, vice president of Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1205 in Boston. W.R. Gibson, Jr., president Kansas City-based Local 1313, said the union probably would ask the bankruptcy court to appoint a trustee to manage the company. ``We're going to plan on replacing Fred Currey,'' Gibson said Tuesday. Unions striking against Eastern Airlines got a bankruptcy judge to appoint a trustee for that company earlier this year, although such a move is considered unusual. Several industry analysts predicted Greyhound would emerge from reorganization as a smaller carrier servicing even fewer routes _ especially to small communities _ than before the strike. ``I would see it as a very positive kind of move,'' said Jim Cammisa, publisher of ``Travel Industry Indicators'' in Miami. ``Prior to the strike, they were marginally profitable on an income basis. There's no reason, with their ridership up to 75 or 80 percent, why they can't pass a break-even profit level fairly soon.'' Others said the reorganization could help Greyhound raise badly needed working capital, but would delay the company's attempted $225 million junk bond buyback. The Chapter 11 filing buys time for Greyhound at the start of the busy summer travel season but may force it to sell assets and jettison bus routes, said Phua K. Young, a Shearson Lehman Hutton analyst in New York. ``Serving a lot of smaller communities, I'm afraid, has gone the way of the dinosaurs. A lot of mom-and-pop bus operators out there are just waiting to see what lines that Greyhound wants to get rid of,'' he said. ``That's where the future lies for regional carriers.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Rebels to Seek Peace with Government
DOC.TEXT: Three leftist guerrilla groups said Tuesday they have agreed to begin peace talks with the government. Leaders of the Popular Liberation Army, Quintin Lame and the Workers' Revolutionary Party said in a joint statement published in newspapers Tuesday that they are willing to work toward a ``stable and durable peace.'' Government peace negotiator Rafael Pardo met Monday with their representatives. According to the statement, signed by Pardo and the guerrillas, the government and rebels will hold meetings to establish a framework for the rebels' demobilization. Two other major insurgent groups, the National Liberation Army and the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia, took no part in Monday's talks. Initial talks between the government and the three groups began last month. Earlier, the M-19 guerrilla group ended two decades of armed struggle by signing a peace treaty with the government. M-19 leader Antonio Navarro ran for president in May 27 elections and came in third with about 12 percent of the vote _ considered the best showing for any leftist candidate in Colombian history. Many Colombians hope this will lead other rebel groups to seek peace. Guerrilla violence in the countryside continued. In the last four days, at least four soldiers and six guerrillas died in clashes, army spokeswoman Lt. Maria Teresa Garcia told The Associated Press. Guerrillas of the National Liberation Army, known as the ELN, stormed a coal mine in northern Colombia on Monday, kidnapping four workers and stealing explosives, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Junk Bonds Continue to Slide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf, `The Taj ...' to UPDATE with casino's May results; picks up 18th graf, `The Journal ...' Also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trump-Cash, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prices of junk bonds used to finance part of Donald Trump's empire fell again Tuesday amid speculation that negotiations between the developer and his bankers would further reduce the value of the securities. Bondholders, meanwhile, filed a class action lawsuit seeking to block Trump and his associates from promoting his new Taj Mahal casino at the expense of the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle holdings in Atlantic City, N.J. The price of 14 percent bonds used to back the Taj Mahal was quoted at $54 to $55 per $100 in face value late Tuesday, down from $56-$58 on Monday. Junk bonds tied to other Trump holdings fared somewhat better. The Trump Plaza casino's 12~ percent issues were quoted at $81-$82, down from $82-$83, and 13} percent issues backing the Trump Castle casino were little changed at $59-$60. Prices for the issues fell sharply Monday _ with the Taj bonds skidding as much as $10 _ when Trump confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal that he has been meeting with major lenders who have grown increasingly uneasy about his ability to handle his reported $2 billion in bank debt. The lenders, who include units of Bankers Trust Co., Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., are said to be seeking a restructuring of the developer's holdings, including a possible sale of some Trump assets. The U.S. District Court lawsuit claimed Trump gave the Taj a confidential list of ``high level gamblers and affluent clientele'' of the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle without compensating the hotels for the information, in violation of bond agreements. The lawsuit claims Trump also violated federal securities laws by not disclosing the transaction and seeks an order barring him from using any of the hotels' information or assets to benefit the Taj. It also seeks unspecified damages for the sharp decline in value of the bonds. Trump Plaza bonds have declined from 102 percent of face value to 82 percent since August, while Trump Castle bonds dropped from 103 percent to 70 percent, the lawsuit claimed. Trump's talks with the banks have been under way for about two weeks. Dan Klores, a spokesman for Trump, refused to say whether the two sides were meeting Tuesday or to give any information beyond Trump's brief statement on Monday. ``At this point, these are things that are between the Trump organization and other people and we're not at liberty to talk about that,'' Klores said. Investors have been unsettled by reports that the banks were trying to prevent Trump from making upcoming payments to junk bondholders. Such a move would devastate the value of the risky securities, which are attractive to investors because they pay a much higher interest rate than other bonds. Trump's lenders are believed to be concerned that his holdings, including the casinos, are not producing enough cash to meet interest payments. The developer has maintained in recent months he has no cash flow problems. He did announce in late April that he was considering putting some of his assets on the block _ including the Northeast air shuttle he bought from Eastern Airlines for $365 million last year _ but claimed he wanted to raise cash to buy new properties. Trump's other assets include the Plaza Hotel, Trump Tower skyscraper and several apartment buildings in Manhattan. Trump's lenders are concerned because of a downturn in the real estate market. Furthermore, the $1 billion Taj Mahal, which opened two months ago, has not flourished amid the plethora of casinos in Atlantic City. The Taj Mahal junk bonds have been hit the hardest because they are seen as the riskiest investment. Analysts say the cash flow from the other casinos is more certain at this point than that of the Taj Mahal. Casino officials reported Tuesday that the Taj Mahal posted a win of $36.5 million in May, a monthly record for an Atlantic City casino. The win averaged $1.18 million a day; industry analysts have estimated it needs to make between $1 million and $1.3 million a day to break even. The Journal reported that the big banks also were concerned that if Trump does sell assets, he might not be able to get the kind of prices that he claims they are worth. The Journal story followed a string of negative reports about how well Trump's empire is doing. Forbes magazine recently sliced its estimate of the developer's net worth to $500 million from more than $1.5 billion. Trump has maintained he was having no liquidity problems.

DOC.HEAD: Five-Pound Note Shrinks, and the Queen Ages
DOC.TEXT: The British will get less for their money Wednesday as a new, smaller five pound note enters circulation engraved with a gracefully aging queen. The new fiver, the first in two decades, is designed to combat high-technology forgeries and cut production costs. ``No item created by man can't be recreated,'' said Nigel Bevitt-Smith, manager of design and development at the Bank of England's printing works. ``What we try to do is to make it time-consuming and as expensive as possible.'' The dominant blue of the older note has been lightened from navy to turquoise, and a blend of background colors was created to challenge sophisticated forgers who use modern color reproduction machines. The position and color of the numbers has also been changed to foil counterfeiters, and a silver-colored thread runs through the new note, as it already does in 10, 20 and 50 pound notes. The Bank of England, which has already printed 200 million of the new notes, said Queen Elizabeth's new portrait shows the monarch ``gracefully aged.'' The older five-pound note portrays the queen as a young, delicate brunette. Railway pioneer George Stephenson replaces the Duke of Wellington on the new notes, which have been slightly reduced in size. The fiver also contain a round turquoise symbol to make them more easily identifiable to the partially blind. All English notes will be redesigned over the next four years and will be 16 percent to 22 percent small, the Bank of England said. Bevitt-Smith said the bank will save ``a few million pounds'' from the size reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Gantt Wants To Be More Than First Black Senator From N.C.
DOC.TEXT: Harvey Gantt has made history as the first black to attend Clemson University, the first black mayor of Charlotte and now the first black to win nomination for the U.S. Senate from North Carolina this century. But Gantt said he wants his campaign against three-term Republican incumbent Sen. Jesse Helms to be about vision, not color. ``There's a difference between Jesse Helms and Harvey Gantt, and I don't just mean because I'm black and he's white,'' Gantt told audiences in the final weekend of campaigning before winning the Democratic nomination Tuesday. He said the difference is in their vision of America. ``In Jesse's vision of America, I would have never had the chance to attend Clemson University,'' Gantt said. ``And run against Jesse for the U.S. Senate? In his vision of America, I wouldn't even have been allowed to vote.'' Gantt, who took a 60 percent to 40 percent victory over Brunswick County District Attorney Mike Easley in the runoff primary, said he wants to campaign on problems that affect working people _ health care, public education and the environment. The runoff was called for by Easley after Gantt failed to win more than 40 percent of the primary vote in a six-way contest in May. Gantt beat the historical trend of minority candidates losing in runoff primaries in North Carolina. ``It's not important for me to be the state's first black senator,'' he said. ``It is important for Jesse Helms to be challenged by someone who understands the problems of the people of North Carolina.'' Gantt, a 47-year old architect with a master's degree from MIT, served two terms as mayor of North Carolina's largest city, which is 75 percent white and usually votes Republican. Before that, Gantt served on the city council. In 1987, Gantt's political fortunes were turned upside down when he lost to Republican Sue Myrick by less than 1,000 votes in the mayoral race. ``That was the worst moment I've had in politics,'' he said. ``We lost the race because we didn't put enough effort forward.'' Gantt and his wife, Cindy, have been married for 25 years. Their oldest daugther, Sonja, 24, is a journalist at WBTV in Charlotte. Erika, 19, is a student at the University of North Carolina, and Angela, 17, and Adam 14, attend public school in Charlotte. Gantt sings baritone in the choir at Friendship Baptist Church, where he is a member of the board of trustees. Gantt was the oldest of five children growing up in poverty in Charleston, S.C. He said that's one reason he wanted to run for Senate. ``One of the reasons I want to do this is because America has been good to me,'' he said. ``I'm someone who came from humble circumstances and I cannot say I live in humble circumstances now. That is what promise did for me, this belief, this hard work, this effort. I don't want to see that snuffed out for a lot of other people.''

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Faces Trouble Two Days Before His Mandate Expires
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is having trouble meeting the demands of potential coalition partners as he nears his deadline for forming Israel's next government, a senior party official said Tuesday. The assessment by Cabinet Minister Ehud Olmert, a leading member of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, comes just a day after the prime minister said he would have a majority in parliament to form a right-wing coalition government and that he expected to swear in a new Cabinet next week. ``Different parties are raising different demands,'' Olmert said. ``Maybe each one of these demands is just and true in their own eyes, but when they all have to come together in the framework of eight parties forming a coalition, it is sometimes impossible.'' ``We are making a tremendous effort to find a common denominator that would allow the coalition to be formed,'' he added, speaking on Israel Television. Despite early predictions that he would quickly form a new government, Shamir has spent the past 40 days trying to forge an alliance with small religious and right-wing parties. A new coalition would replace the national unity government the Likud formed with the center-left Labor Party. That alliance was toppled March 15 in a vote of no-confidence by the 120-member parliament. Shamir's mandate from President Chaim Herzog to form a new government expires on midnight Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Make Arms Proposals, Urge Progress in Cutting Conventional Arms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze quote, minor editing. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `In his...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Tuesday it plans to withdraw ``a very substantive'' part of its nuclear arsenal from central Europe this year. The Soviet foreign minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, told a 35-nation conference on human rights the Soviets will cut 1,500 nuclear warheads by the end of the year from central Europe. In addition, 60 tactical missile launchers and 3,200 artillery guns capable of firing nuclear shells would be cut, he said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Copenhagen for the conference, said the Western allies welcomed the announcement and added: ``The Soviets have quite an advantage in these weapons.'' But he said it was unclear how many such tactical weapons the Soviets had previously intended to withdraw, and whether they would be destroyed or redeployed. Shevardnadze said of the reduction, ``This is going to be a very substantive amount.'' He said relatively few weapons would remain, but he refused to be more specific. Asked if the weapons would be destroyed, Shevardnadze said, ``It's our intention to withdraw the weapons and discuss destruction at a subsequent phase.'' In his speech to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Shevardnadze said that ``by freeing Europe of nuclear weapons, we give further latitude to man.'' European foreign ministers responded carefully to the Soviet plan, citing the Soviet superiority in short-range weaponry. ``We have to look at this in detail,'' said Roland Dumas of France, adding, ``Anything that goes in the direction of disarmament is a good initiative.'' Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany told reporters after meeting privately with Baker, ``We first have to know what is behind this idea of the Soviets.'' He said he would await the details. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said his first impression was that ``there's not much new'' in the proposal. Disarmament is likely to be a top item at the agenda of another Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe meeting in Paris in December. The CSCE is comprised of the United States, Canada and all European states except Albania. Dumas told reporters the Paris summit would probably be held Dec. 19-21 to discuss ``the reconciliation of Europe.'' A preparatory meeting was called for July 10 in Vienna. Genscher said after meeting Shevardnadze that there was a broad understanding the Vienna talks on conventional weapons, which had slowed in recent months, should be concluded before the Paris meeting. Shevardnadze also held out hope of a compromise on the military future of a united Germany, which the West wants to see as a full member of the NATO alliance. NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact alliance were undergoing a process of ``transformation'' and starting to cooperate. In this way ``we can find a compromise on the German issue,'' he said. Baker was carrying a package of proposals to present to Shevardnadze that are designed to overcome Soviet reluctance to let Germany stay in NATO. Presidents George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev failed to resolve differences over the issue during their Washington summit over the weekend. Baker's proposal includes an offer of help by West Germany to build housing for Soviet soldiers returning home from eastern Europe, and other economic inducements. It also includes reassurances that a larger and stronger Germany would not threaten the Soviet Union, move beyond its present borders or acquire nuclear or chemical weapons, U.S. officials said. The Copenhagen meeting granted observer status to Albania in a further sign that Europe's last hard-line communist state wants to end its isolation. An application by Lithuania to attend as an observer was rejected, however. Denmark's Ellemann-Jensen said no consensus was possible since the Soviets would object to seating a separate Lithuanian delegation. The Baltic republic declared itself independent from the Soviet Union in March, and the Kremlin has imposed economic sanctions in an effort to end the independence drive.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Arrives for Talks with Bush, Quayle
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo arrived Tuesday night to discuss with President Bush his government's dramatic new push for normal relations with the Soviet Union as a step toward reunion with North Korea. Roh, Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong and members of their delegation landed at nearby Andrews Air Force Base from San Francisco, where Roh held unprecedent talks Monday with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev at the end of Gorbachev's U.S. visit. ``This historic meeting has improved prospects for peace on the Korean peninsula and eventual Korean unification,'' State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Tuesday, noting the Soviet Union's longtime role in Korean affairs. It launched North Korea as a rival to U.S.-sponsored South Korea after World War II and was North Korea's ally and weapons provider in the 1950-1953 Korean War. Boucher said the United States welcomes the prospect of normal relations between Seoul and Moscow, forecast by Roh after his talk with Gorbachev. Roh's ``northern policy'' was a foreign affairs success leading to Monday's summit with Gorbachev, ``but it has had negative consequences for human rights in South Korea,'' Asia Watch, a private, U.S.-based human rights watchdog organization said Tuesday. Asia Watch recalled in a statement that President Roh announced his northern policy in 1988 declaring that North Korea would no longer be teated as an enemy but more as a partner in development and eventual reunification of the Korean peninsula. Despite this, dozens of South Koreans ``have been jailed or otherwise harassed for advocating or working for ... precisely what the president himself now professes to be doing _ finding ways to reunify Korea,'' the statement said. It urged Bush and other U.S. officials meeting Roh during his tour ``to use every opportunity ... to press the South Korean government to implement legal reforms, including revisions of the National Security Law and to release those imprisoned for non-violent political activity.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico City Air Pollution Just One of Mexico's Environmental Woes
DOC.TEXT: This city of 19 million people, which played host to World Environment Day ceremonies Tuesday, is one of the most polluted on Earth. But impure air is only the most prominent of Mexico's ecological problems. As site of the annual U.N. event to raise environmental awareness, Mexico is focusing on making Earth ``a better planet for children.'' More than 1 million trees were being planted here and the U.N. Environment Program's Global 500 awards were presented in Mexico City on Tuesday. Mexico has been known as a transit point for species traffic, and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari promised to sign the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna, known as CITES. ``We will energetically fight the illicit traffic of species. My government has established protection for marine tortoises,'' he said in an address at the Fine Arts Palace. ``I have asked the Ecology Department to join ... (CITES).'' Mexico banned the killing of sea turtles on May 28. Environmental groups hailed it as a first step toward ending the killing of an endangered species. Those honored ranged from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain _ for drawing attention to the atmospheric deterioration called the greenhouse effect _ to Thai farmer Jom Malai, who turned his mango orchard into a bird habitat. A special prize was awarded to Chico Mendes, the Brazilian rain forest activist assassinated in 1987. A report released Tuesday by the U.N. Children's Fund, UNICEF, said environmental deterioration is killing thousands of children. ``It falls most heavily on the poorest up against the poor, the children of the developing countries pushed against the limits of survival,'' it said. In Mexico, as in other Third World countries, poverty and population growth compete for environmental protection. The government has declared reserves, protected specific species and passed environmental laws. Private organizations are becoming more openly active. In Mexico City, a program taking cars and trucks out of circulation one day a week has reduced overall air contamination 10 to 15 percent, the government says. Other sources say less, with ozone, the main contaminant, not affected. Residents still choke on smog from the city's 3 million vehicles, blamed for 80 percent of air pollution, and from 35,000 industries. Homero Aridjis, president of the Group of 100 environmental defense group, said ozone levels in April and May were double or triple the government-set maximum for four to nine hours a day. But no emergencies were declared. Aridjis said the city keeps on issuing license plates to cars that are nothing more than ``rolling scrap iron.'' In the past 50 years, 70 percent of Mexico's forests have disappeared. In Michoacan state forests, where monarch butterflies winter, cutting by peasant farmers and loggers continues despite the declaration of a reserve. Mexico's wide range of conditions makes it a world leader in biological diversity. Half the world's reptiles and 62 percent of the amphibians are endemic to Mexico. It has more kinds of mammals than Brazil and more kinds of birds than North America.

DOC.HEAD: Gantt Wins Democratic Race; First Black Senate Nominee in N.C.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT vote total, giving Gantt fewer votes, UPDATES with Gantt quotes; pick up 5th graf, `Helms issued ...
DOC.TEXT: Former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt won the Democratic U.S. Senate runoff on Tuesday and became the first black U.S. Senate nominee from North Carolina in this century. Gantt defeated Brunswick County District Attorney Mike Easley, and will challenge three-term Republican Sen. Jesse Helms in November. With 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Gantt had 272,576 votes, or 57 percent, to Easley's 206,397, or 43 percent. ``How sweet it is,'' Gantt told chanting supporters at his victory celebration. ``I want to tell you that God is good, yes he is. And today the people of this state showed their confidence in me with an overwhelming vote. It's a new day in North Carolina.'' Gantt moved quickly to reinforce his support for a woman's right to an abortion, an emotional issue on which he and Helms are polar opposites. ``It's not the business of government to interfere with a woman's right to choose,'' Gantt said, drawing a loud cheer from the crowd. ``What we want is a senator who understands the importance of building a society ... for the 21st century.'' Earlier in the day, Gantt had said he was ``ready to get into this fight'' with Helms. ``I'm ready to get it on with him.'' Helms issued a two-sentence statement congratulating Gantt for his ``hard-earned victory'' and Easley for his ``hard-fought race.'' In a concession speech to supporters, Easley said: `It's been a long and tough road. I congratulate my good friend Harvey Gantt on running a strong campaign. We all know that Harvey is a leader in the Democratic party and he will be a leader in the United States Senate.'' Easley spokesman Hampton Dellinger said the victory ``bodes real well'' for Gantt in the general election race. ``The margin shows he's able to appeal to both black and white segments of the population,'' Dellinger said. ``It shows a very strong possibility for him to defeat Helms.'' Both candidates had campaigned more against Helms than each other. Although both had hoped for a large voter turnout, turnout was light _ between 15 and 17 percent, according to Elections Director Alex Brock.

Gantt, 47, characterized Helms as out of step with the times, and said he wouldn't be able to run for Senate if Helms' views prevailed today. Both candidates attacked Helms for his votes on social and environmental legislation. The attacks prompted Helms, 68, to enter the political fray last week with commercials that accused the Democratis of mudslinging. He also attacked Easley, 40, for plea bargains he made as a prosecutor and Gantt for his opposition to the death penalty. The closest the two Democrats came to a sharp exchange involved Easley's listing of his differences with Gantt in their first televised debate May 26. Easley said he opposed tax funding of obscene art and a bill now before Congress that would raise gasoline taxes and tobacco taxes. In their second debate, broadcast Saturday, Gantt said Easley had distorted his position on the federal tax bill by implying that he favored the new taxes. Gantt, an architect by profession, led the six-way May 8 primary with the help of black voters. He gained 37 percent of the vote, while Easley finished second with 30 percent. Historically, black candidates in North Carolina have lost runoff elections. That history led to a change in state election laws giving an outright primary victory to a candidate with more than 40 percent of the vote. Under the old law, a candidate needed more than 50 percent to win.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Anti-Castro Terrorist Held Without Bond
DOC.TEXT: A reputed leader of an anti-Castro terrorist group sought by authorities since 1984 has been arrested in the bombings of three foreign consulates in Miami in the early 1980s, federal agents said. Jose Ignacio Gonzalez, 48, was ordered held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami until a witness can arrive from New York to testify in his bond hearing, which was continued from Tuesday until Thursday. Gonzalez, sought in the United States since 1984, was taken into custody early Monday by Guatemalan authorities, expelled from that Central American nation, and arrested at Miami International Airport later in the day, FBI spokesman Paul Miller said. Gonzalez is charged with bail jumping, conspiracy to deal in firearms and possess and receive an unregistered destruction device. He was believed to be the last member at large of the militant group Omega 7, according to Miller. Federal arrest warrants described Gonzalez as a leader of the group. Omega 7, which was opposed to Cuba's communist government, claimed responsibility for several bombings in the Miami area in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Gonzalez has been sought on charges he placed bombs at the Miami consulates of Mexico, Nicaragua and Venezuela, countries that had official ties with Fidel Castro's Cuba. He is accused of the Sept. 11, 1981, bombing of the Mexican consulate, which was heavily damaged. Gonzalez also is charged with transporting a bomb to the Nicaraguan consulate on Sept. 2, 1982. While that device did not explode, Omega 7 claimed responsibility for a bombing the same day at the Venezuelan consulate. In addition, Gonzalez is charged in the Southern District of New York with perjury and failing to appear before a federal grand jury. The FBI believes Gonzalez, a U.S. citizen, fled to Central America in 1984.

For Release PMs Wed, June 6
DOC.HEAD: Productivity Is The Ability To Compete
DOC.TEXT: The sharp first-quarter decline in U.S. productivity, or production efficiency, was centered almost entirely in the service sector, and that makes the bad news even worse. The reason: In terms of employment, the American economy is overwhelmingly a service economy, meaning most people earn their living from jobs in the service-producing realm rather than the manufacture of goods. Rather than making nuts and bolts, they use their skills to provide transportation, communication, power, wholesale and retail trade, banking, real estate, insurance, health care, research, government services... Statistically speaking, it is a little known world, even by government, which is one of the largest segments of that world. Washington releases masses of information about goods, much less about the world of services. Popular impressions are even hazier. Most people have mental pictures of mining, manufacturing and construction. But they have no clear image of services as an industry. Something promised, never delivered, they might say. Yet three of four U.S. workers are employed in the economy's service or service-producing sector, and most future employment growth for the next decade is likely to be in those areas. Moreover, much of that growth is likely to be concentrated in just three service areas: retail trade; personal services, such as health care and education; and state and local government. No wonder economists are appalled at first-quarter figures showing a 2.7 percent drop in productivity, or output per hour worked. They know that if productivity doesn't rise, neither can living standards. It's that simple. It shows in various others ways too, most importantly in regard to global competition. A nation that cannot efficiently join ideas and raw materials with manpower and money to produce goods and services cannot compete. And it has a direct link to inflation, most clearly seen in higher labor costs to produce results. Those higher costs, of course, necessitate higher prices, which in turn force higher wage demands. It is no coincidence, for example, that as productivity gains shrank over the past three decades, some of the highest inflation and interest rates in a century burned the economy and helped bring on deep recessions. Those high interest rates, in turn, helped raise the cost of doing business and thereby contributed to the very productivity problem that led to them in the first place. Moreover, those same high interest rates discouraged investment in more modern, state-of-the art plants and equipment, in a better educated work force, in innovative, computer-enhanced measures, all aimed at greater productivity. Lagging productivity is, therefore, a summary term for a whole basket of maladies that afflict the economy and end up in the cost of goods and services. That long list certainly includes poor education, high capital costs, lack of innovation, waste in health care, political chicanery, high legal expenses, government overspending, environmental abuse, short-sighted management, improper economic policies, unmotivated workers, lack of access to capital... You might add to that list the misdirection of capital, such as in the investment of billions of dollars in junk bonds and corporate takeovers in recent years, instead of improvement of production techniques and worker education. All these raise the costs of producing goods and services, and thereby reduce production efficiency. When production efficiency falls, so does the ability to compete. And if you don't compete these days you don't live very well.

DOC.HEAD: Retirement Won't Slow Down Legendary Vocalist William Warfield
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Like the Mighty Mississippi in his signature song ``Ol' Man River,'' William Warfield plans to keep rollin' along. His bass-baritone is still rich with musical thunder, though 40 springs have come and gone since he first became a national star singing the moving anthem about the hard life of black stevedores working on the Mississippi River in the MGM movie ``Show Boat.'' He's 70 now, still on the road captivating audiences here and abroad, and still sharing his art and wisdom with eager fans and students. Since 1974, he's taught at the Champaign-Urbana campus of the University of Illinois, and his retirement from the music faculty is merely a technicality. ``I'll still teach but I'll be able to do more outside things,'' said Warfield, thumbing through a calendar in his small office in Smith Hall. ``I'm booked up with performances through next May.'' During his 54-year career, the versatile singer and pianist has run the gamut of show business _ from stints in churchs and nightclubs that merely paid the rent, to performances on stage and screen. The son of a Baptist preacher, his goal as a student at the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester was not to see his name in lights, but to teach. ``I didn't have stars in my eyes and I wasn't sure you could make a living by singing,'' said Warfield in an interview. ``It never occurred to me that I would be that lucky.'' As luck would have it, Warfield joined the 1946 touring company of ``Call Me Mister,'' a Broadway musical revue about soldiers getting out of the Army after World War II and their adjustment to civilian life. He was ``bitten by the performance bug.'' He appeared on stage with other future stars: comedian Buddy Hackett, comedian-writer-director Carl Reiner, and choreographer-dancer-director Robert Fosse. ``I decided to stick around New York and try to make a career for myself,'' said Warfield. His big break came in 1950. A Canadian stockbroker attended nearly every one of Warfield's shows in a Toronto nightclub, and offered $500 to finance his concert debut at New York's Town Hall. The critics gave rave reviews to Warfield, whose one-man recital ranged from Handel to experimental music, with hymns, spirtuals and blues. ``My attitude was that I'd get a manager and make a living, not that I'd become a star,'' he said. He did not realize the impact of his performance until the the reviews hit the street. The Saturday Review said Warfield had ``remarkable presence and range,'' and the Herald-Tribune said he had a ``wide-ranged, flexible and sumptuous voice.'' Newsweek called him ``one of the brightest stars to appear in music in years.'' ``Whew!'' Warfield recalled. ``Everything broke loose.'' While performing at the invitation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Warfield's manager, Larney Goodkind, signed him to play Joe the dockhand in the MGM version of ``Show Boat.'' It was a role first created by Stepin Fetchit in 1929 and Paul Robeson in 1936. It was during the early days of production that Warfield delivered his famous, one-take recording of ``Ol' Man River.'' Intended as a dry-run with the orchestra to give Warfield an idea of timing and balance, it was flawless. It reportedly brought tears to the eyes of the head of the studio, Louis Mayer. ``I had been singing `Ol' Man River' since high school,'' said Warfield. ``It never occurred to me that I would be singing it in a movie.'' Warfield's career was in high gear, and in 1952 he performed in ``Porgy and Bess'' during a tour of Europe sponsored by the U.S. State Department. He played opposite the opera star Leontyne Price. They soon were married but the demands of two separate professional careers left them little time together. They divorced in 1972. In 1975, Warfield gave a sold-out concert in Carnegie Hall marking the 25th anniversary of his New York debut. But his gifted baritone was not limited to singing. He appeared as De Lawd in ``The Green Pastures,'' a 1957 Hallmark Hall of Fame television production. in 1984, he received a Grammy award for his narration of Aaron Copland's ``A Lincoln Portrait.'' Bob Bays, a retired music educator, said Warfield is superb as both performer and teacher. ``He is one of our major artists. He has a truly magnificant voice with that wonderful, warm quality that communicates with people.'' It was in 1974 that a friend at the University of Illinois suggested Warfield for a faculty position. Though he never had been to the campus, his friend's recommendation and the reputation of the university's music school brought him to the university to teach. ``I kept my career active. I wasn't giving up performing, just adding something,'' said Warfield, who scheduled classes midweek so he could tour and perform. ``It's been a matter of organization.'' One of his students was opera star Jerry Hadley, who studied oratorio with Warfield in the 1970s. ``I got to know him very well,'' said Hadley. ``He told those of us in his first class to call him `Uncle Bill,' and that's what we always called him.'' Bays said Warfield always was close to his students, and provided a role model for young black musicians. ``More black students than we'll ever know got through the university because of Bill's support and concern,'' said Bays. Warfield was born in West Helena, Ark., the eldest of five sons. His father moved the family to Rochester, N.Y., where Warfield grew up loving music. He sang in the church choir as a boy soprano, then studied piano. But it was his high school music teacher who recognized his potential as he matured and his voice changed. She encouraged him to enter a national music competition. He won a scholarship to Eastman, where eventually he earned both a bachelor's and a master's degree. Little will change when Warfield officially retires from the university in August. He will give up, without much regret, administratives chores and chairmanship of the voice program. But he still will perform and teach. And, students likely will continue to drop into his home for advice and, sometimes, a slice of the sweet potato pie for which ``Uncle Bill'' is famous. ``I love to cook _ that's my relaxation when I'm home,'' Warfield said. ``And, there are always a lot of students around to use as guinea pigs.''
