DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, June 9-10

DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, saying it was worried creditors would try to seize buses and terminals as the company struggled into the fourth month of a drivers' strike. Officials said Monday's filing would not affect service at the only nationwide bus company. ``We have taken this action to enable Greyhound lines to continue operation of its of its total system,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and chief financial officer.

American workers' productivity plunged at a 2.7 percent annual rate so far this year, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession, as labor costs continued to increase, the government said. The drop was the worst performance since productivity fell at 5.5 percent rate in the fourth quarter of 1981, the Labor Department said Monday. Unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, shot up at an annual rate of 7 percent.

Doubts about the stability of Donald Trump's casino and real estate empire increased as the developer confirmed he is negotiating with major banks concerned about his ability to handle his billion-dollar debt load. Prices for junk bonds used to finance Trump's Atlantic City casino projects plunged as much as $10 on Monday as investors soured on the investments. The selloff began after The Wall Street Journal reported Trump has been meeting with major lenders who have grown increasingly uneasy about his reported $2 billion in bank debt. They are seeking a restructuring of the developer's holdings, including a possible sale of some Trump assets.

Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., operating under bankruptcy court protection since January, lost $24.5 million in April, officials said. The performance was better than expected, spokeswoman Carol Sanger said Monday. Federated lost $12.7 million. The division operates 132 Lazarus, Bloomingdale's, Abraham and Strauss, Burdine's, Rich's and Goldsmith's stores in 19 states. Allied, which operates 128 Jordan Marsh, Maas Brothers, The Bon Marche and Stern's stores in 17 states, lost $11.8 million.

Insurance brokers Willis Faber PLC of Britain and U.S.-based Corroon & Black Corp. announced they had agreed to merge in a $778 million stock swap that amounts to a trans-Atlantic reach for new markets. The new firm, Willis Corroon PLC, would be based in Britain and is expected to have 1990 revenue of about $1 billion. The merger, announced Monday, would create the world's fourth largest insurance brokerage in terms of revenue.

U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills sought Latin American support for a U.S. effort to eliminate barriers to agricultural trade. In a speech in Paraguay on Monday, Hills said Latin America had a major stake in the outcome of the current global trade talks, due to conclude at the end of this year, because of the dependence of many nations in the region on farm exports.

President Bush is expected to postpone new oil drilling off the California and Florida coasts, for up to 12 years in some areas, so additional environmental-impact studies can be done, administration officials said. The officials said Monday the president appeared ready to endorse a course that would ban new exploration off Florida until 2002, off Northern California until 1997 and off Southern California until at least 1992.

Consumers are paying huge overcharges for credit life insurance that most of them don't need, two private groups claimed in a report calling on states to tighten regulation of the industry. Credit life insurance is sold by banks, finance companies, auto dealers and other lenders to consumers taking out installment loans. The policies pay off the loan if the borrower dies. The report was issued Monday by the Consumer Federation of America and the National Insurance Consumer Organization.

States sometimes may be forced to pay refunds on money collected under taxes later ruled unlawful, the Supreme Court said. The court unanimously ruled in a Florida case that states are not immune from being sued for refunds on unlawfully paid taxes, and that the states can be ordered to provide some remedy. But by a 5-4 vote Monday in a case from Arkansas, the justices said businesses are not entitled to refunds on money paid under unlawful taxes if state officials had no way of knowing the taxes interfered unconstitutionally with interstate commerce.

Stock prices rolled up another broad gain to record highs Monday, picking up where they left off last week. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 80.05 points last week, jumped 34.22 to 2,935.19. The dollar declined against most major currencies except the British pound and Japanese yen. Bond prices edged higher. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower; precious metals were mixed; energy futures were lower; and livestock and pork futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term Rates Slip
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell at the latest auction. The Treasury Department sold $8.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.69 percent on Monday, down from 7.80 percent last week. Another $8.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.62 percent, down from 7.74 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.67 percent on May 14, and six-month bills averaged 7.58 percent on Jan. 22. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.95 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,805.60 and 8.03 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,614.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.18 percent last week, down from 8.22 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Junk Bond Prices Skid As Tycoon Meets With His Bankers
DOC.TEXT: Doubts about the financial stability of Donald Trump's casino and real estate empire are growing, with major banks seeking assurances about the developer's ability to handle his billion-dollar debt load. Investors also are growing uneasy. Prices for junk bonds used to finance Trump's Atlantic City casino projects plunged as much as $10 Monday. The selloff began after The Wall Street Journal reported Trump has been meeting with major lenders who have grown increasingly uneasy about his reported $2 billion in bank debt. They are seeking a restructuring of the developer's holdings, including a possible sale of some Trump assets. The Journal said Trump's lenders have grown concerned that his holdings, including his three Atlantic City casinos, are not producing enough cash to meet payments. The report said they had begun meeting with Trump and his aides two weeks ago. Trump issued a terse but upbeat statement in response to the Journal story, confirming the talks were under way but calling them ``cooperative and constructive.'' Calls to Trump's office were referred to his spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein, who refused to give any information about the negotiations beyond the statement. Monday's developments further eroded Trump's image as a self-made American success story. In recent months the developer, while maintaining he wasn't having cash flow problems, has said he was considering putting some of his assets on the block, including the Northeast air shuttle he bought from Eastern Airlines for $365 million last year. Trump said he wanted the cash to buy new properties. Trump's assets include the Plaza Hotel, Trump Tower skyscraper and several apartment buildings in Manhattan; the casinos, including the recently opened $1 billion Taj Mahal, Trump Plaza and Trump Castle; and the Trump Shuttle. The Journal said Monday that some of the planned sales had fallen through or put on hold. For example, the developer's plan to sell his Trump Princess yacht for $115 million to Japanese investors had failed, the Journal said, quoting people familiar with the talks. Trump's lenders likely are concerned because of a downturn in the real estate market. Furthermore, the Taj Mahal, which opened two months ago, apparently has not flourished amid the plethora of casinos in Atlantic City. Mike Mulvaney, who follows the Taj Mahal and Trump Plaza casinos for Moody's Investors Service, said he had reports the Taj Mahal ``has not been operating to its fullest potential.'' The Trump Plaza was faring somewhat better, he said. The Journal reported that the big banks also were concerned that if Trump does sell assets, he might not be able to get the kind of prices that he claims they are worth. In his statement Monday, Trump continued to talk up the worth of his holdings. ``They are unique, well positioned and they have great long-term value,'' he said. The junk bond market was not reassured by Trump's assertions. Trump Taj Mahal 14 percent bonds were down $10 and being quoted at $56 to $58 per $100 in face value in late afternoon. Trump Plaza 12~ percent bonds, meanwhile, were down $4 and quoted at $82-$83, while Trump Castle 13} percent issues were off $10 and quoted at $59-$61. A high-yield bond market analyst, who asked not to be identified, said the Journal article unsettled junk bond holders. ``It raises a lot of doubt on how liquid the guy is and if the banks are going to call in their debt,'' the analyst said. The Journal story followed a string of negative reports about how well Trump's empire is doing. Forbes magazine recently sliced its estimate of the developer's net worth to $500 million from more than $1.5 billion. Trump consistently has maintained he was having no liquidity problems. After questions were first raised about his cash flow, the developer was so enraged that he threatened to sue newspapers if they reported he was strapped for cash. Rubenstein refused to discuss Trump's cash situation, how much debt he is carrying, or whether he will be disposing of any assets.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe Dominates Discussion at World Bankers Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The United States must reduce its budget deficit to free up funds needed to finance sweeping economic change in Eastern Europe, several former high-ranking government officials said. A looming shortage of capital is one of the biggest threats to reform in the former Soviet bloc and efforts to revamp the worldwide trading system, officials said Monday at an annual meeting of leaders of private and public banks from 22 nations. Deficit reduction is the ``acid test'' for improving the U.S. position in the world economy, former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker told the bankers gathered for the International Monetary Conference. ``I submit to you that no other single measure we could take would be so important in supporting the potential for trade and development in the 1990s,'' he said in a closed-door address to the bankers, according to a text of his remarks. ``Frankly, what has concerned me the most has been the tendency for the United States to retreat from economic leadership in recent years,'' he said. Volcker, who now runs a New York investment house, told reporters later that the United States should stop criticizing Japan for its low consumer spending and high savings rate and instead get its own fiscal house in order. Nigel Lawson, former chancellor of the Exchequer in Great Britain, said there are signs that private savings worldwide are not matching investment needs, ``a discrepancy that will be further exacerbated by the new investment opportunities now beginning to arise in Eastern Europe.'' ``It is important that governments cease to make demands on private savings, whether at home or overseas, by running budget deficits,'' he said, according to a copy of his remarks. Lawson did not specifically mention the United States. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the bankers at an open session that they must help meet the funding needs of Eastern Europe. ``As more countries embrace the principles of economic freedom, creditors will need to stand ready to lend their support,'' he said. ``You in this room cannot simply be bystanders to this process.'' But Lawson said in his remarks that commercial bank lending to the governments of Eastern Europe is not the answer to those nations' needs for capital. ``Governments, for their part, must rigorously refrain from encouraging or urging banks to make such loans'' due to their risky nature, he said. Brady outlined current U.S. efforts to help fund moves away from government-owned industry both in Eastern Europe and South America. He said the United States has committed nearly $1 billion over three years for Poland and Hungary, and that it is the largest contributor to the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Brady did not call for any increases in spending to help these nations. ``Our challenge in the developed countries is to encourage and nurture these impulses for economic freedom,'' he said. ``But let's face it: The world is short of capital, and governments are shorter still.'' He said the developed world also must work to maintain steady economic growth and open markets to make it easier for these nations to succeed. Volcker expressed optimism about the potential for international trade and development in the 1990s in light of the decline of communism. ``After all, if things go reasonably well, 100 million people in Eastern Europe, 300 million in Russia and over a billion in China have the theoretical potential for growing 5 to 10 percent a year, like the East Asians in the 1980s,'' he said. But Volcker cautioned that there are several potential pitfalls for that optimistic scenario, including a shortage of capital and the possibility for trade frictions that could lead to protectionist policies. If current negotiations aimed at liberalizing the global trading system end in disarray later this year, Congress may act to restrict imports and foreign investment, he said. ``That would, in turn, certainly reinforce those in Europe who would like to restrict access to their markets,'' he added. If such trade restrictions coincided with a recession and a softening in the value of the dollar, serious damage to the world economy could result, Volcker said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Greyhound, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events leading up to Monday's filing for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code by Greyhound Lines Inc.

March 19, 1987 _ An investor group led by Fred G. Currey acquires the bus operations of Greyhound Corp., since renamed Greyhound Dial Corp., and takes them private in a $270 million leveraged buyout. July 14, 1987 _ The new Greyhound Lines Inc. pays $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., then the nation's largest operator of Trailways buses. March 2, 1990 _ Most of the company's 6,300 bus drivers go on strike over wages and job security. Two shots are fired into Greyhound's main Chicago terminal but there are no injuries. It is the first of scores of shootings, bomb threats and incidents vandalism reported by the company. March 3 _ A picketing driver in Redding, Calif., is killed after being crushed by a bus driven by a replacement driver. March 18 _ Greyhound walks out of contract negotiations in Tucson, Ariz., to protest strike violence and says it won't resume talks until a week passes without violence. March 31 _ The driver of an independent bus operating on a Greyhound route from Nashville, Tenn., to Louisville, Ky., under a pooling arrangement is shot and critically wounded by a man in a passing pickup. April 12 _ Using new hires and drivers who cross picket lines, Greyhound says it is serving 72 percent of pre-strike miles. The union dismisses the claim. May 3 _ The company says it is serving 87 percent of pre-strike locations and passenger loads are just over half of the previous year's levels. May 4 _ Greyhound reports a $55.8 million first-quarter loss and blames it partly on increased expenses to cope with strike violence. May 5 _ In the first talks in six weeks, Greyhound offers contract that would cut 4,500 union jobs, change from per-mile wage rates to hourly wage rates and freeze wages for four years. Union calls offer an ``insult.'' No further talks are scheduled. May 7 _ Currey declares victory, saying strike has become ``irrevelant'' because company has hired enough drivers to replace strikers. May 21 _ The company asks holders of $225 million of its junk bonds to sell them back at steep discounts to help it avoid bankruptcy. It also changes its pay scale for drivers and withdraws proposed bonus and pension schemes to save money. May 23 _ Two striking employees are sentenced to jail in Boston for damaging buses, the first jail terms handed down for strike-related violence. May 29 _ A financial adviser hired by drivers requests a meeting with Greyhound to discuss a possible employee buyout. June 4 _ Greyhound files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

DOC.HEAD: Corroon & Black, Willis Faber Insurance Brokers Agree to Merge
DOC.TEXT: The merger of British insurance broker Willis Faber PLC and New York-based Corroon & Black Corp. will help both companies expand into new markets in continental Europe and the Pacific Rim, officials said. The companies also said the deal would give each broker access to the other's home market, where they currently have little presence. ``We have a perfect fit and the synergies will come immediately, I believe,'' said Richard Miller, chairman and chief executive of Corroon & Black. Willis Faber and Corroon & Black said Monday they had agreed on a $778 million stock swap that would create the world's fourth-largest insurance broker. The brokers link insurance underwriters with a broad range of clients including airlines, shippers and manufacturers. Top executives of the two companies already are planning to shop for other firms in Europe and the Pacific to fulfill their expansion aims. ``We'll be working Europe together very soon,'' Miller said. ``We're starting to make joint efforts to attract some new players to this team.'' ``It's definitely a drawback if you do not have the resources in place where your customers have offices,'' Miller said. Spreading out internationally ``makes you more competitive, definetely.'' ``You have to be able to take care of your clients wherever they are,'' said John V.H. Robins, executive director of Willis Faber, Britain's second-largest insurance broker after Sedgwick Group PLC. The new firm, Willis Corroon PLC, would be based in Britain and is expected to have 1990 revenue of about $1 billion. The merger would create the world's fourth largest insurance brokerage in terms of revenue. Marsh & McLennan Cos. Inc. of New York is the largest. News of the merger did not cheer investors, though. Willis Faber shares dropped nearly 9 percent to 265 pence, the equivalent of $4.43 a share, on the London Stock Exchange. Corroon & Black fell $2.25 to $34.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Corroon & Black stockholders would get 7.8 Willis Faber shares for every Corroon & Black share they hold, the equivalent of $34.55 a share based on Monday's closing price. The deal values Corroon & Black at the equivalent of $778 million. Despite the lackluster market reaction, some analysts praised the strategy behind the deal. ``I think that some of the best opportunities for 1992 are for the brokers who can easily cross international lines,'' said Gloria Vogel, a stock analyst at Bear Stearns, referring to the scheduled dismantling of trade barriers within Europe's Common Market. The new company would be 60 percent-owned by shareholders of the British group and 40 percent-owned by Corroon shareholders, the companies said. Miller would be chief executive of the merged firm. Roger J. Elliott, chairman of Willis Faber, would be executive chairman of the new company. The board of Willis Corroon is to have equal representation from the two companies. The merger is expected to be completed by the end of September. The proposed transaction must be approved by stockholders of both companies and by U.S. and British regulators. Neither company forsaw much employee overlap in the merged business. Corroon & Black is the world's sixth-largest insurance brokerage. It also provides risk management advice, reinsurance brokerage and other services such as health care and employee benefits. Willis Faber, the world's fifth-largest brokerage, handles insurance and reinsurance brokerage as well as risk management services. Its serves clients in the fields of aviation, marine and energy. Corroon has nearly all its business in the United States, while Willis Faber gets about 80 percent of its revenues from Britain. Corroon sold its 29.9 percent interest in the British broker Minet Holdings PLC in February 1988. Willis Faber's after-tax profit rose 19 percent to 37.6 million pounds, or $63 million, in 1989 on a 4 percent revenue gain to 237.8 million pounds, or $397 million. New York-based Corroon & Black, however, has suffered from its exposure to the depressed U.S. insurance market. For the first quarter, the company reported a 29 percent decline in net income to $9.1 million as revenue fell 4 percent to $117 million.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Optimistic Depite Losses
DOC.TEXT: Seven of eight divisions in Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. showed operating profits in April, encouraging officials who reported a $24.5 million loss overall for the month. ``We continue to make progress across the business,'' said Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive officer of the retailers. Federated and Allied filed their monthly report Monday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, where they sought Chapter 11 protection in January. The retailers said their performance was strong in April, although the cost of servicing their big debt helped leave them with the $24.5 million loss for the month. Federated and Allied are required to report monthly results to the Bankruptcy Court. Spokeswoman Carol Sanger said lackluster sales were expected at the stores immediately following the bankruptcy filing. ``But it has not turned out that way,'' she said. ``The stabilization has come much farther than where we thought we would be at this time.'' The overall April loss in the Federated division was listed as $12.7 million. Federated operates 132 Lazarus, Bloomingdale's, Abraham and Strauss, Burdine's, Rich's and Goldsmith's stores in 19 states. Allied's loss was $11.8 million. Allied operates 128 Jordan Marsh, Maas Brothers, The Bon Marche and Stern's stores in 17 states. The court filing said Federated had an operating profit of $11.2 million for the month, and Allied recorded operating profits of $7.9 million. Those figures don't take into account the retailers' debt servicing costs. For April, Federated listed interest expense of $24.5 million, and Allied listed $16.7 million. Federated and Allied executives have maintained that their divisions and store chains are strong and could be profitable if they were not saddled with so much debt _ most of it stemming from the takeovers of the retailers by Canadian real estate tycoon Robert Campeau. Ms. Sanger said management was encouraged by March-April sales and earnings and that the period marked ``a continuing stabilization of the business in the post-Chapter 11 filing period.'' ``Sales and earnings in the combined March-April period were consistent with management's expectations,'' she said. ``Moreover, both Federated and Allied posted operating gains in April for the second straight month.'' Sales of soft goods increased in April, continuing March trends in such merchandise as women's sportswear, coats, shoes and cosmetics, Ms. Sanger said. ``Key performance indicators in the March-April period showed encouraging trends, and I think any weakness in the business that we currently are experiencing is related more to the general retail climate than to Federated and Allied in particular,'' Questrom said. Also Monday, the retailers told the Bankruptcy Court that they've received their first legal bill from the Chapter 11 filing. The Cleveland legal firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue asked for compensation for $2.43 million in legal fees and $437,125 in expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Make Computers Easier to Use, Industry Gathering Told
DOC.TEXT: Putting the sometimes mind-boggling technological capabilities of computers into easy-to-use packages is the industry's major challenge, executives said at a convention. ``Our successors ... in the year 2000 should judge us not only on the technology we brought to the market, but on how we used that technology to bring the world closer together,'' said Bob Kavner, who manages data systems and federal systems for the AT&T Group. Kavner sounded the call for simplification in his speech opening Comdex@Spring '90 on Monday. The industry's biannual gathering is expected to draw 60,000 through Wednesday. That sentiment was echoed on the exhibit floor. No matter how advanced the technology, ``If people don't turn it on, it does no good,'' said William Roberts, a sales representative for Caseworks Inc. Caseworks, an Atlanta-based software developer, is one of several companies at the show that have enthusiastically endorsed Windows 3.0, a software product introduced last month by Microsoft Corp. to make IBM personal computers easier to use. ``Either people will get on this bandwagon or get left behind very quickly,'' Roberts said. Pat Kenealy, publisher of PC World magazine, said Windows was one of the key software technologies getting a close look. The convention marks the first time many in the industry have been able to see the new version of Windows, he said. Windows was designed to make IBM personal computers and their clones as easy to use as Apple Computer's Macintosh. ``Over the last three or four years IBM's standard computers have been tons cheaper than Macintosh but much harder to use. Macintosh is massively more user-friendly but massively more expensive,'' Kenealy said. Caseworks' latest product, the ``Case:W'' engineering tool, was unveiled on the heels of the Windows introduction and prominently features the new software. Roberts said Caseworks is pushing Windows technology as a way for companies to get more production out of their workers by simplifying computers. With Windows, a user with only limited computer knowledge can perform up to four times as many functions as before, he said. ``It makes the computer less intimidating,'' he said. The emergence of computer networks, which link computer users and allow increased sharing of information, was evident on the Comdex floor as exhibitors jostled to get attention for hundreds of products aimed at offering heightened compatibility. Drawing a sizeable crowd was a demonstration of Wang's ProFound document manager, which the company says provides access to documents anywhere on a large, busy network. The user in a big corporation, for example, can find a document with a search based on the content of the paper rather than worrying about where it was filed, said Christopher Junker, a regional manager for Wang.

DOC.HEAD: Chevron's Soviet Deal Looks Good, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Soviet officials and securities analysts said a Chevron Corp. agreement to study the feasibility of developing the Soviet Union's vast Tengiz oil field holds great potential. ``This is the kind of asset that if opened up to the West could be very significant,'' Warren M. Shimmerlik, an oil analyst for County NatWest USA, said Monday. Chevron signed an agreement over the weekend with the Soviet Ministry of Oil and Gas Industry to study the field, with reserves estimated at more than 25 billion barrels _ about 2{ times those of Alaska's Prudhoe Bay. The ``protocol of intentions'' is just the first step toward a joint venture to actually tap the oil. Long negotiations are expected, and the tangled Soviet bureaucracy could complicate the matter even if extraction is possible. Eugene Nowak, an oil analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said developing the field near the Caspian Sea appears to be ``a tough nut. I can imagine the Soviets are going to need some help on this.'' But he said it appeared to be nothing that Chevron, perhaps working with Parker Drilling of Tulsa, Okla., couldn't handle technically. ``The uncertainty is that this is a new venture for the Soviets, and it's the business side that's questionable rather than the technical side,'' Nowak said. However, Soviet oil and gas minister Leonid Filimonov predicted Monday that a deal to tap the oil field will be signed in the near future. Speaking at a meeting of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists, he said the proposed partnership will be ``a guarantee of further development of Soviet-American business ties.'' The Soviets appear highly motivated to ensure that this and similar projects take place. The Soviet Union is the world's biggest oil producer, but production has fallen off in recent years, and U.S. technology and capital are gravely needed to reverse that trend, Shimmerlik said. However, he said extraction of the oil appears years away, and while Chevron may expect a profit, it's unlikely to get a windfall. Nowak said there appears to be no way Chevron can lose on the deal; the worst that could happen is that the venture falls through.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak, Five Other Companies Sign Agreement With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. hopes expanded business relations with the Soviet Union will allow the photographic giant eventually to open its familiar photo processing laboratories and photo stores in five Soviet cities. The Rochester-based company is one of six companies in the American Trade Consortium, which is seeking increased trade with the Soviet Union. As part of the consortium, Kodak hopes to start joint ventures with the Soviet government for making blood analyzers in Leningrad, X-ray equipment in Kiev and ink-jet printers in Kursk, and for distribution of consumer photo products in Leningrad, according to David Harari, Kodak's general manager for eastern Europe. Kodak spokesman Paul C. Allen said Monday that Kodak still has no go-ahead from the Soviet government on its proposed joint ventures in the Soviet Union. But Allen said Kodak is encouraged by the signing of the new agreement Saturday by the consortium and the Soviet Foreign Economic Consortium. The new agreement calls for Chevron Corp., an ATC member, and Tengizneftegaz, a Soviet oil company, to study the possibility of jointly developing the massive Tengiz oil field in the Kazakh Soviet Republic in central Asia. Because all the oil would be exported, it would generate earnings in ``hard'' currencies _ U.S. dollars, Japanese yen and other currencies accepted in international trade _ which Kodak and other ATC members could swap for ``soft'' Soviet rubles earned in their ventures. Other ATC members are Johnson & Johnson, Archer Daniels Midland Co., RJR Nabisco Inc. and Mercator Corp., an investment bank. In addition to the Chevron deal, the ATC-Soviet agreement defines a new Accelerated Economic Development Program, which calls for additional joint ventures to produce consumer goods, medical equipment and other products. The ATC-Soviet agreement ``reprepesents a strong commitment of American business to participate in the restructuring and development of the Soviet economy,'' ATC president James Giffen said.

DOC.HEAD: CCE to Buy Arkansas Bottler, Sell Two Others
DOC.TEXT: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. announced Tuesday it will purchase the Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Arkansas for a total of about $250 million while selling off its interests in two other bottlers. CCE, the largest bottler of Coca-Cola, said it has agreed in principle to acquire the Arkansas bottler from the Coca-Cola Co. and to sell Portsmouth Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc. and its majority interest in Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio. The Portsmouth and Ohio companies serve parts of Ohio and Kentucky, including the cities of Columbus, Toledo and Akron. The Arkansas bottler serves parts of Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. CCE said the sale of the Portsmouth and Ohio companies to Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group Inc. will bring a total of about $120 million and will result in a one-time gain of about $55 million before taxes. The sale of the Ohio bottler is contingent on the acquisition of the Arkansas company, and all the transactions are contingent on approval from the companies' boards of directors and various regulators, the announcement said. The transactions are expected to be closed before June 30.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 465.58 down .03 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Tomkins, Philips Industries Announce Merger Agreement,
DOC.TEXT: Tomkins PLC has agreed to acquire Philips Industries Inc. in a stock conversion deal worth about $550 million, both companies said today. Under the agreement in principle, each outstanding share of Philips common stock would be converted into $18.50 per share in cash. Philips would be merged with a Tomkins subsidiary. Dayton-based Philips makes components for residential, commercial and industrial buildings; manufactured housing, recreational vehicles and the transportation industry. Tomkins, based in London, is an industrial management company that owns and operates manufacturing and distribution businesses primarily in the United States and United Kingdom. Tomkins' principal businesses in the United States are The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Co., which makes power mowers and bicycles, and Smith & Wesson Corp. The agreement is subject to approval by the boards and shareholders of both companies. Spokesmen for Philips and Tomkins were not immediately available for comment. Philips said a proposed reorganization between Philips and Merrill Lynch Capital Partners from last November was terminated. Philips said Merrill Lynch's financing sources indicated they would not participate and that Merrill Lynch did not propose an acceptable alternative.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell Negotiating for American Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Robert Maxwell, the chairman of Maxwell Communications Corp. PLC, says he is negotiating to buy an unidentified American newspaper. Maxwell, whose interest in buying more papers is widely known, declined to name the company but said the deal would be worth ``hundreds of millions'' of dollars. Maxwell made his comments to reporters Monday after the annual meeting of one of his companies, Berlitz International Inc., in New York. A Maxwell spokesman, David Adler, declined to comment further Tuesday and said Maxwell was in Europe and unavailable for comment. ``Maxwell has many deals come across his desk and he's looking at lots of them all the time. And of course, he has lots of interest in newspapers,'' Adler said. Industry analysts named a few papers that Maxwell could be targeting, including The Daily News of New York, owned by the Tribune Co. of Chicago, and The Chicago Sun-Times, which the New York-based investment firm Adler & Shaykin bought from Rupert Murdoch in 1986. Maxwell reportedly said Monday he would be interested in buying The Daily News if current contract negotiations reach an impasse. Tribune Co. spokeswoman Martha Lindeman said her company does not comment on rumors of negotiations, as did Leonard Shaykin, a managing partner of Adler & Shaykin. Maxwell owns the London Daily Mirror and recently launched The European, an English-language newspaper distributed throughout Europe. Two weeks ago, Maxwell announced he planned to buy three U.S. supermarket tabloids, Globe, National Examiner and Sun, from Montreal-based Globe International Publishing Inc. His biggest acquisition to date in the United States was his $2.6 billion purchase in 1988 of Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information services company.

DOC.HEAD: Grain, Soybean Futures Mixed in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures were higher in the wake of corn planting figures released Monday by the U.S. Agriculture Department. The figures showed planting 88 percent complete as of Sunday. That was lower than expected. Soybean futures staged a short-lived rebound as traders initially bought after Monday's steep decline in prices. But prices pulled back as trading progressed, with analysts citing forecasts of good weather for planting over the next week for the renewed weakness. Weather forecasts for warm, dry conditions in winter wheat regions, which will promote harvesting and crop development, is expected to weigh on wheat futures. However, analysts said followthrough buying from Monday's strong showing, and expectations that China will tender soon for more export bonus wheat should support prices. In early trading, wheat was 1 cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.30 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2\ cents higher with July at $2.75 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with July at $1.44 a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 2{ cents lower with July at $5.92 a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Commerical and professional selling tied to a decline in beef product prices sent cattle futures lower. Hog futures were lower as a result of a weak opening of the cash market. Live cattle were .15 cent lower to .08 cent higher with June at 74.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 85 cents a pound; hogs were .25 cent lower to .15 cent higher with June at 66 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to .13 cent higher with July at 65.15 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled higher in Monday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Western Allies to Discuss Easing Curbs on Exports to East Bloc
DOC.TEXT: Officials from the United States and 16 of its allies will meet Wednesday to discuss the easing of controls on high-technology exports to Eastern Bloc countries. Formed in 1949, at the start of the Cold War, the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls has served as a watchdog agency limiting the shipment of strategic technology to Warsaw Pact nations. Known as CoCom, the committee is made up of all NATO member counties except Iceland, plus Japan and Australia. At the two-day meeting, officials of the 17 countries are expected to approve a relaxation of controls on exports of telecommunications equipment, computers and machine tools. In the past, the United States has been more reluctant than most of the other members to ease controls. But at a CoCom executive committee meeting in February _ following the developments in Eastern Europe _ U.S. officials said they would support total or partial relaxations of curbs on more than 40 of the 120 regulated technology categories. One new issue facing CoCom is the likelihood of rapid German unification. West Germany is expected to outline its plans for dealing with the question of high-technology transfers between East Germany and the Soviet Union, which are major trading partners.

DOC.HEAD: Saatchi Posts Six-Month Loss, Announces Sale of Big Consulting Firm
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC on Tuesday posted a loss of $7.7 million for the first six months of the year and announced it had agreed to sell its largest consulting firm, the Hay Group, for about $81 million. The troubled advertising and communications group blamed the latest loss on disappointing consulting revenues. The company had earned $1.68 million in the same period a year ago. Saatchi said it had agreed to sell Hay to 135 members of Hay's management and institutional investors led by CIN Venture Managers Ltd. of Britain. Hay, based in Philadelphia and acquired by the Saatchi for $100 million in 1984, specializes in employee compensation. It employs more than 2,000 people in 81 offices in 29 countries and has 9,000 clients worldwide. Under terms of ths sale, Saatchi would receive $80 million in cash and a $10 million, 10-year subordinated note paying 10 percent interest. But Saatchi also has agreed to pay expenses incurred by the buyers of up to $9 million. Saatchi has been seeking for months to sell off Hay and five other major consulting businesses to focus on its advertising operations, said a Saatchi spokesman. The Hay sale is the first major disposal since it put its consulting businesses up for sale, and Saathci said the offer from Hay management was the only firm bid the agency received. Saatchi's sales for the six months ended March 31 rose 18 percent to $4.08 billion from $3.5 billion. Its pre-tax profit fell 29 percent to $24.2 million $33.9 million. Saatchi has been suffering from high costs, slower advertising growth in general and its unsuccessful diversification into consulting. In its latest announcement, the company said it would pay no dividend for the period compared with a dividend of 12.4 cents a share paid a year ago. It posted a net loss of $98 million for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Revenue in the company's communications division, which include its ad agencies, rose 17 percent in the first half to $655 million. But the company noted that the figures were enhanced by favorable currency movements and the transfer of market research activities to the communications division. Excludig those factors, it said revenue growth was about 7 percent. The division's profit before taxes and other items rose 40 percent to $52 million, buoyed by relatively solid performance in the United States and Europe. However, the company said that the British performance in the communications sector was disappointing. It said although its client base continues to grow, some clients were reducing spending. ``Despite our strong new business performance, revenue growth will be muted,'' the company warned. ``We expect the second-half communications profit performance to be at least as good as the first half.'' Consulting revenues slid 3 percent to $193 million. The operations had a loss before taxes and other items of $1.2 million compared with a profit of $13.4 million a year earlier. The consulting profits were hurt by the company's decision last year to sell its consulting businesses, the company said. It said negotiations on the disposal of its remaining consulting operations continue. The figures were converted at the current exchange rate of $1.68 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Police Move Striking Canadian Truckers Away From A Border Crossing
Precede BLAINE, Wash.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with police moving striking truckers from one crossing after court injunction, quotes from truckers' spokesman, truckers remaining at 3 other points. Picks up 2nd graf pvs: `The proposed ...' Also moved on general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: Royal Canadian Mounted Police, acting on a court order, moved striking British Columbia truckers away from a U.S. border crossing south of Vancouver today. Truckers at the Pacific Highway crossing jeered police but there was no violence, said Sgt. Peter Montague. Bob Jones, Western Owner Operators Association spokesman, said the drivers were served with an injunction shortly before midnight Monday night, and they felt they had complied with the order by allowing all truck traffic to proceed, he said. But by daybreak, officers ordered them to leave the crossing. ``They told them either to move or get arrested. If we don't move, we would get hurt real bad,'' Jones said. By midmorning, none of the blockading rigs remained at White Rock, British Columbia, the town opposite Blaine, Wash. Traffic was flowing smoothly through the border crossing, though Canadian customs was kept busy processing a backlog of more than 100 trucks that had been stuck on the U.S. side. ``Everything's moving again,'' said G.R. Greig, a Canadian customs official. Truckers remained at three other crossings. The proposed settlement covering 60 of 180 trucking companies involved in the dispute was announced Monday by Bryan Williams, the strike's chief mediator for the government of British Columbia. Some of the 3,000 independent truckers vowed to continue the strike they began May 27 if their demands weren't met. The blockades since Friday have halted most commercial traffic across the Canadian border between Washington and British Columbia. Similar blockades last month caused millions of dollars in losses in eastern Canada. Williams did not disclose terms of Monday's agreement. But Bruce Butler, a member of the Western Owner Operators Association, which represents the independent drivers, told the Seattle Post-Intelligencer it would boost hauling rates to $35 an hour (Canadian), or $5 less than the strikers sought. Butler predicted the offer would be rejected in a vote tonight by the truckers. ``We've been instructed by our executive board to lift the blockade, but our agreement at the time was supposed to be for $40 an hour. Now they want us to go for $35 and we're saying, `No,' '' Butler said. ``We're tired of starving to death.'' Other truckers also were upset by unofficial reports on the agreement. ``I think we've got to stick to our guns here,'' said trucker Jeffrey Snowden of Victoria. ``The $40 per hour rate was non-negotiable,'' said Doug Neal, a spokesman for striking truckers north of this border town. ``If we don't get it, we're going to stay here until we do.'' Trucks carrying fruit, vegetables and other perishables had temporarily been allowed through the blockades, but all produce trucks were blocked Monday night, said Dan Murray, a Canada Customs superintendent at one border stop. Passenger cars, buses and trucks carrying medical supplies and mail have been allowed unrestricted passage throughout the dispute. Blockades at four border points and along two major Canadian highways began in earnest Friday. The strike also has drawn support from the Teamsters Union. The blockades have resulted in food and fuel shortages in the province and in Point Roberts, a small Washington state peninsula that is accessible overland only through British Columbia. They also forced a Burnaby, British Columbia, truck manufacturer to shut down Monday for lack of parts from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Saunders Takes Witness Stand in Guinness Trial
DOC.TEXT: Ernest Saunders, the former chairman of Guinness PLC, took the witness stand Tuesday as the defense began its case in the first of two trials resulting from the giant brewer's 1986 takeover of Distillers Co. Saunders' lawyer, Richard Ferguson, described his client as the victim in Britain's largest white-collar scandal. He said the prosecution's case against Saunders was weak and attempted ``to substitute quantity for quality.'' The jury trial, which began Feb. 16, entered its 63rd day Tuesday. Saunders and six other defendants, are accused of being involved in a scheme to arrange for the purchase of Guinness stock during the takeover fight for Distillers, a Scotch whisky and gin maker. The aim of the alleged conspiracy was to boost the price of Guinness' stock and thus make the company's $4.2 billion cash and stock bid more attractive than a rival offer from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC. The takeover succeeded in April 1986, but in December of that year the Department of Trade and Industry announced it was investigating, and the alleged financial wrongdoings became public. ``The imperative, of course, is to find a scapegoat,'' Ferguson told the court. ``Something has gone wrong with this great company ... Someone has to carry the can.'' Ferguson said Saunders, who had to obtain legal aid to cover his huge legal fees, was testifying voluntarily. Under British law, he is not required to give evidence on his own behalf. ``I could say to you that whatever happens he is a ruined man. Stripped of the means of earning his livelihood, his personal life in ruins and himself undermined. Cast aside, we would say, by the company he served loyally for five years,'' Ferguson said. ``But he still has something to fight for and that is his credibility.'' Saunders, wearing a navy-blue, double-breasted suit, began his evidence by giving details of treatment he was having for two medical complaints, a hernia and a thyroid gland problem. He said he has separated from his wife and she has moved abroad. Standing trial with the 54-year-old Saunders are Gerald Ronson, 51, chairman of Heron International PLC; former stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44; and millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74. They face a total of 35 charges including stock manipulation, theft, false accounting and destroying documents. Saunders faces two charges of conspiring to contravene the Prevention of Fraud (Investments) Act; two charges of authorizing or permitting Guinness to contravene the Companies Act; eight charges of false accounting; two charges of theft and one charge of destroying company documents. In the second trial, scheduled to begin sometime after October, the defendants will be Roger Seelig, 44, former Morgan Grenfell & Co. Ltd. corporate finance director; Lord Patrick Spens, 47, former director of corporate finance at the merchant bank Henry Ansbacher & Co. Ltd.; and David Mayhew, 48, senior corporate finance partner of the investment firm Cazenove & Co. The seven men have pleaded innocent to the charges and each is free on the equivalent of $835,000 in bail. U.S. lawyer Thomas Ward has been charged in connection with the affair and British police are seeking his extradition. Ward has denied wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Decline in Net Income for 2nd Fiscal Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. said Tuesday its profit fell 67.7 percent in its second fiscal quarter from results a year ago that included a big contribution from a financial services company that has since been sold. Paramount said its results from publishing and entertainment were within expectations, and said it was still on track to achieve its previously announced forecast of earnings for the fiscal year of $2.10 to $2.60 a share. The company said it earned $21.2 million, or 18 cents per share, for the three months ended April 30 compared with earnings of $65.6 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. Last's year results included $70.9 million, or 60 cents per share, in earnings from discontinued operations, mainly from The Associates, the financial services subsidiary that Paramount sold to Ford Motor Co. in October. Without that contribution, Paramount lost $5.3 million from continuing operations a year ago. Revenue rose 16.2 percent to $812 million from $699 million a year earlier. The latest results included $21.8 million in net interest income resulting primarily from the investment of the proceeds from the sale of The Associates. The sale price was $3.35 billion. The company said it had significant operating income from entertainment operations although the results fell short of the record performance a year earlier. Motion picture results were also below last year's results despite a strong performance by ``The Hunt for Red October'' and the foreign theatrical popularity of ``Black Rain,'' ``Pet Sematary`` and ``Shirley Valentine.'' Operating income from television operations approximated the results of a year ago, paced by the success of ``The Arsenio Hall Show'' and ``Entertainment Tonight'' and higher syndication revenue from ``Cheers.'' Publishing operations results were in line with those of a year ago. Publishing traditionally posts a loss in the quarter as a result of the seasonality of educational publishing. For the first six months of the year, Paramount earned $42.4 million, or 35 cents a share, down 68.5 percent from $134.8 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 12.9 percent to $1.66 billion from $1.47 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Files for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 new grafs after 5th graf pvs, The Dallas-based ... to UPDATE with Greyhound Dial charge of $100 million. Picks up 6th graf pvs, Striking drivers ...
DOC.TEXT: Fears that creditors would begin repossessing buses and closing off terminals led strike-bound Greyhound Lines Inc. to seek protection in federal bankruptcy court, the company says. The only nationwide bus system filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors Monday. The move allows Greyhound to continue operating under court supervision while it tries to reorganize its finances. A hearing has been set for Thursday at 9 a.m. before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Richard Schmidt in Brownsville. ``There will be no interruption of service,'' senior vice president J. Michael Doyle said. The Dallas-based company has seen ridership and revenues plunge after most of its 6,300 drivers walked out March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. Meanwhile, Arizona-based Greyhound Dial Corp., which leases some buses and facilities to the bus company, said today it is charging $100 million against after-tax earnings to establish a reserve for possible losses related to Greyhound Lines. The company said the actual amount of the loss will be determined by developments including the bankruptcy proceedings and results of ongoing business operations. ``The bankruptcy (filing) action is a positive, stabilizing move which should help solidify the troubled position of Greyhound Lines and go a long way to ensuring the long-term survival of the bus lines,'' John W. Teets, Greyhound Dial's president and chief executive officer, said in a statement. Greyhound Dial sold the bus lines in 1987 for more than $350 million, but still holds preferred stock and notes from Greyhound Lines. Striking drivers, who maintained that Greyhound Lines had tried to bust the union at the expense of the company's economic health, said picketing will continue into the Chapter 11 reorganization. ``We're not surprised about the filing because we've been expecting it all along,'' said Gary H. Daughrity, executive board member of Local 1313, Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Dallas. ``A lot of us can't figure out why it took so long for Greyhound to seek bankruptcy court protection.'' One reason that Greyhound's financial woes worsened was that fewer striking drivers crossed picket lines than company management had anticipated, Daughrity said. The company has hired about 3,000 replacement drivers and claims to have restored service to locations that provided 98 percent of revenues last year. But the drop in ridership and the cost of fighting the sometimes violent strike drained the company's cash, including a strike fund estimated at more than $54 million. Greyhound blamed the strike for much of its $56 million first-quarter loss. The company also has missed more than $17 million in interest, lease and principal payments, putting it in default on many financial agreements. ``In the past few days, there has been a lot of pressure by creditors'' who own buses and terminals and lease them to Greyhound, said President Frank Schmieder. Under the lease agreements, those owners can repossess buses immediately after a missed payment. Spokesman George Gravley said the company was concerned about possible action by owners of leases on 500 to 1,000 of the company's 3,800 buses. ``While most (creditors) have been cooperative, we were faced with the threat of a `run on assets' that would have crippled our ability to operate,'' Doyle said. Greyhound filed its petition in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Brownsville. The filing also includes five affiliated companies: Eagle Bus Manufacturing Co., GLI Bus Operations Holding Co., BusLease Inc., Trailways Commuter Transit Inc. and GLI Food Services Inc. Greyhound's parent, GLI Holding Co., was not included. Greyhound has reported scores of shootings, bomb threats and incidents of vandalism since the strike began. A striking driver in Redding, Calif., was killed on the second day of the walkout after being crushed by a bus driven by a replacement. Talks stalled under the company's demand that a week pass without violence first. The two sides did meet on May 5, but the union balked at Greyhound's insistence on retaining its newly hired drivers and changing from a mileage-based to an hourly wage scale. On May 7, Chairman Fred G. Currey said the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. Two weeks later, however, the company proposed repurchasing $225 million of its junk bonds at a steep discount to avert bankruptcy. Schmieder said negotiations are continuing on a debt buyback, but ``it will take longer now because the courts will have to approve any financial restructuring.'' The company's total debt stood at $384 million at the end of March. The debt is the legacy of a $270 million leveraged buyout led by Currey three years ago that took the company private. A few months later, the group paid $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher After Volatile Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended slightly higher Tuesday on London's Stock Exchange after volatile, heavy trading. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 1.1 points, or 0.05 percent, at 2,380.1 at the close. The market opened strongly, recording a gain of 19.9 points at its peak in early trading. But the gains were eroded by the release of disappointing profit results, and the index showed a decline of 16.5 points at its session low. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 0.5 point at 1,893.9 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 0.91 point to close at 1,279.49. Volume was a heavy 618.2 million shares, up from 430 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Qintex Entertainment to Sell Company Assets of $65 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Qintex also ... to clarify sale of HR Broadcasting assets and CORRECTS name to ABRY sted ARBY. Picks up 5th graf, Qintex said ...
DOC.TEXT: Qintex Entertainment Inc., a television production and distribution firm, will sell its operating assets for more than $65 million in two transactions, it was announced today. Qintex Entertainment said in a statement its board of directors had agreed to sell its entertainment assets to RHI Entertainment for $42.4 million. RHI Entertainment will receive the Qintex library, accounts receivable, development projects and other assets under the deal. Under another agreement, certain assets of HR Broadcasting will be sold to ABRY Communications for $40 million in cash. The funds will be available for distribution to HR Broadcasting creditors and shareholders. Qintex said it expects to receive at least $23 million from the distribution. HR Broadcasting will sell its primary operating assets, which consist of television stations WTTO in Birmingham, Ala., and WCGV in Milwaukee, Wis. The broadcasting company will retire its bank debt and make distributions to its creditors and shareholders. Qintex Entertainment filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code last October. Both agreements are subject to approval by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court and various other regulatory approvals. Qintex Australia Limited, which last year made an unsuccessful attempt to take over MGM-UA Communications, owns a 43 percent stake in Qintex Entertainment. In September, Qintex Australia Limited offered $1.5 billion for MGM-UA. The deal fell through when Qintex failed to make a $50 million downpayment. MGM-UA announced in March it had accepted a $1.2 billion buyout offer by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Coors Buys Memphis Brewery
DOC.TEXT: Coors Brewing Co. has forged a deal with Stroh Brewery Co. to purchase Stroh's Memphis, Tenn., facility _ an aquisition marking the first time Coors will make beer outside of Golden, Co., officials said Tuesday. The companies said they hoped to complete the transaction by July 3, but Stroh said it would operate the 500-employee breery until Sept. 1. The brewery sale price was not disclosed. ``This purchase is part of our overall strategy to position Coors Brewing Co. for future growth,'' said Peter Coors, president of Golden-based Coors Brewing. ``It will provide the additional capacity we need to respond to rising consumer demand for our products.'' Coors Brewing Co. earlier reported shipping a record 3.9 million barrels of beer during the first quarter of this year, when it also reported record net sales of $394 million. The Memphis brewery, with an annual brewing capacity of 5.5 million barrels, will increase Coors' annual production by nearly a third. Adolph Coors Co., the parent company of Coors Brewing founded in 1873 by German immigrant Adolph Coors, this year surpassed Detroit-based Stroh as the nation's No. 3 brewer with a 9 percent market share. Anheuser-Busch, with its 42 percent share, and Miller Brewing Co. with its 22 percent share, were the top brewers. Coors last year produced 17.7 million barrels of beer. The company ships some to its satellite packaging facility in Elkton, Va., which has a packaging capacity of 2.5 million barrels. The announcement comes less than a week after Anheuser-Busch accused Coors of engaging in ``false and deceptive'' advertising by implying that its products contain only ``Rocky Mountain spring water.'' Anheuser-Busch complained to the Federal Trade Commission that Coors ships beer concentrates to its Elkton facility, where local water is added. Coors replied that 14 percent of its beer was shipped last year as concentrate to Elkton, where water and carbonation were added before packaging. But the company said all its beer is brewed with Rocky Mountain spring water. Coors will assume Stroh's collective bargaining agreement with the Memphis brewery's hourly employees when it takes over. Salaried employees will be notified later about employment opportunities with Coors, Stroh said Tuesday. Coors Brewing spokeswoman Carey Baird said the company would not discuss plans for the Memphis brewery until the transaction was completed. The Memphis brewery is one of six owned and operated by Stroh. The breweries employ about 4,500 workers and have a total capacity of about 24 million barrels a year. Stroh began looking for partners in February 1989 amid financial struggles that resulted in more than 300 layoffs and sales of some properties and divisions, including an ice-cream business. Stroh agreed to sell most of its beer business to Coors for $425 million last fall, but the agreement fell apart in December. Officials of both companies have refused to discuss details of the failed buyout such as whether the price or antitrust considerations were stumbling blocks. Neither Baird nor Stroh spokeswoman Lacey Logan would comment on whether the current deal indicated the companies were conducting further negotiations. Stroh President Roger Fridholm indicated in May that Stroh was attempting to position itself to continue independent operation. Peter Stroh, Stroh chairman and chief executive officer, said selling the Memphis brewery ``will permit us to effectively consolidate our production into our remaining five breweries.'' Peter Coors said the Memphis plant is ``strategically located, and it has a solid infrastructure and work force in place. That makes it an excellent fit for us.''

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Airline Orders 4 Boeing Jets
DOC.TEXT: Lynjeflyg, the domestic airline of Sweden, has ordered four additional Boeing 737-500s, worth about $130 million, including spare parts, Boeing Commercial Air Group says. The order converts four options for the 122-passenger, twin-engine planes that Lynjeflyg already held, Boeing said Monday. Lynjeflyg now has 10 of the planes on order. Boeing has received 215 orders from 20 customers for the 737-500. The plane entered service in February and 11 have been delivered so far.

DOC.HEAD: Sikorsky Developing Pilotless Air Vehicle
DOC.TEXT: Sikorsky Aircraft announced Tuesday that it is developing a bicycle-sized, pilotless air vehicle for the Defense Department. The six-foot wide, disk-shaped vehicle, dubbed the ``Cypher,'' will be used for ground and naval surveillance and for relaying communications, Sikorsky said. The craft is designed to take off vertically in a small area and to hover relatively motionless, even in windy conditions. It is being tested at wind tunnels in the United Technologies Research Center in East Hartford, Conn. Possible uses not related to defense missions include anti-drug efforts, forestry, work needed by utility companies, and search-and-rescue missions, Sikorsky said. A preliminary, slightly smaller version of the craft has been tested at Sikorsky's West Palm Beach, Fla., facility. The company is now testing the craft at two locations in Connecticut. Until about two months ago, the project was considered classified by the Defense Department, and Sikorksy had not released any information about it, said Sikorsky spokesman William Tuttle. Sikorsky, a division of UTC, is best known as the pioneer of the helicopter industry.

DOC.HEAD: Dallas and Stamford Stores Being Closed
DOC.TEXT: Bloomingdale's said Tuesday its poorly performing branch stores in Dallas and Stamford, Conn. will close late this summer. Marvin S. Traub, chairman of Bloomingdale's, said the decision to close the two branches came after a regular chainwide review of financial performance and future potential. ``As part of this review, we concluded that it is no longer appropriate for Bloomingdale's to remain in these locations,'' he said. The New York-based department store operator has been under intense pressure to generate sales and income. Its parent company, Campeau Corp.-owned Federated Department Stores Inc., is trying to reorganize under bankruptcy court supervision. The older of the two Bloomingdale's, the one in Stamford, opened for business in 1954 and will close on Aug. 18. The Dallas store has been in operation since 1983 and will close on Sept. 8. Together in recent years, the Dallas and Stamford branches have accounted for an almost insignificant 4.5 percent of the 17-store chain's annual sales. By contrast, sales at the main store in New York City represent one-third of the chain's annual volume. Traub said efforts will be made to make the transition easier for employees and customers. Stamford personnel will be given the opportunity to transfer to stores in New York and New Jersey. The Stamford store has 151 full-time, 200 part-time, and 43 management employees. Bloomingdale's owns the property where the Stamford store is located. No decision has been made on whether the site will be sold or rented. The Dallas employees will be offered counseling and job placement services. Interviews with other area retailers will be held at the Dallas Bloomingdale's, the chain's only branch in Texas. The store in Valley View Mall has 229 full-time, 176 part-time and 27 management employees. Bloomingdale's rents the Valley View Mall site. The closing announcements were made to staff Tuesday morning. After briefing employees at the Dallas store, Richard Hauser, Bloomingdale's regional vice president, said that lagging sales due to difficult economic conditions led to the decision to shut the store. ``The ... store opened at a high level of volume in 1983. Despite a strong start, changes in local market conditions since we opened have caused our volume to decline substantially,'' Hauser said in a brief statement to reporters after the employee meeting. He did not elaborate. Ann Stock, spokeswoman at the Bloomingdale's headquarters in New York, said the economies in both Dallas and Stamford have been difficult for retailing. She said the decision to exit those markets was not precipitated by any extra pressure from Bloomingdale's Cincinnati-based owner, Federated. Federated, along with its sister company Allied Stores Corp., have been operating under bankruptcy court protection from creditors since January. Heavy debts incurred when they were acquired by Canada's Campeau caused them to seek refuge under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code. In the hope of raising cash, Federated had been looking for buyers for the entire Bloomingdale's chain. Last month, the chain was taken off the auction block. Retail analysts say they suspect Federated grew frustrated when it didn't receive high enough offers. Despite the financial problems of Federated, Traub has said Bloomingdale's remains committed to its expansion and renovation plans. In Tuesday's announcement, he outlined a series of store openings and refurbishments currently on the drawing board. A new branch is scheduled to open this autumn in Palm Beach Gardens in West Palm Beach, Fla. Negotiations are underway on two possible new stores, in suburban Chicago's Old Orchard and in the Mall of America in Minneapolis. Renovations are planned at the chain's flagship New York City store as well as at branches in Short Hills, N.J. and Boston, Mass. Traub suggested Bloomingdale's could someday return to the Dallas and Stamford markets. Bloomingdale's considers ``both markets to be viable for future stores and we remain open to exploring other options in these areas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aerospace Company Developing Jet Noise Suppression Device
DOC.TEXT: Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., the nation's largest producer of corporate and business jets, is developing a device to reduce jet engine noise on commercial airlines, the company's chairman said Tuesday. Allen E. Paulson said he has filed for a patent on the device, which he said will ``extend the life of planes, cut the operating costs and help meet government regulations.'' He said it could be in production within two years. Paulson made the announcement at the opening session of the company's annual owners and operators workshop. He did not provide details on how the device will work, but said he finalized its design earlier this year. ``I worked on it to be applied first to Gulfstream IIs and IIIs, but it can be adapted to most all of the existing airliners in operation,'' he said. The device would fill a need created by a growing federal push for noise abatement around major airports, he said, and could ``open up a whole new ballgame'' for Savannah-based Gulfstream.

Stock prices fell today, countering a recent rally that produced record highs. Analysts attributed the decline to scattered selling to take profits after a runup in the Dow Jones industrial average of more than 10 percent since late April. A sharp drop in crude oil prices and a weaker bond market contributed to the selloff. Bond prices rose sharply and interest rates declined _ good for stocks _ in a rally late last week. Declines in several major oil and oilfield industry stocks because of lower oil prices offset gains in financial issues. Airlines, benefitting from the potential for cheaper jet fuel, also fared well. But some market players predicted that the decline was just a pause before a further jump. Money managers with large cash reserves when the market began moving upward have bought stock in recent days, boosting the market to its new highs. That enthusiasm was not seen as waning today.
