DOC.HEAD: Search Begins for Noyce's Successor
DOC.TEXT: Sematech officials pledged to continue efforts to make the United States preeminent in high-technology despite the loss of Sematech leader Robert Noyce, but industry analysts and politicians said the research group cannot get complacent about its federal funding. Noyce, 62, known internationally as a founding father of the Silicon Valley and co-inventor of the integrated circuit, died Sunday morning of cardiac arrest. He was chairman of Sematech _ the Austin-based research group of 14 technology companies, which includes International Business Machines Corp., American Telephone & Telegraph Co., Texas Instruments Inc. and Motorola Inc. He commanded respect in the high-tech industry and had the political skills to win points in Washington. He became the major national spokesman for government intervention in the semiconductor war with Japan. Directors of the consortium are stepping up their effort to replace Noyce. ``The board understands that it must resolve this issue expeditiously,'' said Charles Sporck, Sematech's board chairman and head of the search committee. In the interim, Sematech will be run by two men who Noyce frequently left in charge of day-to-day operations: Chief Operating Office Turner Hasty, 59, a veteran researcher and business executive who came to Sematech from Texas Instruments; and Chief Administrative Officer Peter Mills, 39, a former computer executive and a former Greater Austin Chamber of Commerce executive. Sematech leaders and U.S. Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, spoke to Sematech employees Monday. Pickle, a key backer of the research project, assured workers that Sematech's requested $100 million in federal funds for 1991 remained strong. Sematech receives half its $200 million annual budget from the government and the remaining funds from its member companies. The unprecedented private-public venture has provoked some criticism in Congress, but the Bush administration has proposed continued funding for Sematech for the 1991 fiscal year, which starts in October. But Pickle cautioned that Sematech cannot let its guard down and must move quickly to fill the top job. ``They need to get the best person as quickly as they can, so they can move forward with the program,'' the Austin American-Statesman reported Tuesday. Finding someone of Noyce's caliber won't be easy, said Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research in San Jose, Calif. ``A man like Noyce comes along maybe once every two centuries,'' Hutcheson said. ``They are going to have to have to look long and hard to find someone of his stature and background to take it over,'' he said. Robert Galvin, former chief executive of Motorola Inc., said Sematech will thrive because of Noyce's legacy. ``Bob Noyce has invested well and the fundamentals are all there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly lower Tuesday in worldwide foreign exchange trading, reflecting continued concern about the direction of interest rates. Gold prices rose following a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $359.80 a troy ounce, up $1.20 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $359 an ounce, $1.60 higher. Currency dealers said worries about the effects of a reunified Germany were lending some suppport to the dollar, but that was being overidden by interest-rate fears. Recent reports showing sluggish economic growth have some dealers worried that the Federal Reserve might be loosening its credit grip, they said. Lower interest rates often depress a currency. Economic data due out next week could shed more light on the economy's direction, including reports on consumer and producer prices for May. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar rose 0.01 yen to close at 152.43 yen. It traded at 152.55 yen in London, and at 152.35 yen in New York, down from 152.65 yen Monday. The dollar weakened against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6820 in London, up from $1.6745 Monday, and $1.6880 in New York, up from $1.6770 Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6840 West German marks, down from 1.6905; 1.4280 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340; 5.6785 French francs, down from 5.6960; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00; and 1.17605 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17475. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6910 West German marks, down from 1.6940; 1.4340 Swiss francs, down from 1.4390; 5.7020 French francs, down from 5.7080; 1.9070 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9068; 1,244.25 Italian lire, down from 1,245.50; and 1.1752 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1763. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $359.25 an ounce, up from $356.05 Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $358.60 an ounce, down from $363 late Friday. Zurich markets were closed Monday for a religious holiday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 81 cents to close at $359.87 an ounce. Silver prices strengthened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.065 a troy ounce, up 1.6 cents from Monday. Silver rose in London to $5.08 an ounce from $5.03.

DOC.HEAD: Whirlpool, Matsushita Announce Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. and a leading Japanese producer of consumer and electronic goods announced Tuesday they have signed a joint venture to produce vacuum cleaners for the North American market. The joint venture of Whirlpool, which is based in Benton Harbor, Mich., and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. of Osaka, Japan, will own and operate Whirlpool's vacuum manufacturing plant in Danville. According to the announcement, Whirlpool will assist the joint venture in maintaining and expanding its floor care product business relationship with Sears, Roebuck and Co. The plant in Danville produces a full line of canister, upright and central vacuum cleaners for Sears under the Kenmore brand name. Whirlpool will have continued management involvement to assure continuity in marketing and manufacturing, and the company also will have representation on the board of directors. Whirlpool will report an after-tax gain on the sale of an interest in the joint venture at the time of closing. Matsushita currently imports Panasonic brand vacuum cleaners to the United States and is expected to use the Kentucky facility to expand its manufacturing and marketing base in North America. Matsushita is the world's leading manufacturer of consumer and industrial electronics products, with annual sales of nearly $38 billion. It has production facilities and sales offices in 38 countries and 198,000 employees worldwide. The company markets 14,000 different electronics products under the Panasonic, Technics, Quasar and National brand names. Whirlpool is the world's leading manufacturer and marketer of major home appliances. The company manufactures in 10 countries and markets products under nine major brand names in more than 45 countries. On Feb. 9, Whirlpool announced that it was planning to sell its Danville plant and the floor-care operation there. Whirlpool said it decided to sell the floor-care operation because it didn't have the resources other companies had for continued growth and profitability in the long term. The company said it had decided to concentrate on the manufacture of trash compactors and ice makers. Whirlpool already has begun the phase-out of its two other major operations _ trash compactors and ice makers _ at the Danville plant. The operations are being moved to other Whirlpool plants. Some 250 of Whirlpool's 1,000 Danville employees are involved in the manufacture of trash compactors and another 50 are involving in making ice makers. The rest are assigned to the floor care division.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Drop
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures fell Tuesday amid concerns over reports that Saudi Arabia planned to cut oil prices. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 46 cents to $16.68 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Other contract months also dropped. John Hill, an energy broker at Merrill Lynch & Co., said the fall began Monday on news Saudi Arabia was lowering prices for July contracts. He said ``people are a little concerned there could be further cuts down the road.'' Among refined products traded on the mercantile exchange, wholesale gasoline for delivery in July tumbled 1.76 cents to 57.82 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also falling. The July contract for home heating oil fell .48 cents to 47.11 cents a gallon. Later months also declined. Natural gas prices dropped from $1.582 per 1,000 cubic feet to $1.567 Tuesday. William Byers, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co., said the crude market also was driven by supply numbers suggesting that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had not cut production as much as they had intended. That would create oversupply in the market, depressing the price of crude oil. Byers also said U.S. supplies are at capacity levels, pressuring prices even further.

DOC.HEAD: Reports of Saudi Discounting Send Crude Oil Futures Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices fell sharply Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on reports that Saudi Arabia is selling crude oil at discount prices to its major customers. On other markets, grain and soybean futures were mostly higher, precious metals climbed, copper rallied, and livestock and pork futures rose sharply. Analysts said Saudi Arabia may be selling crude at a discount because of its displeasure with OPEC's failure to be faithful to production quotas. According to Randolph Donney, a research analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York, the Saudis are discounting as much as 75 cents a barrel. He says it appears they are willing to let the price to dip below $15 a barrel. ``That will stun a number of countries who depend on oil to keep their economies afloat,'' Donney said. Last month, members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to reduce crude oil output to just over 22 million barrels a day. Donney said the 13 OPEC countries are currently producing 23.5 million barrels per day. Once again gasoline futures were battered, a bad sign for the market because gasoline usually leads the market at this time of year, Donney said, adding that the driving season got underway with the Memorial Day weekend, which usually triggers higher gasoline prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 14 cents to 49 cents lower with July at $16.68 a barrel; heating oil was .48 cent to .76 cent lower with July at 47.11 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .90 cent to 1.76 cents lower with July at 57.82 cents a gallon. Grain futures prices were higher and soybeans were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade, with corn futures sharply higher as planting continues to lag. The U.S. Department of Agriculture issued a report at the close of trading Monday that said planting of the corn crop was 88 percent complete as of Sunday. That is less than expected, taking into account that there were several days of clear weather last week, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Soggy fields in recent weeks delayed the planting of corn in several Midwestern states. Also helping corn prices was the USDA's export inspection report which showed a pickup in demand for the grain. Wheat futures were higher on indications the People's Republic of China will bid for 500,000 metic tons of wheat under the export bonus program. The USDA on Tuesday accepted a bid for bonus wheat from South Korea. Soybean prices were mixed as professional selling blunted a rally. Wheat was a { cent to 1{ cents higher with July at $3.32{ a bushel; corn was 4{ cents to 5{ cents higher with July at $2.78\ a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 5\ cents higher with July at $1.46{ a bushel; and soybeans were a { cents lower to 1{ cents higher with July at $5.92} cents a bushel. Precious metals were higher in trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. The rally in precious metals was paced by platinum, which rose on reports of heavy buying by the Japanese, said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Gold futures rose as the dollar weakened against major foreign currencies, which also helped silver prices. Gold was $1.20 to $1.30 higher with June at $359.80 a troy ounce; silver was 1.4 cents to 1.6 cents higher with June at $5.065 a troy ounce; platinum was $5.50 to $5.80 higher with June at $491.80 a troy ounce. Copper prices were higher on the Comex as demand for June copper spurred a sharp rally. There was no news to account for the sharp rise in copper prices, but there is the perception that near-term supplies are tight, Ms. Raptopoulos said. Copper was 1.30 cents to 2.90 cents higher with June at $1.171 a pound. Livestock and pork futures were higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with pork belly futures up the daily trading limit on news the Soviet Union is interested in using U.S. credit guarantees to buy meat. Live cattle were .15 cent to .30 cent higher with June at 74.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 84.97 cents a pound; hogs were .52 cent to 1.37 cents higher with June at 66.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .95 cent to 2 cents higher with July at 67.30 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup To Move To Dallas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FoxMeyer is cq throughout
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. on Tuesday said it will move its headquarters to Dallas and its chairman, Howard Love, will resign. The holding company, formerly the majority owner of National Steel Corp., said it will change its name to FoxMeyer Corp., the name of its drug distribution company. Love, 59, will recommend to National Intergroup's board that he be replaced by FoxMeyer head Robert L. King. National Intergroup also said it would sell its Ben Franklin Stores Inc. subsidiary, and it would either sell, spin off or seek a partner for a joint venture for its Permian Partners oil business. The company also sold aluminum assets and announced on Monday the sale of its Genix Enterprises computer company in Robinson Township, Allegheny County. The Genix sale, if approved, would leave FoxMeyer as National Intergroup's sole remaining operating division. The company said it would buy back stock or pay a dividend with cash from the sales. In March, National Intergroup sold 40 percent of its 50 percent share in National Steel, the nation's sixth largest steel producer last year. The company employs about 50 people in Pittsburgh. Centaur Partners, a New York investment group, earlier this year tried unsuccessfully to gain control of National Intergroup's board. The partnership, which owns one-sixth of NII, said it was disappointed in National Intergroup's management and recent earnings. National Intergroup spokesman Edward Klein said Tuesday's moves did not represent appeasement of Centaur Partners.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Support Canadian Pacific Bid for D&H Railway
DOC.TEXT: Federal Railroad Administrator Gilbert E. Carmichael announced his support Tuesday for a $25 million bid by Canadian Pacific Ltd. to buy the ailing Delaware & Hudson Railway. ``Canadian Pacific Railroad and the D&H is more than just saving 1,600 miles of track. It creates another major eastern U.S.A., North American railroad for the Western railroads to do business with,'' Carmichael said at a news conference in the office of Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. D'Amato, who also endorsed Canadian Pacific's bid, said the Justice Department would file a supporting brief at a D&H hearing Thursday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. ``With the federal government asking the court to approve the sale, we have cleared another major hurdle to save the D&H,'' D'Amato said. The Federal Railroad Administrator is D&H's largest creditor, with more than $90 million in secured claims. Last month, the D&H's bankruptcy trustee accepted Canadian Pacific's bid, which also promises about $5 million for the trustee if Canadian Pacific can sell rights to run fiber optic communications cables along the D&H right-of-way. The deal is contingent on agreements by the D&H's 14 unions with the Canadian Pacific before mid-July. D'Amato said Tuesday that tentative accords had been reached with all the unions but Canadian Pacific spokesman John Cox said the senator was mistaken. The only tentative agreement was with the United Transportation Union, the largest of the group, Cox said. He declined to divulge details of the accord until the rank and file vote on it later this week. Cox also hesitated when asked whether federal support for Canadian Pacific's bid might sway Judge Balick. ``I would not like to be in a position of suggesting what will make up the judge's mind for her,'' he said, adding that she ``must be aware of the public support'' for Canadian Pacific's bid. Canadian Pacific's $25 million bid is $10 million less than it had offered earlier this year. Canadian Pacific withdrew it in February after the carrier was unable to secure trackage rights between Hagerstown, Md., and Harrisburg, Pa. Those tracks belong to Consolidated Rail Corp., which refused to negotiate. The new offer is for rolling stock, 600 miles of D&H-owned track and running rights over 900 miles of track of other lines. Canadian Pacific owns about 14,000 miles of track in Canada and 5,000 in the United States. The D&H, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, filed in June 1988 for protection from its creditors. The railroad runs from Montreal to Washington, D.C., and from Albany to Buffalo, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Discuss Impact of Environmental Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Bankers are paying more attention to the impact of environmental concerns on their industry and on business in general, participants in a worldwide banking convention said Tuesday. When banks are asked to finance a factory or other industrial operation, they increasingly explore the potential environmental impact of the project before giving approval, said R. Donald Fullerton, chairman and chief executive of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. ``We're in an early learning process,'' he told reporters at the International Monetary Conference. ``We are paying more attention to the kinds of projects we are financing'' for potential environmental impact, he said. Fullerton called such concern ``a reasonably new development.'' Another concern for banks is the environmental impact of their own operations, said Fullerton, who was chairman of a panel on the environment at the annual banking convention. ``We have a massive paper-generating machine that we need to deal with,'' he said, without offering a solution. Fullerton said the bankers at the closed-door meetings agreed ``that the environment was a major issue that the banking community will have to pay attention to.'' For industry in general, ``the environmental aspects have become a new bottom line,'' said one of the panelists, Alex Krauer, chairman and managing director of Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Basel, Switzerland. ``We are part of the problem, but also want to be part of the solution,'' Krauer told reporters. At their private session, the bankers heard an address by Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, who said he believes business executives are genuinely concerned about the impact of their operations on the environment, according to a text of his speech. ``I don't think I am being unfair if I observe that 20 years ago many companies treated environmental concerns as something to ignore, deflect or fight,'' he said. ``Today, their perceptions and actions have changed greatly.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Greyhound, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines officials said they did not experience any major runs on requests for refunds on Tuesday, the day after the nation's only intercity bus line filed for reorganization under federal bankruptcy laws. Spokeswoman Liz Hale said customers who want refunds should go to their local Greyhound ticket office. The tickets have to be forwarded to Greyhound headquarters, and a refund will be mailed, Ms. Hale said. Some special Greyhound fares are non-refundable, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Seeks Approval to Acquire Commuter Airline
DOC.TEXT: A commuter airline appeared to be saved from shutdown under a proposed agreement Tuesday for Eastern Airlines to acquire full control of the carrier's operations in Florida and the Bahamas. The plan calls for Miami-based Eastern to purchase 59 percent of Bar Harbor Airways from sister carrier Continental Airlines and expand its commuter service. Eastern, which already owns 41 percent of Bar Harbor, operates the Florida service as its Eastern Express subsidiary, said spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak. No price was announced for Eastern's acquisition of Continental's share, said Ms. Ceremsak. Under the pact, Continental would take over Bar Harbor's operations in the Northeast. The carrier presently has 148 daily flights under the Continental Express logo from hubs in Newark, N.J., New York's La Guardia Airport and Boston. Because Eastern will only receive Bar Harbor's smaller southern operations, Continental will pay the carrier $3 million and also forgive all debt owed by Bar Harbor, said Peggy Mahoney, a spokeswoman at Houston-based Continental Express. The deal, if approved, would settle all claims by Eastern against Bar Harbor or Continental in connection with Bar Harbor operations, said Ms. Ceremsak. Bar Harbor, facing growing competition from American Airlines and Pan Am World Airways commuter services, had planned to halt its southern flights on Sunday. ``This plan averts the closing and we have plans to expand,'' said Ms. Ceremsak. Eastern plans to maintain Bar Harbor's present 47 daily flights from Miami to 11 cities in Florida and the Bahamas. Also, Eastern said it plans to increase Miami service and add flights from Key West to Fort Myers and Naples. All 300 Bar Harbor employees in Florida and the Bahamas will keep their jobs under Eastern Express, the carrier said. Eastern said it may increase its commuter operation to more than 70 daily departures to 16 cities by late summer. The plan must receive approval from the U.S. Department of Transportation and U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection shortly after a strike by Machinists, pilots and flight attendants in March 1989. Martin Shugrue, the court-appointed trustee overseeing Eastern, said the Bar Harbor deal is part of a strategy to ``preserve our long-term Florida presence.'' But Eastern will also face competition from other carriers seeking to feed their Miami hubs with commuter flights. American operates 33 flights from Miami under American Eagle and plans aggressive expansion in coming years. Pan Am Express began service with 25 flights from Miami last month and hopes to add up to five more destinations this fall.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined Tuesday in heavy trading, pulling back from a rally that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to new heights. The Dow average of 30 large corporate stocks fell 10.19 to 2,925.00, returning about one third of the Monday gains that left the key market barometer at a record 2,935.19. Analysts attributed the drop to selling of some blue-chip stocks to make profits, sharply lower oil prices and a weaker bond market. But they said the decline did not appear to dampen the enthusiasm in the market's spring surge. ``I think it's a natural consequence of a straight up move we've had here for three weeks,'' said Dudley Eppel, head of equity trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Declining issues edged out advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 774 up, 813 down and 463 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 199.72 million shares, up from 175.52 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 241.4 million shares. Some market participants said the decline was a pause before a further jump with no sign of a broadly based selloff. The rally has been fed in part by stock-buying by money managers with large cash reserves who want to join the upward trend. ``This market is very reluctant to come down,'' said Jack Solomon, technical analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. ``There's a certain buoyancy here. Even as we correct one area another area can act well.'' Oil and oilfield industry stocks were battered by a drop of 46 cents per 42-gallon barrel in the July contract of West Texas Intermediate crude oil. Baker Hughes dropped 2 to 27|; Halliburton tumbled 2} to 46\; and Schlumberger dropped 2} to 55}. Of blue-chip oil stocks, Exxon was unchanged at 48\; Atlantic Richfield fell } to 118\; Texaco dropped | to 59]; and Amoco lost | to 52}. A drop in bond prices, which pushed interest rates higher, also weighed on stocks. Bond prices rose sharply and interest rates declined _ good for stocks _ in a rally late last week. The Big Three automakers lost ground after reporting a 6.7 percent sales decline in late May compared with the same year-ago period. Chrysler fell } to 15~; Ford was off | to 47] and General Motors dropped { to 49~. Airline stocks got a boost on the perception that jet fuel prices could decline. AMR, parent of American Airlines, gained 1] to 68~, and Delta rose | to 80. Financial stocks continued to perform well. BankAmerica rose { to 33[; Citicorp gained ] to 25; and Beneficial rose 1{ to 54~. Greyhound Dial, which owns a large stake in Greyhound Lines, the strike-bound bus company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection late Monday, dropped | to 29. Philips Industries jumped 3\ to 17\. Tompkins PLC of Britain agreed to acquire the company for $18.50 a share, or $550 million. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market declined $5.031 billion, or 0.14 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped 0.28 to 199.93. Standard & Poor's industrial index dropped 1.50 to 426.74, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 0.76 to 366.64. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.00 to 464.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 363.83, down 0.57.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Campbell's Soup Founding Family Form Voting Trust
DOC.TEXT: Six dissident members of the founding family of Campbell Soup Co. disclosed that they have formed a voting trust to further their aim of selling the food products company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission Tuesday, the six revealed they controlled 17.4 percent of the Camden, N.J.-based company's shares. The group _ composed of three nieces of Campbell's late chairman, John T. Dorrance Jr., and their husbands _ said it continues ``to believe that the best interests of the shareholders would be served by sale of the company.'' The dissident group added, however, that their position ``does not reflect dissatisfaction with David Johnson,'' who became chief executive officer of Campbell in January. In Camden, Johnson issued a statement saying: ``I'm gratified by the expression of support from this group of shareholders for the company's new strategic direction. We are confident that Campbell Soup Co. will deliver the financial results needed to build maximum long-term wealth for all of our shareholders.'' Dorrance, whose great uncle founded the company, died last April. Three of Dorrance's children took control last year of his 31.3 percent stake in the company. They issued a statement last December saying they intended to maintain their ownership in Campbell and keep the company independent.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Triples in East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6 `About 100,000' to CORRECT month to May sted June. Picks up 7th, `Mrs. Hildebrandt...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Joblessness tripled in East Germany in just six weeks and the government, worried about mass unrest, unveiled a broad program Tuesday to blunt the shock of the shift to a free market. East German factories will cut hours and reduce wages to try to keep people on the payroll even though there is less work for them to do, said Labor and Social Minister Regine Hildebrandt. A new employment administration has been created to oversee a program for compensating workers for lost wages and retraining them for new jobs, she said. East Germany is to officially shed four decades of socialism July 2 and merge its economy and social institutions with West Germany. It will be the biggest and most difficult stage of full German unification. The effects of unification already are being felt in the form of rising prices and growing unemployment as East German enterprises, many of them inefficient and overstaffed, face Western competition. About 100,000 people were officially unemployed at the end of May, said Mrs. Hildebrandt. That represents only 1 percent of the work force, but it is about three times the ated Mike Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney in the runoff for the Democratic nomination and will face GOP Sen. Jesse Helms.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Oppose U S West-Soviet Fiber-Optic Project
DOC.TEXT: The Commerce Department has told U S West Inc. it will oppose the company's proposal to supply high-speed telecommunications transmission technology for a trans-Soviet fiber optic project, U S West said Tuesday. Company spokesman Ed Mattix said the Commerce Department cited national security reasons in opposing attempts by any country to supply transmission technology with a capacity of 140 megabits a second or greater to the Soviet Union. Mattix declined to say how much U S West stood to make on the project other than to say ``it would be very profitable.'' He said the company would appeal the decision. ``We're hopeful to address those security issues with Commerce and hopefully change their mind about that'' in the next 30 to 45 days, he said. ``The technology we're talking about is not state of the art, it is technology two to three generations behind what's used in the United States today,'' he said. ``The standard today in the United States is 1.7 gigabits or 1.7 billion bits of information per second. We were proposing 565 megabits or 565 million bits of information per second,'' Mattix said. A news release from U S West said the fiber-optic Line would meet growing requirements for communications between the Asia-Pacific region and Europe by providing international voice, facsimile and data transmission. It also would provide long distance telephone communications within the Soviet Union. Principals in the project include U S West, the Soviet Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, Kokusai Denshin Denway of Japan, Societa Finanziaria Telefonica of Italy, British Telecom PLC, OTC of Australia, Denmark's Great Nordic Telegraph Company and Telecom Denmark, and the Deutsche Bundespost Telkom of West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Firm Reportedly To Propose Plan Calling for Full Repayment to Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. will present creditors with a reorganization plan that will pay them 100 cents for every dollar owed, a newspaper reported. The proposal is expected to be announced Wednesday afternoon at a meeting between the creditors and Drexel's law firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges, The New York Times said in an early edition of Wednesday's paper. ``It will begin the process of formulating a reorganization plan with all of Drexel's constituents,'' said Alan B. Miller, Drexel's lead bankruptcy lawyer. The court-appointed creditors committee is expected to meet on Thursday to respond to Drexel's plan, the newspaper said. Weil, Gotshal lawyers already have told some creditors that Drexel would seek to repay them through a new company that would hold Drexel's portfolio of junk bonds, bridge loans and other securities, the paper said. A representative of one creditor said Drexel valued its holdings at about $2 billion but can't sell most of the assets readily because of their poor quality and the weak state of the junk bond market, the Times said. As a result, the company will propose creating a new entity to issue notes to creditors and pay down those notes as the bonds and other investments are sold, the newspaper said. Creditors' representatives said a critical stumbling block to Drexel's plans would be the guarantees the firm can make about the value of its investments, the Times said. The reorganization proposal will cover all Drexel bankruptcy filings, including last week's Chapter 11 filing of the company's investment banking arm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The holding company filed for Chapter 11 in February because of a liquidity crisis brought on by its holdings of junk bonds and other investments.
